headline: A New Editor Named at Wired Magazine
abstract: Chris Anderson, US business editor of The Economist, is named editor of Wired magazine, succeeding Katrina Heron (S)

headline: Chain Stores: Friends or Foes?
abstract: Eric Nussbaum letter on Daniel Akst's June 3 article holds chain stores do not offer service, convenience, product knowledge, special ordering and other benefits of small neighborhood stores

headline: A study looks at an eagerly sought but hard-to-reach group.
abstract: Article on PortiCo Research study intended to give advertisers insight on how to sell to consumers 21 to 25 years old, difficult group for advertisers to reach; photo (M)

headline: Feud Breeds Political Scandals and Public Outrage in Brazil
abstract: The president of the Senate is said to have profited from a $1 billion corruption scheme. Former Senate leaders are accusing each other of  tampering with ballots. And that means trouble for President Fernando Henrique Cardoso, even though he is hardly to blame.     The scandal, involving the three main parties in his coalition, has paralyzed the Congress and enraged Brazil, a nation of 170 million.

headline: I.B.M. Plans To Expand An Alliance In Germany
abstract: IBM and SAP, German business software giant, are planning to broaden their longstanding partnership over next three years; new links include IBM commitment to train more than 5,000 of its service employees on entire suite of SAP products that support business activities on Internet; new agreement calls for crosslicensing and software development efforts by both companies that will integate SAP more closely with Websphere, IBM's package of so-called middleware programs that help server computers play host to business applications on Internet (M)

headline: French Court Approves Extradition of American Fugitive
abstract: RENNES, France, June 28 â€” A French court today agreed to extradite James Charles Kopp, an American anti-abortion activist accused in the sniper killing of an upstate New York doctor.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Advertising account changes noted (S)

headline: Computer Virus Scouts for Child Pornography
abstract: New rogue computer program, possibly intended to perform public service, searches target's computer for what it suspects may be child pornography and reports names of files to police, raising thorny legal and privacy issues; police apparently have not yet acted on such results; virus reportedly has not yet been distributed widely and poses low risk of damaging computers; worm virus arrives as e-mail attachment; experts say virus's search software is apt to falsely identify files as containing child pornography (M)

headline: A Family and Its 5-Year-Old a Symbol of Mideast Violence
abstract: TEL AVIV, May 21 -- Today, intensive care doctors removed 5-year-old Sasha Sorokin's breathing tube, three days after the suicide bomb attack that killed his father and seriously wounded his mother. He cried hoarsely, slept on and off and whimpered in Russian to his 20-year-old uncle, German Moravchik, who sat bleary-eyed by his side.

headline: Defensive Drug Industry: Fueling Clash Over Patents
abstract: The big pharmaceutical companies march to the beat of a steady chant -- that patent protection for drugs is essential for innovation. At the urging of the drug companies, the United States government has pressed many nations to honor patents on medications.     But now, it seems, the industry may have overplayed its hand. Drug patents are under attack, blamed for high AIDS drug prices that deny life-saving therapy to millions of people in developing countries. And some analysts say the industry itself fueled the backlash by staunchly defending its intellectual property in the face of a pandemic that could claim more lives than the Black Death of the Middle Ages.

headline: Funds That Focus On Truly Liquid Assets
abstract: vicarious investing: funds tha

headline: A Guppy-Size Force
abstract: Analysis of Taiwan's military deficiencies notes they cannot be resolved through United States arms sales alone; many of problems stem from Taiwan's own military legacy, island's isolation and uncertainty about United States response to invasion by China; army officers continue to have inordinate influence, even though key to security now rests with air force and navy; photo (M)

headline: Europe Union's Dreams Meet Electoral Reality
abstract: Leaders across Europe are shocked by Irish voters' resounding rejection of treaty that would redistribute power within European Union as it grows from 15 to as many as 27 countries; they are struggling between need to respect democratic vote and need to preserve agreement that was only reached after months of closed-door power struggles (M)

headline: The Philanthropy Mart
abstract: As multimillionaires and philanthropists, Alexander and Ilana Brodt are accustomed to people trying to get at their money. So when they agreed to join German friends recently for a seminar on charitable giving sponsored by Deutsche Bank AG's private banking unit at a swanky hotel in Palm Beach, Florida, they went expecting to hear a sales pitch.

headline: Article 2001042090318016581 -- No Title
abstract: Bike Power: Tired Legs Get a Leg Up

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Ciena Wins First AT&T Order
abstract: Ciena Corp, nation's second-largest maker of fiber optic equipment, reaches its first supply agreement with AT&T; financial terms undisclosed; graph (S)

headline: CITY GUIDE:Doha : Of Souks and Malls
abstract: Palm trees and manicured gardens filled with bougainvillea line Doha's Corniche along one of the most beautiful bays in the Arabian Gulf. Residents of Qatar's capital meet on this superbly landscaped Corniche to jog, walk or just to relax while watching dhows, motorboats, sailboats and jet skis on the sparkling blue waters.

headline: Annan in Washington to Seek AIDS Funds
abstract: Secretary General Kofi Annan goes to Washington to ask Bush administration for more money to fight AIDS in Africa; Annan proposes global fund to provide $7 billion to $10 billion annually on top of money already being spent to battle AIDS; he meets with Secretary of State Colin Powell, who describes talks as 'excellent' (M)

headline: The Paper Chase; Why Newspapers And Newsprint Makers Are at War
abstract: Newspaper publishers are in heated dispute with newsprint producers over rising newsprint prices; producers see widespread consolidation in paper industry giving them edge; newsprint represents about 20 percent of newspaper's cost; graphs; photo (M)

headline: Holiday Travel May Rise
abstract: AAA expects Memorial Day travel volume to be slightly ahead of 2000's record level (S)

headline: Leader of Pakistan Accepts India's Invitation to Summit Talks
abstract: Pakistan's military ruler, Gen Pervez Musharraf, formally accepts India's invitation for summit; says bluntly that troubled territory of Kashmir is main topic to be discussed (M)

headline: New Jornada Pocket PC Creates Storage Space in Wallet
abstract: Hewlett-Packard releases Jornada 525 Pocket PC, scaled-down version of its hand-held computer devices (M)

headline: Clicks for Sale; Paid Placement Is Catching On in Web Searches
abstract: Success of Internet search engine GoTo.com in selling placement on its search results to Web sites is being copied in one way or another by every major search and portal sites; GoTo is thriving as provider of search results to other sites, which share in placement revenue; search engines are transforming themselves from infinite electronic encyclopedias into profitable universal commercial directories; Yahoo, biggest search engine, has started listing five sponsored sites before its normal results; table of how major search engines handle placements; photos (M)

headline: BRITISH CREDIT CARDS SOLD
abstract: As it reported lower-than-expected preliminary results, People's Bank said it would sell its British credit card operation to Citigroup for $526 million. People's Bank, based in Bridgeport, Conn., established the British subsidiary in the mid-1990's as American card issuers sought a share of the British market. Citigroup, which will acquire credit card accounts owing about $426 million, is the world's biggest card issuer with $118 billion in loans. People's Bank said that its first-quarter profit would be 20 to 22 cents a share, less than half of analysts' forecasts.   Alan Cowell (NYT)

headline: Europe Seems More Open To G.E. Merger
abstract: Alexander Schaub, head of European Commission's antitrust department, says General Electric Co's $45 billion takeover of Honeywell International has 'reasonable chance' of winning European approval (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Gasoline rises on concerns about low inventories; June gasoline reaches $1.0843 a gallon, up 1.32 cents; other commodity prices listed; graph (S)

headline: Rallies in Dow and Nasdaq Erase Some Losses for Week
abstract: Investors embrace battered technology stocks and ignite modest rally; Nasdaq composite index gains 38.95 to close at 2,149.44; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index finishes week at 1,260.67, up 4.85; Dow Jones industrial average rises 78.47, to 10,990.41; Treasury prices rise in response to weak manufacturing figures; graph; table of key rates (M)

headline: Addenda: 4 Top Officers Leave San Francisco Office
abstract: The four top executives at the San Francisco office of the British agency Leagas Delaney are leaving, they said, because of disagreements over the course of the agency.

headline: In Ukraine, Pope Tries to Heal Rift With Orthodox Church
abstract: Pope John Paul II, setting aside objections from Orthodox church that broke with Rome millennium ago, makes his first visit to Ukraine and tries to placate his unwilling hosts; says he did not come to Ukraine with intention of proselytizing, airport ceremony, Kiev; urges both churches to 'asks forgiveness' of each other and not to let past errors hinder 'mutual knowledge'; Metropolitan Vladimir, who heads largest Ukrainian Orthodox church, manages to be out of town to avoid chance of meeting Pope; pope's visit is welcome to Pres Leonid Kuchma, whose scandal-ridden administration badly needs a lift; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: MIDWAY GAMES INC., Chicago, said it would cut its work force by about 60 employees and exit the coin-operated arcade video game business because of a decline in demand.

headline: Gucci Strikes The Right Mix
abstract: MILANâ€”  Female fashion's phobias and fears are summed up in the query: "Does my butt look big in this?"

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Airline Bankruptcy
abstract: AOM/Air Liberte, domestic French airline, files for bankruptcy protection; Swissair Group owns 49.5 percent of AOM (S)

headline: Microsoft And AOL Discuss Links
abstract: Microsoft and America Online are negotiating range of licensing and legal issues so contentious that they disagree over whether they are even still talking; seek accord on how to include each other's software in each's own products and services; Microsoft reportedly is demanding AOL agree not to lobbying against it on antitrust matters; talks mainly focus on areas in which companies compete in delivering Internet service; key issue reportedly is inclusion of AOL access software in consumer version of Microsoft's new Windows XP operating system (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Treaty On Space Arms Proposed
abstract: China urges UN Disarmament Conference to begin negotiations on treaty to ban weapons in outer space; cites 'imminent danger' of US plans for missile defense shield (S)

headline: Article 2001041394245719061 -- No Title
abstract: April 12, 2001

headline: Article 2001061490078676161 -- No Title
abstract: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Action On Money Laundering
abstract: Russian parliament passes measure to curb money laundering; government estimates $20 billion is moved abroad illegally each year (S)

headline: Museum Aims to Erase Line Between Video Games and Art
abstract: Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art, in North Adams, opens exhibition devoted to game structures and themes in art, including section on computer gaming; drawing (S)

headline: Private Sector; Once Burned, but Still Bold
abstract: RARELY does Robert E. Knowling Jr. find himself in a corporate situation that does not lend itself to a line borrowed from one of his favorite films. A staff meeting, say, might call for ''Failure is not an option'' (from ''Apollo 13),'' or a convention speech might include an aphorism from ''The Lion King'': ''You can either run from it, or learn from it.''    So, in November, when an earnings shortfall prompted his resignation after two years as chief executive of the Covad Communications Group, the wholesaler of high-speed Web access, Mr. Knowling began to regather his forces and consider his options for a sequel to what had been his first shot as a chief executive.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Fourth Tory In Race
abstract: British Conservative Party chairman Michael Ancram becomes surprise fourth contender in race to succeed William Hague as party leader (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Cisco Has First-Ever Loss As It Writes Off Inventory  Cisco, seeking to wipe the slate clean after enduring a sharp plunge in business, said it took $3 billion in charges against its earnings, leading it to report an overall quarterly loss for the first time in its 11-year history.    At the same time, when Cisco factors out those charges, predominately related to inventory that it may never have a chance to sell, it managed to narrowly beat the forecast Wall Street analysts gave last month. [Page C4.]

headline: The Regulatory Signals Shift; F.T.C. Serves as Case Study of Differences Under Bush
abstract: Change in leadership at Federal Trade Commission offers case study in differences between Clinton and Bush administrations on fundamental areas of regulation; under Robert Pitofsky, commission pursued aggressive approach toward antitrust and consumer protection, effort that its new chairman, Timothy J Muris, has criticized as too harsh on business; photos (M)

headline: Unadorned Sniping
abstract: Letter from Hilary Shank-Kuhl concerns 'sniping' at online auctions, discussed in May 10 Online Shopper column

headline: Paying for That Fun in the Sun
abstract: Myvesta.org reports that 80 percent of vacationers expect to use credit cards to pay for summer trips this summer, up from 74 percent in 2000; says average vacation will cost $3,155 this year, compared with $2,274 in 2000; estimates that people making only minimum monthly credit card payments will need 33.5 years and pay $6,823 interest to repay that $3,155, assuming 17 percent interest (M)

headline: Inflation's Uptick Clouds Outlook for the Bond Market
abstract: Jonathan Fuerbringer column says that although inflation is unlikely to take off soon, subtle, troubling signs of rising costs cast pall over bond market for second half of 2001; chart (M)

headline: Bush Calls Allies in Advance of Missile Speech
abstract: Pres Bush begins paving diplomatic path for missile defense system and possibility of renouncing 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty; calls leaders of several major European and Asian allies in preparation for May 1 speech; tells them he wants to begin consultations on new nuclear treaty (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Pursuing Jehovah's Witnesses
abstract: Russian court revives efforts by prosecutors to ban Jehovah's Witnesses (S)

headline: Investing; Hope for AIDS Vaccine Fuels a Stock's Ascent
abstract: Shares of VaxGen soar on strength of its 'encouraging' findings about its main product, experimental AIDS vaccine, but researchers are at odds over whether VaxGen's approach, using a protein from coating of HIV to stimulate antibodies, is most effective way to stop AIDS (M)

headline: Bush Says Time Has Come for Chinese to Return Plane and Crew
abstract: HAIKOU, China, Wednesday, April 4 â€” Two American officials met here today with the detained crew of an American spy plane that collided with a Chinese jet on Sunday morning and sounded a positive note about how the crew members are being treated.

headline: F.C.C. Chief Seeks Hiring Rules
abstract: Federal Communications Commission chairman Michael K Powell says he will seek to write new rules to encourage television, radio and cable-TV companies to recruit women and members of minority groups (M)

headline: Slumbering in the Egyptian Desert, a Titan of a Dinosaur
abstract: Paleontologists digging at oasis in Egyptian desert find huge fossil bones of what they say appears to have been second most massive dinosaur that ever lived; estimate new species, named Paralititan stromeri, stretched 80 to 100 feet long and weighed as much as 70 tons; discovery could revive vigorous fossil hunting in previously neglected area; photo of computer-generated image of Paralititan stromeri; map (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Gasoline climbs on concern that inventories of cleaner-burning fuel used in big cities are too low before summer begins; in New York, gasoline for June delivery rises 4.1 cents, to $1.0711 per gallon (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: G.A.O. Report Faults Cybersecurity
abstract: General Accounting Office reports says National Infrastructure Protection Center, which gathers information on cyberspace threats and assists federal government in responding to computer-based incidents, has limited strategy for analyzing data, and is thus not capable of providing timely warnings of imminent attacks; says center lacks adequate staff and technological expertise to alert public to dangerous and disruptive incidents (S)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: AMERICASMEXICO: WASTE SETTLEMENT The Metalclad Corporation , a California-based waste management company, said the Mexican government had agreed to pay $15.6 million as compensation for lost profits in an out-of-court settlement after a Canadian court ruled in favor of the company. Last month, the Supreme Court of British Columbia upheld a ruling by a North American Free Trade Agreement panel that Mexico violated a law protecting foreign investors by blocking Metalclad from constructing a waste dump in northern Mexico. The case was heard in Canada as a neutral venue under Nafta rules.

headline: Shift in Technology Markets Is Helping I.B.M., Chief Says
abstract: IBM's chief executive-chairman Louis V Gerstner Jr says company is benefiting from new 'golden age' at its research laboratories and from shift in technology markets toward areas in which IBM is especially strong, address to more than 400 industry analysts in Manhattan; says Internet and e-business will continue to grow rapidly despite recent downturn in industry; holds result will be tremendous demand for server computers, for software known as middleware that knits Web-based activities together, and for new processors tailored to needs of increasingly diverse range of handheld wireless devices and electronic appliances; says IBM is betting that shortage of information technology workers will drive customers toward IBM's huge Global Services unit, which can either take over their computer operations through outsourcing agreements or provide consulting and technical help in integrating networks and new products (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: A Vote For The U.N.
abstract: Swiss Parliament votes overwhelmingly in favor of joining United Nations, bolstering government's plan to put issue to referendum in 2002 (S)

headline: Article 2001050392939584353 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: British Dislike Of the Euro Is Eroding In Campaign
abstract: Britain must decide whether to join 12 European nations that are swapping their national currencies for euro in January; it is most important single decison country will make in immediate future; debate has tapped into broad British cultural reluctance to embrace notions and customs of Continental origin, as well as specific fears of consequences to highly performing British economy of submitting it to interest rates and tax decisions made in Brussels rather than London; three weeks ago, 70 percent of Britons polled opposed exchanging pound for euro; that has changed in past weeks, as euro's fiercest opponent, William Hague, succeeded in turning election into contest over Britain's relationship with rest of Europe and his strategy backfired (M)

headline: MediaTalk; Lou Dobbs Makes Good On His Return to CNN
abstract: Moneyline gains in ratings in Lou Dobbs' first week back as CNN financial news anchor; CNN says he agreed to speak to gathering of Ford executives and dealers, for reported $30,000 fee, before he agreed to return to program, where he interviewed Ford chief executive Jacques A Nasser in one of highly promoted guest appearances of week; says he will donate fee to charity, as is his custom; cancels The Spin Room, political program that features Tucker Carlson and Bill Press; says Carlson will be Press's conservative counterweight on Crossfire; will shift Greenfield at Large, new talk show featuring Jeff Greenfield, to prime time; photo (M)

headline: Italy's New Leader Begins To Assemble His Cabinet
abstract: Italian Prime Min-designate Silvio Berlusconi takes first step toward assuming office; says he will soon release list of cabinet ministers; Northern League leader Umberto Bossi, holding party paid 'monstrous price' in election for support Berlusconi, seeks role for party in his government; photo (M)

headline: POLYONE TO CLOSE SOME PLASTIC AND PIGMENT PLANTS
abstract: PolyOne Corp, chemical maker, will eliminate at least one-third of its 34 plants that make pigments and plastics within two years (S)

headline: Hedge Fund Managers Said to Talk to Grand Jury
abstract: Managers of PTJP Partners, New York hedge fund, have reportedly been testifying before federal grand jury in Manhattan about how Wall Street investment banks controlled market for new stocks in late 1990's; Anthony F Braun, fund manager, has reportedly testified that in exchange for allocations of IPO's, several of biggest investment banks demanded kickbacks of trading profits and commitments to buy more shares of new stocks after offerings (M)

headline: Article 2001063094220065743 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: AKAMAI POSTS HUGE LOSS
abstract: Akamai Technologies Inc says first-quarter loss was $2.22 billion compared with loss of $35.4 million year earlier; sales surged to $40.2 million from $7.22 million (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Not So Fast, Judge Says
abstract: Investigating judge in killing of journalist Georgy Gongadze in Ukraine says it is still too soon to say that murder has been solved (S)

headline: NEC Woes Likely to Continue, Despite Good Results for Year
abstract: NEC Corp says group net profit was 56.6 billion yen ($459 million) for year ended March 31 on revenue that rose about 8 percent, to 5.4 trillion yen ($43.8 billion); president Noji Nishigaki comments on problems facing company (M)

headline: INVESTING WITH/Maura A. Shaughnessy; MFS Utilities Fund
abstract: Carole Gould Investing With column profiles Maura A Shaughnessy, who manages MFS Utilities fund, which has benefited from electricity shortages; photo; chart; data table (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Longer PC Sales Downturn Foreseen
abstract: Michael S Dell, head of Dell Computer Corp, says company does not expect PC business to rebound until second quarter of 2002; photo (S)

headline: U.S. Is Suing Wal-Mart Over Injury Reports
abstract: Consumer Product Safety Commission charges that Wal-Mart Stores Inc failed to report accidents and injuries involving shoppers who were trying out exercise machinery in its stores; lawsuit seeks $4.5 million in fines from Wal-Mart and Sam's Club warehouse stores over injuries, which came from three kinds of machines made by Icon Health and Fitness Inc; Icon is also defendant and faces same penalties; Icon and Wal-Mart are sued because neither one notified government that dozens of accidents occurred on machinery, which were sold at Wal-Mart and Sam's Club stores between 1996 and 1999; retailers and manufacturers are required to report any injuries from products to commission (M)

headline: French Oil Executive Calls Commissions Routine
abstract: A former head of France's state-owned oil company, now on trial for corruption, has told two French newspapers that paying millions of dollars a year in ''secret commissions'' was a routine part of his job and had the approval of the Elysée Palace.     The executive -- Loïk Le Floch-Prigent, who headed Elf Aquitaine from 1989 to 1993 -- said that the payments were made to several African governments as well as to Spain and Germany, and that perhaps as many as 40 people in the French government knew of the payments.

headline: Tokyo Journal; Ryotei: Vanishing Havens of the High and Mighty
abstract: Tokyo Journal on dwingling number of ryotei, exclusive restaurants and gathering places where high and mighty Japanese men have traditionally gathered to conclude secret deals and relax in company of geisha; Noriko Suzuki offers rare glimpse of Kacho ryotei she runs; photo (M)

headline: Scraping the Sky, and Even Breaking Through
abstract: Skyscraper Museum's Web site, www.skyscraper.org, offers archive of its past exhibitions concerning high-rise buildings; photo (S)

headline: State of the Art: Putting You at the PC, Remotely
abstract: YOU can't call yourself a modern mobile professional until you've survived three rites of passage. First, there's boarding the flight on which you hoped to complete an important memo, and realizing that your laptop was "recharging" all night from a dead outlet. Second, there's spilling coffee into your keyboard in flight; extra credit if you're caught without a napkin and the seat-belt sign is illuminated. Finally, there's winding up in some remote and inconvenient city and discovering that you need to consult a crucial file that's nonchalantly resting on your hard drive back home.

headline: Webdenda: Executive Changes at Media Firms
abstract: Julie Bauer, a managing partner at the New York office of Saatchi & Saatchi, owned by the Publicis Groupe, was named equity director for the agency's Sony account across Europe. She will relocate to London. Ms. Bauer succeeds William Leach, who is leaving, the agency said, to take a sabbatical.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Ex-Kremlin Aide Sought -- Again
abstract: Pavel Borodin, former Kremlin official recently held in US on Swiss money-laundering charges, is summoned to Switzerland again for questioning (S)

headline: Australia Blocks Shell-Woodside Deal
abstract: SYDNEY, Australia, April 23 â€” The Australian government today rejected the Royal Dutch/Shell Group's proposed takeover of Woodside Petroleum Ltd.

headline: Article 2001051490173226544 -- No Title
abstract: Looking Back at My First PC

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Rate Cut Vote
abstract: Monthly minutes of Bank of England's monetary poolicy committee meeting show bank's experts voted 8 to 1 to lower interest rates by quarter-point this month, with sole dissenter arguing for bigger cut; vote is taken as sign that benchmark rate, now 5.25 percent, might fall further quarter-point in midsummer (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Power Dispute
abstract: Dabhol Power Co, Enron Corp's unit in India, stops generating electricity at its $3 billion power plant after its sole customer, utility of Indian state of Maharashtra, stops buying power; halt in power generation is latest move in months-long dispute that has cast doubt on future of Dabhol's $2.9 billion power project in India (S)

headline: Japan Says The Economy Is Worsening
abstract: The Japanese government lowered its assessment of the economy's health today for the fourth consecutive month, citing falling production, bloated inventories, declining prices and weak employment trends.    The outlook underscores the significant economic challenges that face Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's new administration and suggests that the political challenges in devising a resolution to Japan's longstanding economic woes will be daunting.

headline: PEABODY ENERGY STOCK SOARS AT INITIAL PUBLIC OFFERING
abstract: Peabody Energy Corp's shares rise 31 percent in their first day of trading as company, biggest coal miner in nation, benefits from rising energy prices and Bush administration's efforts to promote coal; Lehman Brothers Holdings, which owned 87 percent of Peabody before offering, sold 15 million shares at $28; offering raised $420 million; stock closes at $36.80 (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Hiroshima Compensation For Korean
abstract: Japanese court orders government to pay Korean survivor of Hiroshima atomic bomb compensation for medical care that was terminated when he left Japan; Kwak Kwi Hoon, now 76, was in Japanese army at time (S)

headline: Article 2001050691928858234 -- No Title
abstract: Face-Recognition Systems OfferNew Tools, but Mixed Results

headline: Play Now, Pay Later: The 'Shareware' Business
abstract: RECORD companies have watched in horror recently as consumers have turned their nicely packaged CD's into MP3 files and set them loose online. But a corner of the software industry has thrived for years by embracing that same loss of control: instead of selling shrink-wrapped boxes, why not distribute products in digital form and watch them spread?

headline: Sebastian Snow, Eccentric English Explorer, Dies at 72
abstract: Sebastian Snow, eccentric English explorer who helped confirm source of Amazon River as he bumbled about vast portions of South America, died on April 20 at age 72; photo (M)

headline: 2 Interpublic Agencies Are Reorganizing
abstract: Weber Shandwick Worldwide is merging three of its technology public relations practices in Washington area to form Weber Group; Ben Boyd is named to head group as executive vice president and director; Initiative Media North America is consolidating in New York its print division (S)

headline: James Parton, 88, a Founder Of American Heritage, Dies
abstract: James Parton, who was instrumental in founding of American Heritage magazine and was its president and publisher for many years, dies at age 88; photo (M)

headline: Moscow Asserts It Is Eager for Talks on Missile Shield
abstract: MOSCOW, May 2 â€” Russia responded today to President Bush's call for the deployment of a missile defense shield, saying it was eager to begin a new strategic dialogue with the United States in a bid to find a common approach to new missile threats and further reduce nuclear arsenals.

headline: Senators Question Handling of Cole Case
abstract: Gen Henry H Shelton, chairman of Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Adm Vern Clark, chief of naval operations, come under sharp questioning before Senate Armed Services Committee for not punishing Cmdr Kirk S Lippold for failing to follow certain security guidelines before destroyer USS Cole was attacked by suicide bombers last October (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CAMPBELL SOUP CO., Camden, N.J., said that its Arnott's biscuit unit in Australia would close its Melbourne plant in September 2002.    HOME DEPOT, Atlanta, has agreed to buy the Total HOME chain, Mexico's second-largest home retailer, with four stores, from ALFA.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Rate Raised
abstract: Central Bank Monetary Policy committee of Brazil raises interest rates 1.5 percent to 18.25 percent in effort to stem inflation caused by weakening currency (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: 3 Catholic Priests Killed
abstract: Militants in India's northern state of Manipur kill three Catholic priests in incident police say was related to demand for money (S)

headline: Article 2001042292958767793 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: Calling in Sick and Other Tall Tales
abstract: Readers submit stories on excuses for absense from work that they have heard or made; drawings (M)

headline: Nasdaq Puts High Hopes on New European Trading System
abstract: Nasdaq announces new trading system for its Nasdaq Europe subsidiary, and says several major investment banks have bought shares in Nasdaq Europe; one of system's effects is to heighten availability of US stocks to European investors (M)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: INTERNET

headline: SHAKE-UP AT DEUTSCHE TELEKOM
abstract: Deutsche Telekom is reshuffling its top management ranks to relieve chief executive Ron Sommer of operational responsibilities; Kai-Uwe Ricke, head of wireless unit, T-Mobile International, will also take charge of T-Online; Josef Brauner will oversee fixed-line and systems businesses; Max Hirschberger will be head of corporate affairs and will join board (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    YUGOSLAVIA: MORE TROOPS NEAR KOSOVO  NATO has agreed to allow Yugoslav forces into another section of the buffer zone on Kosovo's boundary with Serbia, around the town of Medvedja, an area claimed by Albanian rebels. Farther south, on the border with Macedonia, American and Polish peacekeepers came under fire from suspected Albanian rebels. No casualties were reported.    Carlotta Gall (NYT)    NORTHERN IRELAND: OFFICER ARRESTED  A Royal Ulster Constabulary officer was one of seven people held for questioning in the killing of a Catholic man kicked to death in 1997 by a Protestant mob. The case has aroused Catholic fury because of allegations that constables in a nearby patrol car witnessed the killing but did not intervene. The arrests were the first ordered by Nuala O'Loan, who was appointed Northern Ireland's police ombudsman, a new post, in November.    Warren Hoge (NYT)

headline: JONES APPAREL TO BUY McNAUGHTON FOR STOCK AND CASH
abstract: Jones Apparel Group will acquire McNaughton Apparel Group for $275 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: ATLAS AIR EMPLOYEES AUTHORIZE STRIKE IF TALKS FAIL
abstract: Pilots and flight engineers at Atlas Air Worldwide Holdings vote to give Air Line Pilots Association authority to strike if negotiations with Atlas fails to produce contract; vote comes as carrier is cutting its work force, idling planes and hiring pilots in Britain for lower pay (S)

headline: Priceline Shares Soar on Earnings
abstract: Shares of Priceline.com rise 51 percent after Goldman Sachs analyst raises his rating and company reports better-than-expected earnings; revenue for quarter were $269.7, down 14 percent from year earlier; net loss was $13.8 million compared with loss of $13.6 million in first quarter of 2000 (M)

headline: Europe Expands as Market for Colombian Cocaine
abstract: Trafficking to Europe from Colombia and other cocaine-producing South American countries has increased at particularly rapid pace since mid-1990's as cocaine use in US has leveled off; data from White House Office of National Drug Control Policy indicate up to 200 tons of cocaine flowed into Europe in 2000, as much as double amount in 1996, while US received about 300 tons--figure that has remained stable in recent years as consumption by casual users has fallen; Europol, European Union's police force, reports 35 percent of Colombia's cocaine is winding up in region, entering mainly through Spain and Netherlands; seizures in member nations reached 43 tons in 1999, up 37 percent from year before; chart; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: PHILIPPINES

headline: Dweck to Shut Doors After a 9-Year Run
abstract: Dweck, New York ad agency, will close after nine years; chairman Michael Dweck comments (S)

headline: Glasses So Smart They Know Just What You're Looking At
abstract: Dr Ron Blum, optometrist and head of e-Vision, says that company has crude prototype of electronic eyeglasses that know where person is looking and adjust focus automatically; drawing (M)

headline: Stocks End Higher on Earnings and Economic Reports
abstract: Stocks advanced modestly today in the wake of Wednesday's powerful rally, as investors drew some encouragement from Hewlett-Packard's better-than-expected earnings and from reassuring economic data.

headline: David Spedding Dies at 58; Headed British Spy Agency
abstract: Sir David Rolland Spedding who headed Britain's legendary MI6 intelligence service, dies at age 58; photo (M)

headline: Several Executives Leave Red Sky
abstract: Bill Bingham resigns as chairman and chief executive of Red Sky; president Howard Belk will serve as acting chief executive; several other executives resign, including executive vice president Steve Mignogna and chief financial officer Mark Schulz (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Jets Fly Again
abstract: Regulators say Ansett Australia can resume flying all but two of its 767 jets, which were grounded in April because of safety problems and lax maintenance; other two 767's were already scheduled for overhauls (S)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Trahan, Burden & Charles forms consulting alliance with CIA USA to use its media planning and buying services; Milward Brown, Warick acquires Impact Information for undisclosed terms; Dentsu invests $11.5 million for unspecified minority stake in Harmonic Communications (S)

headline: Razorfish Beats Estimates; Founders Step Down
abstract: The founders of Razorfish, the Web design and consulting firm, stepped down from their senior management positions today, as the company reported its first-quarter loss was slightly smaller than Wall Street had expected.

headline: PG&E Has a Loss; Reliant's Earnings Soar
abstract: PG&E Corp reports fourth-quarter loss of $4.12 billion because of charge at its Pacific Gas and Electric unit, California's largest utility, which filed for bankruptcy protection this month; Reliant Energy says its first-quarter earnings more than doubled; PG&E's loss was $611 million year earlier; sales rose 69 percent, to $8.08 billion; Reliant says profit from operations rose to $273.5 million from $133.7 million year earlier; revenue rose to $13.3 billion from $4.2 billion (M)

headline: P.& G. to Shed Some Businesses and Take $1.2 Billion Charge
abstract: Procter & Gamble said today that it would report a second-quarter loss because of the $1.2 billion in after-tax restructuring charges that it is taking as it cuts its work force and sheds under-performing businesses, including its Oil of Olay line of cosmetics.

headline: MILOSEVIC ARREST CAME WITH PLEDGE FOR A FAIR TRIAL
abstract: Slobodan Milosevic, former Yugoslav president, is arrested by Serbian police at residence in Belgrade; surrender follows protracted and sometimes dangerous negotiations; reportedly threatened to kill wife, daughter and himself; surrenders after assurances that he would get fair trial and that arrest was not pretext for transfer to the Hague to face trial as war criminal; is charged mainly with corruption and abuse of power for alleged financial misdealings that caused damage to economy and brought instability to country during period of hyperinflation in early 1990's; is ordered detained in Belgrade's Central Prison for 30 days while charges are investigated; photos (M)

headline: Turkish Bailout Is Joined to a Political Overhaul
abstract: Turkey's leaders win promises of $16 billion in new loans for ailing economy, but now confront infinitly tougher task of reforming bankrupt political system, effectively doing away with state-controlled economy created in 1923; sweeping overhaul demanded as condition for bailout has backed shaky governing coalition into corner (M)

headline: TWEETER HOME ENTERTAINMENT BUYS FLORIDA COMPETITOR
abstract: Tweeter Home Entertainment Group, consumer-electronics retailer, will buy Sound Advice for $117 million in stock (S)

headline: MAKER OF CHIP-DESIGN SOFTWARE GAINS
abstract: Shares of Cadence Design Systems Inc rise as much as 22 percent after company, maker of semiconductor-design software, forecasts continued sales growth and Intel Corp says demand increased for personal computer chips (S)

headline: Tax Analysts See Big Gains For Top 1% Of Taxpayers
abstract: Supporters and critics of tax cut plans now moving through Congress agree that all of them would result in greater savings for wealthiest over time, as most of breaks for everyone else lessen; tax analysts say that top one percent of earners would gain protections and favorable provisions that do not extend to other 99 percent (M)

headline: Delicate Issues Surface as Cardinals Look to Church Future
abstract: 155 Roman Catholic cardinals gather at Vatican for four-days of closed-door meetings to discuss future of church; delicate issues surface, as some cardinals contest power of Vatican bureaucracy and express need for more democracy within church; photo (M)

headline: Article 2001050390178742344 -- No Title
abstract: Face-Recognition Systems OfferNew Tools, but Mixed Results

headline: Revised Data Shows Economy Growing Slower Than Previously Reported
abstract: WASHINGTON (Reuters) - U.S. economic growth in the first three months of the year was slower than previously thought as companies cut back on their inventories at the fastest pace in 18 years, the Commerce Department said Friday.

headline: New Troubles for Chief of Aer Lingus
abstract: Aer Lingus Group has asked chief executive Michael Foley to stay away from office while it tries to sort out complaints of sexual harassment against him; Irish news media says internal disciplinary committee suspended Foley last week by advising him not to report for work until issue is resolved, and he has complied; Foley has told Irish reporters that preliminary findings are inconsistent and unfair to him, but has not provided specifics; Foley, in eight months as chief executive, has been confronted with soaring fuel costs, sputtering labor dispute that has grounded planes for almost five days, and swoon in reservations of more than 10 percent because of worries about foot-and-mouth disease; photo (M)

headline: DataBank; A Rate Cut Lifts the Market's Mood
abstract: Investors are heartened by fifth interest rate cut of 2001; Dow Jones Industrial Average's 480.43, or 4.4 percent, gain lifts it to 11,301.74; 46.29, or 3.7 percent, rise in Standard & Poor's 500-stock average leaves it at 1,291.96; Nasdaq composite index rallies to 2,198.88, up 91.45, or 4.3 percent; long-term bonds rally slightly; yield on 10-year Treasury note slides to 5.40 percent from 5.45 percent week before; charts; table of rates and yields (M)

headline: MAKER OF ENFAMIL ENDS ITS DISPUTE WITH A RIVAL FORMULA
abstract: Maker of Enfamil infant formula, Mead Johnson Nutritionals, withdraws promotional marterials claiming that generic formula distributed by PBM Products is less nutritious than its product; drops lawsuit contending that PBM Products made false and misleading statements about quality of Enfamil (S)

headline: Advanced Micro Introduces New Line of Chips for Laptops
abstract: SAN FRANCISCO, May 14 â€” In an effort to revive its market position in laptop computers, Advanced Micro Devices introduced a new line of mobile microprocessors today whose name attempts to take advantage of the branding strength of its biggest rival, the Intel Corporation.

headline: As Korean Heirs Feud, an Empire Is Withering; Change and Frail Finances Doom the Old Hyundai
abstract: Succession battle at South Korea's huge Hyundai Group divides sons of late founder Chung Ju Yung and and businesses they control; Chung Mong Hun, Chung's anointed successor, heads remnants of original Hyundai Group, which includes number of ailing companies; Chung Mong Koo controls automotive companies, while Chung Mong Joon controls two of most profitable companies, which are set to be spun off by Hyundai Group; photos (M)

headline: Powell Backing Plan to Monitor Mideast Truce
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L Powell, in Israel, says observers would be needed to monitor cease-fire between Israelis and Palestinians; announces seven-week timetable for two sides to end hostilities and move toward political talks; timetable calls on both sides to prevent all clashes for seven days, then enter into six-week 'cooling off' period; plan combines Israeli Prime Min Ariel Sharon's insistence on week without violence before any further measures are agreed to, with notion that two sides would need several weeks to retreat from bitter hostility and bloodshed of past nine months; Powell says two sides must decide together how to measure reduction of violence; aides to Powell say he got renewed commitment from Yasir Arafat to order his commanders to stop attacks on Israelis, and from Sharon he got pledge to freeze settlement activity; photo (M)

headline: After Lucent Bid Fails, Alcatel Stuns Investors With Warning
abstract: PARIS, May 30 â€” In the wake of the collapsed merger negotiations between Alcatel of France and Lucent Technologies, Alcatel issued an unexpected and severe financial warning today, and investors punished its shares and those of its optical fiber subsidiary.

headline: AMTRAN SHARES RISE 57% ON NEWS OF CHAIRMAN'S OFFER
abstract: Amtran Inc, parent of American Trans Air, says its chairman and majority shareholder, J George Mikelsons, offered $21 per share to buy rest of company and take it private; offer values company at $239 million; stock rises $7.15, to $19.75 (S)

headline: Private Sector; She Gets the Last Laugh
abstract: Financial Women's Association annual dinner honors Nancy Peretsman, managing director of Allen & Co; photo (S)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: INTERNETLEGAL BATTLE OVER INTERNET MUSIC ESCALATES A recording industry trade group filed a countersuit in a Manhattan federal court Friday against a group of Internet broadcasters in an intensifying legal battle over the payment structure for music played on the Web. At issue is whether Web broadcasters that allow users to personalize the music they hear should require a separately negotiated license from the record companies or whether they should be eligible for compulsory licensing like traditional radio. The Recording Industry Association of America, which represents some of the music industry's biggest labels, has argued that Web broadcasters like MTVi , MusicMatch and Xact Radio provide services that violate the Digital Millennium Copyright Act. Through their trade group, the Webcasters said last week that they were "disappointed that the recording industry has chosen to initiate another in a long line of lawsuits." Â Â Andrew Zipern (NYT)

headline: Auto Sales Off A Mere 1.2% Last Month
abstract: Enduring strength of automobile market again surprises economists, as auto sales fall mere 1.2 percent in May, 2001, from year-earlier totals; General Motors posts slight gain as Ford reports sharp drop (M)

headline: Retooling Products So All Can Use Them
abstract: Federal regulations taking effect June 21, 2001, issued under Section 508 of Rehabilitation Act of 1973, mandate that all technology purchased by federal agencies must be accessible to the disabled, with few exceptions; technology developers, ranging from photocopiers to computer software, retool to meet requirements (M)

headline: New Economy; The steamy side of the Internet, pervasive and resilient to recession, is the underpinning of a new online cash venture.
abstract: Online pornography industry is proving resilient to recession hitting rest of online world, in part because it does not depend on advertising revenues; provides first customers for Duocash, which uses prepaid phone long-distance cards as anonymous, secure method of making payments over Internet; drawing (M)

headline: Two Agencies Reviewing Accounts
abstract: Dial Corp places in review creative account of Dial brand of bar soap, which has been handled by DDB Worldwide for 21 years; billings estimated at $20 million; Kmart Corp expands its relationship with Don Coleman Advertising (S)

headline: MediaTalk; Security Concerns Blur an Artist's Drawings
abstract: Christine Cornell drawing of Kenyan witness in trial of four men charged with joining conspiracy to bomb two United States Embassies in Africa is run on CNN Web site with face deliberately left blank; witness, who is in witness protection program, feared for safety of his children in Kenya; photo (M)

headline: FIVE QUESTIONS for LAURIE WACHTER; The Census: A Marketing Data Trove
abstract: Laurie Wachter, senior vice president in charge of Consumer Insights group of Information Resources Inc, answers questions on how businesses are reacting to data gleaned by 2000 census; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Hybrid Push By Toyota
abstract: Toyota Motor president, Fujio Cho, expresses determination to step up production of gasoline-electricity hybrid vehicles tenfold by 2005; photo (S)

headline: Key Shifts Made At Critical Path
abstract: Critical Path Inc, software company under investigation by Securities and Exchange Commission, dismisses its president, Diana Whitehead, and says it will cut 450 jobs to reduce costs as it concentrates on e-mail services; says it will close about two-thirds of its 77 offices worldwide and lay off workers not involved in its core business; company also dismisses Mari Tangredi, executive vice president for sales (S)

headline: Article 2001062592849375605 -- No Title
Japan Risks Angering China on Visa for Ex-Taiwan Chief
abstract: TOKYO, April 20 â€” In a move that could further strain relations with China, the Japanese government announced today that it had granted a visa to the former president of Taiwan after he agreed to conditions set by Tokyo.

headline: Cendant Deal for Travel Service Is Near
abstract: Cendant Corp reportedly nears deal to buy Galileo International, electronic travel reservation business, for about $3 billion in cash and stock (S)

headline: Atlanta Company Offers to Buy Petroleum Exchange in London
abstract: In tercontinentalExchange, online commodities trading company based in Atlanta, has offered to buy Intercontinental Petroleum Exchange in London, world's second-largest oil futures market, in bid to computerize it; IPE shareholders will receive stock valued at $75 million to $131 million in Intercontinental Exchange, firm backed by several financial and oil companies, including Goldman Sachs and BP Amoco unit (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: New Foot-And-Mouth Cases
abstract: Restrictions on animal movements are imposed on nearly 1,000 farms in northeastern England after 17 cases of foot-and-mouth disease are confirmed in Yorkshire Dales National Park, a major tourist area, at time when incidence of disease is falling elsewhere in Britain (S)

headline: Administration Says Belgrade Meets Criteria to Receive Aid
abstract: WASHINGTON, April 2 â€” After holding out for the arrest of Slobodan Milosevic, the Bush administration certified today that Yugoslavia had met the requirements of an American law on cooperation with the international war crimes tribunal, freeing up economic assistance to the ruined nation.

headline: Parrying CNN, CNBC Plans To Augment 'Business Center'
abstract: CNBC's marquee Business Center financial program will revamp to meet challenge posed by return of Lou Dobbs as host of CNN's Moneyline News Hour; program will be expanded by half-hour; was regular second-place finisher to Moneyline before Dobbs left to pursue other interests; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | United Nations: 'Important Work' On Iraq Sanctions
abstract: UN technical experts and diplomats, studying lists of goods US does not want Iraq to buy without prior approval, ends two days of talks in Paris; report completing 'important work' on sanctions, but that talks will go on (S)

headline: Image And Reality On Social Security
abstract: Richard W Stevenson Economic View column says commission named by Pres Bush to devise plan for personal investment accounts in Social Security should address questions of whether plan is needed, whether nation can afford it, whether other steps are also needed to shore up Social Security and whether plan is politically feasible; graph (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Banking Consolidation
abstract: Germany's HypoVereinsbank says it may close as many as 90 branches to cut costs at consumer banking unit because of drop in earnings; photo (S)

headline: Brazil's AIDS Chief Denounces Bush Position on Drug Patents
abstract: Dr Paulo Roberto Teixeira, director of Brazil's AIDS program, accuses Bush administration of toughening America's stance toward Brazil's manufacture of generic AIDS drugs and of dragging AIDS policies into trade negotiations; Brazil is positioning itself to take lead over South Africa and other affected countries in debate over drug prices; Brazil was among first developing nations to deal with epidemic on many fronts; its program is considered model for third world; one action was to order production of generic AIDS drugs to compete with higher-priced drugs from international pharmaceutical companies (M)

headline: Article 2001050893063088494 -- No Title
2 Finalists Are Left In Jiffy Lube Review
abstract: Jiffy Lube International, part of Pennzoil-Quaker State Co, narrrows review of it advertising account to two agencies from four; billings estimated at $20 million; account had been handled by Richards Group (S)

headline: President Is Selected By Ad Industry Group
abstract: National Advertising Review Council names James R Guthrie president; International Advertising Association names Walter O'Brien director-general, succeeding Norman Vale, who is retiring (S)

headline: Raid Further Divides Gaza Neighbors
abstract: Stunned Palestinian residents of Khan Yunis refugee camp in Gaza Strip sift through wreckage after Israeli army bulldozers level 15 cinder block houses, leaving scores homeless; Israeli army claims it targeted buildings used by gunmen to shoot at neighboring Jewish settlement; photo (M)

headline: Continental's Profit Drops 36%; Rival Airlines Brace for Losses
abstract: Continental Airlines became the first leading carrier today to report first-quarter earnings, and if industry analysts are correct, it will be one of the few.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Automaker's Profit Is Up
abstract: Bayerische Motoren Werke AG says net income rose to 409 million euros ($362 million) in first quarter; graph (S)

headline: Iran's President Seeks New Term, Vowing More Political Change
abstract: Iran Pres Mohammad Khatami registers as candidate for re-election, ending months of speculation; gives emotional speech vowing to continue efforts to carry out political and social changes despite fierce conservative opposition (S)

headline: Intel Remains Cautious Amid Conflicting Industry Reports
abstract: Intel Corp says it will meet revenue projections for quarter, conference call to investors; see no indication that semiconductor industry has reached its bottom (M)

headline: A Stable Economy, but for How Long?
abstract: Russian economy is consistently and curiously stable for third consecutive year; government, with budget in surplus, has sworn off International Monetary Fund aid and is paying all its foreign debts in full for first time in post-Soviet history; economy, which rose 8.3 percent last year, is beginning to crawl back from decade of decline during which it shrank by half; economists question how long recovery, which has made Russian industry attractive to investors, will last; graphs (M)o

headline: Article 2001051492947093754 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Exports Fall
abstract: Philippine exports fell 0.5 percent in first quarter, to $8.5 billion; economists say export slowdown is sure to hurt country's economic growth; government has set growth target of 3.8 percent (S)

headline: Genome Research Pioneer to Buy Drug Maker
abstract: Celera Genomics will buy Axys Pharmaceuticals for about $174 million in stock in move intended to help Celera expand into drug business; Celera's chief executive J Craig Venter comments (M)

headline: Consortium Of Investors To Offer Bid For Eircom
abstract: Consortium led by Sir Anthony O'Reilly is preparing to bid for Ireland's formerly state-owned telephone company, Eircom PLC; includes Providence Equity Partners, Soros Private Equity Partners, Warburg Pincus and Goldman Sachs (M)

headline: Apple Aims at Schoolrooms With Latest Portable Computer
abstract: CUPERTINO, Calif., May 1 â€” Seeking to recapture its fading leadership in the educational computer market, Apple Computer Inc. today introduced a more compact and less expensive version of its iBook consumer-oriented portable computer.

headline: Chinese Hackers Invade 2 Official U.S. Web Sites
abstract: Chinese hackers take over Web sites maintained by Labor Department and Department of Health and Human Services, posting homage on the former to Wang Wei, Chinese pilot who was killed in collision with US spy plane (S)

headline: Slower Growth Seen in Europe, Held Back by German Woes
abstract: European Commission, acknowledging that United States slowdown will retard European economic growth, cuts its 2001 forecast for growth in 12 nations adopting euro currency by by 0.4 percentage point, to 2.8 percent; expects German economy to slow most because its exposure to United States is greatest; predicts 2.9 percent 2002 growth; sees average inflation of 2.2 percent in 2001 and 1.8 percent in 2002 (M)

headline: Talks Stalled Over Rights Of Albanians In Macedonia
abstract: Deadlock reported in political negotiations to end Macedonian government's conflict with ethnic Albanian rebels (S)

headline: 4 Laptops Lilliputians Might Like
abstract: David Pugue column on four laptop computers that suffer neither from full-sized laptops' bulkiness nor from ultralight laptops' lack of features; they are made by Apple, Fujitsu, NEC and WinBook; photos (M)

headline: AOL Raises Price for Unlimited Use
abstract: America Online Inc., the largest provider of Internet service, said today that it would raise the price of its unlimited-use plan by $1.95, to $23.90 a month, beginning in July.

headline: SOLECTRON WILL CUT ANOTHER 1,075 JOBS AND CLOSE PLANT
abstract: Solectron Corp, contract electronics manufacturer, plans to cut 1,075 jobs, or 1.5 percent reduction, and close Georgia plant because of slowing demand (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: General Warns President
abstract: Gen Endriartono Sutarto, Indonesian army's chief of staff, warns Pres Abdurrahman Wahid not to dissolve Parliament as way of evading possible impeachment proceedings (S)

headline: European Union Will Open Relations with North Korea
abstract: PARIS, May 14 â€” The European Union announced today that it was opening diplomatic relations with North Korea in an effort to help the country solve its humanitarian crisis. It also said it planned to support peace efforts between the two Koreas, which have remained technically at war since 1950.

headline: California Oil Refineries May Avoid Blackouts
abstract: California oil refineries are expected to be granted exemption from possible electrical power shutdowns under plan that will be voted on by state's Public Utilities Commission; regulator plans to exempt refineries on issues of health and public safety (S)

headline: Manila Moves Incite Talk of 'Dark Side of People Power'
abstract: Pres Gloria Macapagal Arroyo of Philippines uses 'state of rebellion' as reason to widen crackdown on opposition leaders, whom she acuses of inciting violence; this leaves even her own supporters fearing that abrupt ouster of her predecessor, Joseph Estrada, was dangerous precedent; ouster occurred before Estrada's impeachment trial on corruption charges had reached verdict; Aquilino Pimentel, president of Senate, says fear now is that massing million people on streets can topple any government; says country cannot afford to have such 'people power'; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Optimism On The War
abstract: Momentum is growing toward ending the war in Congo, envoys from the United Nations Security Council said as they ended a tour of eight nations involved in fighting or trying to settle the nearly three-year-old conflict. On their last stop, in Uganda, the team of envoys heard assurances from the main rebel leader, Jean-Pierre Bemba, that he would pull back from front-line positions, and President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda repeated promises to all but end military assistance to Mr. Bemba.     Ian Fisher (NYT)

headline: Hong Kong Slaughters Chickens to Halt Spread of Flu Virus
abstract: With chickens dying by the hundreds and public alarm mounting, Hong Kong today ordered the slaughter of 1.2 million chickens and other poultry to halt the spread of a deadly flu virus.     The slaughter, which echoes Hong Kong's drastic response to a similar virus in 1997, will eliminate every chicken from the city's markets and all market-age poultry from its farms. Hong Kong also halted the importation of live birds from mainland China, which supplies much of its poultry and so far has taken no action against the virus. ''This is a large-scale exercise,'' said Lily Yam, the secretary for the environment and food, ''but we feel that early and determined action is necessary to arrest the spread of the influenza.''

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Finance Chief At Swissair
abstract: Jacqualyn Fouse, group treasurer for Nestle SA, is named chief financial officer of Swissair Group; Georges Schorderet, current finance chief, will take charge of special audit of company that was approved at recent shareholder meeting (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Public Fight Over Private Property
abstract: Fistfight breaks out in Russian Parliament after government official presents draft bill on private ownership of land; Communist lawmakers try to block official from making way to podium but bill is approved on first of three required readings; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | The World: Thou Shalt Not Get Away From It All
abstract: Pope John Paul II urges believers 'not to take a rest from ethics' while on holiday; deplores rise of sophisticated holiday resorts that are 'cut off from any real contact with host countries'; warns that search for 'superficial exoticism' could lead to sex tours that exploit women and children (S)

headline: Canadian Driller Fights Hostile Kazakh Bid
abstract: Central Asia Industrial Holdings, offshore affiliate of Kazkommertsbank, Kazakhstan's leading banking group, offers $6.66 a share for 18.4 million shares of Canada's Hurricane Hydrocarbons, enough to give it control (M)

headline: Article 2001052891223567399 -- No Title
Article 2001051592393335499 -- No Title
abstract: Cyber Law Journal: Does a Parody Site Go Too Far?

headline: Aetna Says First-Quarter Profit Will Fall Far Short of Expectations
abstract: Shares in Aetna, nation's largest health insurer, drop more than 17 percent after company warns that its first-quarter earnings will be significantly lower than expected; says its costs rose faster than expected because of increased use of medical centers, doctors' services and drugs; chief executive Dr John W Rowe says continued increases in medical costs are clearly unacceptable and do not reflect positive potential of Aetna (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Tallying Fascists' Thefts
abstract: Italian government study finds that between 1938 and 1945 Fascist government robbed Jewish Italians of property now worth $890 million (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Peru: Fujimori Accused In Killings
abstract: Peru Atty Gen Nelly Calderon files charges accusing former Pres Alberto K Fujimori of having approved killings of 15 people by death squads allegedly organized by his intelligence chief Vladimiro Montesinos; photo (S)

headline: LTV ASKS COURT TO ELIMINATE SOME RETIREE BENEFITS
abstract: Steel maker LTV Corp asks bankruptcy court to terminate labor agreements and eliminate some retiree health benefits; says it will cut about 800 jobs so it can avoid closing operations (S)

headline: Lilly Reports 17% Rise in Profit, Spurred by Schizophrenia Drug
abstract: Eli Lilly & Company says first-quarter net income rose to $806.8 million from $692.3 million in year-earlier quarter; sales rose 10 percent, to $2.81 billion (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Loss At Shipbuilder
abstract: Hyundai Heavy Industries, the world's largest builder of merchant ships, paid the price in the first quarter of this year for diverting funds into money-losing companies in the Hyundai group. The shipbuilder, generally one of Korea's most profitable enterprises, reported an unconsolidated loss of $63 billion in the first quarter of this year, largely as a result of losses suffered by Hyundai Petrochemical, of which it is the major shareholder. A court in Seoul, meanwhile, ordered the liquidation of Dong Ah Construction, once Korea's second-largest builder. Dong Ah, which failed to pay debts of $3 billion in November, will still be able to complete its ditch project in Libya.   Don Kirk (NYT)

headline: Market Place: Decision Time Nears for the Treasury Market
abstract: Thomas Juterbock, head of global government bond trading at Morgan Stanley & Company, says there have not been many disruptions in fixed-income markets so far as a result of the shrinking Treasury bond market and the decline in new issues of Treasury notes and bonds.
