headline: Fear of Ethnic Attacks Grips Macedonia's Cities
abstract: Fear grips Macedonia's cities, notably capital of Skopje, that three-month-old conflict between Macedonian security forces and ethnic Albanian rebels in mountainous border areas could spill over into urban areas and develop into ethnic violence; both sides fault coalition unity government, accusing it of not moving fast enough to end conflict; Macedonians prefer quick military solution; Albanians are demanding constitutional changes that would put them on equal footing with Macedonians and remove source of protest; map; photo (M)

headline: Backing Sought for Offshore Tax Initiative
abstract: Tax officials from US and other countries end meeting in Paris and return home to seek political agreement for proposals under which US and Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development would cooperate on reducing tax revenue lost to offshore havens (S)

headline: Losses Narrow As AOL Posts Higher Revenue
abstract: AOL Time Warner says revenue for first quarter grew strongly and its losses narrowed as its AOL and cable businesses prospered; losses fell 7 percent, to $1.37 billion from $1.46 billion year ago; revenue rose 9 percent, to $9.1 billion from $8.3 billion; company still expects to reach its goal of $11 billion in cash flow and $40 billion in sales for year (M)

headline: MORTON'S TO CONSIDER BUYOUT BID FROM FLORIDA COMPANY
abstract: Morton's Restaurant Group will consider buyout offer made by BFMA Holding Corp with backing from Carl C Icahn; BFMA owns 9.3 percent of Morton's and has bid $28.25 per share to acquire rest (S)

headline: Seeing Blue Skies, Again, For Chips
abstract: IN the technology food chain, nothing is more basic than semiconductors and the machines that make them.     If the chip makers are not doing good business, most technology companies will not fare well, either. Just now, semiconductor conditions could not be much worse.

headline: The 4-Letter-Word Patrol Is in Pursuit
abstract: Crackdown on dirty jokes, swearing and other offensive speech in the workplace is gaining ground; Carl Jaskolski, who teaches employment law, see swearing as form of workplace harassment and has drafted language policy that he distributes free to human resource practitioners across country; some experts believe crackdown is doomed to fail; Susanna Seaman comments on losing her job at Verizon for using profanity when she was under stress; photos (M)

headline: Fulbright Scholar Sentenced to 37 Months in Russian Jail
abstract: MOSCOW, April 27 -- A court in the southwest Russian city of Voronezh convicted a visiting American Fulbright scholar on drug charges today and sentenced him to 37 months in a penal colony near Moscow.

headline: In Radio Feud, a Higher Kind of Superpower Irks Italy
abstract: Many residents in Cesano, small north Rome suburb, say radiation from Vatican's nearby radio transmitters causes cancer; Vatican is seeking to end dispute over antennas of Vatican Radio, which transmits Roman Catholic programming to five continents in 35 languages; although Vatican considers itself sovereign state and not subject to Italian law, it has announced that it will begin reducing electromagnetic emissions from antennas in order to meet stringent Italian limits; photo (M)

headline: Payoffs Rife and Approved, French Ex-Oil Chief Asserts
abstract: PARIS, May 19 â€” A former head of France's state-owned oil company, now on trial for corruption, has told two newspapers that paying millions of dollars a year in "secret commissions" was a routine part of his job and had the approval of ElysÃ©e Palace.

headline: Personal Business Diary: Online Banking Remains a Tough Sell
abstract: Many American consumers are clearly comfortable with technology. There are personal computers in most homes, and people regularly use the Internet for a wide range of everyday tasks â€” except when it comes to banking.

headline: Rich Nations Consider Fund Of Billions to Fight AIDS
abstract: Group of Seven considers multi-billion dollar global program to fight AIDS and other infectious diseases, but US warns effort would likely fail unless it is carefully tailored to difficult conditions in countries where diseases prevail; issue is taken up at finance ministers' meeting in Washington; World Bank president James Wolfensohn says $3- to $4-billion a year would be needed for AIDS program in Africa alone (M)

headline: Times Co. Plans Share Buyback
abstract: New York Times Co board authorizes spending of as much as $300 milion for repurchase of Class A shares; increases dividend payment (S)

headline: Harsh Chinese Realities Feed Market in Women
abstract: Article on trafficking in women in China, where tens or hundreds of thousands of poor women are sold on black market each year; trade thrives in rural areas, where there are nearly 120 boys for every 100 girls but where it is considered culturally and economically essential that 100 percent of men find brides and produce heirs; for every 100 rural men who marry, 20 others mustr resort to extraordinary measures to find brides, like buying kidnapped women; government is waging harsh campaign against practice which, though significantly dampened, still thrives in rural areas; photo (M)

headline: Anlong Veng Journal; Praying to Pol Pot, Seeking Health and Good Luck
abstract: Some residents of area around Anlong Veng, Cambodia, come to pray at site where Pol Pot was cremated in disgrace in 1998; Pol Pot, who headed Khmer Rouge government responsible for over million deaths, has become something of patron saint in region, where he is remembered by many with respect and some with reverence; map; photo (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Yen falls to 123.08 per US dollar; charts (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Guatemala: Ex-Dictator Faces Inquiry
abstract: Guatemalan court orders prosecutors to investigate Efrain Rios Montt, former dictator and current speaker of Congress, on charges of masterminding massacres of tens of thousands of people during country's civil war (S)

headline: Memo to Blair: Stand and Deliver
abstract: News analysis of British Prime Min Tony Blair's re-election victory; voters' support for Blair is seen conditional, even as it is overwhelming, with people demanding that he fulfill his promises; two areas where Blair must deliver are restoring Britain's decrepit public services and building national acceptance for joining European common currency (M)

headline: Entrepreneur Envisions a Cat That Doesn't Cause Allergies
abstract: Transgenic Pets is developing genetically engineered cat that will not cause allergies, effort that could allow millions of people who cannot do so keep cats as pets; allergies-free cat is closer to concept than execution; Transgenic Pets is shoestring operation run out of home of its founder Dr David Avner; research to develop cat is being done under contract by Dr Xiangzhong Yang at University of Connecticut (M)

headline: Labor Standards Clash With Global Reality
abstract: Article in series, Made in Squalor, examining third-world production for first-world markets; focuses unsuccessful efforts of Gap retail chain to improve working standards at factory in El Salvador, demonstrating limits to good intentions when first-world appetites collide with third-world realities; competing interests among factory owners, government officials, American managers and middle-class consumers have made it difficult to achieve even basic improvement in standards, and even harder to maintain them; even though US has pressured developing countries to raise pay and working conditions in thousands of plants from Bangladesh to Brazil, results have been negligible; labor advocates say basic problem is that jobs and capital are competitively priced and can move relatively fast, and is made worse by cozy ties between government and factory owners with eyes on lowest possible cost; photos; map; chart (M)

headline: On Hainan Island: U.S. Officials Wait
abstract: American Embassy officials arrived yesterday on the island where the United States surveillance plane made an emergency landing on Sunday after a midair collision with a Chinese military jet.    The American officials, Brig. Gen. Neal Sealock, the defense attaché, and Capt. Bradley Kaplan, the naval attaché, came from Beijing to meet with the crew members and arrange their return. They also wanted to arrange for the repair and return of the EP-3E, which is equipped with sophisticated equipment. The plane landed at Lingshui Air Base, at the south end of the tropical island.

headline: FUJI RECALLS SOME AUTOS
abstract: Fuji Heavy Industries recalls 173,000 of its Legacy automobiles because of defect that could cause fuel tank to crack (S)

headline: Diesel Campaign Wins at Cannes
abstract: Advertising campaign for Diesel apparel brand meant to parody Eurocentric world view wins Grand Prix in press and poster competition at International Advertising Festival in Cannes, France; campaign was developed by Paradiset DDB, which is no longer Diesel agency, having been replaced by Kessells Kramer; other winners noted (M)

headline: Market Place; First Union's Bid for Wachovia Gains Momentum
abstract: Market Place column says battle for Wachovia Corp seems to be tilting toward First Union Corp as value of SunTrust Banks' hostile bid continues to drop; SunTrust's premium over First Union's friendly offer has fallen to 2 percent, down from 17 percent when bid was made; SunTrust is unlikely to raise bid and risk driving down its stock price even further (M)

headline: Economic Scene; In America, to the richest go the biggest tax benefits. So what else is new?
abstract: Jeff Madrick Economic Scene column on Government's preference for 'tax expenditures,' credits and deductions from federal income taxes that tend to favor wealthy by rewarding some kinds of spending or saving; notes deductions are worth more to those in highest brackets and to those who can spend most on deductible items; puts tax expenditures at some $700 billion to $800 billion a year; holds programs may be inefficient and drain money that could be used for social program; photo (M)

headline: Samsung Puts a Colorful Twist On Its Handheld-Phone Hybrid
abstract: Samsung SPH-1300 combines capabilities of cellular phone and digital assistant; it utilizes Palm operating system; photo (M)

headline: If Microsoft Builds It, Will They Upgrade?
abstract: Microsoft is expected to release new version of Windows operating system in autumn, one that promises crash-resistant stability and interface that is sparkling, intuitive and easy to use; it remain uncertain whether users will flock to upgrade to Windows XP; photo; chronology of development of Windows systems (M)

headline: Canadian Cable Unit Sold
abstract: Shaw Communications Inc, Canada's second-largest cable television company, sells its cable systems in Nova Scotia to Bragg Communications for $143.5 million (US) to reduce debt (S)

headline: Shares Decline as Outlook for Technology Stirs Concern
abstract: Nasdaq composite index falls 44.32 points, to 2,170.78; Dow Jones industrial average drops 54.91 points, to 10,922.09; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declines 10.57 points, to 1,254.39; graph; chart (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: EUROPE

headline: Even the Best Boats Need Rocking
abstract: Fred Andrews reviews Creative Destruction by Richard Roster, senior partner and director of McKinsey & Co, and Sarah Kaplan; book argues that successful companies must overcome obstacles to innovation created by their own success; photo (M)

headline: Article 2001063090419508830 -- No Title
abstract: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

headline: Photographer's Hand Is Steadied With Aid From Nerves of Silicon
abstract: Nikon offers new telephoto zoom lens that can be used without support by even most jittery photographers; lens uses microprocessors, electronic sensors, special lenses and sophisticated miniature motors to eliminate vibration; photo (S)

headline: Renewed Jitters on Profits Set Back Technology Issues
abstract: Nasdaq composite index drops 91.04 points, to 2,084.50; Dow Jones industrial average loses 166.50 points, to 10,872.64; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 19.85 points, to 1,248.08; graph; chart (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Political Friction and Jets
abstract: China hints that recent tensions with United States could have impact on whether it continues to buy commercial aircraft from Boeing Co; state-owned China Southwest Airlines tests Airbus Industrie jet (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: New Chief At Energis
abstract: Britain's Energis says chief executive Mike Grabiner will retire as of Aug 1, and will be replaced by David Wickham, currently chief operation officer; company reports loss of $139 million (US) for year to March 31; photo (S)

headline: School Was Important, After All
abstract: PricewaterhouseCoopers poll of chief executives, many of whose companies have acquired other businesses, cite incompatibility of top management as potential barrier to successful takeovers (S)

headline: Business; Recovery Lessons From an Industrial Phoenix
abstract: Companies that have sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection recently because of asbestos-related liability claims will look to resuscitated Johns-Manville Corp, which underwent similar difficulties and survived; Robert A Falise is chairman of Manville Personal Injury Trust, created in 1988 to pay claims filed against company; photo; list of recent asbestos-related bankruptcy filings (M)

headline: Amazon Pares Quarter Loss As It Increases Some Sales
abstract: Amazon.com reports lower-than-expected first-quarter loss of $234.13 million, down from loss of $308.4 3 million year earlier; sales increased 22 percent, to $700.36 million; gross profit--sales minus cost of goods sold--was $183 million, up 43 percent; photo (M)

headline: Ulster Voters Hand Victory To Opponents Of Peace Pact
abstract: Results of Parliamentary elections in Northern Ireland casts future of fragile peace accord in doubt; Protestant opponents of agreement, led by Rev Ian Paisley, gain two new seats, while pro-agreement forces led by David Trimble loses three of nine; voting in Catholic areas shows Sinn Fein, political wing of Irish Republican Army, taking power away from moderate Social and Democratic Labor Party, increasing number of seats from two to four, while competitor remains with three (M)

headline: Executive Pay and Priorities
abstract: Jacqueline Jones letter addresses economic disparity; replies to April 1 article about executive compensation

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ALCATEL S.A., San Francisco, the Genesys Telecommunications Laboratories Inc. unit of Alcatel has agreed to purchase International Business Machines Corp.'s CallPath assets. Financial terms of the deal weren't disclosed.

headline: Barneys Loss Widens on Slump in Sales
abstract: Fiscal first-quarter losses at Barneys New York Inc widen to $3.3 million from $934 million a year earlier; sales fall 2.6 percent, to $91.1 million (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Maker of Painkiller Is Urged By U.S. to Alter Marketing  Federal officials have urged the maker of a widely abused narcotic painkiller to limit voluntarily how it distributes and markets the drug, which has played a role in more than 100 fatal overdoses in several states.    Federal officials have also been in talks about withdrawing or modifying a claim that the painkiller, OxyContin, made by Purdue Pharma, may be less prone to abuse than similar narcotics. [Page A16.]

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Soccer Indictments Sought
abstract: Congressional committee in Brazil investigating corruption in professional soccer recommends that 32 team managers and player agents be indicted, including Ricardo Teixeira, president of Brazilian Soccer Federation (S)

headline: Business; And Now, a Case for the Forensic Accountant
abstract: Forensic accountants are in demand for fraud cases, litigation and divorces; photo (M)

headline: Test Results Reported on New Antibiotic
abstract: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 3 (Bloomberg News) â€” Cubist Pharmaceuticals Inc. said today that its lead drug, an antibiotic intended to fight resistant bacteria, appears to work as well as older drugs in treating infections from skin wounds.

headline: Big Hopes Are Still on the Table As the Writers' Deadline Nears
abstract: Leaders of Writers Guild of America, who came to power in 1999 with pledge to play hardball with media conglomerates that many writers feel exploit them, face increasing political and public pressure to reach accord with Alliance of Motion Picture and Television Producers; represent diverse group, with goals of television writers differing from those of movie writers (M)

headline: Michelin Baby Dances in New Ad
abstract: Michelin North America's new commercial features same Michelin baby that its ads have featured for almost two decades; baby is dancing as if tire was hula hoop in new ad; spot was created by DDB Worldwide (S)

headline: VIVENDI WILL CREATE VIDEO GAMES BASED ON TOLKIEN BOOKS
abstract: Vivendi Universal SA receives eight-year exclusive license from Tolkien Enterprises to create video games based on J R R Tolkien's books The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: I.B.M. Gets Big Service Contract
abstract: IBM will supply computer services to NTL Inc, Britain's largest cable television company, under 10-year contract that could be worth more than $2 billion; IBM and Seiko Epson Corp agree to set up venture to make chips for mobile, Internet and wireless computing devices; venture will use IBM plant in Japan (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Wahid And Army At Odds
abstract: Pres Abdurrahman Wahid says he will declare state of emergency in Indonesia and use military to prevent his removal from office (S)

headline: More Than One Way of Looking at Software Maker's Earnings
abstract: C

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Kenya: Two More U.N. Workers Charged
abstract: Two more employees of United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees in Nairobi are charged with extorting money from people seeking to resettle in United States and Europe (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: Pinochet Hearing Delayed
abstract: Appeals court in Chile delays hearing on whether to suspend human rights case against Gen Augusto Pinochet after one of three judges fails to show up (S)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: EUROPE

headline: Arafat Orders Troops to Bar Any Violence
abstract: Israel buries victims of suicide bombing in Tel Aviv disco which killed 19, as Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat follows up on appeal for cease-fire by ordering Palestinian security chiefs to prevent all attacks on Israeli targets from Palestinian ruled territory; Palestinian security forces begin active patrols in many locations in West Bank and Gaza; Israeli officials are skeptical that Arafat's intentions are ploy to regain some ground in battle for world support; diplomats say Israel seems prepared to withhold military reprisals somewhat longer to convince world opinion that Arafat is being given chance to prove desire to restore calm; Prime Min Ariel Sharon visits survivors of attack; says restraint is element of strength; says he is faced with very complicated and difficult situation; Defense Sec Benjamin Ben-Eliezer says forces are ready; government says military plan of action has been drawn up; photo (M)

headline: Minority Staff Members In Journalism Are Fewer
abstract: American Society of Newspaper Editors survey finds number of minority journalists dropped to 6,563, from 6,665, in year; minorities now make up 11.64 percent of journalists, compared with 31 percent of national population (M)

headline: Germany Looks Like Europe's Weak Economic Link
abstract: German economy, still suffering from results of unification, continues to lag behind economies of other European countries, and government is cutting forecast for economic growth this year, to 2 percent from 2.75 percent; European Commission and most private experts predict that Europe as whole will still expand about 2.5 percent; Germany's relative weakness is dragging down entire region at time when Europe is anxious to escape worst effects of slowdown in US (M)

headline: Magazine for Teenagers Benefits in Publishing-Internet Marriage
abstract: Anne Zehren, publisher of AOL Time Warner's Teen People, cites magazine's link to America Online as example of how Internet and print magazine world can work in tandem; says magazine provides AOL with content and acts as consultancy, while AOL offers ways to sell subscriptions and promote magazine; photos (M)

headline: U.S. Venture Capital Sees Treasure In Europe; But the Welcome for Silicon Valley Is Not Always Friendly Overseas
abstract: American venture capital firms, ladened with dot-com failures, are turning to Europe, which they consider underdeveloped market that has avoided worst of Internet boom and bust; many venture capitalists may find it tough going because value of deals are shrinking; comments from Charles Muirhead, British entrepreneur who runs Orchestream, John Fisher, managing director of Draper Fisher Jurvetson, Douglas Brown, chief executive of Advent International, and Jerome Mol, chairman of Dutch firm Gorilla Park that advises entpreneurs; graph; drawing; photos (M)

headline: South Korea's Conservative Press Takes Heat From the Liberals
abstract: New battle is under way in South Korea between government and press; critics say government is trying to stop big three papers from criticizing liberal Kim Dae Jung, whose popularity is waning under their attacks; ostensibly, all country's 23 news media companies are under investigation for possible violations of tax and fair trade laws; executives of three biggest-selling papers say they are being singled out; together they control 70 percent of newspaper sales in country; government recently extended deadline on tax probe of three papers, action seen as evidence of its determination to find evidence to bring charges (M)

headline: Private Sector; Imitating Mr. Ghosn in Japan
abstract: Carlos Ghosn's success in making Nissan Motor Co highly profitable prompts speculation that other troubled Japanese companies may look abroad for chief executives; Ghosn was born in Brazil; photo (S)

headline: Banking in a Troubled Country
abstract: Brusque, formal and flanked by stone-faced bankers, Edwin Gerungan can enter a room looking less like a civil servant than a corporate raider poised to present a tender offer to a takeover target.    But as the former Citibank executive loosens up and talks about his job, it becomes clear that he is very much a government official -- one mired in a bureaucracy that would test the truly civic minded.

headline: Unearthing Office Tools Long Buried
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column explores Microsoft's new, upgraded software suite, Office XP; recommends XP upgrade to those who work in teams, produce heavily formatted documents or work extensively on Outlook screens (M)

headline: For Chrysler These Days, It May Be Robots or Mexico
abstract: Chrysler unit of DaimlerChrysler AG invites journalists to inspect its $700 million Jeep Liberty factory in Toledo, Ohio, where use of robots and better production processes have eliminated more than 1,000 jobs that would have been needed in old Jeep Wrangler factory nearby; company will greatly increase production of hot-selling Chrysler PT Cruiser by expanding factory in Toluca, Mexico, instead of using one in Belvidere, Ill; photo (M)

headline: Arafat Calls for Cease-Fire, Deploring Tel Aviv Attack
abstract: Yasir Arafat makes public call for immediate and unconditional cease-fire, his first such call since latest Israeli-Palestinian violence began eight months ago, and he condemns suicide bombing that killed 18 young Israelis outside Tel Aviv nightclub; Israeli security cabinet urges Arafat to follow up his words with 'deeds,' such as rearresting immediately Islamic militants who were released from Palestinian prison last fall; their systematic terrorist campaign reached new peak with nightclub bombing, deadliest attack on Israel in five years; senior Israeli military official says Israel would hold off direct military reprisal against Palestinian Authority targets to give Arafat time to follow through on his public statement; European diplomats who have shuttled between two side say Arafat needs to take concrete and discernible steps toward counterterrorism within next 24 hours for Israel to continue to hold its fire; photos (M)

headline: Firestone to Stop Sales to Ford, Saying It Was Used as Scapegoat
abstract: Bridgestone/Firestone Inc, acting ahead of expected effort by Ford Motor Co to replace as many as 13 million more Firestone tires on its Explorer sport utility vehicles, says it will stop selling tires to Ford; accuses Ford of questioning safety of its tires to divert attention from problems with Explorer, in which more than 100 people have died in tire-related crashes, almost all rollovers; announcement severs almost century-old corporate relationship and revives national controversy over tire and vehicle safety that began in August 2000, when Firestone at Ford's request recalled 6.5 million tires supplied as factory equipment on Explorers; Firestone chairman John T Lampe says he terminated relationship following refusal by Ford to share its safety data on Explorer; statistical analysis prepared by Ford, and shared with regulators without Firestone's knowledge, found remaining Firestone tires on Explorers also have higher rates of problems than tires from other manufacturers, although not nearly as high as tires already recalled; August recall covered 14.4 million tires produced from 1990 through January 2000; Ford has been secretly preparing to replace rest of Firestone tires for customers at its own expense; photo (M)

headline: If the Bond Market Is a Haven, Its Walls Are Shaking
abstract: THESE have been rough days for bonds,  even though there is no sign that the economy is rebounding and no reason to think that the Federal Reserve will fail to cut its short-term interest rate benchmark by at least another half of a percentage point.    While bonds are still doing much better than stocks this year, the sell-off is a reminder that this supposed haven can be quite volatile itself. And the sell-off has probably been enough to make many investors wonder what they should do next.

headline: Court Says H.M.O.'s Must Give More Data
abstract: Judge Federico Moreno rules Aetna Inc, Humana Inc, Cigna Corp and other health insurers must turn over more documents to doctors suing them; physicians charge HMO's with engaging in racketeering and breaking contracts by not paying claims on time (S)

headline: More Protests in Nepal as Inquiry Stumbles
abstract: Protests continue in Nepal over murder of royal family and suspicions that authorities are not telling public the truth; photo; officials impose curfew (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CHRONIMED INC., -- Minnetonka, Minn., a maker of health care products, said it would buy Transplant Pharmacy, a mail order distribution unit of SangStat Medical, Fremont, Calif. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: People
abstract: * Dennis Miller resigns as chairman and chief executive at Publicis in the West, Seattle; Randy Browning, president and chief marketing officer, and Kevin Kehoe, president and chief creative officer, will assume Miller's duties and retain current titles; Barry Lowenthal is named media director at Bartle Bogle Hegarty; Jeff Weber, chief operating officer at Wolf Group, is named president, succeeding Tom Moore, who resigned; Ben Kline, director at Wieden & Kennedy, is named managing director, succeeding Dave Luhr, who continues as chief operating officer; Niland Mortimer is named to new post of global account director on Fujitsu advertising account at New York office of Bozell Kamstra (M)

headline: Article 2001061293642649250 -- No Title
abstract: Who's on First? Wonder No More

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Job Growth Slows
abstract: Slowing global economies cut into French exports, causing growth of new jobs to begin to slow (S)

headline: Patents; Relying on the Internet for early and late updates: traffic jams, weather, even a humane alarm clock.
abstract: Mary Smith Dewey patents system that downloads real-time data about weather and traffic from Internet and uses data to determine whether to change alarm clock setting; Primo Bugane patents method and special pot for cooking pasta in tomato sauce instead of water (M)

headline: More at a Wall Street Firm Are Investigated on I.P.O.'s
abstract: Several more employees of Credit Suisse First Boston are under investigation in broad federal inquiry into how Wall Street investment banks doled out shares in offerings of new stocks; regulatory filings show that federal investigation into how initial public offerings were sold at height of technology stock boom in late 1990's extends to First Boston's New York headquarters; among New York-based employees who have disclosed that they are subjects of investigation are Andrew S Benjamin, managing director in firm's private client services division, which provides brokerage services to wealthy individuals (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Data-Storage Vendors Back Common Standards
abstract: Leading data-storage system vendors back industry standards aimed at making it easier for customers to mix and match certain types of storage equipment; negotiate accord under Storage Networking Industry Association auspices (S)

headline: Digital Storage: Computer Age Gets a Valhalla
abstract: Computer Museum History Center in Moffett Field, Calif, is repository for most products of computer era; Dr Leonard Shustek is chairman of its board of trustees; some of museum's holdings are drawn from collection of former Computer Museum in Boston; photos (M)

headline: Polaroid to Cut 2,000 Jobs; Instant-Photo Woes Are Cited
abstract: Polaroid Corp, acknowledging its ailing instant photography business is unlikely ever to recover, says it will cut 2,000 jobs, at least half in Massachusetts; photo of chief executive Gary DiCamillio demonstrating Polaroid's Opal digital printing technology (M)

headline: Health Care Industry Braces For Change in Senate Focus
abstract: Health care industry is bracing for changes that could affect costs and profits of drug companies, insurers and employers as Senate prepares to reorganize with Democrats in control; health care agenda changes radically when Sen Tom Daschle, who will be new majority leader, says he will move ahead with patient protection legislation that has been locked up in Senate by Republican leadership; lobbyists for managed care industry begin saying that right to sue insurers for medical malpractice will be unacceptably costly unless awards are held to no more than $500,000 and cases are confined to federal courts, as Republicans have proposed; drug companies are preparing for fight over management of prescription drug benefit for elderly; Alan F Holmer, president of Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America, comments (M)

headline: Venlo Journal; The New Reefer Madness: Drive-Through Shops
abstract: Officials in Venlo, Netherlands, want to open two drive-through shops where 'drug tourists' can buy small amounts of marijuana and hashish without getting out of cars; proposal attracts flock of curious journalists to town near German border; is aimed at curbing illegal drug trade that caters to Germans who patronize five licensed coffee shops selling such soft drugs by moving business to town's outskirts; map; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Hynix Stays Afloat
abstract: Korea Exchange Bank and other Hynix Semiconductor creditors hope to keep company afloat by issuing bonds and rolling over debts totaling 5.1 trillion won ($3.9 billion) (S)

headline: Compaq Plans To Phase Out A Widely Used Computer Chip
abstract: Compaq Computer plans to phase out Alpha microprocessors at heart of most of its high-performance computers, and by 2004 all of its business computers will be designed around Intel's new processor family, known as Itanium; hundreds of Compaq engineers who work on Alpha will move to Intel; Compaq will also migrate from chips designed by MIPS Technologies to Itanium in segment of its business that makes ultra-high-reliability computers; Compaq says it recently sent memo to employees detailing reorganization steps over next six months to cut costs, increase sales and place greater emphasis on selling software and services; photo (M)

headline: Forming Battle Lines On Workaholics' Ways
abstract: Charles H Zwicker letter endorses May 6 On the Contrary column lauding workaholism

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   7.50   8.00   9.00        Discount rate   4.00   4.50   5.50        Federal funds   4.69   4.99   6.00        3-month T-bills   3.79   4.01   5.58        6-month T-bills   3.79   4.00   5.74        10-yr. T-infl.   3.32   3.42   3.97        10-yr. T-note   5.15   5.21   6.13        30-yr. T-bond   5.66   5.66   5.94        Telephone bd.   7.95   7.90   8.03        Municipal bds.   5.42   5.39   5.98          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Talks Tie Trade In the Americas To Democracy
abstract: 34 leaders of Western Hemisphere, including Pres George W Bush, close international trade summit in Quebec; reinforce commitment to Vast Free Trade Area of the Americas, vowing to ensure that its benefits are shared by hemishphere's 800 million people; vow to uphold democratic principles or risk losing economic and political support, though some may have trouble meeting standard; propose 'action plan' backed by billions of dollars in support from international financial institutions; commitment of more than $20 billion by World Bank and Inter-American Development Bank to strenghten democratic foundations in Americas and prepare for free trade despite disparate levels of development noted; leaders also agree to release draft of agreement, giving organizations that oppose it chance to review it for first time; photo (M)

headline: Thailand's Annual Water War Mirrors a Wild Era
abstract: Bangkok is a danger zone this weekend. Many foreigners flee. Middle-class Thais stay cautiously in their homes. The usually gridlocked streets are strangely empty -- except for roving bands of armed youths.    They are armed with water: buckets, pails, high-powered hoses, water bombs, squirt guns, water rifles, portable pumps and vats of ice.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Microsoft To Sign Data Pact
abstract: Microsoft Corp will sign on to European Union-US safe harbor agreement that allows companies to export personal data to US from Europe (S)

headline: Flood of New Corporate Debt Pushes Down Treasury Prices
abstract: US Treasury prices post their biggest losses in two weeks; benchmark 10-year Treasury note falls one point, to 97 24/32; yield rises to 5.30 percent from 5.16 percent; 30-year Treasury bond loses 1 9/32, to 94 19/32, increasing its yield to 5.76 percent from 5.66 percent; graph on tax-exempt yields; chart on US key interest rates (M)

headline: Some Russians Are Alarmed At Tighter Grip Under Putin
abstract: Russian intellectuals and democracy advocates fear relative freedom from state surveillance and restriction relished in last decade may be drawing to close; see resurgence in government obsession with internal security and threats from abroad that has set off limited but growing crackdown on supposed challenges to state; are unsettled by Pres Vladimir V Putin's failure to restrain or speak out against signs of crackdown; photo (M)

headline: G.E. Chief Courts Europeans on Acquisition of Honeywell
abstract: General Electric Co's chief executive John F Welch Jr meets twice with Mario Monti, European competition commissioner, in effort to win approval for GE's $45 billion acquisition of Honeywell International; GE has offered to divest itself of assets worth as much as $3 billion in annual revenue; has proposed selling its grounded proximity warning systems business, its auxiliary power systems unit and its satellite collision-avoidance systems; would also divest itself of Honeywell's regional jet engines, Honeywell's engine-starter businesses and aircraft maintenance business in Germany; deadline for GE to submit concessions expires at midnight June 14, but negotiating is expected to continue well beyond, with European Commission deadline of July 12; photo (M)

headline: Investment Banking Loses 150 Workers In Goldman Job Cuts
abstract: Goldman Sachs says layoffs of almost 150 employees in investment banking include managing directors, vice presidents and associates (S)

headline: Market Seems Unimpressed by Big German Bank Deal
abstract: Top management at Allianz AG begins uphill task of selling investors on its proposed takeover of Dresdner Bank for about $20 billion in cash and stock; both companies' stocks decline as analysts offer positive but tepid assessment of deal; boards of two companies approve deal; photo (M)

headline: A Leapfrog Pattern in Pay Pacts for Airline Pilots
abstract: Delta Air Lines' contract agreement with its pilots leapfrogs agreement at United Airlines, making its pilots the highest paid in industry; Delta says increases will add more than $2 billion to its current pilot costs over life of four-year contract; average Delta pilot earned $188,038 in salary and benefits last year; such pattern bargaining is expected to raise labor costs across rest of industry by equal measures in coming years as pilots at American, Continental and Northeast also demand raises above current rates at Delta and United; analysts say airlines can do little to counter increases other than raise business fares (M)

headline: World Business Briefing  Australia: Australia: Lamb Trade Dispute
abstract: World Trade Organization rebuffs appeal by US to earlier ruling voiding its restrictions against imports of Australian and New Zealand lamb (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: Europe

headline: Article 2001042293514563560 -- No Title
abstract: April 21, 2001

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Chad: Losing Candidates Arrested
abstract: Six candidates who lost in recent disputed presidential election in Chad are arrested on charges of civil disobediance after trying to organize rally to mark death of supporter; are challenging legitimacy of victory by Pres Idriss Deby (S)

headline: U.S. Envoy Has Tried to Bridge Gap
abstract: US Amb Joseph W Prueher, who as former commander of American military forces in Pacific cultivated exchanges and personal relationships with Chinese leaders, expresses disappointment and betrayal over China's holding of crew and reconnaissance plane, which made emergency landing on Hainan Island after colliding with Chinese fighter over South China Sea; photo (M)

headline: E-Commerce Report; EBay's entry into the market for assisting small companies poses challenges for rivals.
abstract: eBay's plan to sell easy-to-build Web stores and list them on its site for monthly fee poses challenges for rivals in market for selling e-commerce services to small businesses; comes at particularly bad time for Network Commerce and Bigstep, which are just beginning to charge customers for services after failed experiments with advertising-supported models; photo (M)

headline: AT&T to Raise Some Rates By as Much as 11 Percent
abstract: AT&T will raise basic residential phone rates by as much as 11 percent, citing decline in long-distance consumer revenue (M)

headline: CORNING SAYS IT PLANS TO CUT 1,000 ADDITIONAL JOBS
abstract: Corning, fiber optics maker, will eliminate 1,000 jobs on top of 3,300 already planned in recent weeks; reports first-quarter net profit of $132 million, up 71 percent from $77 million in year-earlier quarter; sales rose 42 percent, to $1.92 billion from $1.35 billion (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Alternative-Fuel Program Fails to Reach Its Goals  A report by the Bush administration recommends continuing federal incentives for ethanol-fueled vehicles. But it does so despite finding that the program has failed to live up to both of its goals: reducing gasoline consumption and increasing the use of alternative fuels.    By building dual-fuel vehicles, automakers receive credits that allow them to lower the average gas mileage of all other vehicles in their fleets. That has allowed them to sell more gas-guzzling sport utility vehicles. [Page A1.]

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Kosovo: Some Guns Handed In
abstract: United Nations police say that Kosovo residents have turned in hundreds of weapons during monthlong amnesty ahead of tough gun laws in province (S)

headline: ALLIED-WASTE, A TRASH HAULER, TO ACQUIRE STAR SERVICES
abstract: Allied-Waste Industries, leading trash hauler, will acquire Star Services Group for $34 million in cash and assume long-term debt (S)

headline: Technology Shares Are Hit as Investors Turn Cautious
abstract: Nadaq composite index falls 104.09 points, to 2,059.32; Dow Jones industrial average declines 47.62 points, to 10,532.23; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops 18.62 points, to 1,224.36; graph; chart (M)

abstract: Tension in Macedonia's capital eases, even as Pres Boris Trajkovski warns of civil war, and NATO defends its role in face of angry charges of aiding Albanian rebels; photo; Rear Adm Craig R Quigley describes incident with Slavs who confronted convoy transporting Albanian rebels as part of cease-fire agreement aimed at moving battle away from Skopje (M)

headline: Argentines Sell Short-Term Debt at a High Cost

abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission, responding to outpouring of complaints, issues alert to investors not to rely solely on stock analysts' reports when they make decisions about buying and selling stock; says alert is needed because investors might not fully understand many roles that analysts can play at their firms and inherent conflicts in those activities; Rep Richard Baker, chairman of recent Congressional hearings on analysts' conflicts, applauds SEC alert (M)

abstract: Avaya, leading maker of corporate phone equipment, lays off 220 workers at cable plant in Omaha, Neb (S)

headline: Looking for Fuel Bargains? Boot Up Before Gassing Up
abstract: People who drive 20 miles out of their way to save a penny on a tank of unleaded may now save a trip by visiting www.gaspricewatch.com. That Web site tells users where the cheapest gasoline is within a 20-mile radius of any ZIP code.

headline: Europe Opens Door for G.E., Just Slightly
abstract: European Commission indicates that it would entertain offers of more concessions by General Electric to win approval of its planned takeover of Honeywell International; signs of US political pressure abound, and renewed US-European trade tensions are feared (M)

abstract: Indonesian Pres Abdurrahman Wahid, on visit to Philippines, denies repa

headline: Layoffs Pushed Jobless Rate to 4.5 Percent Last Month
abstract: The country's unemployment rate climbed to 4.5 percent last month, following the elimination of 223,000 more jobs from American business payrolls, the Labor Department announced today.

headline: 223,000 JOBS LOST
abstract: Labor Department reports April jobless rate of 4.5 percent, with loss of 223,000 jobs, largest one-month decline since Feb 1991 during recession; job cutbacks appear to have spread from manufacturing and temporary employment to vast service sector as well; graphs; report seems assured to lead to another half-point cut in interest rates later in month (M)

headline: ART TECHNOLOGY CUTS STAFF
abstract: Art Technology Group, which makes software that helps run e-commerce sites, says it has laid off 150 workers, or 12 percent of its work force, to reduce costs (S)

headline: S.E.C. Says Dunlap Directed Accounting Fraud at Sunbeam
abstract: Albert J. Dunlap, the former chief executive of the Sunbeam Corporation, directed a huge accounting fraud, the Securities and Exchange Commission charged today

headline: Waiting for the Organizing Fairy To Wave Away the Office Clutter
abstract: Lisa Belkin column on consulting professional organizer to help her improve home office that had fallen into disarray; drawing (M)

headline: Sharon's Family 'Diplomat' Annoys Some Israelis
abstract: Omri Sharon, 36, described by his father as sensitive soul in 'large and overgrown' wrapper, is also Prime Min Ariel Sharon's housemate, closest confidant and emissary to Yasir Arafat; role annoys some Israelis, although few unlikely defenders say it is better Sharon dispatch his son than to have no envoy to Palestinians at all; Israeli High Court will hear petition to bar Omri from such missions, and Atty Gen Elyakim Rubinstein has sharply rebuked prime minister (M)

headline: Boeing and Russia to Study Making Planes
abstract: As Russia moves to consolidate its foundering aircraft industry, the Boeing Company and Russian government officials said today that they had agreed to study joint development of regional commercial jets to be built in Russia and sold here and abroad.    Russia's aviation industry plunged deep into recession in the early 1990's when government orders for military and civil aircraft evaporated. The manufacturing sector is clogged with dozens of money-losing companies, while domestic commercial aviation, once dominated by a single state monolith, Aeroflot, has atomized into some 200 airlines. Many of those lines are small, cash-short regional operators with little ability to replace aging planes, many of them Soviet-era craft nearing the ends of their intended working lives.

headline: Biggest Drop In Prices Of Imports Since 1992
abstract: Labor Department says prices of goods imported into US fell 1.6 percent in March, biggest drop since December 1992, after 0.6 percent decline in February; prices excluding oil fell 0.9 percent after 0.8 percent decline (S)

headline: Putin Urges Bush Not to Act Alone on Missile Shield
abstract: BRDO PRI KRANJU, Slovenia, June 16 â€” Russian President Vladimir V. Putin cautioned President Bush today about developing a missile defense shield without Moscow's consent, telling Mr. Bush that such an action could seriously strain relations between the two countries.

headline: Warring Windsors (Cont'd): Charles Mad at Dad
abstract: Two British newspapers that are most ardent champions of monarchy, Daily Telegraph and Daily Mail, print articles on strained relationship between Prince Philip and his son, Prince Charles; Telegraph articles quote friends of Philip who say he regards his son as delicate, wasteful and unlikely to be effective king; Mail reports that Charles is 'sad and upset' that his father allowed confidants to speak to media about their difficult relationship and may abandon effort to write filial tribute for Philip's 80th birthday next month; photo (M)

headline: Italy Arrests 5 North Africans Suspected of Bin Laden Ties
abstract: ROME, April 5 - Saying they had struck a ``nerve center'' of Islamic terrorism in Europe, Italian officials announced the arrest today of five North African men suspected of having ties to the Saudi exile Osama bin Laden. They added that they were searching for five others.

headline: Ethnic Albanians Flee Drive By Macedonia Against Rebels
abstract: Thousands of ethnic Albanians lagers fled on foot this week from a government offensive against rebels in the northern hills, and an additional 1,000 followed today as the bombardment continued.    Dirty and disheveled and with shock visible in their faces after the three-week assault, the refugees huddled against driving rain as the police loaded busloads of women and children and kept the men back for screening.

headline: Webdenda: Executive Changes in the Media Industry
abstract: Scott Allison, general manager at the San Francisco office of Connors Communications, a public relations agency, was promoted to the new post of president.

headline: Yugoslav Chief Says Milosevic Shouldn't Be Sent to Hague
abstract: Interview with Yugoslav Pres Vojislav Kostunica, who says former Pres Slobodan Milosevic should not be extradited to The Hague to face war-crimes charges, even if US again threatens to withhold foreign aid; says Milosevic's extradition should never happen; accuses war crimes tribunal of being political, practicing selective justice, following shaky rules of law and of being biased against Serbia; says Yugoslavia will investigate war crimes and help The Hague to do so; says Milosevic should be brought to trial for war crimes, but before domestic court; photo (M)

headline: British-Australian Deal Is Seen in Industrial Services
abstract: GKN, large British engineering firm, has agreed to merge its industrial services division with Australia's Brambles Industries; merger will produce company with market value of about $10 billion; Brambles shareholders will own 57 percent of new group, which will keep Brambles name; GKN's chief executive Sir C K Chow will head combined firm, which will be based in Sydney; Brambles chief executive John Fletcher will resign (M)

headline: Jerusalem Journal; Women Seize Counseling Role on 'Family Purity'
abstract: Jerusalem Journal on counseling of Orthodox Jewish women with intimate marital problems; Tova Ganzel is one of eight women who have taken 1,000 hours of training and been certified to advise through help line that gets calls from women in Israel, US and other countries; legal adviser Dr Deena Zimmerman explains program (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: SARA LEE CORP., Chicago, the maker of Jimmy Dean meats, has awarded ICG Commerce, Wayne, Pa., a unit of the Internet Capital Group Inc., an electronic-procurement contract for purchases worth up to $800 million over 18 months.    CALLAWAY GOLF CO., Carlsbad, Calif., the maker of Big Bertha golf clubs, said it was licensing its name to Ashworth Inc., also of Carlsbad, a maker of sportswear. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Goldman Shifting 2 Executives to Lead Investment Management
abstract: Goldman Sachs Group names Philip Murphy and Peter Kraus, co-heads of its private wealth management unit, to succeed John P McNulty who retires as head of investment management division (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Aer Lingus Appointment
abstract: Aer Lingus names John O'Donovan to serve as chief executive until replacement can be found for Michael Foley, who was dismissed (S)

headline: Wrong Place, Wrong Time
abstract: Travails of Rodney Adler, who was on corporate boards of Australia's HIH Insurance Ltd and One.Tel Ltd, both companies that have become insolvent, illustrate larger issue in Australia where companies tend to draw their directors from narrow, clubby pool of people who tend to travel in same circles and, critics say, generally avoid rocking one another's boat; overlapping directors among several companies tends to be high in Australia beause Australian industry is more concentrated; Australian newspapers turned Adler into symbol of arrogance when they ran photos of him vacationing in May while his lawyers defended his actions as director of HIH; Adler's involvement in HIH and One.Tel Ltd detailed; photo (M)

headline: Article 2001061992131186880 -- No Title
Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Drop at Samsung Electronics Is Not as Steep as Expected
abstract: Samsung Electronics says it earned 1.24 trillion won ($944.5 million) in first quarter of 2001, down 22 percent in won terms or, because of won's recent weakening, down 36 percent in dollar terms from first quarter 2000; sales rose in quarter to 8.6 trillion won ($6.55 billion), 10.2 percent rise in won terms from year earlier but decline in dollar terms (S)

headline: 5-Nation Pact Is Step Toward 'Open Skies'
abstract: SINGAPOREâ€”  The United States and four other Pacific rim nations say that they have broken significant new ground by concluding the first multilateral accord to liberalize air transport based on "open skies" principles.

headline: Corrections
abstract: An article last Sunday about E. Floyd Kvamme, a Silicon Valley venture capitalist recently appointed as co-chairman of the President's Council of Advisors on Science and Technology, misstated the career path of Robert Noyce, who once worked with Mr. Kvamme at Fairchild Semiconductor. Mr. Noyce left Fairchild in 1968 to be a founder of Intel; he did not go to National Semiconductor with Mr. Kvamme in 1967.    The article also misstated the year in which National Semiconductor appointed Mr. Kvamme as president of its computer division. It was 1979, not 1972.    The article referred incorrectly to an acquisition made by National Semiconductor in 1979. It acquired the computer systems division of the Itel Corporation, not the entire company.

headline: Article 2001052691961162840 -- No Title
Daimler Rebuffs Kerkorian's Suit in Chrysler Deal
abstract: Daimler-Chrysler AG files motion to dismiss lawsuit by Kirk Kerkorian over way in which Chrysler Corp became German-run subsidiary; argues that it provided ample warning in merger's proxy statement that Chrysler would become Daimler subsidiary and had made no binding commitments on who would run unit; Kerkorian contends combination of Chrysler and Daimler-Benz in May 1998 was presented by Daimler as merger of equals, but was really plan to turn Chrysler into little more than Daimler division (M)

headline: ATLAS AIR WILL CUT 200 JOBS AND TAKE A CHARGE
abstract: Atlas Air Worldwide Holdings to cut 200 ground-crew jobs and idle up to six aircraft at its air-freight unit; expects to miss earnings forecasts; will take second-quarter charge of up to $50 million (S)

headline: CALPERS WILL INVEST $122 MILLION IN SPORTS BUSINESSES
abstract: California Public Employees' Retirement System agrees to pay $122 million to J P Morgan Chase for 15 percent stake in Sports Capital Partners LP, which is partly owned by IMG, sports marketing firm that represents athletes Tiger Woods and Wayne Gretzky (S)

headline: Court Halts Book Based on 'Gone With the Wind'
abstract: A Federal District Court in Atlanta granted an injunction yesterday blocking the imminent publication of ''The Wind Done Gone,'' concluding that its author, Alice Randall, plagiarized from Margaret Mitchell's Civil War epic, ''Gone With the Wind.''     Ms. Randall set part of her novel on the plantation described in Ms. Mitchell's book and told the story from the perspective of a slave who was the half-sister of Ms. Mitchell's leading character, Scarlett O'Hara, and the daughter of Ms. Mitchell's character Mammy.

headline: Macedonia Expands Attacks Against Rebels
abstract: Macedonian government intensifies its attacks against ethnic Albanian rebels, despite rebel offer of cease-fire; Prime Min Ljubco Georgievski, under intense international and local pressure, withdraws his call for declaration of state of war; Pres Boris Trajkovski says he is preparing peace plan to present to Parliament that would offer partial amnesty to rebel fighters; Macedonian Slav members of government are at odds over how to deal with growing insurgency, with Georgievski wanting to crush rebels by military means and others heeding Western admonitions to offer political concessions to persuade rebels to disarm and withdraw; photos (M)

headline: Angry Beijing Denounces Washington's Reports That Its Pilot Caused the Collision
abstract: The Chinese government today angrily described as ''irresponsible'' the statements by senior American officials that a Chinese fighter jet, and not an American spy plane, caused the mid-air collision on April 1.    A spokeswoman for the Foreign Ministry, Zhang Qiyue, said American officials continued to ''confuse right and wrong and even falsely accuse the Chinese side.'' She warned of ''further damages'' to Chinese-American relations, according to the New China News Agency.

headline: A Humbling Tour of Entry-Level America
abstract: Diana B Henriques reviews Barbara Ehrenreich's book, Nickel and Dimed, journal of her first-hand experience as an unskilled laborer; photos (M)

headline: Japan Plan On Wireless To Be Delayed
abstract: NTT DoCoMo will delay plans for full commercial introduction of its next-generation wireless service, dealing setback to mobile communications industry; graph (M)

headline: A Comedian Gets Serious
abstract: Rosie, new magazine published by Rosie O'Donnell's KidRo Productions and Gruner & Jahr, focuses on pits and crags of American woman's life, giving extensive space to emotionally charged issues; will be sent to 3.6 million subscribers of McCall's, which Gruner & Jahr folded to make way for Rosie; photos (M)

headline: TRAVIS STREET INCREASES BID FOR ICO TO $70.3 MILLION
abstract: Travis Street Partners raises its hostile bid for Houston oil services company ICO Inc to about $70.3 million to top offer from company's management (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip-Equipment Sales Seen Falling
abstract: Semiconductor Equipment and Materials International says shipments of chip-making equipment, measure of demand for computer products, are expected to decline 27 percent this year, sharp drop from 87 percent growth last year; predicts worldwide shipments will drop to $35 billion in 2001, from $47.7 billion in 2000 (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Accusations Of Forced Labor
abstract: Two leading human rights groups contend Myanmar's military government continues to employ forced labor in practice that was recently condemned by ILO (S)

headline: Earnings Fall 21% at Merrill Lynch, Close to Estimates
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co reports 21 percent drop in net income for last quarter and says it will have trouble meeting expectations this quarter if market conditions do not improve; firm earned $874 million in quarter ended March 30, down from $1.10 billion in year-earlier period (M)

headline: DEBT RATING OF UNITED AIRLINES IS REDUCED BY MOODY'S
abstract: United Airlines' senior unsecured debt is lowered to junk status by Moody's Investors Service, part of downgrade affecting $12.9 billion in debt securities for company, operating unit of UAL Corp (S)

headline: Part Time, and Proud of It
abstract: Paula L Green My Money, My Life column on her successful transition from working full time to part time; cartoon (M)

headline: I.B.M. Enhances Liquid Crystal Display Process
abstract: Team of researchers at IBM perfects significant improvement in process used to align liquid crystals that form displays in laptop computers and increasingly in desktop machines; new system employs ion beam gun to deposit ultrathin layer of carbon, whose molecules form in such way that liquid crystals align themselves when they are deposited on carbon layer, or substrate (M)

headline: Kofi Annan: An Idealist Who Took the Heat, Shook Up the U.N. and Keeps Top Post
abstract: Profile of Kofi Annan, Ghanaian who has been named to second term, by acclamation, as United Nations Secretary General; photo (L)

headline: Mubarak Urges Strong U.S. Role on Mideast
abstract: Pres Hosni Mubarak of Egypt meets with Pres Bush at White House and urges him to increase US involvement in Middle East; Bush defends policy of allowing Israelis and Palestinians to take initiative in seeking peace; Mubarak is first Arab head of state to visit with Bush; photo (S)

abstract: Cyber Law Journal: Questioning Continues in Copyright Suit

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Banking In China
abstract: Taiwan government will allow Taiwanese banks to open representative offices in China, move that has been resisted because of fear that growing economic ties between political rivals could leave Taiwan beholden to mainland China (S)

abstract: Shawne Fielding, forÃ¿

headline: SOUTH KOREA: SAMSUNG'S PROFIT SLIPS
abstract: Samsung Group had pretax profit of $2.06 billion for first quarter, 3.6 percent less than first quarter of 2000; total sales were $23.7 billion, increase of 3.6 percent (S)

headline: THE BOSS; I'm Always Up for a Face-Off
abstract: Sun Microsystems Corp chief executive, Scott McNealy, writes The Boss column on his life and career; photo (M)

headline: Reality TV Goes Back To Basic
abstract: Fox reality series Boot Camp outperforms expectations, spurring support among programmers for reality shows that do not push boundaries of taste; show is being embraced by advertisers; Fox weighs ordering added episode, beyond eight scheduled so far (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: DYNEGY CORP., Houston, a power and natural-gas trader, said it planned to buy back as much as $250 million, or 6 million shares, of common stock.

headline: Investing; Just Who Brought Those Duds To Market?
abstract: WHEN the stock market closed on Nov. 12, 1998, the corridors of the Bear, Stearns offices on Park Avenue rang out with triumphant cheers and applause. The investment bank had made a big score: the initial public offering of theglobe.com, which it had underwritten after several rival investment banks refused the deal, had just achieved a record-breaking 606 percent gain on its first day of trading.    ''I was getting a lot of applause for getting us into the game,'' recalled Scott Ehrens, who at the time was  an Internet analyst at Bear, Stearns.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Deaths Linked To Tainted Water
abstract: Health officials in Canada say contamination of water system in North Batteford, Saskatchewan, may have caused deaths of 3 people and illness of 100; commission is investigating Canada's drinking water supplies and qualifications of officials who run local water systems (S)

headline: STRIDE RITE HIRES AN AGENCY TO MANAGE ITS BRANDS
abstract: Stride Rite Corp hires Beanstalk Group licensing agency to help company expand its namesake brand beyond children's shoes (S)

headline: Harper's Bazaar Editor Ousted; Hearst Names Her Successor
abstract: Kate Betts, the successor to the celebrated editor in chief of Harper's Bazaar, Liz Tilberis, was asked to resign this afternoon, a full year before her three-year contract is due to expire, executives at Hearst Magazines said.

headline: Module Lineup Gives A Little Organizer Big Ambitions
abstract: Wide range of modules available for use with Handspring's Visor organizer assessed; most are made by company's licensed developer partners; photos (M)

headline: Taliban's Eradication of Poppies Is Convulsing Opium Market
abstract: Unexpected success of Taliban in Afghanistan in eradicating three-quarters of world's crop of opium poppies in one season raises questions about where production is likely to spring up next; UN expert Pino Arlacchi, noting sharp rises in heroin and opium prices, says officials are looking at Myanmar, Pakistan and Central Asia (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Arrests In Chechnya Killings
abstract: Nineteen Russian soldiers are arrested for suspected murder of several civilians in Chechnya; Chechens and human rights groups have accused Russian military of widespread abuses during war with rebels (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Chad: Opposition Leaders Released
abstract: Chad releases six opposition candidates who had charged Pres Idriss Deby with stealing recent election (S)

headline: Economy Flagging? Don't Tell the Publicists
abstract: Public relations industry has its best year ever in 2000; US revenues were up 33 percent, to nearly $3.4 billion; rise worldwide was 34 percent, to $4.6 billion; world's largest public relations firm was Fleishman-Hillard, with revenue of $342.84 million in 2000 (M)

headline: Two Sides of PowerPoint
abstract: Brian P Gatens letter responds to May 31 article about use of PowerPoint computer program among K - 12 students

headline: Technology Briefing | People: Former Lucent Scientists To Stand Trial
abstract: Hai Lin and Kai Xu, scientists dismissed from Lucent Technologies, and business partner, Yong-Qing Cheng, are tentatively scheduled to stand trial in January 2002 on federal charges that they collaborated to pass Lucent secrets to company owned by Chinese government, Datang Telecom Technologies Ltd (S)

headline: My First PC
abstract: John Markoff article recalls his first personal computer, IBM PC5150, purchased in October 1981; says IBM's entrance into PC market a few months earlier signaled that nature and potential of computing had changed; table compares capabilities of similarly-priced computers, then and now; photo (M)

headline: THE HOSTAGE BUSINESS: A Special Report; Kidnapping With Money as the Only Object
abstract: Kidnapping of 10 oil-field workers in Ecuador on Oct 12, 2000, offers case study of what not to do when kidnappers seize workers for sole purpose of extracting money from their employers; kidnappers demanded $80 million from Ehlmerich & Payne Inc, Erickson Air-Crane and Schlumberger, but companies gambled with low bid of $500,000 only to start frantically raising it after kidnappers killed a hostage, Ronald Sander; seven workers -- two of the original 10 having escaped on their own -- were freed for $13 million 141 days after being seized; families feel betrayed by companies they trusted; some of survivors are still struggling with deep emotional tremors; Colombian government has arrested 52 people suspected of playing role in this kidnapping as well as others reaching back several years; kidnapping for money, not for ideological or political goal, has become one of biggest overseas worries for American corporations; photos; map (L)

headline: New Effort At Curbing Tobacco Ads In Europe
abstract: European Commission proposes new restrictions on tobacco advertising, seven months after court overturned previous ban (M)

headline: A Royal Blossoming Brings Joy in Japan
abstract: Photo of Japan's Crown Prince Naruhito and Crown Princess Masako after Imperial Palace isues statement that says princess is possibly pregnant

headline: CHEMICAL COMPANY TO LAY OFF UP TO 1,260 PEOPLE
abstract: Rohm & Haas Co will lay off as many as 1,260 employees to cut costs and make company more competitive (S)

headline: Have Black Bag, Will Travel
abstract: Dr David McKenas comments on American Airlines program he oversees that provides on-board nurse to patients who require one; photos (M)

headline: Q&A / Pavol Hamzik : Bratislava Goal:Fast Track Into EU
abstract: Until 1998, Slovakia was generally considered to have little chance of joining the European Union in the first wave of expansion. The statist, pro-Russian trade policies of the prime minister at the time, Vladimir Meciar, suggested that Slovakia would have to watch while its erstwhile federal partner, the Czech Republic, together with Hungary and Poland, took their seats at Brussels.

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Kabila Meets U.N. Delegation
abstract: President Joseph Kabila told visiting members of the United Nations Security Council that negotiations, not further fighting, would end the nearly three-year war in his country. But he reportedly emphasized that a peace accord backed by the United Nations could not be carried out unless troops from Rwanda, Uganda and Burundi left Congo.      Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

headline: A Battery Recharges The Remote Road Warrior
abstract: Electric Fuel Corp introduces Instant Power Charger; device is used to recharge cellular telephone batteries; it derives its power from common disposable batteries; photo (M)

headline: Russian Reiterates Stand in Favor of ABM Pact
abstract: Russian Defense Min Sergei B Ivanov says Russia continues to view Antiballistic Missile Treaty as foundation for modern arms control and sees no reason to amend it, as American officials have urged; Pres Bush is scheduled to discuss missile defense and ABM treaty with Pres Vladimir V Putin next week; Ivanov says he will visit Washington at Defense Sec Donald Rumsfeld's request to continue talks (M)

headline: For E-Mail On the Go, Or the Sly
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column on so-called e-mail pager, which have built-in keyboard that allows user to send as well as receive text messages; comments on products from Research in Motion Ltd and Motorola products; photo (M)

headline: The Romance of the Early PC
abstract: Letter from Arnold Wengrow responds to May 10 'My First PC' article

headline: A Test for the Parents
abstract: When it comes to understanding financial matters, many young people turn to their parents for guidance. But a recent survey shows that many adults, who may think they are experts, have a thing or two to learn themselves about managing money.    In the nationwide survey, conducted by the American Savings Education Council and the Employee Benefit Research Institute, 51 percent of 1,000 parents said they understood financial matters very well. Asked how they managed their money, 57 percent said they did a good job and 25 percent an excellent job.

headline: Private Sector; Dollars to Doughnuts on Wall Street
abstract: Krispy Kreme Doughnuts Inc will give away 40,000 'hot original glazed' doughnuts outside New York Stock Exchange when it stock begins trading there, moving from Nasdaq; photo (S)

headline: Article 2001041492689550931 -- No Title
abstract: Teenage Overload, or Digital  Dexterity?

headline: U.N. Assembly Votes to Condemn Attacks on Religious Sites
abstract: General Assembly votes to condemn all attacks on religious sites, and calls on governments and international organizations to take responsibility for protection of religious and cultural treasures; resolution follows ransacking of mosques and churches in Balkans and destruction of giant Buddhas in Afghanistan (S)

headline: Ship Planning to Offer Abortions Makes Waves, but Hits Shoal, at Irish Port
abstract: Women on Waves, which has outfitted trawler as clinic that was to perform abortions in offshore Irish waters, will only be able to provide counseling and contraception services because it lacks Dutch and Irish licenses, one for operating medical facility and other for carrying passengers to sea; Dr Rebecca Gomperts comments (S)

headline: Europe Shifts Tactics on Proposed E-Commerce Rules
abstract: European Commission officials have shifted tactics on proposed law governing cross-border Internet commerce in Europe, and are trying to sidestep opposition by enacting it using fast-track procedure with almost no public debate; proposal, known in Brussels shorthand as Rome II, began life as 'green paper,' or preliminary draft placed on commission's agenda in February for formal discussion; Rome II drew criticism from corporations, lawyers and Internet experts, who argued that it could smother e-commerce under legal obligations; 'green paper' has been removed from agenda (M)

headline: Article 2001052893567141101 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Genuity Loss Widens
abstract: Genuity Inc reports first-quarter loss of $292.4 million; sales rose 21 percent, to $299.5 million; lowers its 2001 sales forecast by as much as 18 percent; is eliminating 800 jobs, or 12 percent of its work force; graph (S)

headline: E-Commerce Report; A reservation site owned by the airlines has raised competitive concerns in the travel industry.
abstract: Orbitz, airline-owned travel Web site that recently began selling tickets in advance of its official June rollout is raising competitive concerns in travel industry; consumer advocates fear five founding airlines, Delta, United, Northwest, Continental and American Airlines, will abuse system that could give them more control over pricing and distribution; Orbitz has agreements to also sell tickets of 35 other airlines; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing/EUROPE: GREECE: PATRIARCH NOT WELCOME
abstract: Greek Orthodox church leaders, who have led protests against Pope John Paul II's visit to Athens on Friday, have pressed the Vatican not to include in the papal entourage Cardinal Ignace Moussa Daoud, who is the church's official in charge of relations with the Eastern Churches and is the Patriarch of the Syrian Catholic Church. The Syrian church follows Eastern rites but is loyal to Rome. Cardinal Daoud is expected to rejoin the pope in Syria on Saturday.   Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

headline: W. N. Jayme, 75, Wordsmith Known for Magazine Mailings
abstract: w n jayme, 75,

headline: Itching to Escape The Land of SGX374
abstract: Michelle Slatalla column on shopping online with program called Copernic Shopper Plus; photo (M)

headline: London Journal; If Iraq Ever Needs a King, Here's a Dapper Hopeful
abstract: Interview with Sharif Ali bin al-Hussein, who aspires to become king of Iraq, taking throne vacant or nonexistent since 1958, when Hahsemite forbears were shot to death in military led-coup; he left Iraq at age of two following coup; lives in exile in London; photo (M)

headline: RUMSFELD SEEKING AN ARMS STRATEGY USING OUTER SPACE
abstract: Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld will propose sweeping overhaul of Pentagon's space programs, sharply increasing importance of outer space in strategic planning; proposal will be first step toward making space focus of Pentagon spending, and is intended to emphasize importance Bush administration places on developing weapon systems for outer space; Rumsfeld wants to establish new Pentagon post for four-star Air Force general to serve as advocate for what could become new space force; Rumsfeld has expressed interest in developing costly and complicated space weapons systems, including lasers capable of shooting down ballistic missiles and satellites designed to attack other satellites; any efforts to build such weapons would be opposed by China, Russia and European nations, and by arms control advocates; space programs currently represent only $8 billion of Pentagon's $310 billion annual budget (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Sony And Universal Rename Music Service
abstract: Sony Music Entertainment and Universal Music Group rename their online subscription service Pressplay, and say they plan to start it in late summer, even as questions linger about just how harmonious relationship between record labels is shaping up to be (S)

headline: Warming Threat Requires Action Now, Scientists Say
abstract: Scientists and experts on risk management agree with assertion by Pres Bush that much remains to be learned about potential impact of global warming, but take issue with idea that uncertainty justifies further delay in acting to limit climate change; say question of how much warming is too much constitutes 'red herring,' and that it is more important to start from point of widest agreement, namely: that rising concentrations of heat-trapping gases are warming atmosphere, and that adding lot more is probably bad idea (M)

headline: Markets Rally on Hopes for Higher Corporate Earnings
abstract: Nasdaq composite index gains 50.72 points, or 2.44 percent, to close at 2,125.46; Dow Jones industrial average rises 131.37 points or 1.26 percent, to 10,566.21; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 15.13 points, or 1.25 percent, to 1,226.20; graph; chart (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Chief Financial Officer Is Dismissed at Lucent  Lucent Technologies, the troubled maker of communications equipment, dismissed its chief financial officer, Deborah C. Hopkins, in an effort to revamp the company's leadership.    Ms. Hopkins, who had been chief financial officer for a little more than a year, will be succeeded by Frank D'Amelio, president of Lucent's switching solutions group. The departure of Ms. Hopkins comes after nearly a year of turmoil at Lucent, which is trying to raise cash by selling parts of its business and is restructuring after large losses. [Page C2.]

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: Absolved Of U.N. Deaths
abstract: Fuad Hussein Haidar, gunman who attacked Baghdad office of United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization in 2000, is absolved of guilt for slaying of deputy director and computer expert, but sentenced to 10 years in prison for attempted killing of Iraqi guards outside building; said he wanted to avenge deaths of Iraqis who perished under UN sanctions (S)

headline: Wary Spending By Companies Cools Economy
abstract: Corporations rather than consumers are most influencing latest business cycles, and are proving much less responsive to Federal Reserve's rate cuts; spent heavily on tools of production in 1990's with promise of rising profits but have reduced business investment in face of overcapacity; new trend suggests nature of business cycle may have again changed, from one in which economy responds primarily to consumers by expanding and contracting in step with their spending to one more like those in first half of 20th century, in which capital spending was determining factor; economists say getting executives to spend again on machinery and equipment they do not need is far harder than getting consumers to step up spending on extras; graphs (M)

headline: Beijing Steps Up Its War of Words Over Air Collision
abstract: BEIJING, April 4 â€” China hardened its position today on the midair collision of an American spy plane and a Chinese jet, with President Jiang Zemin personally insisting that China receive an official apology and the country's foreign minister accusing the United States of being wrong-headed and "arrogant."

headline: INFO-QUEST REDUCES STAKE IN AREMISSOFT TO 14%
abstract: Info-Quest SA cuts stake in AremisSoft Corp to about 14 percent (S)

headline: A Trail of Misery as Macedonia Fights Albanian Insurgency
abstract: Noon deadline passes for ethnic Albanian rebels to withdraw from mountain villages along Macedonia's northern border, and government says it is suspending its threatened offensive in interests of peace; government is bowing to international pressure to refrain from assault on villages where thousands of civilians remain holed up in cellars; photo; map (M)

headline: Philips Will Quit Making Mobile Telephones
abstract: Royal Philips Electronics will abandon handset-making business completely, except for minority stake in Chinese joint venture; will eliminate 1,230 jobs at factory in Le Mans, France, and transfer control of its research and development unit and its factory in Shenzhen, China, to China Electronics Corp, its joint venture partner there (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Central Asia: Force To Fight Muslim Rebels
abstract: In a further sign of Russia's deepening military involvement in former Soviet republics, Russia and three Central Asian nations agreed to establish a rapid-reaction force to combat Islamic insurgency in the region. Meeting in Armenia, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and his counterparts from Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan agreed on a joint force to be based in Kyrgyzstan's capital, Bishkek.   Douglas Frantz (NYT)

headline: F.T.C. Accuses Drug Makers Of Collusion to Delay Generics
