abstract: Federal Trade Commission accuses Schering-Plough Corp of paying $90 million to American Home Products and Upsher-Smith Laboratories to delay sales of alternatives to Schering's K-Dur 20 potassium-chloride supplement; says Aventis and Andrx Corp settled charges that Aventis paid Andrx $90 million to delay release of generic version of Cardizem CD, Aventis's most popular heart medication (M)

headline: Spain Court Refuses to Extradite Man G.M. Says Took Its Secrets
abstract: Spanish High Court refuses to extradite Jose Ignacio Lopez de Arriortua to Detroit to face charges he misappropriated trade secrets when he left senior GM post in 1992 to join Volkswagen; rules charges are not serious enough to justify move; scores US for seeking extradition so long after events involved in 1999 indictment; notes GM and Volkswagen have long since reached civil settlement and that Lopez's memory was marred by 1998 auto accident that left him in coma for months; Lopez hails decision (M)

headline: NEW CHIEF AT SWITCH MAKER
abstract: OMM Inc., a San Diego manufacturer of optical communications gear, said Hus Tigli, its president and chief executive for the last 14 months, had been replaced by Philip Chapman, OMM's chief financial officer, effective immediately. Mr. Chapman, left, who is 47, declined to explain the abrupt transition. He said it would not affect the business plans of OMM, which is a pioneer designer of light-wave switches consisting of arrays of tiny adjustable mirrors.   Barnaby J. Feder

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: JB OXFORD HOLDINGS INC.,  Los Angeles, said it agreed to buy Bull & Bear Securities, New York, a Royal Bank of Canada subsidiary, for an undisclosed amount of cash to expand its brokerage business.    NETWORK PERIPHERALS INC.,  Fremont, Calif., a maker of computer-networking products, said it bought a $25 million stake and acquired an option to merge with the closely held FalconStor Software Inc., Melville, N.Y., a maker of network-storage software. The option to merge with FalconStor may be exercised during a 14-day period expected to begin during the last week of this month.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Corruption Fighter Quits Government
abstract: Turkey's Interior Min Saadetin Tantan, widely viewed as leader of country's anticorruption drive, resigns from cabinet and Motherland Party rather than accept lower-ranking position; photo (S)

headline: Riots Break Out as Nepal Gets 3rd King in 4 Days
abstract: Rioting erupts in Katmandu, Nepal, hours after enthronement of King Gyanendra, third monarch in four days; government imposes curfew; protestors hurl rocks and accusations and demand truth about slaying of nearly entire royal family; enthronement follows death from gunshot wounds of King Dipendra, son of King Birendra and Queen Aiswarya, who is suspected of slaying them along with brothers, sisters and uncle in royal palace before turning weapon on himself in reported disagreement with parents over his choice of bride; some protestors openly blame Gyanendra, who described killings as accident--explanation that is considered preposterous by many; he has promised full public disclosure following investigation; photos (M)

headline: In Bush's Words: 'Substantial Advantages of Intercepting Missiles Early'
abstract: Excerpt from Pres Bush's speech on international military policy, including proposed missile defense system (M)

headline: Rowling's Readers Are Ready for Film
abstract: NPD Group plans series of surveys tracking popularity of J K Roling's Harry Potter book series and related products; finds at least 60 percent of American children 6-17 have read at least one of four books in series; graphs; photo (S)

headline: Big Jump in Trade Gap in March May Be Sign of Slower Economy
abstract: US trade deficit rises 16 percent in March, to $13.17 billion, perhaps signaling slowdown of US economy (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Tire Venture
abstract: Japan's Yokohama Rubber Co will form 50-50 joint venture with Continental of Germany to sell tires to Japanese automakers (S)

headline: For Angolans, U.N. Suggests Timid Return To the Farms
abstract: United Nations World Food Program takes tentative steps to revive farming in Angola in hopes of preparing for return to countryside, which has been largely depopulated by fighting over last 26 years; now feeds more than a million Angolans encamped in and around cities like Kuito, and its resources are becoming exhausted; government's gains have altered dynamics of war, dislodging rebels from towns and cities and leaving them to wage hit-and-run attacks from the bush (M)

headline: Microsoft Drops Controversial Tagging Feature from Windows XP
abstract: Facing severe criticism and a potential public relations debacle, Microsoft is pulling one of the features from Windows XP. The planned inclusion of "Smart Tags" in both the new operating system due Oct. 25 and in the upcoming browser Internet Explorer 6 has been indefinitely postponed.

headline: Liberty to Buy Some Deutsche Telekom Cable Systems
abstract: Liberty Media Corp, controlled by John C Malone, is acquiring cable TV systems with 10 million subscribers from Deutsche Telekom for about $4.7 billion; Liberty and Klesch & Co, private equity group in London, reach separate agreement that gives Klesch option to buy up to 24.9 percent of Liberty's cable interests (M)

headline: Another Gaza Day, Another Dead Child
abstract: Iman Hijo, 4-month-old baby killed by Israeli tank fire in Gaza Strip, is portrayed by Palestinians as innocent victim of what they contend is Israeli policy of collective punishment; Israeli diplomats and army spokesmen depict child as latest tragic casualty of what they say is deliberate Palestinian guerrilla tactic of firing from dense urban neighborhoods with hope of inviting politically useful military response; many Israeli commentators, most of them military veterans, are skeptical about army's assertion that it responds to attacks with pinpoint bombing; Israeli government is irked that international investigative committee headed by former Sen George J Mitchell has urged Israel to limit itself to use of 'nonlethal force' and to better supervise young draftees under fire (M)

headline: Safety Debate On Baby Seats For Bathtubs
abstract: At least 78 babies have died in infant bath seat since 1983, statistic that has prompted government to consider banning product; about million bath seats are sold each year, most of them by Safety 1st, division of Dorel Industries; some experts suggest that Consumer Product Safety Commission miscalculated danger of bath seats, which may lower, not raise, risk of drowning for children; debate will be fueled at commission hearing next week by Harvard University Assistant Prof Kimberly M Thompson suggesting that bath seats may actually protect children from drowning; long-simmering fight highlights differences between Ann Brown, agency's chairwoman, and Mary Sheila Gall, whom Pres Bush has nominated to lead commission; agency first considered banning seats in 1994, move supported by Brown; but Gall and another commissioner, who is longer on board, successfully opposed ban; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Sri Lanka: Rebels Set Condition For Talks
abstract: As a condition for entering peace talks, rebels of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam have demanded that the government lift a ban on them imposed after the Tigers attacked the Buddhist Temple of the Tooth in 1998. But the state-run newspaper reported that it ''reliably understands'' that the ban will remain in place.     Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

headline: Baltic States Seek Bush's Help in Joining NATO as Political Insurance Against Russia
abstract: Baltic states--Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia--lead list of nine nations seeking to enter NATO alliance in 2002; Soviet leader Vladimir Putin, his top military commanders and most of Russian establishment strongly oppose what would be first NATO advance onto territory of former Soviet Union; Baltic states seek Pres Bush's help in joining NATO as political insurance against Russia; photo; map (L)

headline: I Praise or Pan in the Dark
abstract: Rosalind D Friedman writes My Job column on being theater critic for WMNR Fine Arts Radio in Monroe, Conn; photo (M)

headline: Luke.com if It's a Boy, Mary.com if It's a Girl
abstract: In Silicon Valley, even the stork has gone high-tech. Starting June 1, parents with newborns at Sequoia Hospital in Redwood City, Calif., will get free Web domain names and e- mail addresses for their babies.

headline: U.S. REPORT SHOWS JOB LOSS IN MARCH WAS MOST SINCE '91
abstract: Labor Dept report shows job losses in March were greatest for single month since 1991, leading many economists to say United States is on verge of recession; report shows unemployment rate going up to 4.3 percent from 4.2 percent in Feb and 3.9 percent in Oct; job figures reflect parade of layoffs and hiring freezes since last fall; job losses in March, totaling 86,000 jobs, are mostly in manufacturing; job gains elsewhere are no longer sufficient to offset cutbacks; Labor Dept survey of 365 industries shows increasingly broad array is cutting jobs; not since last recession have cutbacks been so widespread; but there is probabaly just enough strength--or ambiguity--in March jobs report for Federal Reserve's policy makers to resist demands for emergency rate cut ahead of their next scheduled meeting on May 15; graphs (M)

headline: Annan Begins 2nd Term Pledging To Bring U.N. Closer to People
abstract: Kofi Annan swears himself in for second term as secretary general of United Nations after being re-elected by acclamation and applause of 189 member nations; pledges to bring organization closer to people it was created to serve (M)

headline: KOREAN PROBLEMS FOR LERNOUT & HAUSPIE
abstract: The Belgian software company Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products is close to filing for bankruptcy protection for its South Korean division, the chief executive, Philippe Bodson, said. The company also said it planned to sue the former chief executive of L&H Korea, Joo Chul Seo, and four Korean banks -- Hana, Shinhan, Chohung and Hanvit -- or their officials, accusing them of conspiring to overstate sales. Lernout & Hauspie is under bankruptcy protection in the United States and Belgium.   Paul Meller (NYT)

headline: U.N. Spotlights Plunder of Congo by Officials in Nearby Lands
abstract: UNITED NATIONS, April 20 â€” A tough and explicit report this week on the looting of Congo's natural resources by armies involved in Africa's widest war has opened what some diplomats say is a long overdue debate on official profiteering.

headline: FED LOWERS RATES BY QUARTER-POINT IN 6TH CUT OF YEAR
abstract: Federal Reserve cuts benchmark interest rate by quarter of percentage point and signals that its campaign to revive flagging economy may be entering its final stages; this is sixth rate cut by central bank since beginning of year, when economy began slowing precipitously; latest move reduces federal funds target rate on overnight loans among banks to 3.75 percent from 4 percent; analysts expect central bank to cut rates at least once more this year; latest cut brings muted response from investors; graphs (M)

headline: In Mexico, Stocks Rise As Growth Slows
abstract: Kenneth N Gilpin Market Insight column interviews Jose Luis Gomez-Pimienta, manager of Mexico Fund, a mutual fund, about that country's current surging stock market; photo (M)

headline: 2 New Predictions Of Slower Ad Spending
abstract: Zenith Media in London, owned by Cordiant Communications Group and Publicis Group, is revising downward forecast of American advertising spending in 2001 that agency made in December; Zenith is halving predicted growth rate for this year to increase of 2.4 percent--or flat compared with last year, if inflation is factored in; Myers Reports releases results of survey of executives at ad agencies and client companies showing confidence as of March fell 24 percent from December (S)

headline: CENDANT CONFIRMS TALKS TO BUY GALILEO INTERNATIONAL
abstract: Cendant Corp, leading franchiser, is in talks to acquire Galileo International, provider of computer reservations systems to travel agencies (S)

headline: Showdown On Wall Street; Banks Are Getting Business At the Expense of Elite Firms
abstract: Investment banks still get large percentage of fees from debt and equity underwriting, but investment banking arms of commercial banks, notably Citigroup, have made significant inroads into field; J P Morgan Chase vice chairman Marc Shapiro and Merrill Lynch & Co chairman David H Komansky comment; chart; photos (M)

headline: Milosevic Trial: Test on Many Levels
abstract: News analysis of move to bring Slobodan Milosevic before tribunal in The Hague for crimes against humanity; Milosevic is accused of war crimes committed during war in Kosovo, but he could later be indicted in connection with his role in wars in Bosnia and Croatia, and his testimony is likely to embarrass number of Western leaders who negotiated with him and coddled him for much of his rule; one Serb government adviser observes that Milosevic became 'too expensive to keep'; but manner and haste of transfer of Milosevic to Hague will also have significant repercussions for democratic reformers who defeated him in elections last October and arrested him in early April (M)

headline: Bush Will Continue to Oppose Kyoto Pact on Global Warming
abstract: Pres Bush reiterates opposition to 1997 Kyoto protocol on global warming, aimed at reducing reducing emissions of greenhouse gases below 1990 levels, on eve of five day trip to Europe, whose leaders support it; strongly suggests that any new accord bind developing nations, especially China and India, to same commitments made by US; acknowledges severity of problem, but notes accord sets no standards for major emitters of greenhouse gases while creating mandates for US that could prove economically crippling; aides argue that accord was written to make it easier for Europe than for US to meet goals; Bush vows US will lead way by advancing science on climate change; describes several new research initiatives that could mark potentially significant focusing of American climate study; photo (M)

headline: U.S. SAYS SPY CREW WIPED OUT SECRETS IN FRANTIC LANDING
abstract: Senior American officials and diplomats say crew of American spy plane spent 15 furious minutes destroying secret materials before opening hatch and surrendering to Chinese troops that had surrounded their plane, waving guns and shouting at them; it is not clear how much material was destroyed; Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld says crew did major portion of their 'checklist,' indication that loss of American intelligence data and technology may not have been as great as feared; two senior diplomats who played central roles in negotiations to win crew's release reassert United States' position that mid-air collision was caused by reckless flying by pilot of Chinese fighter jet tailing spy plane; Beijing rejects that assertion; American officials have become eager to get out their side of story since crew's release on Apr 12 (M)

headline: Some Conflicts Arise at Hearing On Ford Replacement-Tire Issue
abstract: National Highway Traffic Safety Administration briefs members of House Energy and Commerce Committee on safety of tires that Ford Motor Co is using to replace those made by Bridgestone/Firestone Inc after committee chairman Repr Billy Tauzin says automaker might be using tires with even higher failure rates than Firestones (M)

headline: Addenda: Leadership Changes at Industry Association
abstract: The International Advertising Association in New York has named Walter J. O'Brien Jr. its director general, effective July 1, succeeding Norman Vale, who has held the post since 1990.

headline: Job to Raytheon Venture
abstract: Raytheon Technical Service Co, unit of Raytheon Co and JT3 LLC, in joint venture with JT3 EG&G Technical Services Inc, receives Air Force contract valued at up to $1.7 billion (S)

headline: Chief Executive Leaving Finnish Phone Company
abstract: Kaj-Erik Relander, chief executive of Finland's Sonera, resigns his post to join Accel Partners, venture capital firm in London; Aimo Eloholma will assume Relander's duties while new chief executive is sought (M)

headline: Shares Outlast an Early Sell-Off to Close Little Changed
abstract: Nasdaq composite index closes down 0.8 point, at 2,169.95; Dow Jones industrial average rises 26.29 points, to 10,948.38; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 1.46 point, to 1,255.85; graph; chart (M)

headline: Mexico Grows Parched, With Pollution and Politics
abstract: Poor of Mexico City find clean water is increasingly scarce; Mexican aquifers are becoming polluted and country's system of water treatment has deteriorated severely in recent decades; Mexico's new president, Vincente Fox, has called water 'national security issue'; roughly 12 million people, one out of eight Mexicans, poorest of poor, have no easy access to drinking water at all; those who can afford it have it trucked to their homes; those without money drink what they can find; bad water kills thousands every year; photo; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Finland: Nokia Plans Job Cuts
abstract: Nokia Oy will cut as many as 1,000 jobs at its network unit, as demand for mobile equipment slows (S)

headline: J. P. Morgan Chase Profit Falls 40% on Market Turbulence
abstract: J P Morgan Chase & Co says first-quarter net profit declined to $1.2 billion from $2 billion a year earlier; excluding special items related to Chase merger, operating earnings were $1.4 billion (M)

headline: Bell Labs: A Bit Abstract and Always Curious
abstract: Bell Labs and its parent company, Lucent Technologies, are still considered giants in innovation despite recent management fumbles and business failures (M)

headline: European Media Lash Out at Leading Italian Candidate
abstract: European media bitterly attack Italian presidential candidate Silvio Berlusconi, denouncing media tycoon's business practices and current conflicts of interest; photo (M)

headline: When Weekly Finds Scandal, Beijing Purges Top Editors
abstract: Chinese authorities remove top editors of China's most probing major newspaper, Southern Weekend, in crackdown on its semi-independent reporting; Southern Weekend, owned by Communist Party of Guangzhou, has been pioneer in growing coverage of corruption, police brutality and official misdeeds; it has avoided direct questioning of Communist rule or reporting on sensitive scandals in Beijing until Apr 19, when commentary on notorious criminal suggested that ill treatment by prisons helped create killer (M)

headline: Rumsfeld Calls on Europe To Rethink Arms Control
abstract: US Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld, in first extended trip to Europe for Bush administration, offered detailed thoughts on military strategy, problems with treaties and need for America to project immense power to deter and dissuade enemies; warned of proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and urgent need to act, preferably by scrapping 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty and building antimissile shields; sketched broad outlines of 'strategic framework' with Russia that might replace ABM treaty; said framework should not only include missile defenses, but also provisions to reduce size of nuclear arsenals, as Pres Bush has vowed to do; photo (M)

headline: Article 2001062391439848420 -- No Title
abstract: Game Simulations for the Military Try to Make an Ally of Emotion

headline: Solid April Takes Some of the Sting Out of March Losses
abstract: Nasdaq composite index gains 40.56 points, or 2 percent, to 2,116.24; Dow Jones industrial average falls 75.08 points, or 0.7 percent, to 10,734.97; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 3.59 points, or 0.3 percent, to 1,249.46; graph; chart (M)

headline: Private Sector; Laughing All the Way to the Banamex
abstract: Roberto Hernandez, president of Mexican bank Banamex, will gain greatly from Citigroup's $12.5 billion purchase of Banamex's parent company; photo (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   7.00   7.00   9.50       Discount rate   3.50   3.50   6.00       Federal funds   4.25   4.05   6.54       3-month T-bills   3.61   3.57   5.73       6-month T-bills   3.56   3.51   5.98       10-yr. T-infl.   3.26   3.28   4.10       10-yr. T-note   5.37   5.50   6.12       30-yr. T-bond   5.75   5.84   5.89       Telephone bd.   7.95   8.09   8.15       Municipal bds.   5.42   5.47   6.02          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Pacts Made On New Domains
abstract: Internet Corp for Assigned Names and Numbers, or Icann, announces agreements with NeuLevel that will operate new .biz and consortium of 18 domain registrars that will operate .info databases of names (S)

headline: 100 Years in Pen and Pencil
abstract: Society of Illustrators Web site displays drawings, watercolors, oils and etchings which appeared in magazines; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Refinery Purchased
abstract: Yukos Oil Co, Russia's second-largest producer, buys more than a quarter of Mazeikiu Nafta, Lithuanian oil refinery managed by Williams International, for $75 million (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: European Union: A Deal With China
abstract: China agrees to open its markets further to European companies in service industries as it prepares to join World Trade Organization (S)

headline: Article 2001062991386242532 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: Can't Sit on a Laptop
abstract: Nancy Coates letter on May 31 article concerning laptop computers

headline: Thatcher Plunges In
abstract: Former Prime Min Margaret Thatcher makes her first appearance of British election campaign, lauding Tory leader William Hague and criticizing Prime Min Tony Blair (S)

headline: MICROSTRATEGY TO CUT 600 JOBS
abstract: MicroStrategy, beleaguered business data software company, will lay off 600 employees, or one-third of its work force; will fall short of first-quarter revenue expectations; graph (S)

headline: Article 2001061990970778520 -- No Title
abstract: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: POST PROPERTIES INC., Atlanta, the largest apartment developer in Georgia, said it had sold two apartment developments in Dallas and Irving, Tex., and land in Charlotte, N.C., for $99 million to pay down debt and finance development.    WILLIAMS COS., Tulsa, Okla., an energy company, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to raise as much as $1.9 billion through the sale of debt securities and preferred and common stock.

headline: Powell Begins New Talks With Leaders Of Caucasus
abstract: State Sec Colin L Powell opens peace talks, Key West, Fla, on conflict between Azerbaijan and Armenia over Nagorno-Karabak, enclave in Azerbaijan occupied by Armenia; his direct involvement signals United States desire for resolution to dispute to encourage stability in Caucasus; he meets separately with Armenia Pres Robert Kocharian and Azerbaijan Pres Heydar Aliyev, then joins two for start of formal session; holds out little hope for breakthrough; Aliyev accuses Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe negotiators of ignoring international law to please Armenians who live in enclave (M)

headline: STARMEDIA, AN INTERNET COMPANY, SET TO CUT 200 JOBS
abstract: StarMedia Network Inc will eliminate about 200 jobs, or 25 percent of its work force; announces first-quarter loss narrows to $31.2 million, or 46 cents a share (S)

headline: IVAX SAYS IT WILL INCREASE OUTPUT OF ITS GENERIC TAXOL
abstract: Ivax Corp is increasing production of its generic version of Bristol-Myers Squibb's cancer drug Taxol after regulators approve additional raw-materials supplier and manufacturer for Ivax (S)

headline: CNBC.com To Be Merged Into MSN
abstract: NBC will merge its CNBC.com site into personal finance area of Microsoft's MSN site; CNBC.com, which had as many as 125 employees at end of 2000, has been cutting back and now has fewer than 50 workers, many of whom split their time between cable TV network and Web site; some of those will be offered jobs by Microsoft (S)

headline: 2 Buyout Firms Will Acquire Yell of Britain
abstract: Hicks Muse Tate & Furst Inc and Apax Partners & Co agree to buy Yell Group, yellow-pages unit of British Telecommunications, for 2.14 billion pounds (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Crisis Worsens, U.N. Says
abstract: UN team reports conditions worsening in war-ravaged, drought-stricken Afghanistan (S)

headline: Compressed Data; Despite Teligent's Woes, It's Glowing in Times Sq.
abstract: Teligent may have filed for bankruptcy, but it still has 70-square-foot sign shining atop Conde Nast tower in Times Square; photo (S)

headline: Youths Rally for Re-election of Iran's Reformist President
abstract: High school students stage large rally in Tehran for Iran's reformist president, Mohammad Khatami, who is seeking re-election on June 8; he faces daunting obstacles, notably crackdown by hard-line Islamic clerics, who hold real power (M)

headline: Belfast Journal; In the Ulster Spring, Seeds of Peace Lie Dormant
abstract: Spring has brought sense of gloom to Northern Ireland, where network of paramilitary influence has broadened since signing of Apr 1998 peace accord intended to end it; accord has ended systematic violence that convulsed nation for three decades, but Protestant and Catholic politicians continue bitter confrontation over how to put its terms into effect; paramilitary groups are devoting energies to organized crime; photo (M)

headline: At Annual Meetings Around the World, the Shots Aren't Heard
abstract: Survey of corporate annual meetings around the world reveals distinct cultural differences but at least one commonality: shareholders no matter where rarely succeed at changing minds of management; shareholder activism has spread from US overseas, making annual meetings rowdier in many places; survey covers Germany, France, Hong Kong, Russia, US, Switzerland and Brazil; photos; graphs (L)

headline: Metro Business Briefing
abstract: BANKRUPT THE BUNNY Golden Books Family Entertainment Inc. , the publisher of the children's book "Pat the Bunny" and owner of the rights to the cartoon characters Felix the Cat and Underdog, filed for bankruptcy protection for the second time in two years yesterday to speed the sale of the company for $170 million. In Chapter 11 papers filed in United States Bankruptcy Court in Wilmington, Del., the publisher listed $170.1 million in assets and $220.6 million in debts. The New York-based company said it would be sold to DIC Entertainment Holdings Inc. for $170 million in assumed debt, cash and commercial paper, and will become private. DIC Entertainment will gain Golden Books's library of more than 500,000 titles, including comic books and 3,000 movies, the companies said in a statement. Golden Books filed for bankruptcy protection in early 1999 in New York and emerged from that reorganization process in January 2000. Â Â (Bloomberg News)

headline: Private Sector; New City, New Best Friend?
abstract: April has been busy -- and expensive -- for Laurence Graff. Despite the softening economy, he just opened a Manhattan branch of his international jewel house, which also has stores in London and Monte Carlo. Other people might think twice about making another big expenditure. But not Mr. Graff. On Tuesday, he bought the 50-carat ''La Favorite'' diamond ring at Christie's for $3.6 million.    Mr. Graff, who has often sold rare, and larger, gems to the world's wealthy during his more than 40 years in the business, thinks the long, emerald-cut diamond -- named the most perfect diamond in America at the 1934 Chicago World's Fair -- could use improvement. ''I am going to recut it to make it totally flawless,'' he said. If all goes according to plan, he said, only a little of the diamond's weight will be lost.

headline: A Dark View of the Street; Spotlight Shines on Skeptic Who Sees a Long Slowdown
abstract: Interview with Stephen S Roach, Morgan Stanley's chief economist, who says US economy has only begun to hit bottom and faces long stretch of anemic growth; he blames excesses of 1990's: overinvestment in information technology, depletion of personal savings, reliance on foreign capital and stock market bubble capped off by Nasdaq folly; says companies are now burdened with overcapacity and corporations and individuals are choking on debt; says Alan Greenspan, Fed chairman, bears much of blame because he did nothing about stock market's 'irrational exuberance' in 1996 after identifying it and because he endorsed 'new paradigm' hypothesis that technology investment was paying off in form of permanently higher productivity growth rates; photos (M)

headline: Article 2001040591022969652 -- No Title
abstract: CYBERTIMES EDUCATION

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Sonia Gandhi To Visit U.S.
abstract: Sonia Gandhi, president of Congress Party and widowed heir to Nehru-Gandhi dynasty, will make her first trip to United States as leader of opposition to Indian government; will speak at Asia Society in New York; photo (S)

headline: U.S. Envoy Meets Chinese Foreign Minister as Negotations on Plane's Crew Continue
abstract: American ambassador, Adm Joseph W Prueher, meets with China's foreign minister in latest in series of negotiations aimed at securing release of 24 crew members of American spy plane; United States diplomats in China say American representatives would be allowed to have second meeting with crew members, who are being held incommunicado on Hainan Island, as two governments search for face-saving compromise over China's demand for open American apology (M)

headline: Team Bush: Partisan but Nimble
abstract: Pres George W Bush's economic team has set in motion many of biggest items on his agenda in its four months on the job; conservatives like team's focus on smaller government, deregulation and individual responsibility; Bush's ideological opponents say team's approach is fiscally irresponsible, a payoff to its corporate patrons and an effort to repackage right-wing policies in centrist guise; even some of harshest critics are impressed by team's discipline and political touch and its nimbleness in turning events to its own favor; lead player for now appears to be Lawrence B Lindsey, director of National Economic Council; others on team are Treasury Sec Paul H O'Neill, Mitchell E Daniels Jr, director of Office of Management and Budget, Robert B Zoellick, trade representative, R Glenn Hubbard, chairman of Council of Economic Advisers, Josh Bolten, Deputy White House chief of staff, and John B Taylor, nominee for under secretary of Treasury for international affairs; photos (M)

headline: Business Travel; As airlines iron out labor woes, the travel industry must deal with corporate belt tightening.
abstract: Rolfe Shellenberger, travel consultant, says most important shift in business-travel environment has been caused by costs, which are expected to rise 7 percent this year even as companies scramble to cut back on travel; says some of most striking recent changes in business travel are in hotel spending because prices at top chains have not fallen significantly (M)

headline: Settlers Press Sharon to Declare War on the Palestinians
abstract: Furious Jewish settlers fight Palestinians near West Bank crossroads where Israeli infant is wounded by Arab stone-throwers; settlers then gather in Jerusalem to demand that Israel declare war against Palestinian Authority; thousands of settlers call for death of Yasir Arafat and condemn Prime Min Ariel Sharon for not retaliating immediately after bombing at beachfront nightclub in Tel Aviv, which has now claimed 21 lives (M)

headline: Article 2001052892327353262 -- No Title
abstract: CYBERTIMES EDUCATION

headline: Powell Warns of Damage To Ties as Crisis Drags On
abstract: Bush administration strikes slightly stiffer tone with China, warning Beijing that its relationship with United States is already being hurt and that it risks further harm with every day that crew of American spy plane remains in detention; senior American officials again reject kind of apology that China has demanded and they insist that US would not give up its right to conduct eavesdropping flights such as one that collided with Chinese jet; Secretary of State Colin Powell, in apparent effort to mollify Chinese, says for first time that Washington is 'sorry' about loss of Chinese pilot; in another gesture, Pres Bush sends condolence to Ruan Guoqin, wife of downed pilot, Wang Wei; photo (M)

headline: Article 2001042594035075672 -- No Title
abstract: April 23, 2001

headline: United Airlines Contract Talks to Resume
abstract: United Airlines is scheduled to resume talks June 18 with machinists union on contract for baggage handlers, customer-service agents and reservations workers in attempt to avert strike (S)

headline: Shares of Software Company Slide After Trading Resumes
abstract: Shares of AremisSoft Corp fall 9.8 percent in wake of articles in TheStreet.com and New York Times questioning whether software company misled investors about value of its contract to modernize Bulgaria's health care information system (M)

headline: It's Time to Pass the Torch, Powell Tells Zimbabwe's President
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell today called on President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe to ''submit to the law and the will of the people'' in a fair and free presidential election next year instead of clinging to power.    In a speech assessing the state of Africa, General Powell praised presidents in countries like Mali, Senegal and Ghana who have stepped aside or have agreed to do so in favor of a new generation of leaders.

headline: Article 2001051191725820602 -- No Title
Cadbury Is Said to Be Close to a $592 Million Deal for Orangina
abstract: Cadbury Schweppes reportedly nears accord to buy Orangina brand from Pernod Ricard; move would expand soft drink's distribution in United States andCadbury's European market share (M)

headline: Those Dimples May Be Digits
abstract: Infant science of face-recognition, in which software compares digitized video, photographic or drawn representations of faces, works reasonably well in identifying those wishing to log onto computers or pass through security checkpoints; its technology needs refining to yield consistent results in law enforcement and surveillance; as it improves, issues of privacy are likely to burgeon; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Nevada Proposal Lifts Cryptologic
abstract: Shares of Cryptologic Inc, which sells software that lets people bet over Internet, soar after Nevada Legislature votes to let casinos offer online gambling; graph (S)

headline: MEDIA: A Starchy Old Sport Gets a Youthful Swing; Fresh Crop of Magazines Recasts Golf With Mix of Celebrities, Gonzo and Sex
abstract: A Starchy Old Sport Gets a Youthful Swing*

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Copper drops after report shows US industrial production declined, intensifying concern that demand will fall; in New York, copper for July delivery falls 0.85 cent, to 75.5 cents per pound; graph; chart (S)

headline: How to Take Back Our Analog Brains
abstract: Matt Richtel column on exercising the brain to take back functions of that have been taken over by digital equipment, including spelling, memory, mathematics, sense of direction and attention span (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: ASIA

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Creditors Balk At Swap
abstract: Hyundai Engineering and Construction struggles for survival as several creditors balk at swapping debts for equity (S)

headline: CNBC Europe To Buy Stake In an Italian TV Channel
abstract: CNBC Europe, London-based arm of NBC's financial news cable channel, is acquiring 20 percent equity interest in Italian-language financial news channel, CFN; deal is valued at about $123.6 million (M)

headline: Article 2001041392324337952 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: India's Leader Speaks of Reconciliation in Letter to Pakistan
abstract: In a graceful letter, Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee today officially invited Pakistan's military ruler, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, to India for the first talks between the two nations since an earlier peace program was ruptured by a violent conflict in Kashmir two years ago.    ''Our common enemy is poverty,'' Mr. Vajpayee wrote. ''For the welfare of our peoples, there is no other recourse but a pursuit of the path of reconciliation.''

headline: In a Surprise, Central Bank Sees No Need To Cut Rates
abstract: European Central Bank declines to reduce interest rates and suggests that it might not do so any time soon; decision represents calculated gamble that Europe's prospects will remain much healthier than those in US; bank's president, Wim Duisenberg, predicts that European inflation will not decline below bank's target of 2 percent a year for at least another 18 months (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Soybeans fall 12.25 cents, to $4.585 a bushel, on prospects of bumper crop; charts (S)

headline: CHINESE INSISTING U.S. MUST DO MORE TO END STANDOFF
abstract: China insists in strongly worded statement that United States has not done enough to end crisis over 24 Americans detained after their spy plane made emergency landing nearly week ago; negotiations to find way out of crisis continue; official propaganda in China both reflects popular anger and keeps it ratcheted high; China asserts that collision was 'entirely caused' by US side, and that US should apologize; photo; maps (L)

headline: Online Seller's Book Business Is Up in Quarter
abstract: Barnesandnoble.com says it expects to report that first-quarter sales rose 23 percent from period year earlier, suggesting that it is gaining market share on its much larger competitor, Amazon.com (S)

headline: Article 2001041991678891962 -- No Title
abstract: April 18, 2001

headline: Pentagon Says It Suspended Military Contacts With China
abstract: The Pentagon announced today that it was suspending military contacts and programs with China, following Beijing's failure to release a United States Navy surveillance plane that landed on Hainan island a month ago after colliding with a Chinese jet fighter.

headline: General Dynamics Makes $2.1 Billion Deal for Shipbuilder
abstract: General Dynamics Corp will buy Newport News Shipbuilding Inc for $2.1 billion in cash, deal that would make it Navy's sole maker of aircraft carriers and submarines and solidify its position in construction of other Navy and commercial ships; analysts predict deal, certain to raise antitrust concerns, will win needed approvals; photo (M)

headline: Behind the Curtain, Minding the Manager
abstract: THEY don't get much publicity. It is doubtful that you will see one on CNBC. In the investment management business, where securities analysts and money managers are the rock stars, the people who advise pension funds, institutions, endowments and foundations on how and where to invest their money are blips on the radar screen.    But when you talk to people in the business, it quickly becomes clear that these consultants, however anonymous, are a major force.

headline: Consumer Prices Up; Home Building Rises
abstract: Labor Department reports Consumer Price Index increased 0.3 percent in April; core index, which excludes energy and food, increased 0.2 percent for second consecutive month; Commerce Department reports builders started new homes in April at annual rate of 1.609 million units, up 1.5 percent; starts of single-family homes rose 6.7 percent, to rate of 1.288 million units, after falling 6.3 percent in March; housing completions rose 4.7 percent, to annual rate of 1.533 million units; 30-year mortgage rates averaged about 7 percent during first four months, lowest since early 1999; graph; chart (M)

headline: White House Memo; Global Realities Redefine Bush's Agenda
abstract: White House Memo notes global and domestic politics have forced Pres Bush to back away from hard-line pronouncements of his first five months in White House, which will likely be known in retrospect as anti-Clinton phase of Bush presidency; senior administration official says realities of governing have begun to overwhelm memories of campaigning (M)

headline: Iomega Builds a Bigger Pen To Corral Those Digital Hogs
abstract: 'Peerless' drive system introduced by Iomega Corp stores data on 10- or 20-gigabyte disks; photo (M)

headline: Technology Shares Gain But Dow and S.& P. Decline
abstract: Nasdaq composite index rises 25.20 points, to 2,198.77; Dow Jones industrial average falls 51.66 points, to 10,883.51; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 2.31 points, to 1,261.20; graph; tables (M)

headline: Compaq's Results Fall Short of Estimates
abstract: Compaq Computer Corp misses Wall Street's already lowered expectations by one cent for third quarter; earnings were $200 million, down from $296 million during same 2000 period; revenue declined to $9.2 billion from $9.5 billion last year; company says it will eliminate 2,000 more jobs than it announced in March, increasing its cuts to 10 percent of its work force (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Vivendi Seen in Early Talks To Buy Houghton Mifflin  Vivendi Universal of France is in preliminary talks to acquire Houghton Mifflin, the venerable United States publishing house, people close to the discussions said.    People involved in the talks said they were in very early stages and could still collapse. A price has not been settled on, they said. Shares of Houghton Mifflin gained $3.95, to $57.45, while the American depository receipts of Vivendi rose 43 cents, to $68.80. [Page C2.]

headline: Investing; In an Energy Fog, Coal Starts to Shine
abstract: Coal stock prices climb sharply after years of industrywide slump, helped by rise in natural gas costs; coal producers, mine owners and investors rely on permanence of higher energy prices to keep coal mining profitable; photo; graph (M)

headline: Russia Takes Advantage of Brain Power at Home
abstract: ST. PETERSBURGâ€”  This city has earned a number of nicknames in its 300-year history â€” Venice of the North, the Northern Palmir and Russia's Cultural Capital. Now St. Petersburg has joined the growing list of places trying to add a "Silicon Valley" nickname.

headline: Positive Signals For Tobacco Stocks
abstract: Kenneth N Gilpin Market Insight column interviews Marc Cohen, Goldman, Sachs & Company tobacco analyst, who sees positive signals on industry's future; photo (M)

headline: CONAGRA TO RESTATE RESULTS FOR THREE FISCAL YEARS
abstract: Conagra To Restate Results Fo

headline: Grudge Match; For Michael Dell and Steve Jobs An Old Rivalry Still Boils
abstract: Apparent personal grudge between Apple Computer co-founder Steven P Jobs and Dell Computer founder Michael S Dell has only intensified as personal computer industry has started to shrink after decades of rapid growth; Dell is again predicting Apple's demise, while Jobs recently used boxy portable Dell computer as foil to show off features of Apple's sleek new laptop; graphs comparing companies' industry rankings; tables of biographical data; photos (M)

headline: France and Germany Caution Bush on Missile Defense Plan
abstract: Pres Bush, meeting with NATO leaders, Brussels, again signals he would set aside 1972 Antiballistic Missile treaty with Russia to proceed with missile defense plan; French Pres Jacques Chirac warns plan could spur arms proliferation; German Chancellor Gerhard Schroder indicates skepticism about plan; Bush administration officials hold others in Europe shows new willingness to at least consider idea; European officials say plan remains too value to re-evaluate and that Bush did not provide needed data; Bush projects awareness of European concerns and willingess to address them; photos (M)

headline: Business Diary: A Stadium Name Deal Leaves Investors Fuming
abstract: The stock of PSINet has plunged more than 99 percent in the past year, and the company said last week that it might seek bankruptcy protection. The announcement, coming after the hiring of investment banks to restructure debt and find potential buyers, has stymied investors.

headline: Annan Urges Mideast to Make Peace Move
abstract: UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan urges Israelis and Palestinians to seize moment and move toward resumption of peace talks; comments after meeting with Yasir Arafat in Ramallah, hours before violence breaks out anew (S)

headline: Detectors Can Find Just the Right Spot to Drive That Nail
abstract: How It Works column surveys and explains variety of devices designed to facilitate location of building studs behind wall surfaces; drawings (M)

headline: Webdenda: Executive Changes at Media Firms
abstract: Todd Gallentine was named vice president and group creative director on accounts including Marshalls and Quick & Reilly at Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, Boston, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies. He succeeds Ron Wilcox, who left to become senior vice president and creative director, currently on the Citizens Bank account, at Arnold Worldwide, Boston, part of the Arnold Worldwide Partners unit of Havas Advertising. Mr. Gallentine had most recently been freelancing in New York.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Dot-Com Job Erosion Slows
abstract: Challenger Gray & Christmas reports that dot-com job cuts fell to 9,216 in June, down 31 percent from May level; says Internet technology accounted for bulk of dot-com layoffs; 74,199 dot-com jobs were cut in first six months of year (S)

headline: Fired Workers Fire Back, Then Fall Hard
abstract: Workplace arbitration has been around for years, but has become controversial of late as more employers require workers to use it to settle all disputes; Supreme Court sanctioned practice in March, agreeing with lower courts that it offers a quick, inexpensive and fair way of resolving conflicts out of courts; comment on case of Suzanne and Ira Stitz of Orangeburg, NY, who own insurance brokerage firm, and who were part of long and costly arbitration dispute; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Aides Visit Held Americans Again
abstract: Two US diplomats hold third meeting with 24 American servicemen and women detained on Hainan Island, China, in aftermath of midair collision between US spy plane and Chinese fighter jet; photo (S)

headline: U.S. Trade Deficit Climbed Sharply in March
abstract: After a steep drop in February, the United States trade deficit expanded widely in March, producing a record first-quarter gap, the Commerce Department reported today.

headline: British Police Arrest 4 Youths in Slaying of Nigerian Boy
abstract: LONDON, June 26 â€” Police today brought murder charges against four teenage boys in the killing of a 10-year-old Nigerian immigrant whose stabbing death on the stairwell of a London housing project caused national revulsion because of evidence that passersby had let him slowly bleed to death.

headline: Hasbro Has Loss as PokÃ©mon Wanes
abstract: Hasbro Inc reports loss of $25 million in its most recent quarter compared with earnings of $15 million year earlier; revenue declined to $463 million from $773 million (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Bush Seeking To Modify Pact on Trade With Jordan
abstract: Pres Bush tells visiting King Abdullah II that enacting free trade agreement between US and Jordan is priority, but suggests that labor and environmental standards negotiated by Pres Clinton may requirement readjustment under his administration; White House reportedly is concerned about setting precedent for future trade agreements (M)

headline: Bush Asks Congress to Grant Him a 'Fast Track' in Trade Talks
abstract: Pres Bush begins difficult battle to win Congressional support for broad authority to negotiate new trade agreements; puts this at top of his trade agenda; Democrats say he has offered no mechanism for enforcing labor and environmental standards that could win over moderates in their ranks and break long Congressional stalemate over trade policy; many Republicans say such provisions have nothing to do with trade, and Bush has called them veiled efforts at protectionism (M)

headline: Chinese Banking Case
abstract: China is offering reward for information leading to arrest of Wang Liming, former manager of Hainan branch of Bank of China, his wife, Wang Yulan, his brother-in-law, Wang Weidong, and two other people, all wanted for 'alleged economic crimes' (S)

headline: Editor in Chief at Harper's Bazaar Is Forced Out
abstract: Katherine Betts is asked to resign as editor in chief of Harper's Bazaar a full year before her three-year contract is due to expire and about 23 hours after her replacement, Glenda Bailey, knew she had new job; Cathleen J Black, chief executive of Hearst Magazines, says she and Bailey had been discussing possibility for about two weeks; photo (M)

headline: Democrats Set to Block Bush Initiatives
abstract: WASHINGTONâ€”  The incoming Senate majority leader made it clear Sunday that Democrats planned to use their new control of that chamber to block some key Bush policy initiatives, from early deployment of a missile-defense system to oil-drilling in the Alaska wilderness and increased use of nuclear power.

headline: Aimster Heads Down a Path Already Taken by Napster
abstract: Recording Industry Association of America asserts that Aimster, its latest legal nemesis in fight over online music, is essentially clone of Napster that permits free exchange of copyrighted files over Internet; outside legal experts say it is unclear whether recording industry can prevail over Aimster as easily as it did over Napster, given what they say may be crucial differences between way users exchange files on two services (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: NEXT LEVEL COMMUNICATIONS INC., Rohnert Park, Calif., a provider of broadband access systems, said it would receive a two-year, $60 million loan from Motorola Inc., Schaumburg, Ill., a wireless technology giant and major shareholder.    INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS MACHINES CORP., Armonk, N.Y., the largest computer maker, said it planned to spend $255 million to buy back its only preferred stock and related depository shares.

headline: SUPERVALU CUTS JOBS AND TAKES A CHARGE TO EARNINGS
abstract: Supervalu Inc, food distribution and supermarket company, will cut 4,500 jobs, or 7.3 percent of its work force, as it consolidates distribution centers and leaves some retail markets; will take charge of $153.9 million against earnings in quarter ended Feb 24 to reflect moves; revamping follows loss of distribution contract with Kmart that is expected to reduce revenue this year by $1.7 billion; company reports loss of $93 million in fourth quarter of its fiscal year, compared with profit of $72 million year earlier (S)

headline: 2 Sony Executives Disciplined For Faked Praise in Film Ads
abstract: Sony Pictures Entertainment reprimands and suspends without pay two executives for fabricating movie critic to praise four of its films in advertisements (M)

headline: Russia to Decide Whether to Shake Up Giant Gas Monopoly
abstract: Pres Vladimir V Putin is scheduled to decide this week whether to allow Gazprom, natural gas monopoly and Russia's most valuable company, to continue downward spiral or shake it up with new management in hope of new beginning; government is to decide whether to renew contract of Gazprom's Rem Vyakhirev, chief executive since 1992; Vyakhirev and group small group of top managers have controlled Gazprom, preventing even government from learning much about its finances; Boris Fyodorov, who was elected to Gazprom's board in 2000 by minority shareholders, is plotting Vyakhirev's ouster; Fyodorov has accused management of diverting assets to companies owned by their relatives; management is trying to eject him from board; both men claim Putin as ally (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Lobbying Is in Full Swing From Microsoft and Rivals  As federal and state prosecutors ponder what to do next with Microsoft, they have already come under enormous lobbying pressure from the company to quickly settle and from its rivals, most notably AOL Time Warner, to continue litigating.    The lobbying campaign was in full swing even before the decision by a federal court of appeals on Thursday that vacated the order to break up Microsoft but also found that the company had engaged in a raft of anticompetitive practices. [Page A1.]

headline: Sony and AOL Join Forces On the Video Game Front
abstract: Sony Computer Entertainment and America Online form relationship aimed at blending video game and online Internet experience; underlying alliance is coming collision among personal computer, online and video game industries that will tend to blur lines between different markets in home; Sony will announce series of peripherals for PlayStation 2 (M)

headline: Baghdad Journal; O Iraqi Youth, Dig It, the Time Has Come to Rock
abstract: Pop radio station in Iraq run by Saddam Hussein's son, Uday Saddam Hussein, draws millions of listeners with programming that seemingly encourages addiction to things American, especially among Iraqis drawn to rock, rap and country music; Uday Hussein, who has history of violent and unpredictable behavior, is now member of Parliament; loyalists claim he is winning strong following among young Iraqis by founding radio station, which draws 95 percent of listening audience across country; there is quiet talk in Iraq about role radio station could play in eventual succession to Saddam Hussein, who is 63 and rumored to have cancer; photo (M)

headline: Latest Disaster Tests Resiliency of Jerusalem's Residents
abstract: This is a city accustomed to coping with crisis. But as sirens screamed through the night, with ambulances racing to a collapsed wedding hall in which at least two dozen people died, Jerusalemites struggled to deal with what some described as crisis overload.    One city resident, Moshe Zilber, said he was drawn to visit the disaster scene by a rescue worker's description of uncovering a family of five, dressed in their finest, still sitting at their banquet table, frozen forever. The five, who had dropped two stories and eerily landed in place, were killed in what is being called the largest civil disaster in Israeli history.

headline: New Little GlowGuard Makes Game Boy Glimmer
abstract: Interact Accessories markets fliptop light that snaps onto top of new Nintendo Game Boy Advance; photo (S)

headline: Yellow Ribbons Galore and Embracing All the Crew
abstract: Oak Harbor, Wash, home of Whidbey Island Naval Air Station, rejoices that crew of American spy plane detained on Hainan Island, China, has returned to American soil, and will soon be returning to Whidbey, crew's home base; town plans massive celebration; Pres Bush, who has expressed gratitude to and respect for crew, is not expected to attend (M)

headline: Blood, Sweat And Fellowship
abstract: Bob Kenzer, founder and chairman of Kenzer Corp, executive recruiting firm, writes My First Job column on working at slaughterhouse as a teenager; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: F.C.C. Reports On Cellular Growth
abstract: Federal Communications Commission study shows 3 percent of mobile phone users had only wireless links last year, and more callers are choosing to buy mobile phones instead of installing conventional copper wires in their homes; mobile phone subscribers increased 27 percent last year, to 109.5 million; average price of US call fell to 21 cents per minute from 28 cents in 1999; average wireless bill increased to $45.27 from $41.24 (S)

headline: SUEZ BUYS OUT EXXON MOBIL'S STAKE IN CHEMICAL VENTURE
abstract: Suez, global water company, acquires Exxon Mobil Corp's 40 percent stake in Nalco/Exxon Energy Chemicals, taking full control as it seeks to increase sales to petroleum industry (S)

headline: Economic Scene; Variety is a good gauge of progress. But how well can economists measure it?
abstract: Virginia Postrel 'Economic Scene' column on variety of goods as a gauge of economic progress and how to measure it; cites study by Dr Mark Bils and Dr Peter J Klenow; photo (M)

headline: Turner's U.N. Fund Plans World Resource Survey
abstract: Ambitious project to assess global environmental damage from rapid consumption of natural resources is announced by unusual coalition of scientists, corporations, foundations and international agencies; Timothy E Wirth of co-sponsoring United Nations Foundation explains 'first global report card' on environment; fund was set up in 1997 with ten-year, $1-billion grant from Ted Turner; other contributors include World Resources Institute, Global Environment Facility, David and Lucille Packard Foundation and World Bank; project will be run by UN Environmental Program (S)

headline: Europe Panel Is Rethinking How It Views E-Commerce
abstract: European Commission is considering abandoning long-held position that in cross-border disputes involving Internet commerce, laws in country where consumer is situated should govern; publishers, merchants and others have complained that such approach would smother e-commerce under legal obligations and be so burdensome for small businesses as to make Internet sales impractical for them; Justice and regulatory experts who are drafting European Union law, known as Rome II, have decided to hold consultations with industry and consumer groups (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ST. JOE COMMERCIAL,  Jacksonville, Fla., Florida's largest real estate operating company, said it had sold a 310,000-square-foot office building in Boca Raton, Fla., to the National Council on Compensation Insurance Holdings for $52.5 million.    FIDELITY NATIONAL FINANCIAL ,  Irvine, Calif., which underwrites and issues title insurance policies through its units, signed a definitive agreement with Vista Information Solutions to combine real estate information, technology products and assets into a joint real estate services company.

headline: Aetna's Chief Financial Officer Will Leave
abstract: Four days after Aetna said its earnings for the first quarter would be ''significantly lower'' than expected and its shares dropped sharply, the company announced yesterday that its chief financial officer, Alan J. Weber, would leave.    Aetna said Mr. Weber's departure was unrelated to the earnings warning that by Thursday had pushed its stock price down 25 percent, to $27.

headline: When Few Knew the Code, They Changed the Language
abstract: International Business Machines team that developed Fortran, programming language that was historic breakthrough in computing, in 1950's recalled; sought to simplify programming and open up computing to more people; John Backus, who headed team, recalls effort, interview; photos (M)

headline: More Than a Palmtop, Not Quite a PC
abstract: Computer and consumer electronics makers are introducing lightweight home computing devices called Web Pads, which offer more power than palmtops, but less than personal computers, and do not depend on keyboards; producers include Airspeak, Frontpath, Siemens and Sony; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing  Asia: Pakistan: 'No Political Activity'
abstract: Thousands of security forces are deployed in Karachi, Pakistan, to block May Day rally against military rule; hundreds are arrested (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Presidential Election Rescheduled
abstract: French Constitutional Council approves reversal of next year's election calendar, allowing presidential election to precede legislative voting as proposed by Prime Min Lionel Jospin (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Seeking More Trade With Pakistan
abstract: India's most influential trade body, Confederation of Indian Industry, asks Pakistan to reciprocate and grant most-favored-nation status to India, which confederation holds would lead to more trade and investment between countries (S)

headline: Profitable or Not? It Depends on Who's Measuring
abstract: It will dominate retailing around the world. Or it will be the Internet's most spectacular flameout.

headline: Private Sector; Blunt Words From One Who's Done It Before
abstract: Chairman of General Electric, John F Welch Jr, gives frank interview to Harvard's MBA graduates as he speaks at graduation ceremonies; photo (M)

headline: Unrequited Job Seekers Kept in the Dark
abstract: Hiring executives admit that they frequently neglect to inform unsuccessful applicants that they have not been passed over, even after multiple inquiries from them; their foremost explanation is that giving reasons for rejection might provoke lawsuit; there is also expectation that candidates should realize when no word means 'no'; photo (M)

headline: Port-au-Prince Journal; A Haitian Bank Takes Its Money to the Streets
abstract: Haiti's leading commercial bank, Sogebank, has division that has aggressively expanded into microfinance, courting struggling, self-employed people, many of them street vendors, that make up more than 80 percent of country's work force; lenders are beginning to realize untapped potential in financing small entrepreneurs; Sogebank was preceded by three other banks who themselves built upon success of smaller lending programs pioneered by nongovernmental organizations; banks entered microlending market when Haitian regulators removed cap on interest rates in mid-1990's; loans start at $100, with most borrowers using money to buy merchandize, slowly expanding into new products; photo; map (M)

headline: Testing Links Potato Famine To an Origin In the Andes
abstract: Light is cast on origins of blight that caused Irish potato famines century and half ago; analysis of DNA from stricken potato leaves confirms that pathogen was fungus known as Phytophthora infestans, but suggests it did not originate in Mexico, as has been thgought, but instead it may have arisen in ancestral home of potato in Andean highlands of South America; Irish potato famines lasted from 1845 to 1860, during which million of Ireland's 8 million people straved to death; new findings reported in journal Nature (M)

headline: Holland Mark Chairman To Start New Company
abstract: Bink Garrison will leave Holland Mark Advertising to start Bink Inc, consulting agency that will specialize in marketing strategy and development; Garrison will be succeeded by Bill Davis, chief executive, who will take on added post of chairman (S)

headline: Advertisers Have Also Revved Up for Indy 500
abstract: All but three of Indy 500 drivers have lined up major corporate sponsorship; brand loyalty is peerless (S)

headline: Comair and Its Striking Pilots Reach a Tentative Agreement
abstract: WASHINGTON, June 14 â€” Comair and its striking pilots reached a tentative agreement today, on the 81st day of a strike, raising the prospect that the airline, which flies as the Delta Connection with hubs in Cincinnati and Orlando, Fla., could begin partial service again soon.

headline: IDEX SAYS IT WILL CUT 250 JOBS AND COMBINE TWO PLANTS
abstract: Idex Corp, maker of pumps and dispensing equipment, will cut about 250 jobs, or 6 percent of its work force, and combine two production plants in Michigan (S)

headline: Adventures With Dragons And Monkeys
abstract: Charles Herold reviews two computer games; Heroes of Might and Magic: Quest for the Dragonbone Staff, developed by New World Computing, and Monkey Brains, developed by Yobro Productions; photos (M)

headline: Ford's Earnings Decline 49%, but Sales Rival Those of G.M.
abstract: DETROIT, April 19 â€” The Ford Motor Company's profits dropped 49 percent in the first quarter, but the company earned much more than its arch-rival, the General Motors Corporation, and came within a whisker of outselling G.M., which has been the world's largest automaker since the 1930's.

headline: Australian Phone Upstart Declared Insolvent
abstract: Future of One.Tel, upstart Australian telecommunications company heavily backed by sons of media magnates Rupert Murdoch and Kerry Packer, is thrown into doubt when Ernest & Young, auditors, unexpectedly declare it insolvent (M)

headline: Nuclear Power: A Debate Renewed
abstract: Tom Redburn Economic View column on debate over future of nuclear power, which has been revived by threats of electricity shortages in many parts of nation and fears of environmental effects of burning fossil fuels; graph (M)

headline: Howard M. Packard; Former Executive, 90
abstract: Howard M Packard, former president of SC Johnson & Son Inc, dies at age 90 (S)

headline: Stocks End Mixed After Fed Rate Cut
abstract: Some small gamesmanship aside, investors yawned today at the Federal Reserve's sixth interest-rate reduction this year, having fooled themselves twice before.

headline: Banks Growing Cautious on Loans
abstract: Federal Reserve survey shows number of banks that have tightened standards for credit card loans surged early this year amid worries consumers would have difficulty paying debts in slowing economy; survey also says that banks remained cautious with business borrowers; Fed's vice chairman Roger Ferguson tells House committee that while both lenders and borrowers have become more cautious, there still is healthy flow of credit (S)

headline: Dr. Rodolphe Coigney, 89, Hero Of Wartime French Resistance
abstract: Dr Rodolphe Lucien Coigney, French resistance hero, dies at age 89 (M)

headline: Lifting the Curtain on the Real Costs of Making AIDS Drugs
abstract: Ciple Ltd in India and other foreign drug manufacturers making copycat versions of patented AIDS medicines are shedding new light on how little these medicines cost to make; produce either active ingredients in AIDS drugs or package ingredients into finished drugs themselves and sell them for fraction of what companies like GlaxoSmithKline and Bristol-Myers Squibb charge; big drug companies say they have to charge more than foreign generic makers because they have many costs the copycat manufacturers do not have, including cost of finding and developing new drugs; their financial reports show that many of them spend far more on marketing and advertising than on research and still have enough left over to make them one of most profitable industries in US; chart; photo (M)

headline: Sharon Scolds His Nation Over Calamity
abstract: Prime Min Ariel Sharon, attending session on Parliament on deadly collapse of wedding hall in Jerusalem, scores what he describes as national instinct to skirt rules and regulations; accident has been attributed to shoddy construction owing to corner-cutting by builders and improper oversight; there has been much self-flagellation in Israel over what senior officials have called 'culture of sloppiness' and 'culture of improvisation' (M)

headline: Article 2001062093412748141 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: Zambia's President Abandons Re-election Bid
abstract: Zambia Pres Frederick Chiluba, with his party in revolt over his bid for another five years in office, says that he will abandon his effort to change Constitution's two-term limit and will step down when his second term ends later this year (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank Profit Falls
abstract: France's BNP Paribas says first-quarter net profit dropped 7.4 percent, to $1.25 billion euros ($1.1 billion); photo (S)

headline: Crew May Be Held Until Hunt for Pilot Ends
abstract: Many Chinese say Americans detained since their surveillance plane collided with Chinese fighter jet are unlikely to be released until search for missing Chinese pilot, Wang Wei, ends; see added delay possible for period of mourning for Wang, who has become national hero; search has grown in recent days to massive scale that suggests its purpose is as much political as practical; photos (M)

headline: Who Runs Congo? The People, New Leader Says
abstract: At the end of a corridor in the labyrinthine Marble Palace, where he had just moved his office, a heavy door opened to show President Joseph Kabila sitting alone in a large room after a morning of receiving guests.    Everything seemed new, from the beige leather couches and the artificial flowers, to the $150 wristwatch and the jacket and tie. Nothing yet revealed the new president's imprint, no photographs, no books, no knickknacks, nothing that would diminish the feel of a hotel suite with a recently checked-in guest.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Protest Broken Up
abstract: Riot police drive labor activists from Hyosung Corp petrochemical plant, Ulsan, South Korea, held for 12 days by militant union members; 36 officers and 8 union members are hurt; union called strike after company ordered transfer of 14 workers whose jobs were taken over by machines (S)

headline: Beauty Queen From Texas Causes Stir, Bern to Berlin
abstract: The sober-minded Swiss diplomatic world was shocked when word leaked of a splashy magazine spread featuring its new embassy in Berlin.     It was not the photographs of the 1870's building that caused the stir, but the provocatively dressed ambassador's wife in them.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Yugoslavia: Poverty In Serbia
abstract: United Nations World Food Program reports that almost one million people in Serbia are living in poverty after decade of wars and international isolation (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Testing The Watery Limits
abstract: South Korea's Defense Ministry says small North Korean freighter crossed line in Sea of Japan that South has long claimed as marking its territorial waters; says freighter, carrying bicycles, identified itself and sailed on toward North Korea; map (S)

headline: EUROPEAN UNION: DE BEERS INQUIRY
abstract: European Commission has begun four-month investigation of planned joint venture by De Beers and LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton: commission is concerned that De Beers might use venture to increase its already dominant hold on world diamond market and that it might favor those middlemen who would buy De Beers rough diamonds and then supply cut diamonds to venture over those who supply cut diamonds to competing retailers (S)

headline: Revisiting a Venture Capital Conference a Year Later
abstract: AUSTIN, Tex. -- WHEN a speaker at this year's Texas Venture Capitalist Conference talked about how dot-coms went wrong last year, thinking, for instance, they could "turn gardeners into online couch potatoes," there was more than a little squirming in the audience. After all, one investor said, about half the people in the room had put money into Garden.com, a local and highly publicized failure.

headline: Looking at E-Business From Both Sides Now
abstract: Fred Andrews reviews two books on e-business, D2D: Dinosaur to Dynamo by David Stauffer and Place to Space: Migrating to E-Business Models by Peter Weill and Michael R Vitale; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Citigroup Agrees to Buy Big Mexican Bank Company  In the biggest Latin American acquisition by a United States company, Citigroup announced that it would buy Mexico's second-largest bank for $12.5 billion in cash and stock.    The purchase of Grupo Financiero Banamex-Acival, also known as Banacci, demonstrates Citigroup's faith in the recovery of Mexico's economy and banking system since the financial crisis of 1994. [Page A1.]

headline: New Executives At 2 Companies
abstract: Mediamark Research names president and chief operating officer Kathleen D Love chief executive, succeeding Alain Tessier, who remains chairman; names Ian Jack chief operating officer; Lowe Lintas & Partners Worldwide names Paul Edwards chief executive for its British operations, succeeding Paul Hammersley, who is becoming chief executive for United States operations at Lowe Lintas in New York (M)

headline: People
abstract: T&O Group names Dave Robinson general manager, new post (S)

headline: Airline Based At Kennedy Expands West
abstract: Slow pace of development at Kennedy Airport by Port Authority is pushing JetBlue Airways to expand near Los Angeles; JetBlue plans to anounce that beginning on Aug 29, it will fly twice per day between Long Beach Airport and Kennedy, and it will add 25 daily departures from California over next two years to as many as 14 other cities, including Boston, Washington, Denver and Salt Lake City; move represents important shift in strategy for JetBlue, which began operations last year with plan to base its operations solely at Kennedy; JetBlue says it needs to keep growing to lower operating costs, and it will run out of gate space by end of year; it has 14 Airbus jets, and expects to have 21 by end of year; JetBlue's chief executive David Neeleman comments (M)

headline: Article 2001040691148517491 -- No Title
abstract: April 5, 2001

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: INTERNETONLINE BANK TO BE SHUT DOWN The Bank One Corporation said that it would close its Internet bank, WingspanBank.com, and fold its 225,000 customers into the company's other online service, BankOne.com, this fall. By closing the two- year-old Internet-only venture, Bank One, based in Chicago, hopes to save on the cost of maintaining and marketing separate brands. In a statement, Bank One said it planned to integrate some WingspanBank resources and features into its other consumer Internet offerings. Shares of Bank One rose 52 cents yesterday, to $35.52.

headline: Ex-Mexico Governor Arrested And Linked to Cocaine Traffic
abstract: One of Mexico's most wanted men, a fugitive former governor, was arrested late Thursday night in the resort town of Cancún and charged on Friday in New York with helping to ship 200 tons of cocaine to the United States in exchange for millions of dollars in bribes.    Mario Villanueva was governor of the State of Quintana Roo on Mexico's Caribbean coast from 1993 to 1999. He was jailed in a maximum security prison in Mexico City on Friday after two years on the run, officials said.

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: HARDWARE

headline: Delays Possible for Over-the-Counter Allergy Drugs
abstract: It is not clear whether Food and Drug Administration has authority to force allergy drug manufacturers, Schering-Plough, Aventis and Pfizer Inc, to make products available over the counter; drug companies are almost certain to fight back in court, even if government does order change; advisory committee review of status of drugs was requested by Wellpoint Health Networks, insurance company; typically, pharmaceutical companies are ones that ask for permission to sell their drugs without prescription (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: EUROPE GERMANY: LAYOFFS AT SIEMENS Siemens, the big electronics maker, plans 3,500 more job cuts and has scrapped earlier forecasts for robust growth this year as its latest quarterly financial results fell short of expectations because of a significant decline in its telecommunications division. The chief executive, Heinrich von Pierer, said the new job cuts would be in Germany and the United States in the next 18 months, mostly in the Siemens sales unit. About 2,100 American workers are to be laid off. Â Â (AP)

headline: Patents; For tax season, a software package that helps end the hunting for pieces of paper.
