headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Musicians Sue MP3.Com
abstract: Recording artists Tom Waits and Randy Newman and rock band Heart sue MP3.com, seeking $40 million for copyright infringement; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Sales Growth Slows
abstract: British department store operator Harvey Nichols Group says sales at stores open at least 12 months rose 2.5 percent in first 10 weeks of financial year, down from 3.1 percent year earlier (S)

headline: 2 Rivals in the Crowd of Italy's Once and Future Chiefs
abstract: Francesco Rutelli is center-left candidate hoping to become Italy's next prime minister; his center-right rival, Silvio Berlusconi, is business tycoon whose assets include three television networks and soccer team; Rutelli faces parliamentary elections May 13 against the wealthy Berlusconi; he hopes to persuade Italians to look beyond his opponents's Reaganesque promises and realize they are better off today than they were five years ago; main problem for Rutelli, former mayor of Rome, is that his coalition failed to reform political system along with economy; photos (M)

headline: U.S. Appeals Court Overturns Microsoft Breakup Ruling
abstract: Afederal appeals court today struck down a judge's order to break up the Microsoft Corporation, but it ruled that the software company did violate antitrust law in order to protect a monopoly for its Windows computer operating system.

headline: As Nepal Mourns Royals, Mystery and Confusion Linger
abstract: King Dipendra dies of gunshot wounds in military hospital in Katmandu, Nepal, two days after becoming monarch after palace bloodbath, in which he reportedly shot and killed father, King Birendra, mother Queen Aiswarya and six other members of royal family before shooting himself; reportedly objected to parent's resistance to his choice of bride; new king will be his uncle, Prince Gyanendra; nation of 23 million mourns; circumstances surrounding shootings remain unclear amid conflict news reports; photo; map (M)

headline: You're Special
abstract: To paraphrase a remark often used to describe certain country-music aficionados, American Airlines was customer relationship marketing before customer relationship marketing was cool.

headline: Navratilova Gets Her Close-Up
abstract: The increasing diversity of the images in American advertising to reflect the increasing diversity of the consumer market is underscored by the return of Martina Navratilova. She has been given a starring role in a general-market campaign for Subaru of America.

headline: Investing; For a Venture Fund, Home Is an Exchange
abstract: Shares of meVC Draper Fisher Jurvetson Fund I, closed-end venture capital fund that provides financing to established and start-up technology companies, are selling at 37 percent below value of assets, tempting some investors despite general wariness ov venture capital funds (M)

headline: Shareholders Vote to Make De Beers Private Concern
abstract: Shareholders approve sweetened plan to turn De Beers into private company, with fewer formal obligations to report on its business; buyout cost will be $18.7 billion; stock will be delisted June 1, 2001 (M)

headline: Rumsfeld Seeks to Withdraw American Troops From Sinai
abstract: Bush administration officials say Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld told Prime Min Ariel Sharon of Israel last month that he wants to withdraw American soldiers serving as peackeepers in Sinai, as part of Pentagon's drive to reduce troop commitments abroad; say State Dept officials were not informed of Rumsfeld's proposal in advance, although Rumsfeld had discussed idea with Secretary of State Colin L Powell; it is not known whether Powell endorses it; unit, known as Multinational Force and Observers, was set up in 1982 after Camp David agreement between Israel and Egypt; force of about 1,900 soldiers includes 865 Americans; it is not under United Nations flag; there have been no major incidents along border since creation of force; in order to withdraw forces, US must win agreement of both Israel and Egypt; officials say Pres Hosni Mubarak, who was told of plan earlier this month, is vocal in his opposition; Israeli diplomats say Sharon was taken aback by idea and briefly argued against it before saying he would go along with proposal if symbolic American presence remains; chart (M)

headline: China's Ban Of Magazine Clouds Forum In Hong Kong
abstract: Fortune magazine is sponsoring Fortune Global Forum in Hong Kong, bringing together corporate titans and former Pres Bill Clinton, but conference is marred for Fortune's parent company, AOL Time Warner, because newsstand sales of Time magazine, another unit, have been banned in China since early March, shortly after magazine published article on Falun Gong spiritual movement in Hong Kong; Falun Gong, which is banned in China but not in Hong Kong, will hold demonstration three blocks from conference to protest speech by Pres Jiang Zemin (M)

headline: Powell Assails Israel for Gaza Incursion
abstract: State Sec Colin L Powell scores Israel for using 'excessive and disproportionate' force in seizing part of Palestinian-ruled Gaza and urges its forces to withdraw; notes fighting was spurred by provocative Palestinian mortar attack on Israel, but his criticism of Israel is far stronger; urges Palestinians to renounce terrorism and bring their military forces under control; Israeli Army, reversing stand by generals that they would hold positions for time, says it has completed operation and is withdrawing; photo (M)

headline: Attendants Accept 9.5% Raise And End Strike at AeromÃ©xico
abstract: Aeromexico flight attendants agree to 9.5 percent pay increase, ending two-day strike that stranded thousahds of passengers in Mexico and abroad; Aeromexico says it was able to rebook about 18,000 of 30,000 passengers whose flights were cancelled; resumes normal operations (M)

abstract: National Geographic Society manages Web site on Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor; photo (M)

headline: Richard McGee Morse, 78, Latin America Expert
abstract: Richard McGee Morse, a historian who influenced the field of Latin American studies through his belief that the cultures of Ibero America could help Anglo America understand its own assumptions, died on April 17 in Pétionville, Haiti. He was 78.    The cause was Alzheimer's disease, said his daughter, Marise Morse-Mahos.

headline: U.N. AIDS Gathering Draws Thousands
abstract: UNITED NATIONS, June 25 â€” Asserting that "in the ruthless world of AIDS, there is no us and them," Secretary General Kofi Annan pleaded today for international solidarity against the disease and compassion for its victims.

headline: Private Sector; Global Power Brokers Who Miss Their Old Wings
abstract: Former Defense Secretary William S Cohen, now geopolitical consultant, and James D Robinson III, former American Express chairman, agree that the thing they miss most about life at the top is not having airplanes at their personal disposal; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Telecom Stake
abstract: British Telecommunications is reported to be considering selling its 21.7 percent stake in LG Telecom Co of South Korea to Telesystem International Wireless of Canada (S)

headline: NUVEEN TO BUY SYMPHONY, AN INSTITUTIONAL FUND MANAGER
abstract: John Nuveen Co, mutual fund and money manager, will buy Symphony Asset Management for $210 million from Barra Inc and Symphony's management (S)

headline: Diesel Engines Get Spotlight in Fuel-Efficiency Contest
abstract: Diesel engines for sport utility vehicles are getting spotlight in fuel-efficiency Future Truck contest in Milford, Mich; competition is to see which vehicles emit least amount of global-warming gases; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Cautions China on Spy Plane Talks
abstract: BEIJING, April 17 - As United States negotiators arrived in Beijing today for meetings with Chinese officials to try to resolve issues surrounding the mid-air collision of a U.S. Navy spy plane and a Chinese fighter earlier this month, the rhetorical gulf between the two sides seemed huge and - if anything - widening.

headline: New-Generation TV's Are Catching On
abstract: Sales of digital television sets are rising rapidly, despite slow progress toward digital broadcasting; are driven by popularity of DVD's and increasing availability of digital cable TV; graph; table; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE    YUGOSLAVIA: PURSUING MILOSEVIC  A delegation from the United Nations war crimes tribunal in The Hague handed Yugoslav officials an indictment and arrest warrant for former President Slobodan Milosevic, asking that he be transferred swiftly to The Hague for prosecution for war crimes. Mr. Milosevic was arrested Sunday by the Serbian police on charges of embezzlement and abuse of power and is being held in Belgrade's Central Prison.    Carlotta Gall (NYT)    RUSSIA: TV TALKS BREAK DOWN  Talks between Russia's independent NTV television network and the state-dominated company Gazprom broke down, leaving both sides locked in conflict after Gazprom's hostile takeover of the network on Tuesday. NTV journalists met with Gazprom officials for less than an hour and asked the company to join them in an appeal to President Vladimir V. Putin. Gazprom said journalists walked out of talks after it refused their request.    Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

headline: A Funeral in Jerusalem Arouses Palestinian Nationalism
abstract: Thousands of Palestinians waving flags march through East Jerusalem in fervent display of nationalism as they bury Faisal Husseini; photo; senior Palestinian official, who died of heart attack and asthma at age 60, is buried in family tomb near Dome of the Rock (S)

headline: New Rules for Net Searches: Location, Location, Location
abstract: Nonprofit SRI International proposes reorganizing some Web sites according to geography to make searching for local data easier; has devised new top-level domain, .geo, and corresponding system for classifying sites based on data related to neighborhoods, businesses and travel destinations; drawing (M)

headline: Bush Will Sign Treaty Curtailing 'Dirty Dozen' Lethal Chemicals
abstract: President Bush said today that he would sign an international agreement negotiated during the Clinton administration to curtail and in some cases eliminate the production of 12 lethal chemicals known as ''the dirty dozen.'' They include DDT, dioxin and PCB's, which have been linked with cancer, reproductive failure and birth defects.     The agreement has the backing of both environmentalists and the chemical industry and is expected to be approved by the the Senate and signed by 122 nations next month in Sweden. The treaty, formally titled the Stockholm Convention on Persistent Organic Pollutants, would go into effect four or five years after its final approval.

headline: Rumsfeld Says U.S. Must Be in Balkans, but Not Become Mired
abstract: Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld says American troops are still needed in Kosovo to stem violence, but warns that United States should proceed cautiously in Balkans and elsewhere to avoid becoming mired in extended conflicts where American interests are unclear; also says US should be wary of tendency of some missions to grow beyond their original scope and focus; Rumsfeld has made no secret of his desire to scale back American peacekeeping missions in certain parts of world, particularly Bosnia, where 3,500 American troops are stationed (M)

headline: In Ruin, Symbols on a Stone Hint at a Lost Asian Culture
abstract: In an unexpected benefit of the cold war's end, Russian and American archaeologists say they have discovered an ancient civilization that thrived in Central Asia more than 4,000 years ago, before being lost in the sweep of history.    The people of that area, the archaeologists say, built oasis settlements with imposing mud-brick buildings and fortifications. They herded sheep and goats and grew wheat and barley in irrigated fields. They had bronze axes, fine ceramics, alabaster and bone carvings and jewelry of gold and semiprecious stones. They left luxury goods in the graves of an elite class.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Chile: Delay For Pinochet
abstract: Augusto Pinochet wins third judicial delay in having fingerprints and mug shots taken, as he awaits trial in Chile on human rights charges (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Telephone Contract
abstract: Ericsson, Sweden's telecommunications giant, signs agreement to supply $850 million in equipment and services to Chinese telecommunications operators (S)

headline: Europe Sees a Major Test for the New Bush Administration
abstract: Europeans see standoff between United States and China over collision of American spy plane and Chinese fighter jet as serious international crisis and test of Pres Bush's young administration; many European newspapers urge China to return American plane and crew; many also express concern that Bush will try too hard to be tough, rather than seek diplomatic solution (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: Security Talks?
abstract: Pres Bush's Mideast adviser, William Burns, continues shuttling between Israeli and Palestinian leaders; may have spurred resumption of talks between security commanders (S)

headline: Bid for Bankrupt Airline
abstract: International Lease Finance Corp and unidentified investor are offering to buy National Airlines, which is bankrupt (S)

headline: AOL Reorganization to Cost $965 Million
abstract: AOL Time Warner estimates that cost of reorganizing its merged businesses will be about $965 million, with more than half from job cuts; about $565 million is for eliminating jobs, and about $400 million is for canceling leases and other contracts; company is reducing its work force and closing businesses to meet its goal of $11 billion in cash flow this year; company has eliminated 2,400 jobs, or 2.8 percent of its work force since merger; chief executive Gerald M Levin comments (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar is little changed against euro and Japanese yen; in New York, euro settles at 85.05 cents, down from 85.07 cents on June 8; dollar is unchanged at 120.69 yen; graph; chart (S)

headline: Business Diary: Keyless in Seattle: Alarm Mystery Unsolved
abstract: Car alarms have been known to go off en masse in an earthquake, and Seattle has certainly had its share of earthquakes recently. But there was no apparent reason for the spate of Seattle car alarms that sounded a few weeks ago. The only clue to the mystery was that all the cars in question had keyless entry systems.

headline: People
abstract: Recent appointments and departures at advertising agencies noted (S)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: This Week, New York, weekly news magazine being introduced by Dennis Publishing, names Boston MediaWorks to handle advertising space sales in New England; ABC Radio Networks is joining with National Highway Traffic Safety Administration to introduce public service campaign to educate Americans about dangers of distracted driving; Dentsu Advertising opens Dentsu Asia, Singapore; Robert A Becker Euro RSCG acquires Cytocom, health care consulting agency; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: THE BOSS; The Discovery of Flying Solo
abstract: Philip M Condit, chairman and chief executive of Boeing Co, writes The Boss column on his career; photo (M)

abstract: Carole Gould Investing With column on investment strategies of Richard A Mayo, manager of $120 million Pelican Fund; photo; chart (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Chief of Webvan Resigns As Dot-Com Allure Fades  George T. Shaheen resigned as the chief executive of the Webvan Group, an online grocer, ending an 18-month tenure that symbolized both the allure and ultimate disappointment of Internet start-ups for established executives.    Mr. Shaheen, who had previously been the chief executive of Andersen Consulting, said in a statement that Webvan needed a ''a different kind of executive'' as it tries to cut costs and survive until late next year, when it expects to begin making a profit. [Page C2.]

headline: Powell Is in Driver's Seat On Plane Crisis Strategy
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L Powell and his deputy secretary and longtime friend, Richard L Armitage, have been managing minute-by-minute developments between Beijing and Washington over spy plane incident with China; efforts to win release of 24 American military personnel being detained in China provide first window on how new Bush administration handles crisis; Pres Bush has appeared before cameras at various points, but majority of step-by-step plan to win release of crew without permanently damaging United States-China relationship is handled by Powell and Armitage; talks over past three days are based in large part on letter mostly composed and then given by two men to China's ambassador in Washington, Yang Jiechi; Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld has deliberately stayed out of public eye, even though military personnel are detained, because administration does not want to lend too militaristic tone to standoff and risk counterreaction from Chinese military (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar posts slight gains; in New York, dollar settles at 124.85 yen, up from 124.47 yen; euro trades at 88.79 cents, down from 88.80 cents; graph; chart (S)

headline: Israelis Kill Protester, 12, Palestinians In Gaza Say
abstract: Palestinian boy, 12, is shot and killed by Israeli soldiers during demonstration in Gaza Strip; was fifth fatality in five-day-old cease-fire; despite incident, Israeli military reports sharp drop in number and seriousness of violent incidents during truce; Palestinian and Israeli security forces conduct first joint patrol in months; photo (M)

headline: Robert Igiel Retiring From Media Edge
abstract: Robert Igiel, longtime media executive, retires as president of broadcast division at Media Edge (S)

headline: DEBT CONFLICT IN ECUADOR
abstract: Paris Club of creditor countries suspends debt negotiations with Ecudor's government because of failure of Congress to approve tax revisions, giving creditors right to demand immediate reimbursement for interest payments that have been suspended since 1995; legislature's refusal to ratify highly unpopular increase of 3 percent in value-added tax also brings Ecuador close to violating restructuring agreement it signed with International Monetary Fund (S)

headline: A Rally as Growth Report Stirs Optimism
abstract: Stocks rise, eliminating Dow Jones industrial average's year-to-date loss; Nasdaq composite index gains 40.80, or 2 percent, to 2,075.68; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 18.53, to 1,253.05, up 1.5 percent; Dow advances 117.70, or 1.1 percent, to 10,810.05; Treasury bond prices tumble on dampened hopes for interest rate cuts; 10-year Treasury note falls 1 4/32, to 97 18/32, its yield rising to 5.32 percent, from 5.17 percent April 26; 30-year Treasury bond sinks 1 14/32, to 94, and yields 5.80 percent, up from 5.70; graph; table of key rates (M)

headline: Real Life, Real Emotion
abstract: Matt Donath letter, responding to May 31 article on hoax of Kaycee Nicole Swenson's life and death, relates his similar but true situation

headline: P.& G. to Abandon Some Product Lines and Report Quarterly Loss
abstract: Procter & Gamble will abandon some big initiatives, write off $900 million of under-performing assets and report loss for current quarter; stock retreats 3.5 percent, closing at $62.60; analysts question company's rosy long-term profit forecast; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen declines as Japanese stocks fall after unexpected drop in wholesale prices brings concern economy is headed for recession; in New York, dollar settles at 124.99 yen, up from 123.97 yen; graph; chart (S)

headline: LUCENT TO SELL SYSTEMS TO U.S. CELLULAR
abstract: Lucent Technologies wins four-year contract from US Cellular to supply company with wireless technology; agreement could produce as much as $100 million for Lucent (S)

headline: Top Executive Stepping Down At Audit Firm
abstract: James J. Schiro, the chief executive of the accounting firm PricewaterhouseCoopers, announced unexpectedly in Paris yesterday that he planned to step down as soon as a successor was found.    Mr. Schiro did not offer a reason and was unavailable for comment, the firm said.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Ex-President In Court
abstract: Joseph Estrada, former Philippine president, refuses to enter plea to perjury charge stemming from corruption scandal; court enters plea of not guilty on his behalf; photo (S)

headline: Trucker Found Guilty in Death of Immigrants
abstract: LONDON, April 5 â€” A Dutch driver was found guilty and sentenced to 14 years in jail today for killing 58 Chinese immigrants found suffocated in the sweltering airless container of his rig when it arrived in Dover after a Channel crossing last June.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Turkey: Hunger-Strike Toll Reaches 23
abstract: Former prison inmate starves to death, bringing death toll to 23 in hunger against strike against changes in Turkish prisons (S)

headline: Tokyo Journal; A Politician's Face Launches 1,000 Cash Registers
abstract: Poster with larger-than-life photograph of Japan's new prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, is hit with Japanese public; his Liberal Democratic Party has printed 385,000 posters but demand keeps rising; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Inaugural Message For Berlusconi
abstract: Giving Silvio Berlusconi, the conservative prime minister-elect, a taste of conflicts to come, 65,000 metalworkers took to the streets in major industrial cities to protest a wage increase offer that is less than the 3.1 percent inflation rate. Their contract expired in December and negotiations resumed in February. Protesters held banners saying, ''Comrade Berlusconi, we've done our part, now you sign the contract.''   Alessandra Stanley (NYT)

headline: CHINA: PROFIT AT OIL CONCERN
abstract: PetroChina says profit more than doubled in 2000, to 55.2 billion yuan ($6.7 billion) (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Distribution Deal For Dragon
abstract: Dragon NaturallySpeaking, computer dictation program, will be distributed in US and Canada by Learning Co, which will take exclusive retail responsibility for Dragon and L&H Voice Xpress (S)

headline: Jerez Journal; Candidate Lives in U.S., but So Does Half the State
abstract: Andres Bermudez, successful tomato grower in central California, returns to Jerez in central Mexican state of Zacatecas to run for mayor; he is among thousands of Mexicans who have migrated from Zacatecas, which sends more immigrants to US each year than any other state in Mexico; demographers estimate there are almost same number of Zacatecas natives living in US as there are in home state; map; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Ssangyong Has Profit
abstract: The Ssangyong Motor Company, a motor vehicle manufacturer that specializes in sports utility vehicles, made an operating profit of $20.7 million in the first quarter of this year from sales of 31,646 vehicles, up 7.8 percent from the first quarter of last year. The company, once part of the Ssangyong Group, was taken over by Daewoo Motor in the depths of Korea's economic crisis in December 1997 and then placed in the hands of creditors when the entire Daewoo Group collapsed in mid-1999. The creditors, looking for a buyer independently from efforts to sell Daewoo Motor to General Motors, have so far found no one willing to place a bid.   Don Kirk (NYT)

headline: A Small Town With a Tragic Past
abstract: More than a decade before Harold Frederick Shipman came to town, Hyde was the central location for another series of grisly murders.

headline: Bush Angers Europe by Eroding Pact on Warming
abstract: Pres Bush's abrupt decision to abandon Kyoto Protocol, treaty on global warming, provokes even more than usual level of anger and frustration in Europe; has aggravated mixture of grudges that have gnawed at Europeans for years; Europeans are angry that US appears oblivious to widespread environmental concerns across most of Europe; are frustrated that US, by virtue of size can undermine treaty negotiated by more than 100 countries; are depressed that there is not much they can do about it; US produces about 25 percent of gases associated with global warming, and refusal to meet goals set by Kyoto to reduce greenhouse emissions makes it difficult for competitors to do so (M)

headline: Article 2001051190085414422 -- No Title
abstract: Cyber Law Journal: Does a Parody Site Go Too Far?

headline: Britain Found to Violate Rights in Ulster Cases
abstract: European Court of Human Rights rules that Britain violated human rights of 10 members of Irish Republican Army and two civilians shot to death by security forces in Northern Ireland in 1980's and early '90's (M)

headline: Business; Click and Win: Inventors Cash In on Their Ideas
abstract: Ideas.com, one of several new Web sites that buy, sell or solicit intellectual property, allows inventors to send their ideas directly to corporate decision makers; inventors are spared headache and expense of patenting and developing ideas on their own, but there is tradeoff in that they must accept agreement intended to protect companies from lawsuits accusing them of stealing inventions; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Revised Inflation Estimate
abstract: Brazil's central bank raises its forecast for inflation this year to 5.8 percent from 4.8 percent, saying decline its currency may increase prices; cuts its estimate for economic growth to 2.8 percent from 4.3 percent; graph (S)

headline: Want Some Respect? A Few Jobs to Consider
abstract: Americans surveyed on their views of six professions express greatest respect for teachers, followed, in order, by doctors, social workers, athletes, lawyers and politicians; survey was conducted by Maritz Marketing Research (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Belarus: Date Set For Election Showdown
abstract: Belarus parliament sets Sept 9 election date, setting stage for contest between Pres Aleksandr Lukashenko and pro-democracy parties (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: European Union: Crackdown On Tobacco
abstract: European Parliament gives final approval to new tobacco code that will put graphic photos depicting harmful effects of smoking on cigarette packs (S)

headline: International Business Briefing
abstract: ASIA JAPAN: ECONOMIC ESTIMATE LOWERED Japan's government downgraded its estimate for economic growth in the final three months of last year, underlining the struggle ahead for the incoming administration of Junichiro Koizumi. Japan's gross domestic product rose a revised 0.7 percent in real terms in October, November and December from the previous quarter, compared with a preliminary estimate of 0.8 percent growth, as net exports dipped and as companies made modest spending plans amid increasing gloom in Japan, the world's second-largest economy.

headline: Article 2001051192227777102 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Cellular Bid
abstract: Wireless venture between Pacific Century CyberWorks and Telstra Corp will bid for Singapore's second-largest cellular operation, MobileOne Asia (S)

headline: Europe Sees Bush's Trip Exceeding Expectations
abstract: Many experts and newspapers across Europe call Pres Bush's five-country excursion success, at least compared with what they had expected; his brand of good cheer, first names and small jokes charmed hosts; photo (M)

headline: 'Marathon Man' and Root Canals
abstract: Robert D Markowitz writes My Job column on being endodontist, dentist who specializes in root canals; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Cutbacks in Yemen
abstract: State Department reduces personnel at its embassy in Sana, Yemen, and suspends services to public, citing increased threat since October 2000 attack on United States Navy vessel in Aden, country's main port (S)

headline: Spy Plane to Return In Pieces, as Cargo
abstract: American and Chinese officials have ''agreed in principle'' that a damaged American surveillance plane will be partly dismantled and removed from China on a giant Russian-designed cargo plane, the American Embassy said. The details are still under discussion, but it appears that an incident that has inflamed relations will soon be resolved.    Article, Page A8.

headline: PRIMEDIA NEAR DEAL FOR EMAP'S U.S. MAGAZINES
abstract: Primedia, which publishes Seventeen and New York magazines, will reportedly buy Emap's US magazine business for about $515 million; British company owns Petersen Publishing's 'enthusiast' titles, such as Skin Diver and Guns & Ammo (S)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Off the Testing Bandwagon

headline: 'Survivor' Admits Some Scenes Are Re-Enacted
abstract: Survivor television program executive producer, Mark Burnett, says he sometimes uses re-enactments of reality show's competitions, played out by stand-ins for contestants, to maintain high production values; says re-enactments never affect outcomes of contests or show; CBS says it has no problem with his use of stand-ins (M)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: HARDWARE ANTEC CUTTING 400 JOBS The Antec Corporation, which makes equipment to send Internet service and phone calls over cable television lines, said it was cutting 17 percent of its work force and taking a $5 million pretax charge. The company said it was eliminating 400 factory and management positions in Duluth, Ga.; Englewood, Colo.; El Paso; and Juarez, Mexico. (Bloomberg News)

headline: EGL, A GLOBAL FREIGHT COMPANY, TO LAY OFF 950 WORKERS
abstract: EGL Inc, international freight company, is cutting its US work force by about 15 percent to help trim $30 million in annual costs after unexpected first-quarter loss of $9.1 million; company dismissed more than 450 employees through May 5 and plans to cut 400 more full-time workers (S)

headline: Sour About Their Choices, Peruvians Are to Vote Today
abstract: Peruvians to vote for president, as polls show tightening race and many disillusioned or undecided voters; this is second presidential election in 13 months after collapse of Pres Alberto K Fujimori's government and intelligence network that throttled democracy through voter fraud, news media manipulation and torture; Alejandro Toledo has watched his lead in polls wither in face of allegations of drug use and sex with prostitutes, charges he denies; his opponent, Alan Garcia, a former president, coninues to anger some voters with failed populist policies as well as old charges of corruption; photo (M)

headline: JAPAN: ECONOMIC OUTLOOK WEAKENS
abstract: Bank of Japan describes economy as being in 'state of adjustment,' amid flagging exports and slowing production; assessment represents downgrade from bank's view a month earlier (S)

headline: Tougher U.S. Tone On Spy Plane Crisis
abstract: Striking a slightly stiffer tone, the Bush administration warned China that its relationship with the United States was being hurt and that it risked further harm with every day that the crew of an American spy plane remained in detention.    Senior American officials went out of their way to reject the kind of apology China has demanded for the collision between the American plane and a Chinese fighter jet.

headline: Israeli-Palestinian Negotiations Break Off After 4 Hours
abstract: Israeli and Palestinian security officials meet for four hours, but reportedly fail to reach agreement on American-initiated proposal that would extend fragile and partial 10-day-old cease-fire; closed session was mediated by CIA director, George J Tenet; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: 'Abortion Ship' Docks
abstract: Dutch trawler outfitted as floating abortion clinic docks in Dublin, Ireland; Women on Waves organization, which favors abortion rights, abandons plan to perform abortions for Irish women in international waters because it does not have proper license from Dutch authorities (S)

headline: West Bank Bloodshed Spoils Effort for Firm Cease-Fire
abstract: Bloodshed mars efforts to solidify a truce between Israelis and Palestinians; but both sides still seemed prepared to pursue efforts to end nearly nine months of violence; Israeli intelligence officer and a Palestinian man are killed in mysterious shootout on West Bank road near Jerusalem; photo (M)

headline: Article 2001050993666576900 -- No Title
abstract: Face-Recognition Systems OfferNew Tools, but Mixed Results

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: XBOX To Go On Sale Nov. 8
abstract: Microsoft Corp will start selling its Xbox video game system in US on Nov 8; photo (S)

headline: Fidelity Ending Ties To Its Main Agency
abstract: Fidelity Investments is parting ways with Hill, Holliday, Connors, Cosmopulos, citing agency's work for competitor (M)

headline: Profits More Than Double At Conoco and Exxon Mobil
abstract: Exxon Mobil Corp says first-quarter profit rose 51 percent, to $5.05 billion; sales rose 5.9 percent, to $57.3 billion; Conoco Inc's first-quarter profit rose 58 percent, to $616 million; sales rose 22 percent, to $10.6 billion (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: PC Distributor Cuts Jobs
abstract: Ingram Micro Inc, computer distributor, to cut 1,000 jobs to save $30 million to $40 million annually in response to slowing demand; will close Newark, Calif, distribution center and two returns processing centers and downsize Miami distribution center; will consolidate product management and restructure American sales operation, requiring $15 million charge this quarter (S)/

headline: Dumas Claims 2 Jospin Aides Knew of Payoffs In Elf Scandal
abstract: PARISâ€”  Facing a prison sentence in the Elf corruption scandal, France's former foreign minister, Roland Dumas, accused two heavyweights in Prime Minister Lionel Jospin's Socialist cabinet of having known about Elf's foreign payoffs when they were made in the 1990s.

headline: Only a Tool
abstract: Sue Aldine letter, responding to May 31 article about students' use of Powerpoint in their presentations, stresses need for actual understanding by pupils of subjects presented

headline: Harold Ridley, Eye Doctor, 94, Early Developer of Lens Implants
abstract: Sir Harold Ridley, opthalmologist who developed lens implants for cataract-scarred eyes, dies at age 94; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Yahoo Japan High-Speed Service
abstract: Yahoo Japan, Softbank Corp unit, to offer high-speed Internet service at sharply reduced prices in Japan; will work with Softbank's broadband service company, BB Technologies (S)

headline: Entrepreneur to Begin Proxy Fight for Computer Associates
abstract: Billionaire Texan Sam Wyly plans to begin proxy fight to take control of Computer Associates; will ask shareholders to oust current board and replace it with board that will elect him as its chairman; his plan is to split company into four divisions, which might eventually be spun off as independent companies; Wyly's plans set up battle between himself and billionaire Charles Wang, who founded company in 1976 (M)

headline: DREYFUS WILL PAY $20.5 MILLION TO SETTLE LAWSUIT
abstract: Federal Judge Harold Baer approves $20.5 million settlement of shareholder lawsuit that accused former Dreyfus Corp fund manager Michael Schonberg of buying stock for two mutual funds in companies whose shares he also owned (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: U.N. And Taliban Still At Odds
abstract: Talks fail to resolve differences between ruling Taliban and United Nations aid officials over planned survey to assess food distribution, with Afghanistan in midst of life-imperiling drought (S)

headline: FLORIDA BANK TO EXPAND ITS PRESENCE IN PENNSYLVANIA
abstract: FNB Corp, Florida bank with branches in Pennsylvania and Ohio, agrees to buy Promistar Financial Corp for $418 million in stock to expand in Western Pennsylvania (S)

headline: Lucent's Credit Rating Downgraded by S.& P.
abstract: Standard & Poor's Corp lowers credit rating of Lucent Technologies to junk status in move that may make it more costly for company to borrow money; says that falling demand for Lucent's communications equipment products will make it harder for company to increase cash flow and report profit (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Softbank Buying Access Provider
abstract: Softbank Corp acquires more than two-thirds of Tokyo Metallic Communications Corp, gaining larger foothold in high-speed Internet access market that is expected to grow to as much as 35 billion yen ($283 million); Softbank founder Masayoshi Son comments; photo (S)

headline: PrivateSector; Flying Americans Home, And Reaping Bonus Miles
abstract: There was, aside from President Bush, one chief executive who was particularly enthusiastic about the return of the 24 men and women detained in China when their spy plane made an emergency landing there two weeks ago. Splashed across the front pages of newspapers throughout the world -- and seen by millions on television -- was a white jet with a huge Continental Airlines logo carrying the returning crew members. ''We are tremendously proud,'' said Gordon M. Bethune, the airline's chief executive, who, after receiving word on Wednesday, announced to a cheering Houston Chamber of Commerce meeting that the Continental plane was ''in the air.''    It was, of course, the kind of feel-good publicity that companies can only dream of.

headline: Software Failure Halts Big Board Trading for Over an Hour
abstract: Failed software upgrade leaves investors unable to trade on New York Stock Exchange for nearly 1 1/2 hours; stocks drop broadly when trading resumes; NYSE's reputation for reliability is tarnished; photo (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None

headline: Suggestions Rise From the Floors Of U.S. Factories
abstract: Growing number of companies expand employee-involvement programs that encourage employees to suggest ways to save money; among them are Bic Corp, Dana Corp, Voyant Technologies Inc and Procter & Gamble Co; photos (M)

headline: Morgan Stanley's Earnings Decline 36%
abstract: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Co says net income for its fiscal second quarter ended May 31 fell to $930 million compared with $1.46 billion in year-earlier period; net revenue fell 15 percent, to $6.05 billion (S)

headline: Sizing Up AOL
abstract: Letter from Steven A Ludsin responds to June 21 article on Internet service providers by expressing his satisfaction with America Online

headline: Gotham Holdings is an illustration of just how volatile loosely regulated hedge funds can be.
abstract: Market Place column on Gotham Holdings, small fund that ended year down 90 percent as hedge fund's technology portfolio plunged (M)

headline: Micrel to Acquire Kendin Communications
abstract: Semiconductor manufacturer Micrel Inc agrees to buy Kendin Communications Inc for about $215 million (M)

headline: U.S. Resumes Its Spy Flights Close to China
abstract: United States resumes reconnaissance flights off coast of China for first time since collision on Apr 1 between Navy surveillance plane and Chinese fighter jet bruised relations between two nations; defense officials say unarmed Air Force plane flew mission in international airspace off China's northeastern coast during daylight hours and returned to its base without incident, and without being trailed by Chinese interceptors; China had demanded after Apr 1 incident that American patrols be halted off its entire coast; defense officials refuse to say when next intelligence-gathering mission would be ordered to fly near China (M)

headline: MY FIRST JOB; In a Friend's Death, A Turning Point
abstract: In short, I was to be the glue that held the program of 1,000 students together. I learned how to build consensus among people who had strong, radically different agendas, dividing resources between more popular, well-known competitive sports like rugby and recreational sports like the canoeing club. I learned a surprising amount about dealing with big egos.

headline: MediaTalk; Newspaper Budget Cuts Pinch Book Pages
abstract: Newspapers seem to be cutting space devoted to book reviews and weekend book sections as budgets become tight; photo (M)

headline: ROCKWELL TO CUT 1,000 JOBS AS EARNINGS FORECAST FALLS
abstract: Rockwell International, largest maker of factory-automation equipment, reduces fiscal third-quarter earnings and says it will eliminate 1,000 jobs (S)

headline: Hyundai Attributes Income Rise To Demand for Its Big Vehicles
abstract: Hyundai Motor Co says first-quarter income rose 28 percent, to $213 million; sold 211,000 vehicles overseas in quarter, up 10.7 percent, while number of vehicles sold in South Korea declined 6.7 percent, to 162,00) (S)

headline: Article 2001042894237225343 -- No Title
abstract: EDUCATION

headline: Once Burned, but Still Bold
abstract: SAN FRANCISCO -- Rarely does Robert E. Knowling Jr. find himself in a corporate situation that does not lend itself to a line borrowed from one of his favorite films. A staff meeting, say, might call for "Failure is not an option" (from "Apollo 13)," or a convention speech might include an aphorism from "The Lion King": "You can either run from it, or learn from it."

headline: The Boss: Imprints of the Holocaust
abstract: My grandfather told me I would be a businessman some day. When I was a child, he once sent me to buy him a pack of cigarettes, but the store did not have his brand. I knew if I bought a different brand, he would be annoyed and if I came back empty-handed, he would also be annoyed. I had to develop some judgment.

headline: Suit Against Drug Maker
abstract: TAP Pharmaceutical Products, joint venture of Abbott Laboratories and Takeda Chemical Industries, is sued on behalf of Medicare recipients over accusations that it overcharges for its prostate cancer drug, Lupron (S)

headline: For Lack of Support, U.N. Agency Shrinks Aid to Refugees
abstract: The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, responsible for the welfare of 22 million people, is making drastic cuts in staff and services because of diminishing support, especially from Europe.     The wealthy world loses interest when refugees are not in its own backyard or on television screens, refugee experts say. ''When we had Kosovo, we had no problems,'' said Soren Jessen-Petersen, assistant high commissioner for refugees, in a recent interview from the agency's Geneva headquarters. ''When we had the Great Lakes in Africa in '95-'96, no problems; Bosnia in the early 90's, no problems,'' he said, ''But when you've got the Afghan situation going on into the 20th year, we have enormous difficulties. And for most of the crises in Africa, there are enormous difficulties, too.''

headline: Former Philippine President Jailed on Corruption Charges
abstract: Former Pres Joseph Estrada of Philippines is arrested on charge of corruption and locked inside cell in central compound of National Police in Manila; Estrada, in taped radio statement, says he will answer all charges against him; he is second Philippine president to be ousted by nonviolent popular putsch, after Ferdinand E Marcos in 1986, and first to face humiliation of jail cell; charges against Estrada pale beside allegations against Marcos, who is said to have stolen tens of billions of dollars; officials say Estrada will be given private cell but no other special treatment; his critics, including Roman Catholic church, have demanded harsh conditions including mass lockup among common criminals; Filipinos came to see Estrada as running their country like gangland boss; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Australia: Australia: Bid For Drug Maker
abstract: Australia's Mayne Nickless Ltd bids $1 billion (US) in stock to take over drug maker FH Faulding & Co (S)

headline: In the economic slump, Madison Avenue carries on. Deals, new campaigns and layoffs.
abstract: Business of advertising goes on amid economic slump as large accounts change agencies, campaigns are approved and deals are made; economic slowdown is still having its effects as additional agencies lay off employees (M)

headline: AGENCY.COM TO CUT 350 JOBS AS LOSSES WIDEN
abstract: Agency.com, Internet-consulting firm, will cut 350 jobs, reducing work force by 25 percent; reports $10.3 million loss in first quarter; says founders Chan Suh and Kyle Shannon will sell their shares to Seneca Investments LLC; cash sale will raise Seneca's stake from 45.3 percent to 65.7 percent (S)

headline: Toyota to Introduce Another Hybrid Engine
abstract: Toyota Motor Co, hoping to expand on modest success of its Prius hybrid gas-electric car, announces new hybrid engine system that it says is simpler, cheaper and more versatile, though not as stingy with fuel; new engine, which combines gasoline and electric power, reduces fuel consumption by 15 percent and emissions by half (M)

headline: Reuters to Cut Senior Jobs
abstract: Reuters Group will eliminate unspecified number of management jobs as part of reorganization (S)

headline: GENERAL SEMICONDUCTOR SAYS IT EXPECTS LOWER SALES
abstract: Demand for General Semiconductor's power-management components remains weak, second-quarter sales will be lower than first quarter's, and company expects 1 cent to 3 cents profit a share (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Gesture To Opposition
abstract: Myanmar military junta, in its latest conciliatory move, allows National League for Democracy, party of Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, to reopen two branch offices outside capital that had been closed four years ago (S)

headline: Razorfish Founders Quit Top Management Positions
abstract: Razorfish co-founders Jeffrey A Dachis, chief executive, and Craig Kanarick, chief strategic officer, resign; will become co-chairmen of company's board; will be replaced by chief operating officer Jean-Phillip Maheu; company reports loss of $24.8 million on revenue of $42.7 million for first quarter (M)

headline: Disliking Coverage, Cleveland's Mayor Retaliates
abstract: Mayor Michael R White of Cleveland bars reporter and photographer from Plain Dealer from news conference at which he announces to rest of local news media that he will not seek re-election to fourth term; says Plain Dealer has been unfair in its coverage of him (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: DUCOMMUN INC., Long Beach, Calif., which supplies external tanks and components for the space shuttle, has agreed to buy the closely held Composite Structures L.L.C., Monrovia, Calif., to expand its business, which bonds metals together. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Private Sector; To the Rescue, Quietly, at Hyundai
abstract: Profile of Finbarr O'Neill, chief executive of Hyundai Motor America, who has succeeded stemming sales decline caused by quality problems, banal design and lineup that lacked sport utility vehicle; US sales jumped 82 percent in 1999 and 49 percent in 2000, and they are expected to rise 30 percent this year, to record 300,000 vehicles; typical Hyundai buyer is just 31 years old, 10 years younger than industry average, and Hyundai attracts slightly more women than men as buyers, the reverse of industry norm; photo (M)

headline: Israel Seizes Swath of Land in Gaza as Reply to Shelling, Then Pulls Out
abstract: Israeli forces seize swath of Palestinian-ruled territory in Gaza Strip, announce plans to hold land indefinitely as border-area buffer zone and begin setting up outposts; withdraw abruptly after US State Sec Colin L Powell criticizes move; attack follows night of fierce Israeli land, sea and air bombardment of Palestinian security installations in Gaza Strip in response to Palestinian mortar attack on Sederot, Israel; Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat scores Israeli attack; map; photo (M)

headline: Shares Slip on Fears That Fed's Rate Cuts Will Soon End
abstract: Stocks fell yesterday after reports of unexpected strength in retail sales and consumer confidence convinced some investors that the Federal Reserve would not reduce interest rates as aggressively as expected.    General Electric and Intel led the decline, while the New York Stock Exchange had its slowest day this year. All three major gauges had a losing week for the first time since April 6.

abstract: AFRICA

headline: World Briefing
abstract: ASIA

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: At-Home Access Dips
abstract: Telecommunications Reports International survey finds number of United States homes with Internet access fell in first quarter for first time, largely as result of failure of free Internet service provider as viable business model (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Real Estate Payout
abstract: British's Canary Wharf Group says it will return capital to shareholders earlier than expected because its development of financial center along Thames is ahead of schedule; will begin using $626 million (US) of its cash reserve to buy back shares (S)

headline: Investing Diary: The Fund Industry vs. Folios, Round 2
abstract: The mutual fund industry stepped up its pressure last week on a fledgling group of competitors that sell folios, or baskets of stocks sold in tandem as an alternative to mutual funds. The Investment Company Institute, the mutual fund industry trade group, petitioned the Securities and Exchange Commission to subject folios to the same laws as mutual funds, following up on a letter it sent to the S.E.C. last year.

headline: A Rising Tide for Value Funds
abstract: Strategic Insight survey finds that investors turned to value stock mutual funds in first half of year and that funds focusing on rapidly growing companies slumped (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Gasoline rises on concern that Pres Bush's energy plan will not do enough to prevent disruptions; in New York, gasoline for June delivery rises 3.36 cents, or 3.4 percent, to $1.0212 per gallon; graph; chart (S)

headline: Auction House Indictments Focus on the U.S. Executive
abstract: Prosecutors are poised to build case against A Alfred Taubman, former chairman of Sotheby's who is also its largest shareholder by indicting Taubman and Sir Anthony Tennant, onetime chairman of Christie's; Taubman and Tennant are charged with organizing scheme to fix fees charged to about 130,000 customers; Taubman is American citizen, and in this country, antitrust violations, which he is accused of, are criminal offense; even though prosecutors think Tennant is guilty of crime, his British citizenship will make it nearly impossible to extradite him as long as he remains in Britain because price fixing is not criminal offense there (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Railtrack Severance Deal
abstract: Survivors of two fatal train wrecks during Gerald Corbett's tenure as Britain's Railtrack chief executive and labor union leaders score his $1.4 million severance package, holding it rewards failure; photo (S)

headline: Skip the Climbing Wall: This Start-Up Just Wants to Hang On
abstract: Efforts of Michael Hejtmanek to create wireless software company Enterprise Air on shoestring budget described as typical of new-style technology start-ups now that era of easing financing has passed; he plans to make business applications for wireless devices that do not have to connect to Internet; photo (M)

headline: Business Dairy: In a Default Record, a California Flavor
abstract: Here is a statistic that at first glance should stimulate the salivary glands of bankruptcy lawyers and buyers of failed businesses: In the first quarter of 2001, the Standard & Poor's credit rating agency says, 48 companies worldwide defaulted on $37 billion of debt, making it the worst quarter for defaults â€” or, depending on how you look at it, the best. Of the defaulters, 41 were American companies.

headline: Oppenheimer Family and Partners Raise Offer for De Beers
abstract: Oppenheimer family and its partners raise their bid for De Beers after several major shareholders say they will oppose original offer; new terms increase cash portion of offer by $2, to $16.40 per share, raising total value of deal about 5 percent, to $18.2 billion; stock portion of bid, 0.43 share of Anglo American for each De Beers share, is unchanged; plan is intended to take De Beers private and unwind major cross-shareholdings between it and Anglo American; photo of Nicky Oppenheimer; graph; photo (M)

headline: In a Downsizing, Loyalty Is a Two-Way Street
abstract: I'M not particularly good at firing anyone. I know few people who are. On the few occasions when I was part of a group of managers considering layoffs, the process was agonizing. I found it excruciating to sit down with a list of people with whom I worked every day and assess who might be expendable.    For me, at least, the underlying question was always whether what we were about to do was fair to the company, the employees and those of us who would stay. Deciding the right thing to do was never easy.

headline: CRITICAL PATH RESTATES RESULTS
abstract: Critical Path, Internet messaging company that warned that there might be material misstatements in its recent revenue reports, says its revised financial results for third and fourth quarters are worse than feared; revises its revenue to $135.7 million from $155 million; annual loss is widened to $78.9 million from $57.2 million (S)

headline: 7 North Koreans Allowed to Leave China
abstract: Group of seven illegal North Korean immigrants who walked into the office of the United Nations High Commission on Refugees demanding political asylum are allowed by Chinese government to leave for a third country; photo (M)

headline: Latin American Markets Show a Glimmer of Hope
abstract: Spate of reassuring news brings renewed optimism in beleaguered Latin American stock markets; analysts say recent gains in Peru, Argentina and Brazil may be temporary because political and economic uncertainty continue; stock price graphs; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GERALD STEVENS INC., Fort Lauderdale, Fla., a leading marketer of floral products, said it would file voluntary Chapter 11 bankruptcy petitions.    CLOROX CO., Oakland, Calif., a leading maker of cat litter, said it would close a factory in Wrens, Ga., and dismiss 50 employees to lower costs.

headline: Merrill's Assets Unit Is Cutting Work Force
abstract: Merrill Lynch Investment Managers is cutting work force by 20 percent this year, from 4,500 people to 3,600, to cut costs; Lehman Brothers Holdings is adding up to 1,000 workers this year (S)

headline: Mbabane Journal; Wanted: Mates. Turn-Offs: Old Rules.
abstract: Swaziland has its first dating agency, one of more unusual harbingers of change in kingdom determined to resist change; for decades, rulers have outlawed political parties and attacked independent voices in news media and civil society, all in name of tradition; King Mswati III is still respectfully referred to, but trade union alliance is now clamoring for multiparty democracy and Internet cafes are sprouting up in bigger towns; photos; map (M)

headline: Robinson McIlvaine, 87; Envoy in '66 Guinea Crisis
abstract: Robinson McIlvaine, career diplomat who was at center of international incident while he was US ambassador to Guinea in 1966, dies at age 87; photo (S)

headline: New Merger Rules Force Railroads to Give Assurance of Competition
abstract: Federal regulators adopt tougher standards for mergers among major railroads that will force the few remaining rail freight companies with more than $250 million in yearly revenue to give written assurances that combining their operations will actually increase competition; Surface Transportation Board will also require biggest companies to give written assurances that any proposed merger will not interrupt existing service; several large railroads are opposed to what they see as increased regulation of industry (M)

headline: Declaration of Quebec City
abstract: We, the democratically elected Heads of State and Government of the Americas, have met in Quebec City at our Third Summit, to renew our commitment to hemispheric integration and national and collective responsibility for improving the economic well-being and security of our people. We have adopted a Plan of Action to strengthen representative democracy, promote good governance and protect human rights and fundamental freedoms.* We seek to create greater prosperity and expand economic opportunities while fostering social justice and the realization of human potential.

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Banking Profits Rise
abstract: Profits at Westpac Banking Corp, Australia, for six months ended March 31, 2001, rise 13 percent, to $480 million (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Changes At Viag
abstract: Viag Interkom says chief executive-chief operating officer Maximilian Ardelt has resigned; will be replaced by Keith Cornell; photo (S)

headline: Vodafone to Buy Stakes Held by British Telecom
abstract: Vodafone will issue $4.3 billion in new stock to help it acquire stakes in Japan and Spain that British Telecommunications must sell; Vodafone will pay 3.7 billion pounds ($5.3 billion), for British Telecommunications' 20 percent interests in Japan Telecom Co and its wireless unit, J-Phone Communications, raising its stakes to about 45 percent and giving it effective control; buying British Telecom's 17.8 percent of Airtel, leading wireless company in Spain, for 1.1 billion pounds ($1.6 billion) will bring Vodafone's stake in Airtel to about 92 percent; photo (M)

headline: France Debates Bill That Would Strip Its President of Immunity
abstract: French National Assembly debates bill that would strip Pres Jacques Chirac of immunity from prosecution, in response to mounting evidence of corruption scandal during his long tenure as mayor of Paris, from 1977 to 1995 (M)

headline: AT&T Wireless Fills Post
abstract: AT&T Wireless Group names Joseph McCabe Jr its chief financial officer and executive vice president (S)

headline: JUNIPER NETWORKS CUTS SALES FORECAST BY ONE-THIRD
abstract: Juniper Networks cuts second-quarter sales forecast by one-third, to about $200 million, setting off 18 percent decline in its stock price (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: ASIA

headline: Palestinians in Gaza Fire Shells at Israelis
abstract: Just hours after Israel withdrew from a corner of the Gaza Strip, Palestinian militants fired a volley of mortar shells at nearby Israeli settlements and military posts.

headline: Peacekeepers in Kosovo Seize 19 Macedonia Rebel Suspects
abstract: NATO peacekeepers in Kosovo, Serbia, detain 19 men suspected as members of ethnic Albanian rebel army fighting government forces in Macedonia; seize large cache of weapons and ammunition (M)

headline: INTERACTIVE ADS TAKE ON SUBSTANCE ABUSE
abstract: Partnership for a Drug-Free America introduces its first entirely interactive ad campaign to help teenagers learn about physiological effects of drugs like cocaine and heroin; banner ads were created by i-traffic, interactive marketing division of Agency.com (S)

headline: China, Fearing a Bolder U.S., Takes Aim on Proposed National Missile Shield
abstract: China's top arms control official, Sha Zukang, says country is working on low-cost ways to thwart antimissile defense being developed by US, and his comments reflect deep-seated Chinese concerns that US will developer closer ties with Taiwan's armed forces and that missile shield might make US more comfortable in rushing to island's defense (M)

headline: PRICELINE SHARES INCREASE ON WORD OF NEW INVESTMENT
abstract: Priceline.com Inc shares rise 30 percent after companies controlled by Li Ka-shing say they will increase stake in company; Hutchison Whampoa Ltd and Cheung Kong (Holdings) Ltd to buy 25 million shares for $4.40 each from company founder Jay Walker and a trust; will be biggest shareholders, owning about 30 percent of company (S)

headline: A Manhattan school starts a campaign to bring out the inner artists in New Yorkers.
abstract: School of Visual Arts' new advertising campaign dares potential students to 'make something'; campaign was created by Wieden & Kennedy; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Peru: More Pressure On Fujimori
abstract: Peruvian congressional committee investigating former Pres Alberto K Fujimori, who fled to Japan, calls on him to answer charges that he was involved in human righst abuses (S)

headline: Technology Briefings
abstract: INTERNET

headline: Bush Links Aid to Yugoslavia to the Extradition of Milosevic
abstract: Pres Bush tells Pres Vojislav Kostunica of Yugoslavia that American financial aid to Belgrade would depend on cooperation with war crimes tribunal at The Hague; Kostunica, in visit to Washington, does not commit to handing over his predecessor, Slobodan Milosevic, but does say he is pushing to have his country's law changed so that Belgrade can cooperate with international tribunal investigating war crimes against ethnic Albanians in Kosovo in 1999; White House views Kostunica's remarks as first step and evolution in his thinking from month ago, when he refused outright to hand over Milosevic; but administration officials continue to press him to move further and allow foreign trial of Milosevic (M)

headline: BRITAIN: VODAFONE ADVANCES TECHNOLOGY
abstract: Vodafone says it has become first to make live voice call over new high-speed wireless network (S)

headline: A Wider War on AIDS in Africa and Asia
abstract: Groups involved in fight against AIDS epidemic, having won big price cuts for drugs sold in poor countries, press for far broader line of attack costing billions of dollars at time when traditional sources of financial aid are shrinking; from UN and wealthy governments to public health groups and foundation researchers, groundwork is being laid for broad campaign in Africa and Asia; estimated 36 million people are infected worldwide, 70 percent in Africa; experts are looking beyond treatment drugs, with emerging issues encompassing more effective education and prevention programs, better clinics, larger numbers of trained health-care workers and imaginative development projects to put AIDS-devastated societies back on their feet (M)

headline: Police Killings of Israeli Arabs Being Questioned by Inquiry
abstract: Formal inquiry this month into police killing of 13 people in violent protests by Israeli Arabs in October raises questions about several of shootings, particularly whether police needed to fire live ammunition; it has also served as platform to air what Israeli Arabs say is discrimination that has gone on for decades; photo (M)

headline: Ulster Leader to Quit Despite Pleas From Britain and Ireland
abstract: Last-ditch talks conducted by Prime Minister Tony Blair and his Irish counterpart, Bertie Ahern, in Belfast fail to dissuade Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble from resigning this weekend as head of the Northern Ireland Assembly (M)

abstract: Alfie Kohn letter responds to May 24 article describing computerized preparation for standardized school testing

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Jordan: Sanctions-Busting Air Service
abstract: Royal Jordanian Airlines, in defiance of UN sanctions, resumes regular passenger service between Amman and Baghdad; map (S)

headline: Radio Deal in Canada
abstract: Chum Ltd., a big owner of Canadian radio stations, said today that it had agreed to buy the Vancouver television station CKVU from the CanWest Global Communications Corporation, Canada's biggest media company, for 125 million Canadian dollars ($80 million). Broadcasting regulators ordered CanWest to sell the station and another in Montreal after it acquired several stations from WIC Western International Communications Ltd. in July.

headline: Compressed Data; Tags Could Help Keep E-Book Links Alive
abstract: International Digital Object Identifier Foundation, nonprofit standards group that developed publishing industry format for tracking e-book content, says dozens of publishers have started to use format or plan to; publishers who assign identifiers to pieces of their books can use centralized online database to register those numbers and Web addresses where pieces can be found (M)

headline: G.E. Defends Deal to European Panel
abstract: General Electric Co and Honeywell International Inc present their case to European regulators for approval of their planned $40 billion merger (M)

headline: SECURITY GROUP TO SELL SERVICES
abstract: The CERT Coordination Center at Carnegie Mellon University said it would begin selling its computer security warnings to private clients. Since 1988, CERT, the taxpayer-financed computer security organization formerly known as the Computer Emergency Response Team, has issued warnings on viruses and security attacks to government agencies. Now CERT has formed the Internet Security Alliance to offer businesses immediate access to those warnings as well. Membership in the alliance costs $2,500 to $75,000, depending on size and participation level. CERT's current $3.5 million in financing comes from the government, most of it from the Defense Department. The new arrangement will help CERT cope with the heavy demand for its services, said Richard Pethia, its director. ''The relationship will allow us to grow the staff a little so that we'll be able to produce more information for everybody,'' he said.     Andrew Zipern (NYT)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Belarus: Former Soviet Republics Meet
abstract: Russian Pres Putin opens Minsk meeting of Commonwealth of Independent States, loose assembly of Russia and other former Soviet republics (S)

headline: Bush Talks With Dalai Lama Seen by China as 2d Jab in Eye
abstract: P> BEIJING, May 22 â€” It is just "a coincidence," of course, that President Bush will have a well publicized "private meeting" with the Dalai Lama on, of all days, May 23.

headline: Addenda: Deutsch to Close Office in Boston
abstract: Deutsch Inc. in New York, in its first significant contraction, said yesterday that it would close its Boston office, which has been open only since July 2000, on July 11.

headline: Bush Avoids Homecoming 'Hoop-De-La'
abstract: Pres Bush will not attend homecoming ceremonies at Whidbey Naval Air Station for 24 crew members released from China; Ari Fleischer, Bush's spokesman, says president does not think politicians must insert themselves into such tender moments with family and friends (S)

headline: Cranberry Growers Told to Cut Yields
abstract: Agriculture Dept imposes strictest limits on nation's cranberry crop in 30 years, in effort to reduce surplus that is more than half of a full year's harvest; cranberry growers, starting on Sept 1, will have to cut their yields by 35 percent, reducing nation's total crop to 4.7 million barrels from record 7.1 million barrels it was on pace to reach this year (S)

headline: Insurance Giants Are Near Merger Of $23 Billion
abstract: American International Group is close to deal to acquire American General for $23 billion in stock; deal would be blow to British insurer Prudential PLC, which reached its own agreement to buy American General for $26.5 billion (M)

headline: People
abstract: Gerry Frascione is named president and chief executive at BBDO Canada, succeeding Michael Fyshe, who resigned in February (S)

headline: Royal Dutch/Shell Profit Is Up 23%
abstract: Royal Dutch/Shell Group reports 23 percent increase in first-quarter profits, to $3.86 billion; sales rose 6 percent, to $47.8 billion; photo (M)

abstract: Let the Game Wars Begin

headline: Broad Rally on Wall Street Propels Dow Above 10,000
abstract: Stock prices rose broadly and vigorously today, bursting a menagerie of pent pessimism and hoisting the Dow Jones industrial average to close above 10,000 for the first time since March 15.

abstract: Bike Power: Tired Legs Get a Leg Up

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Legal Battle Over Internet Music Escalates
abstract: Recording Industry Association of America files countersuit in Manhattan federal court against group of Internet broadcasters in intensifying legal battle over payment structure for music played on Web; at issue is whether Web broadcasters that allow users to personalize music they hear should require separately negotiated license from record companies or whether they should be eligible for compulsory licensing like traditional radio (S)

headline: 6 Red Cross Workers Slain Delivering Medicine in Congo
abstract: Six workers of the International Committee of the Red Cross were shot and hacked to death Thursday in northeast Congo, but a spokesman for the organization said today that it ``had no idea'' who carried out the attack, the worst on the group's aid staff in years.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bill Would Ban Human Cloning
abstract: Draft bill in Canada would ban cloning of human beings (S)

headline: Article 2001052293563532598 -- No Title
U.S. Response Guarded, Calls Downed Plane 'Tragic Error'
abstract: WASHINGTON, April 23 â€” The United States and Peru offered scant information today about the downing of an American missionary flight, playing down what the White House called an "isolated incident" and trying to keep it from scuttling one of its few successful counterdrug operations.

headline: Shares Finish Almost Flat After Latest Fed Rate Cut
abstract: Blue-chip stocks fall modestly, while technology stocks post slight gains after Federal Reserve lowers interest rates for sixth time this year; Dow Jones industrial average drops 37.64 points, or 0.4 percent, to 10,434.84, while Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 5.69 points, or 0.5 percent, to 1,211.07; Nasdaq composite index gains 10.12 points, or 0.5 percent, to 2,074.74; graph; chart (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stocks Decline on Tension Between U.S. and China  Stocks declined broadly and sharply as worries about weak corporate earnings continued and concern mounted about rising tension between the United States and China.    The Nasdaq composite index fell 57.29 points, or 3.1 percent, to 1,782.97. The Dow Jones industrial average did little better, closing at 9,777.93, down 100.85 points, or just more than 1 percent. And the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 14.46 points, or 1.3 percent, to 1,145.87. [Page C12.]

headline: TELLABS CUTS JOBS
abstract: Tellabs Inc, maker of communications equipment, says it is cutting 6 percent of its work force, or about 550 workers; reports first-quarter net income of $123 million, up 13 percent from year earlier, on sales of $772 million, up 21 percent; photo (S)

headline: Investors Are Rushing to Mexico, Despite Slowing Growth
abstract: Foreign investors have been investing heavily in Mexico despite that country's slowing growth; Mexico received $3.6 billion in direct foreign investment in first quarter, 17 percent increase over period last year; international investors are ignoring Mexico's downturn and looking decades in advance at Mexico's favorable long-term growth prospects; graph (M)

headline: G.M. AND RUSSIAN CAR PRODUCER SET TO START VENTURE
abstract: Joint venture agreement between General Motors Co and Russia's biggest car producer, AvtoVAZ, becomes official, starting point of $332 million project; venture will begin producing Russian all-terrain vehicles next fall and is expected to reach annual production of 75,000 cars by 2003 (S)

headline: Some Suffer Tax Hangovers From Microsoft Option Spree
abstract: Some financially naive Microsoft Corp workers who incurred big tax bills by exercising stock options, turned options into stock and borrowed against shares to pay taxes face bankruptcy now that stock has plummeted; midlevel employee holds broker at Salomon Smith Barney, which runs option program for Microsoft, pushed him to take such risks and then sold his shares to pay margin loan as price dropped, leaving him with no stock and big tax debt; graphs of tax impact on employees and tax benefits to company of options (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Heating oil rises on speculation that inventories will be left low as refiners concentrate on making gasoline; in New York, heating oil for July delivery rose 3.14 cents, or 3.9 percent, to 83.28 cents per gallon; graph; chart (S)

headline: Coke's New Ad Campaign Returns to Sentimentality
abstract: After months of soul-searching about the inner meaning of its sodas, the Coca-Cola Company announced an advertising campaign yesterday that it hopes will jump-start sales of its flagship brand at a time when the company is struggling to gain some momentum.    To the ire of investors, Coke has been virtually bereft of a major advertising theme since last year, when it dumped its commercials featuring touching reunions gone hopelessly awry because they were not toasted with Coke. The company facetiously entitled it the Moments campaign, but many viewers found it more offensive than funny.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Trade Dispute With Japan
abstract: China retaliates for higher Japanese duties on farm products by placing high duties on some Japanese manufactured goods (S)

headline: Chinese Were 'All Over' Spy Plane, Envoy Says
abstract: HAIKOU, China, April 3 â€” Expectations of a promised meeting between United States diplomats and the detained crew of an American spy plane increased this evening when several of the diplomats abruptly left a luxury hotel here in the tropical capital of Hainan in the company of armed Chinese military police.

headline: House Hearings on Ford and Firestone Clarify Little
abstract: Rep Billy Tauzin further muddles dispute between Ford Motor Co and Bridgestone/Firestone Inc over tire safety, holding he has data showing seven of tire models Ford is using to replace 13 million Firestone tires might have higher failure rates than those being replaced, House committee hearing; identifies only two and says statistics may not be valid; two Democrats on committee get access to data, after long wrangling, but are pledged to secrecy; Tauzin says he will give data to National Highway Traffic Safety Administration and to Ford; Deputy Sec Michael Jackson says agency will weigh data immediately; Ford chief exec Jacques A Nasser and Firestone chief exec John T Lampe exchange charges about whether Ford Explorer's safety problems are caused by tires or poor design (M)

headline: WELLS FARGO EXPECTS A $1.3 BILLION CHARGE
abstract: Wells Fargo & Co will take $1.13 billion in second-quarter charges (S)

headline: West's Slump and Intifada Hit Israel's Pocketbook
abstract: Israeli economy, booming until last fall, slows to crawl, battered by eight months of Palestinian violence and bludgeoned by Nasdaq; at least 25 hotels have closed, white-hot real estate market in high-tech hinterlands of Tel Aviv has cooled and Jerusalem apartments in range of guns are vacant; bank and airline losses, rising unemployment and falling exports and foreign investments also noted; graphs (M)

headline: Havas Makes a Move And Adds a Client
abstract: Havas Advertising is expected to announce it will acquire McKinney & Silver from MarchFirst; estimates of purchase price by trade publications are $20 million to $35 million; Havas's plans call for McKinney & Silver to operate as autonomous unit; Credit Suisse Group names Euro RSCG Wnek Gosper, part of Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas, to handle its worldwide branding account, with billings estimated at $20 million (S)

headline: Where Bush's Team Disengages, Russia Looks for New Roles in Diplomacy and Trade
abstract: Russian officials say Pres Vladimir V Putin is trying to strengthen Moscow's bonds with Europe, increase Russia's role as mediator in regional conflicts and open new trade links with Asia; say Putin is acting in part to gain leverage for day when he and Pres Bush meet to chart new agenda in relationship that has been cut adrift by disputes and changes of administration in both countries; say Putin seeks hedge against any Bush administration attempt to exclude Russia from security decisions that affect Russia's interests; photo (M)
