headline: XEROX TO CUT 1,500 JOBS AND SOME PRODUCTS
abstract: Xerox Corp plans to stop making personal copiers and desktop inkjet printers and to eliminate 1,500 jobs as part of its plan to cut $1 billion in costs by the end of the year; president Anne M Mulcahy says company will discontinue products within six months (S)

headline: U.N. Expert: Crucial Battle Against AIDS Is Prevention
abstract: UNITED NATIONS, May 25 â€” Peter Piot, the epidemiologist who has been coordinating an international campaign against AIDS since 1995, is spending less time worrying about the price of drugs and more about the shortage of condoms.

headline: Shares Fall on Slow Growth in Phone Equipment Sales
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average drops 66.49 points, to 10,623.64; Nasdaq composite index falls 15.64 points, to 2,028.43; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declines 5.51 points, to 1,214.36; Treasury bond prices fall; 10-year note's yield rises to 5.24 percent; chart; list of key rates (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Telecom Ties
abstract: KDDI Corp and China Unicom Group sign technology and roaming pact that will eventually let KDDI customers use their mobile phones in China and some Unicom customers use their phones in Japan; accord is based on CDMA technology developed by Qualcomm Inc (S)

headline: E-Commerce Report; Online billing, an idea that looked like a winner, has held its own but has not caught on in a big way.
abstract: Bob Tedeschi column on fate of online billing, promising Internet application that has not caught on in big way; only small percentage of Internet users use Internet to pay any bills and most of them still get billing statement on paper through mail; few actually go to single Web site to view incoming bills and electronically pay them; photo (M)

headline: Planning the Digital Smorgasbord
abstract: First article in weekly series The Media Giants, examining business strategies of major media conglomerates, focuses on AOL Time Warner; chief executive Gerald M Levin outlines plans to deliver media smorgasbord to every home in nation, using subscription-based, on-demand approach, interview; company stands alone among media rivals because it controls major Internet service and major cable television operation; chairman Stephen M Case cites plan to knit together PC, TV, phone and stereo, interview; co-chief operating officer Richard D Parsons says goal is to create new industries; graphs of company's, stock and financial data; tables comparing company's roles in various media industries; photo (L)

headline: U.N. Sanctions Didn't Stop Iraq From Buying Weapons
abstract: Report by American arms control experts, Gary Milhollin and Kelly Motz, who combed through unpublished reports by disbanded arms inspection commission, say they found evidence that Iraq continued to buy prohibited weapons or parts long after UN sanctions were imposed in 1990; say many of purchases appear to have been made in Central and Eastern Europe; found documents concerning illegal sales or potential sales by companies in Ukraine, Belarus and Romania; says Pres Saddam Hussein's procurement network is alive and well and has been working steadily despite sanctions; report comes as UN Security Council debates new oil-for-food program for Iraq that would lift most restrictions on sales of civilian goods (M)

headline: The Search for E.T. Yields Earthly Cheats
abstract: Stanford University doctoral students Ilya Mironov and Philippe Golle compose set of security schemes that can help thwart those trying to claim computing work that they did not actually complete on SETIhome program, computing project that harnesses power of personal computers to search for signs of extraterrestrial intelligence; photo (M)

headline: Role of U.S. Companies in Colombia Is Questioned
abstract: Questions are raised in American Congress and even by Colombian officials about logic of relying on private American companies for operations that are not open to public scrutiny; at issue are American pilots, radar operators, former Army Special Forces trainers and other former military personnel who have been under private contracts to fly spray planes and helicopters, train and advise Colombian military personnel, repair high-tech machinery and help pave remote airfield runways; policy makers in Washington question whether US should be spending tens of millions of dollars annually on contractors when Colombian officials say Colombians could be trained to complete same operations for much less money; human rights groups say use of contractors provides way for American government to deny responsibility if anything goes wrong; some policy makers fear that use of contractors could grow if Colombia's conflict with guerrillas escalates (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Future May Be More Uncertain For Technology
abstract: Market Place column on Merrill Lynch report showing technology shares remain expensive, even at their current depressed levels; report holds true earnings of such companies began to deteriorate three years ago, before economy soured, even as their reported earnings soared; cites use of stock options in lieu of higher salaries as big contributor to reported earnings (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Bond Market Gives Signals Of an Upturn
abstract: Recent performance of US government bonds suggests that these investors are already looking ahead to economic rebound; over last two months, longer-term Treasury securities have been selling off, pushing their yields higher, while shorter-term rates have been relatively stable (M)

headline: Cashing in On the World's Energy Hunger; Caterpillar Is Riding High on Demand for Diesel Generators
abstract: Soaring demand for Caterpillar Inc's diesel-powered generators is bolstering profits in fast-growing unit and helping stabilize company that is coping with slowing sales of construction and mining equipment; analysts say global energy demand is expected to continue to rise for several year, raising company's long-term prospects; graphs; photos (M)

headline: Concern Grows That Crew May Not Be Free Soon
abstract: American diplomats are denied second meeting with crew of spy plane being held in Hainan Island, China; United States considers scaling down its diplomatic presence on island as concern grows that crew might not be released soon; focus of China's state media shifts from charges of American responsiblity to fate of Chinese pilot who has been missing since he ejected from his aircraft after collision with plane; photos (M)

headline: Former Argentine President Arrested in Arms Conspiracy
abstract: Former President Carlos Saul Menem, whose 10 years in office were marked by sweeping economic reform but also by reports of government corruption, was placed under house arrest today by a federal judge investigating his involvement in a conspiracy to smuggle arms to Croatia and Ecuador between 1991 and 1995.

headline: Article 2001051990118692048 -- No Title
abstract: Cyber Law Journal: Hacker Gadfly at Center of New Suit

headline: Production At Factories Decreases For 7th Month
abstract: Federal Reserve says production at factories, mines and utilities declined 0.3 percent in April, after falling 0.1 percent in March; Commerce Department figures show inventory-to-sales ratio was 1.37 months in March; graphs (M)

headline: AUTONOMY EXPECTS PROFIT SHORTFALL
abstract: In another sign that the slowdown in the United States economy is spreading to Europe, Autonomy, a British software company, warned that first-quarter profit would fall below analyst estimates. Its shares fell 43 percent, to £3.25, or $4.67. Autonomy now expects to earn 4 cents a share for the quarter that ended March 31 on revenue of $14 million to $15 million. Earnings will be reported on April 26. Michael Lynch, the chief executive, said the slowdown in orders for software came suddenly. ''Almost without exception,'' he said, ''we have been informed that purchasing decisions have been delayed.''     Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

headline: Auto Sales Were Down Last Month
abstract: Auto industry sold 16.6 million vehicles in April at seasonally adjusted annual pace, 10 percent decline from year earlier; General Motors, Ford Motor Co and Chrysler unit of DaimlerChrysler all post declines in sales of 15 percent to 18 percent, compared with sales in April 2000; Toyota reports increase of 6.7 percent, while BMW's sales soared 30.5 percent; photo (M)

headline: MOST WANTED: DRILLING DOWN/Internet Access; Higher Speeds Take More Time
abstract: Nielsen/Net Ratings finds small but growing number of home users with higher-speed Internet connections tend to log on more often and stay online for longer periods; graphs of connection speed and time spent on line; photo (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Jobless Rate Continued Its Ascent in April, to 4.5%  The unemployment rate, which has been inching up since a low of 3.9 percent in October, rose again in April to 4.5 percent from 4.3 percent in March.    The work force fell last month by an estimated 223,000 jobs on top of a loss of 53,000 jobs the previous month, the Labor Department reported. The back-to-back job losses indicated to some analysts that the already sluggish economy has become even weaker and may be nearing, or even in, a recession. [Page A1.]

headline: I.R.S. Guide Focuses on Consultants
abstract: Internal Revenue Service is teaching its auditors how to uncover tax cheating by self-styled business consultants and by corporations that use former employees as consultants to avoid withholding income, Social Security and Medicare tax; new audit technique guide, posted at IRS Web site, instructs auditors to check business records of consultants to determine whether they are improperly deducting vacations and family travel on their tax return (M)

headline: U.S. MAY WITHHOLD MAIN  RADAR  ITEM ON  TAIWAN'S  LIST
abstract: Pres Bush's senior national security aides recommend he defer sale to Taiwan of advanced destroyers equipped with highly sophisticated Aegis radar system; favor sale of range of less advanced weapons; reportedly hold Taiwan lacks skill to handle Aegis; Bush faces pressure from conservative Republicans to provide Taiwan with all of arms it seeks; administration says standoff with China over American spy plane will not influence decision (M)

headline: Jordan Limits Entry of West Bank Palestinians
abstract: Jordan limits entry by Palestinians from West Bank; Palestinians complain but Jordanian officials say rules were adopted at urging of Palestinian Authority, out of concern that Israel might order mass expulsions; photo of Min Awad Khleifat (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Gypsies Plan To Sue I.B.M.
abstract: Gypsy groups say they will sue IBM, asserting that its tabulating machines helped Nazi Germany track and identify people killed during Holocaust; estimated 600,000 gypsies are believed to have died at hands of Nazis (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Fed Cuts Interest Rates In 6th Reduction This Year  The Federal Reserve cut its benchmark interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point and signaled that its campaign to revive the economy might be entering its final stages.    The rate cut was the sixth this year. In holding to a quarter-point reduction, the Fed suggested that it wanted to slow the pace of its response to the downturn while it waits to see the full effect of its earlier steps. [Page A1.]

headline: U.S. Student Says Russia Tried to Recruit Him
abstract: us student says

headline: Patents; Inventors focus on making credit cards easier to carry and easier to process.
abstract: Kurt Campisano patents credit card that holder can use without carrying card; card holder can instead enter phone number with personal identification number into reading device already in use among merchants; James Yang patents combination drivers license and credit card; James Johnson patents device to prevent credit and smart card reading machines from confiscating bent cards (M)

headline: Rightist Chief In Colombia Shifts Focus To Politics
abstract: Carlos Castano, commander of right-wing paramilitary army that has terrorized villagers in Colombia for years, resigns to oversee group's political wing; development reflects divisions in organization, whose 8,000 members have massacred villagers believed to be collaborating with leftist rebel groups warring against government; experts speculate that Castano and others in nine-member command differ over dealing with recent government attacks; say hard-line paramilitary leaders favor retaliation and Castano opposes such response (M)

headline: OPEC Maintains Output Levels, With Another Look in July
abstract: Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries decides to delay output rise; will meet July 3 to weigh output rise again should Iraq's plan to halt exports spur steep price rise; is gambling that it can maintain relatively high though stable prices in near term; analysts expect individual nations like Saudi Arabia to fill in for Iraq and informally supply more oil to major markets, but fear moves may not be enough; photo (M)

headline: Private Sector; Standing Up to the Men, With Nerve and a Step Stool
abstract: With Jacques Nasser of Ford, Jack Welch of General Electric, Christopher Galvin of Motorola and 54 other Fortune 500 chief executives in attendance, Sheila Wellington, president of Catalyst, the nonprofit women's research organization, had the right audience last Monday -- and pulled no punches. Speaking in New York at her group's annual awards dinner, she said companies could no longer use the ''pipeline excuse'' -- that women entered the work force later than men -- to explain the lack of women at the top of corporate America.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Map Guides Cabinet Changes
abstract: Regional politics appears to have been major consideration in appointment of new top prosecutor, Shin Seung Nam, and dismissal of justice minister, both from Cholla (S)

headline: SWISS REINSURANCE TO BUY CONNING & CO. FROM METLIFE
abstract: Swiss Reinsurance Co will buy Conning & Co from MetLife Inc, expanding its asset-management business (S)

headline: Cable's Contents Shine a Harsh Light on German Diplomacy
abstract: BERLIN, May 22 â€” A leaked diplomatic cable from the German Embassy in Washington has strained German-American relations, raised questions about Germany's relationship with the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, and prompted a furious fight between the top officials who shape German foreign policy.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Tobacco Purchase
abstract: Gallagher Group to buy Austria Tabak for $1.8 billion in cash and assumed debt; merger will make Gallagher Europe's fourth biggest tobacco maker; includes Austrian govenrment's 41.13 percent stake; Gallagher shares fall after company says it will issue new shares to help finance deal; stock price graph (S)

headline: Private Sector; She's Good at Playing With Numbers
abstract: Brief interview with Rosario Marin, Pres Bush's nomineee for United States Treasurer (S)

headline: Investing; The Planners Pounce on the Tax Cut
abstract: the planners pou

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hewlett-Packard Moves In With Officemax
abstract: OfficeMax signs agreement to make Hewlett-Packard computers only personal computers sold in chain's 1,000 stores nationwide; deal replaces similar one OfficeMax had with Gateway (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: A Deadly Anachronism
abstract: Hundreds of people in northern Afghanistan, living on tea and bread in a drought-hit region, have scurvy, which is caused by a lack of vitamin C and leads to skin discoloration, bleeding gums and eventually death, Doctors Without Borders reports. ''This disease should not exist in the 21st century,'' said Stephan Goedgebuur, the group's regional coordinator.   Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

headline: In Stock Prices, What a Difference a Digit Makes
abstract: BOTTOM FISHERS beware. When stock prices sink to single digits, the odds are that they are sunk for good.     That is the conclusion of a study by Thomas W. Watts, Internet infrastructure analyst at Merrill Lynch. Going back to 1985, Mr. Watts studied the trading of 1,900 publicly held companies spanning the technology sector. He found that of those companies whose stocks had fallen to single digits, only 3.4 percent rebounded to $15 or higher within the next year. Most of those that didn't bounce back in the first year never did.

headline: Suits Accuse Drug Makers of Keeping Generics Off Market
abstract: Seventeen consumer groups file several lawsuits against Barr Laboratories and AstraZeneca, accusing them of illegally keeping generic version of important breast cancer drug, tamoxifen, off market; say 1993 agreement between both companies cost breast cancer patients tens of millions of dollars in overpayments; seek to recoup excessive payments; action comes as federal legislators and regulators are trying to stop industry's efforts to block more sales of generic drugs (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Value Investors Warm to Technology Stocks
abstract: Professional value investors like Bruce C Baughman, who manages money for Franklin Templeton, are starting to buy technology stocks; that could provide modest glimmer of hope for embattled sector, though value investors are sticking at least initially to stocks with industrial bent, like semiconductor and electronic equipment makers; photo (M)

headline: Suicide Bomber Kills 5; Israel Retaliates in Jet Strikes
abstract: A Palestinian suicide bomber killed at least 5 Israelis and wounded more than 100 at a bustling shopping mall here this morning. By evening, Israel had retaliated by unleashing warplanes against the West Bank and Gaza Strip for the first time since the 1967 war.     It was the deadliest day of the year in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. At least nine Palestinians were killed in F-16 fighter jet attacks on Nablus and Ramallah, and a sixth Israeli, an army officer, was killed in his car on a West Bank road.

headline: Lawyers and Accountants Expect Windfall From Estate Tax Repeal
abstract: Lawyers and accountants expect windfall from repeal of Federal estate tax; those who paid to have will and estate plan drafted under old law need to pay to have it reviewed and in many cases rewritten; under new law, amount exempt from estate taxes and rate of tax on larger sums are slowly reduced beginning in 2002 until 2010, when estate tax is repealed for one year; law is then reinstated in 2011 (M)

headline: Article 2001062791796782068 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: Todd Sweeney, 82, Is Dead; Briton in Vital D-Day Raid
abstract: Col Todd Sweeney, who commanded platoon of glider-borne British infantrymen in storied raid that captured two vital bridges in first moments of D-Day, dies at age 82; photo (M)

headline: Broad Rally on Wall Street Pushes Dow Above 11,000
abstract: Aday after the Federal Reserve lowered short-term interest rates for the fifth time this year, stocks of all stripes posted strong gains today and bond prices rose as investors belatedly roared their approval.

headline: Dream Prize Draws Closer For Murdoch
abstract: Rival media companies brace for Rupert Murdoch to become even fiercer competitor in American television industry if his News Corp's acquires DirecTV along with rest of General Motors' Hughes Electronics division; DirecTV, fast-growing satellite television service, has become force in arena once fully controlled by cable industry; would give new leverage to News Corp, already TV power with its Fox network; table of Hughes holdings (M)

headline: Standing Out in a Tough Crowd; A Ford Model Wins Rare German Praise
abstract: Germany's big car magazines rank Ford Motor Co's renovated Mondeo, midsize sedan that sells for $20,000, as best car in its class, ahead of of home-market favorite, Volkswagen Passat; magazines have never had much use for cars from Ford of Europe; Ford's market share in Europe has inched up in last few months, thank in large part to new Mondeo; Ford earned profit of $88 million in first quarter after losing $1.13 billion last year; David W Thursfield, Ford of Europe's chief executive, comments; charts; photos (M

headline: Robert L. Crowell, 92, Head Of Reference Book Publisher
abstract: Robert L Crowell,

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: True North Holders Approve Takeover
abstract: True North Communications shareholders approve takeover by Interpublic Group of Cos (S)

headline: Reporter's Notebook; Smoking? At a Conference on Health?
abstract: Reporter's Notebook vignettes from United Nations conference on AIDS (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Schools Get Tool to Track Students' Use of Internet  ESniff, which makes a program that monitors corporate Internet networks, plans to make a modified version of it available to schools today. A federal law requires almost all schools and libraries in the United States to choose a ''technology protection measure'' to protect minors from inappropriate online materials.    The program, eSniff Solution, is a so-called packet sniffer. Because all Internet traffic is broken into data packets before being sent from one computer to another, a packet sniffer can sit on the network and watch the traffic go by, sniffing for the information it has been programmed to sense. [Page C6.]

headline: SBC Is Penalized On Ameritech Deal
abstract: SBC Communications has paid Federal Communications Commission more than $17 million since January for failing to meet requirements of its 1999 purchase of regional phone company Ameritech Corp; FCC says from September to January, company missed targets used to monitor treatment of rivals like Covad Communications Group Inc and Allegiance Telecom Corp when leasing lines and other pieces of its network (S)

headline: Orthodoxy and Catholicism Collide in a Ukrainian Town
abstract: Town of Sukhovolya in western Ukraine is battleground of ethnic and religious conflict, wrought by centuries of competition between Orthodoxy and Catholicism; Orthodox believers are now building their own church, within sight of building they had shared with Greek Catholics; photo; map; Pope John Paul II, saying Mass in nearby Lviv, speaks in his native Polish, telling Roman Catholics to leave behind 'sorrowful past' (M)

headline: As California Sweats It Out, 2 Funds Profit
abstract: California Public Employees' Retirement System and California State Teachers' Retirement System have increased their positions in electric power and natural gas companies as California continues to experience energy crisis; funds' stakes in 10 companies singled out by politicians have risen to $1.6 billion, up about 45 percent in last 11 months (M)

headline: Disney Has Net Loss Because of Charges
abstract: Walt Disney Co posts fiscal second-quarter net loss of $567 million because of $1 billion in charges and write-offs and change in accounting; excluding those items, Disney's profit rose 33 percent; revenue fell 3.8 percent, to $6.05 billion (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Jobless Rate Falls Slightly As Economy Remains Weak  The economy remained weak in May as American employers continued to cut jobs, though at a slower pace than during the previous two months, the government reported. The unemployment rate fell to 4.4 percent from 4.5 percent. Analysts said the drop, the first in nine months, masked an economy and a labor market that were worsening. Over all, employment fell by a seasonally adjusted 19,000 jobs, leaving it virtually unchanged since January. [Page A1.]    Nasdaq Ends the Week Down 4.5%  Investors embraced battered technology stocks, touching off a modest rally. The Nasdaq composite index gained 38.95 points, or 1.9 percent, to 2,149.44, but ended the week down 4.5 percent, its worst performance since the first week of April. The Dow rose 78.47 points, or 0.7 percent, to 10,990.41, cutting its loss for the holiday-shortened week to 0.14 percent. And the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 4.85 points, or 0.4 percent, to 1,260.67, off 1.4 percent for the week. [C3.]

headline: Dell to Cut Up to 4,000 Jobs In Move on Market Share
abstract: Dell Computer Corp, signaling it will not ease personal computer price war, says it will cut 3,000 to 4,000 jobs, about 10 percent of its work force, over next two quarters in bid to raise market share; again says it expects to meet previous estimates for first quarter ended May 4; says it will force most United States employees to take unpaid time off in second quarter; will take one-time pretax charge of $250 million to $350 million in second quarter (M)

headline: Compressed Data; Panel on Encryption Turns Into Pessimistic Assessment of Privacy
abstract: Researchers and policy makers taking part in recent Columbia University panel discussion are pessimistic about whether encryption can safeguard Internet; say broader security issue on Internet involves privacy, with technology alone unable to bring about privacy protections; photo (M)

headline: America the Roughneck (Through Europe's Eyes)
abstract: Analysis: vote that ousted United States from United Nations Human Rights Commission was prompted by irritation among European nations at themes of Bush administration; torrent of hostile articles in Europe has greeted Pres Bush's first three months in office; their chief theme has been arrogance of what German weekly Der Spiegel calls 'snarling, ugly Americans'; diplomats attribute embarrrassing snub to United States to seeming absence of 'dialogue and respect' in Bush administration's approach to outside world; photo (M)

headline: FAB INDUSTRIES, MAKER OF TEXTILES, WILL SHUT 2 FACTORIES
abstract: Fab Industries Inc, textile maker, will close two factories and cut about 150 jobs, 15 percent of its work force, by end of year (S)

headline: The House Votes Strongly in Favor of Putting Pressure on Sudan
abstract: House, expressing outrage at Sudan's government role in human rights abuses, votes 442-2 to bar foreign oil companies that do business there from raising capital in United States or listing their securities in US financial markets; seeks to pressure Sudan to end long civil war; rebels in Sudan's mostly Christian and animist south say Muslim-dominated government uses oil revenues to finance war; aid groups charge oil companies abet government human rights violations; Talisman Energy Corp, Canadian company with stake in company operating in Sudan, holds it works to improve conditions there (M)

headline: DaimlerChrysler Vows to Match Rivals in S.U.V. Gas Mileage
abstract: After deriding for months the pledges of Ford Motor and General Motors to improve the fuel economy of sport utility vehicles and other light trucks by close to 25 percent, DaimlerChrysler A.G. has reversed itself and now says its light trucks will meet or exceed its rivals' models in average gas mileage.    DaimlerChrysler last year sold 1.9 million light trucks, a category that encompasses pickup trucks like the Dodge Ram and minivans like the Dodge Caravan, as well as sport utility vehicles like Jeeps and the Dodge Durango. G.M. sold 2.4 million light trucks and Ford sold 2.5 million. So the three manufacturers have now pledged to increase the gas mileage of nearly seven million vehicles a year, or two-fifths of the American market.

headline: War Dims Eritrea's Hopes, but Clears Its Eyes
abstract: Article on effects on Eritrea of war with Ethiopia, which ended in June 2000; war damaged 'pluck, pride and hope' of fiercely independent country which was created with great optimism in 1993; economy is in shambles and nation that once kicked out foreign aid groups as show of self-reliance now depends on UN to feed nearly two-thirds of its three million people; Eritreans are mulling next stage in nation's young life, seeing it as much different from what they had imagined; many say they face future with clearer, more grown-up eyes; map; photos (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar edges lower against euro and yen; euro settles at 85.07 cents, up from 84.76 cents; dollar trades at 120.09 yen, down from 120.39 yen; graph; chart (S)

headline: China Unconvinced as Missile Talks End
abstract: China publicly opposes United States plan for missile defense system, even as Asst Sec James Kelly meets with Chinese officials to defend Pres Bush's plan; China fears even modest missile defense will neutralize its own small arsenal (M)

headline: Berlin Journal; Spendthrift City Turns Its Icon Into a Billboard
abstract: Brandenburg Gate, Berlin's enduring symbol, is draped with advertisements from major corporations, who have agreed in return to pay bill for its renovation; Berlin is short of money, teetering on edge of bankruptcy thanks to huge real estate lending losses at city-controlled bank; flood of red ink could lead to startling polticial consequences; city has for years been governed by chilly coalition between center-right Christian Democrats and center-left Social Democrats; now Social Democrats are threatening to abandon coalition and call for new elections; some even consider teaming up with successors to Eastern Germany's old Communist Party, now Party of Democratic Socialism; photo (M)

headline: U.N. Delegation Finds Reasons for Hope in Congo Peace Talks
abstract: Twelve Security Council ambassadors find positive developments in their visit to Congo and neighboring countries to encourage peaceful resolution of war there; Amb Jean-David Levitte of France, leader of group. says all major foreign participants in Congo's war are committed to withdrawal, and Congolese rebels are also ready to disarm (M)

headline: BUSH TEAM VOWS TO SPEED UP WORK ON MISSILE SHIELD
abstract: Bush administration puts European allies on notice that it intends to move quickly to develop missile defense and plans to abandon or fundamentally alter Antiballistic Missile Treaty, that has been keystone of arms control for nearly 30 years; Pres Bush will discuss issue in upcoming speech at National Defense University; will reportedly lay out broad vision of missile defense but not specific program; US officials say Pentagon is developing plans for multi-layered ssytem that would involve radars and interceptors, in addition to land-based and space-based elements (M)

headline: Powell Arrives in Israel to Push Peace Effort
abstract: Sec of State Colin L Powell arrives is Israel hoping to persuade Israeli government to move forward on peace effort and to urge Palestinians to keep situation calm; says it is up to Prime Min Ariel Sharon to decide when level of violence is sufficiently low to progress beyond current cease-fire; statement appears to put onus on Sharon and to suggest that Sharon's stated goal of total quiet is probably unachievable; Powell goes out of his way to contrast Pres Bush's description of 'realistic' level of violence before more steps should be taken with Sharon's demand for 'zero'; photo (M)

headline: Temporary Jobs Have Become the Victims of a Slow Market
abstract: Article reports situation regarding temporary employment in Tampa, Fla; recently, job openings exceeded applicants; now, applicants outnumber jobs, which have fallen 20 percent or more; result is scarce jobs and lower pay for those in most need (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Sale Talks End
abstract: Body Shop International ends merger talks with Grupo Omnilife; photo (S)

headline: Bush's Vision: 'We Will Not Trade Away the Fate of Free European Peoples'
abstract: Excerpt from Pres Bush's speech in Warsaw about future of Europe (M)

headline: Math Error May Mean MP.3 Owes More in Lawsuit
abstract: Verdict in copyright lawsuit against MP3.com that resulted in award of $296,873 for independent record label Tee Vee Toons may have included mathematical error representing difference of millions of dollars; eight-person jury intended amount to be as high as $3 million; two jurors left telephone messages at Judge Jed Rakoff's office after seeing news reports of total amount, alerting court of discrepancy between intended and reported amount (M)

headline: Goldman Sachs to Create an Image-Shielding Japan Advisory Board
abstract: Goldman Sachs Group is expected to announce that it has created blue-chip advistory board for its Japanese operations, with members including former US House Speaker Thomas S Foley and Sony Corp chief executive Nobuyuki Idei; board will advise Goldman on regulatory and public policy issues in Japan and on its business operations in Tokyo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: RHEOMETRIC SCIENTIFIC, Piscataway, N.J., acquired Aviv Instruments, Lakewood, N.J., to gain products used to identify proteins and drugs.    GENERAL ELECTRIC CO., Fairfield, Conn., agreed to buy out an electricity-technology joint venture with the Harris Corp., Melbourne, Fla.

headline: LEGG MASON IS BUYING INVESTMENT FIRM FOR $1.4 BILLION
abstract: Legg Mason Inc pays as much as $1.38 billion to buy Private Capital Management LP, investment firm that manages more than $8 billion (S)

abstract: To the Editor:    Re ''In Proud Defense of the S.U.V.'' (March 25), in which William D. Brouse, the president of the Sport Utility Vehicle Owners Association of America, defended S.U.V.'s by saying that Americans have a right to drive whatever kinds of vehicles  they want:

headline: When Colorblindness Cramps Careers
abstract: Dr. Jay M. Cohen has heard it all at the clinic on West 42nd Street in Manhattan. Patients vent about workplace frustrations, stalled careers and shattered dreams.    But Dr. Cohen is neither a psychiatrist nor a career counselor. He is an optometrist who treats colorblindness, a condition that affects about 12 million Americans, mostly men. And because colorblind people can usually perceive colors and have difficulty distinguishing only some of them, many do not even know they have the deficiency. Many patients Dr. Cohen sees at the color-vision service of the State University of New York's College of Optometry have failed the test for jobs that require normal color vision.

headline: Beijing Blocks U.S. Attempt to Debate China Rights Record
abstract: UNITED NATIONS, April 18 â€” China, backed by Russia and major Asian, African and Arab countries, succeeded today in striking off the agenda of the United Nations Human Rights Commission an American resolution calling attention to Beijing's rights record.

headline: Phone Giant In Britain Is on the Eve Of Key Votes
abstract: British Telecommunications board is reportedly working on restructuring plan that includes spinning off of wireless operations; is also expected to vote on proposal to raise $7 billion by issuing equity to existing shareholders (M)

headline: BRITAIN: REUTERS EXPECTS SLOWER GROWTH
abstract: Reuters Group reports first-quarter revenue in line with analysts' expectations, but warns that growth will slow in second quarter; graph (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Price of crude oil rises on speculation that strengthening demand will shrink inventories as refineries make gasoline for summer; in New York, crude oil for June delivery rises 48 cents, to $28.94 per barrel; graph; chart (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: AFRICA    NIGERIA: REGIONAL WAR PROMPTS SUMMIT MEETING  The presidents of 10 West African countries held an emergency summit meeting in Nigeria's capital, Abuja, on a widening war that has drawn in Sierra Leone, Guinea and Liberia and caused a refugee crisis. Sierra Leone's president, Ahmed Tejan Kabbah, and Liberia's president, Charles Taylor, who is widely regarded as the principal cause of the instability, attended the meeting, which was led by Nigeria's president, Olusegun Obasanjo. The leaders asked the United Nations Security Council to approve the deployment of regional forces to the war zone.    Norimitsu Onishi (NYT)

headline: Pepsi Earnings Increase 18%, Continuing Growth Streak
abstract: PepsiCo says net income rose 18 percent in first quarter, to $498 million, while sales reached $4.54 billion, up 8 percent (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  Inventory-Sales Ratio -- March  Industrial Production -- April  Capacity Utilization -- April

headline: S.E.C. Accuses Former Sunbeam Official of Fraud
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission civil suit charges former Sunbeam Corp chief executive Albert J Dunlap directed huge accounting fraud to create illusion of successful restructuring of company and facilitate its sale at inflated price; charges he was aided by other former top officials and Phillip E Harlow, Arthur Andersen partner in charge of auditing Sunbeam; Dunlap and others say they will fight charges; Sunbeam, in bankruptcy reorganization, has settled related administrative proceeding with SEC; photo (M)

headline: Business; As Power Prices Surge, Montana, Too, Asks Why
abstract: Power deregulation crisis is unfolding in Montana, where large industrial companies are being forced to lay off workers and shut down operations because they cannot afford to pay soaring electric bills; photos (M)

headline: CLOROX DROPS VENTURE
abstract: Clorox Co withdraws from announced joint venture with Bombril SA of Brazil after unspecified conditions of deal are not met (S)

headline: Deep U.S.-Europe Split Casts Long Shadow on Bush Tour
abstract: Pres Bush and European leaders express sharp differences and conflicting intentions today about global warming at a summit meeting of European Union and United States; it is Bush's first appearance at a European Union meeting, and his first introduction to several of leaders, but it also second day in row that he finds himself at odds with European officials; photo of Bush with Finnish Pres Tarja Halonen (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: MONDAY: Consumer Borrowing, March

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Yugoslavia: Milosevic Timing Unclear
abstract: Pres Vojislav Kostunica of Yugoslavia says former Pres Slobodan Milosevic cannot be handed over to international war crimes tribunal in The Hague until after international conference on aid for Yugoslavia on June 29, because he is entitled to appeal his transfer (S)

headline: California-to-Australia:U.S. Spy Plane Without a Pilot Faces a Key Test
abstract: CANBERRAâ€”  The United States will attempt to fly a sophisticated robot airplane from California to Australia on Saturday, testing a new technology that one day could revolutionize land, sea and coastal surveillance from the air.

headline: Bush Says He'll Press Effort For Hemisphere Trade Pact
abstract: Pres Bush pledges to intensify his efforts to win authority from Congress to negotiate to build free trade zone for all of North and South America, speech to Organization of American States; stresses importance of ending trade barriers; has yet to ask Congress for 'fast track' negotiating authority; photo (M)

headline: Independence In Computers Is I.B.M. Goal
abstract: IBM plans to invest billions of dollars over next few years in effort to design computers and networking products that would adjust to changing workloads, recognize faults and repair themselves without human intervention; industry analysts say IBM's vision, called Project Eliza, is expected to encourage IBM's diverse units to focus on problem and invest more resources (M)

headline: SAWTEK TRIMS PROFIT FORECAST AND SAYS IT WILL CUT JOBS
abstract: Sawtek Inc, maker of cellular-phone components, says that profit and sales for rest of 2001 will be lower than in 2000, that it will cut 35 jobs in Costa Rica because of slowdown in wireless and communications markets and that it is reducing work hours and encouraging workers to take early retirement (S)

headline: Last Chapter: Berlin to Pay Slave Workers Held by Nazis
abstract: German Parliament approves motion that opens way for payment of $4.5 billion to laborers forced to work by Nazis; agreement comes 56 years after fall of Third Reich and after two years of often bitter negotiations; many Germans hail settlement as closing chapter of difficult process of confrontation with crimes of Hitler; nation is now almost three generations distant from Nazi era, and has long yearned for some form of closure with crimes that sullied name of Germany; Jewish organizations have been central to negotiations, although only 10 percent of expected beneficiaries are Jewish; they take more guarded view of settlement's meaning (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: New Foreign Minister
abstract: Ahmed Maher, a former ambassador to Washington, Moscow and the United Nations, has been appointed foreign minister, succeeding Amr Moussa, a figure of immense popularity who is becoming secretary general of the Arab League. President Hosni Mubarak has a history of replacing officials if their domestic popularity soars, and Mr. Moussa's criticism of Israel's treatment of the Palestinians has made him beloved.   Neil MacFarquhar (NYT)

headline: Forming Battle Lines On Workaholics' Ways
abstract: Matt Pfeffer letter comments on May 6 On the Contrary column touting workplace monomania

headline: Article 2001040692302692218 -- No Title
abstract: In the Storage Race, Will Consumers Win?

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Central African Republic: Fighting Continues
abstract: Government forces in Central African Republic launch big attack on rebel positions near capital (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Mozambique: 6 Charged In Journalist's Killing
abstract: Mozambique authorities charge six men with murder of journalist Carlos Cardoso six months ago (S)

headline: U.S. Resumes Reconnaissance Flights Off China's Coast
abstract: WASHINGTON, May 7 â€” The United States resumed reconnaissance flights off the coast of China today for the first time since an April 1 collision between a Navy intelligence-gathering plane and a Chinese fighter bruised relations between the two countries, defense and military officials said.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Teenage Hacker Shows No Remorse
abstract: Presentencing report holds Montreal youth who has admitted hacking into at least 75 computer networks and hobbling five Internet sites in Feb 2000 shows not sign of remorse; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Taiwan Businessman Executed
abstract: China executes Taiwanese businessma, Cao Yufei, for his role in big investment scam (S)

headline: Willing but Wary, Irish Vote on Wider Europe
abstract: Referendum in Ireland will ask voters if European Union should expand to include poorer Eastern European countries like Poland, Hungary and Czech Republic; referendum raises broader questions about Ireland's relationship with Europe, recalling Ireland's years of taking $25 billion in aid from European Union when it was one of poorer relations; boom of 90's filled Ireland's coffers and now, as Irish start giving rather than receiving aid, they find they also have power to shut door on poorer applicants (M)

headline: JUDGE RECALLS COMPANY OFFICIAL IN GAS PRICE INQUIRY

headline: Private Sector; Flying Americans Home, And Reaping Bonus Miles
abstract: There was, aside from President Bush, one chief executive who was particularly enthusiastic about the return of the 24 men and women detained in China when their spy plane made an emergency landing there two weeks ago. Splashed across the front pages of newspapers throughout the world -- and seen by millions on television -- was a white jet with a huge Continental Airlines logo carrying the returning crew members. ''We are tremendously proud,'' said Gordon M. Bethune, the airline's chief executive, who, after receiving word on Wednesday, announced to a cheering Houston Chamber of Commerce meeting that the Continental plane was ''in the air.''    It was, of course, the kind of feel-good publicity that companies can only dream of.

headline: What's Next: For Efficiency, Light-Emitting Diodes May Turn to Carbon

headline: John W. Raber -- Banker, 89
abstract: John W. Raber, a former chairman and president of the Green Point Savings Bank, died on March 29 at his home in Jacksonville, Fla. He was 89.    Mr. Raber joined Green Point in Brooklyn in 1928 as a clerk. He became an officer in 1942 and was secretary and executive vice president before becoming president in 1967. He became chairman in 1974 and retired in 1981.

headline: EUROPEAN UNION: INFLATION STEADY
abstract: Annual inflation in the 12-member euro zone was 2.6 percent in March, the European Union's statistical office, Eurostat, said. It was the same level as in February, but up from 2.4 percent in January. The core rate, excluding energy, food, alcohol and tobacco, rose to 1.8 percent from 1.7 percent in February. The highest inflation levels were in Portugal at 5.1 percent; the Netherlands, 4.9 percent; and Ireland, 4.1 percent. The lowest levels were France at 1.4 percent and Austria at 1.9 percent.     Paul Meller (NYT)

headline: Privacy Policy Notices Are Called Too Common and Too Confusing
abstract: Critics say privacy notices being sent out by financial institutions in compliance with new federal law are confusing; customers must be notified about how their personal information will be shared with third parties, and be given option of not having it shared, now that Depression-era legal barriers have been lifted, allowing mergers between banks, insurance companies, brokerage firms and other financial institutions; Mark Hochhauser, consultant who helps companies make their materials comprehensible for consumers, gives low marks to most of privacy notices he has encountered; says print is too small, vocabulary too sophisticated, and overall message too vague to be helpful; excerpts from some notices sent recently (M)

headline: Bush Foreign Policy Plans Through Democrats' Prism

headline: MEDIA COMPANIES SUCCEED IN EASING OWNERSHIP LIMITS

headline: 'A Dangerous Game'
abstract: News analysis; collision between Chinese fighter and US Navy intelligence plane over South China Sea was not random accident; reflects increasingly dangerous military rivalry between China and US as US expands intelligence-gathering in region, turning away from cold war theaters of Europe and Soviet Union (M)

headline: Newspaper Circulation
abstract: Audit Bureau of Circulations list of circulation figures for nation's largest newspapers, which compares six-month period ended March 31 with period previous year

headline: Article 2001042793990376259 -- No Title
abstract: EDUCATION

headline: Article 2001041892458774059 -- No Title
abstract: April 18, 2001

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Electronic Arts Fills Online Post
abstract: Electronics Arts says Erick Hachenburg has been named chief operating officer of EA.com, its online gaming unit, replacing Joe Keene, who resigned; photo (S)

headline: AT&T OFFERS TO SWAP $10 BILLION IN TRACKING STOCK
abstract: AT&T Corp offers to swap 1.176 AT&T Wireless Group tracking shares for each share of parent as part of its plan to break up company; offer is worth as much as $10 billion; premium on AT&T shares is about 7 percent; AT&T Wireless will become independent company by mid-2001 (S)

headline: Tibetans Going to Meeting
abstract: Committee of nations meeting in Geneva to plan United Nations conference on racism and other forms of discrimination, set for Durban, South Africa, approves participation of Tibetan Center for Human Rights and Democracy and International Campaign for Tibet, Tibetan exile groups usually barred by China from international events; excludes group Human Rights in China (S)

headline: Royal and DuPont Rethink The Calculator. Go Figure.
abstract: Royal and DuPont join to create new line of calculators that are easier to read in bright light; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: STAPLES INC., Framingham, Mass., an office supplies retailer, said it had sold its Staples Communications unit to the closely held Platinum Equity of Los Angeles. Terms were not disclosed.    COMPUTER NETWORK TECHNOLOGY CORP., Minneapolis, a maker of computer-networking hardware and software, said it had acquired the closely held Articulent Inc., Hopkinton, Mass., a storage-management company, for $36 million in debt and cash to expand its storage services business.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Wall Street's New Interest In Bulgaria
abstract: Investors scramble to get facts about AremisSoft, New Jersey-based software company that reported in December 1999 that it had contract worth $37.5 million to overhaul Bulgaria's health information network; documents filed by company with Securities and Exchange Commission in March 2000 indicate value of contract is less than $4 million; discrepancy is just one of problems weighing on shares of AremisSoft, which have fallen more than one-quarter in extremely heavy trading since May 14; graph (M)

headline: Halifax Pact With Bank Of Scotland Is Reported
abstract: Bank of Scotland and Halifax Group say they hold merger talks (M)

headline: Food Industry Sets Tougher Labeling Rules for Allergens
abstract: Many of largest food companies agree to specify whether products they sell contain even tiny amounts of everyday ingredients that can cause potentially fatal allergic reactions; Grocery Manufacturers of America and National Food Processors Association are issuing voluntary guidelines for nutrition labels on processed foods; guidelines come as Democrats in House and Senate prepare to introduce legislation that would impose even stiffer requirements on food manufacturers; Sen Edward M Kennedy, who is sponsoring one of bills, comments (M)

headline: Article 2001062091822299169 -- No Title
abstract: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

headline: Europeans Open Door For Hostile Takeovers
abstract: European Parliament and European Commission officials agree on law to make it easier to carry out hostile takeovers and more difficult for companies to defend selves by selling shares to friendly shareholders; accord comes despite vehement German objections; law will not take full effect until 2006; is likely to spur cross-border takeover bids (M)

headline: Article 2001052492519790669 -- No Title
abstract: Wariness Yields to Motivation in Baltimore Free-Computer Experiment

headline: Israel's Chagrin: Earning Rebukes From All Sides
abstract: Many Israeli pundits believe that this week's brief Israeli capture of Palestinian Authority territory in the Gaza Strip, which ended less than 24 hours after it began following harsh American criticism, was a fiasco militarily, diplomatically and politically.    The brief reoccupation caused friction between Israel and the United States, and provoked European censure and wrath in the Arab world. It generated tension between the government and the army, and within the government, because many ministers learned about it from the news media. It earned Prime Minister Ariel Sharon criticism from settlers for retreating and from leftists for advancing in the first place.

headline: At Annual Meetings Around the World, the Shots Aren't Heard; A Family Affair, And Cozy at That
abstract: Survey of corporate annual meetings around the world describes scene at Banco Itau's meeting in Sao Paulo, Brazil (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Tajikistan: Help On The Way
abstract: International donors pledge $430 million to help rebuild Tajikistan, which is struggling to reduce poverty; map (S)

headline: Strong Instinet Debut Signals Some Life Returning to I.P.O. Market
abstract: Providing a sign that the moribund market for initial public offerings may be coming back to life, shares of the Instinet Group surged as much as 34.5 percent today as the company made its debut on the Nasdaq Stock Market.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Raising The Sunken Sub
abstract: Russia announced plans to raise the nuclear submarine Kursk from the floor of the Barents Sea in an operation by a Dutch salvage company than would run from mid-July to mid-September, Deputy Prime Minister Ilya I. Klebanov said. Divers will cut away the front section of the submarine, which was destroyed on Aug. 2 by a still unexplained internal explosion. All 118 crewmen died. Hydraulic lifts on a barge will hoist the submarine, and the vessels will be towed 60 miles to shallower waters.     Patrick E. Tyler (NYT)

headline: U.S. Guns Smuggled Into Mexico Feed Drug War
abstract: Though public attention focuses on the drugs smuggled from Mexico to the north, officials here are increasingly concerned by an ever more lethal flow of guns south from the United States.    The growing number of assault rifles and semiautomatic weapons showing up in shootouts and assassinations has bolstered the arms caches of Mexico's drug cartels, officials in both countries say. And they feed one of the highest rates of gun homicide anywhere in the world.

headline: Judge Rejects Plan by Belgian Software Maker
abstract: Commercial court in Ieper, Belgium, rejects reorganization plan by Lernout & Hauspie Speech Products, saying that it is too vague and that it favors some creditors over others; company is under bankruptcy protection in Belgium as well as US, where several units are based (M)

headline: World Briefing | United Nations: Budget Hamstrings Refugee Agency
abstract: UN agency for refugees warns that shortage of donations and budget shortfall will end operations in Balkans and East Timor (S)

headline: The Boss: A Job and a Life Intertwined
abstract: Three days after graduating from the all-women Smith College in 1968, I entered Columbia Business School where I was one of four women in a class of 275. I felt both special and out of place. I simply wanted to earn money and not type (someone said an M.B.A. would save me from the typewriter) so that my husband-to-be, George, who was in medical school also at Columbia (yes, I followed him there), and I could be married.

headline: Mitchell Report on Mideast Violence May Thaw the Ice; U.S. Gingerly Discusses Taking More Active Role
abstract: Bush administration, facing increasing pressure to help curb Mideast violence, seeks way to become involved in Israeli-Palestinian conflict while avoiding what it views as ex-Pres Clinton's failures; Bush meets with top foreign policy advisors, including Secs Colin L Powell and Donald H Rumsfeld, to discuss report by international panel led by George J Mitchell; seeks formula that does not fully support report's call for freeze on Israeli settlements (M)

headline: Awful War, Real Peace: The Model Of Eritrea
abstract: Eritrea and Ethiopia, whose troops fought each other for two years, have both respected cease-fire for last six months; this is welcome relief for 4,100 United Nations peacekeepers who have since arrived; in four months, there has not been single serious incident involving peacekeepers; their task is complex: formal creation of demilitarized zone; delay in demarking zone is particularly hard on 135,000 displaced Eritreans; photos; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Wireless Setback
abstract: British Telecommunications delays by three months introduction of faster, Internet-linked mobile phones on Isle of Man (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: UNITED NATIONS

headline: Growing PC's Into Supercomputers, All in a Row
abstract: "Clusters" have all but replaced the expensive "big iron" supercomputers of just a few years ago and are useful in applications that require massive number crunching: weather forecasting, traffic simulations, deciphering the human genome and modeling the birth of stars, to name just a few.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Unhappy with Castro
abstract: Argentine government withdraws its ambassador to Cuba to protest comments by Pres Fidel Castro that characterized Pres Fernando de la Rua's government as 'bootlickers of the Yankees' (S)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Surprise Verdict In Spy Case
abstract: Egyptian state security court acquits Sherif al-Filali, 34-year-old engineer, on charges of spying for Israel (S)

headline: Wal-Mart to Sell Cosmetics Line
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores Inc has started selling cosmetics under its own label to compete with major brands for teenage customers; company began selling cosmetics under No Boundaries name in test at small number of stores in March, and in June expanded sales to 1,500 stores (S)test at

headline: Deutsch Making Management Changes
abstract: Deutsch names Linda Sawyer chief operating officer, new post; she remains managing partner; agency names Kathy Delaney, Val DiFebo, Eric Hirshberg and Mike Sheldon managing partners; Peter Drakoulias will leave as business development director to join dRush, firm's joint venture with Russell Simmons, as president, succeeding Anne Simmons, who resigned; will take equity stake in venture (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Grocer's Sales Up
abstract: Tesco, largest British supermarket chain, says that first-quarter sales rose 14 percent; will begin another wave of price cuts (S)

headline: Stocks Are Dragged Lower by Sluggish Reports on the Economy
abstract: Series of economic reports revealing sluggishness of US economy drag stocks down; Dow Jones industrial average drops 117.05, or 1.1 percent, to 11,005.37; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index's 15.28 point, or 1.2 percent, fall takes it to 1,277.89, down 1.1 percent last week; Nasdaq composite index drops 30.99, to 2,251.03, down 1.4 percent but 2.4 percent higher than week ago; some bond investors expect rate cut in June; 10-year Treasury note's yield rises to 5.49 percent, from 5.47 percent, as its price slips 4/32, to 96 11/32; graph; table of key rates (M)

headline: Alcoa Says First-Quarter Profit Rose 16%
abstract: PITTSBURGH, April 5 â€” Alcoa said today that its first-quarter profit had risen 16 percent because of cost savings and sales from acquired companies.

headline: Hyatt moves to raise the global profile of its hotel brands.
abstract: Hyatt International is introducing $10 million global advertising campaign to raise profile of its three brands: Park Hyatt, Grand Hyatt and Hyatt Regency; mostly print campaign is by New York office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: EBay Suspends Account Of Internet Coin Trader  EBay has suspended the account of a seller suspected of taking hundreds of thousands of dollars from people who bid successfully on gold and silver coins, sent their money and received nothing in return.    The auction company suspended the account of Anthony L. McEnroe of Peoria, Ill., and said that it was cooperating with the authorities in an investigation. [Page C4.]

headline: A Growing Rivalry Derails AOL Talks For Microsoft Deal
abstract: Collapse of talks between Microsoft and AOL Time Warner was rooted in Microsoft's strategy of making its new operating system tool to provide wide range of tightly integrated services directly to computer users, area dominated by AOL for years; breakdown complicates future for Microsoft, which is awaiting appeals court decision about breaking company into two parts; raises prospect of new antitrust challenges concerning company's operating system, Windows XP, and creates risk that opposition from AOL and its 30 million users will hinder its introduction in fall; shows how rivalry in computer industry has shifted from individual pieces of software, likw Web browsers, to control over whole systems that govern how consumers use computers (M)

headline: 40,000 Turn Out in Hong Kong To Mark Tiananmen Killings
abstract: HONG KONG, June 4 â€” Defying claims that the memory of Tiananmen Square is fading with time, more than 40,000 people turned out here today to remember the student protesters who were cut down 12 years ago in Beijing.

headline: Money Can Motivate. So Can Love of the Job.
abstract: On the Contrary article questions relationship between money earned by corporate executives and motivation to perform well; predicts that there will be no wholesale resignations among top corporate executives when executive compensation and severance packages diminish (M)

headline: Credit Offerings Planned This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 3.83 percent and on a six-month, 3.79 percent.

headline: Continental Union Vote
abstract: Pilots and flight instructors at Continental Airlines Inc vote to merge their independent union with Air Line Pilots Association; about 61 percent of members of Independent Association of Continental Pilots, which represent pilots at carrier's main airline and Continental Express, vote to merge with larger Air Line Pilots Assn (S)

headline: PrivateSector; New City, New Best Friend?
abstract: April has been busy -- and expensive -- for Laurence Graff. Despite the softening economy, he just opened a Manhattan branch of his international jewel house, which also has stores in London and Monte Carlo. Other people might think twice about making another big expenditure. But not Mr. Graff. On Tuesday, he bought the 50-carat ''La Favorite'' diamond ring at Christie's for $3.6 million.    Mr. Graff, who has often sold rare, and larger, gems to the world's wealthy during his more than 40 years in the business, thinks the long, emerald-cut diamond -- named the most perfect diamond in America at the 1934 Chicago World's Fair -- could use improvement. ''I am going to recut it to make it totally flawless,'' he said. If all goes according to plan, he said, only a little of the diamond's weight will be lost.

headline: A Knight Ridder Officer Resigns Suddenly
abstract: Jean H Mordo resigns as chief financial officer of Knight Ridder; Gary Effren will succeed Mordo (S)

headline: Merger of Giant Pet-Food Makers Unites an Unusual Mix of Foes
abstract: To the bafflement of Europeans, genetically modified food has never stirred much of an uproar in the United States, and many people in this country eat hormone-infused beef without batting an eye. But the Swiss food giant, Nestlé S.A., is fast learning that consumers of almost every ilk can get riled over at least one staple in the American diet: pet food.     Although many mergers have occurred in the food industry in the last year with little protest, several divergent groups have begun to pull together in opposition to Nestlé's proposed $10.1 billion purchase of Ralston Purina, the nation's leading pet food maker, which makes products like Puppy Chow and Meow Mix.

headline: Chinese Test New Weapon From West: Lawsuits
abstract: Young Chinese are testing weapon borrowed from West: lawsuits; number of lawsuits in Chinese courts has grown exponentially, including suits for defective products, wrongful injury, poor service and wrongful dismissal; as legal awareness improves and legal system develops, more and more people are going to court to defend their rights; Chinese have high hopes about power of lawsuits to remedy injustice; cases reflect growing concern about rights among Chinese themselves, even as their government faces criticism from abroad of its poor rights record; photo of two workers who have sued their former employer (M)

headline: Losses Posted For Quarter By Palm Inc. And 3Com
abstract: Palm Inc reports loss of $392 million in fiscal fourth quarter ended June 1 compared to net income of $12.4 million in year-earlier quarter; sales fell to $165.3 million from $350.2 million; ThreeCom Corp says loss grew to $517.7 million in fourth quarter as revenue fell 39 percent (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Compaq Mulls Proxicom Bid
abstract: Compaq Computer will consider raising its takeover bid for Proxicom after receiving notice of higher competing bid from Dimension Data Holdings that values Proxicom at $448 million; graph (S)

headline: Russia Trying To Head Off Debt Squeeze
abstract: The order seemed simple enough in the late 1980's: 79 brand-new fishing trawlers for the Soviet Union to upgrade its fleet.    Work began at European shipyards, financed by bank loans backed by millions of dollars in guarantees from the Soviet government.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BEL FUSE INC., Jersey City, a maker of fuses and computer-networking components, has bought the E-Power Co., Hangzhou, China, a closely held Chinese research company that develops power-conversion devices. Terms of the cash purchase were not disclosed.

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: INTERNET SEARCH PROVIDER FOR NBCI AND EXPLORER GoTo.com , an Internet search service, announced yesterday that it had signed an agreement with NBCi and renewed a deal with Microsoft to provide pay-for-placement search results for the two companies. Under the NBCi agreement, which will last two years, GoTo will provide sponsored search results to the 15 million users of NBCi Web sites. The Microsoft deal, originally signed in January of last year, offers sponsored results to those who use the search button on the Internet Explorer Web browser. GoTo, based in Pasadena, Calif., says it has more than 40,000 advertisers. It surprised analysts last month when it said its earnings would beat Wall Street expectations. Andrew Zipern (NYT)

headline: State of the Art: Zeroing In on Wristwear
abstract: As the information age chugs along, most of us have accepted three inexorable trends in consumer technology: personal electronics get cheaper every year, they get smaller every year, and if any two products can be combined, they will be. At this rate, by 2020 we can expect high-definition cell-phone/camcorder/MP3-player/organizers that cost $1.99 and are no bigger than lima beans.

headline: Addenda: Executive Buys Back a 55% Stake in AG
abstract: Fourteen months after Draft Worldwide in Chicago acquired a 55 percent stake in AG Worldwide in New York, the agency founded by Peter Arnell, Mr. Arnell is buying back the stake for undisclosed terms.

headline: China Charges U.S. Citizen With Spying For Taiwan
abstract: American Embassy in Beijing says that China has charged Li Shaomin, Chinese-born American citizen, with spying for Taiwan; Li is one of several ethnic Chinese scholars with American citizenship or permanent residency who have been detained in China over several months, often on vague grounds of espionage; Li is first of these to be formally charged with spying; reasons for charge are not announced; Western diplomats and China scholars voice grave concern about apparent hardening of policy by State Security Bureau, seemingly intended to intimidate growing number of Western-educated Chinese who are returning to work or conduct research (M)

headline: Stocks End Lower on Profit Warnings
abstract: Stock prices fell today after Sun Microsystems warned that its earnings would fall below Wall Street's estimates, reviving investors' concerns that the technology sector faces more profit pressures.

headline: Newsweeklies Turn a Cold Shoulder to Hard News
abstract: Key changes at newsweeklies, whose news coverage has grown softer over decades, suggest they have finally ended their days as hard news arbiters; financial issues and shifting cultural tastes are carving new landscapes inside Time, Newsweek and US News & World Report; readership graph; photo (M)

headline: Militants in Zimbabwe Now Take Aim at Industry
abstract: Many white owners of large businesses in Zimbabe are under attack from black militants who style themselves as veterans of guerrilla war that helped end minority rule 21 years ago; they have support of Pres Robert Mugabe and his ruling party; militants are using same tactics they used last year when they invaded white-owned farms, often violently, in name of rural landless; they are sowing fear not only among owners but also among some of poor they claim to represent; country is gearing up for next year's presidential election; Mugabe, seeking re-election, is eager to recapture urban votes his party lost last year; white business owners are particularly alarmed by sudden resignation of Nkosana Moyo, minister of industry and international trade who criticized attacks on industry and urged aggressive government action against them; photo (M)

headline: Omnicom Merging 2 New York Units
abstract: Omnicom Group merges its Griffin Bacal agency into its Moss Dragoti unit after Griffin Bacal loses key client and lays off workers; Sharp Electronics shifts account from Griffin Bacal to Oasis Advertising (M)

headline: Web Rings Connect Like-Minded Surfers
abstract: Q. What is a Web ring?    A. A Web ring is a group of Web sites with a similar theme. Each site is connected to the others in the ring by a hypertext link so people can click to go from site to site in the ring.

headline: TWO SENIOR MANAGERS RESIGN FROM KNIGHT TRADING
abstract: Knight Trading Group says president John Hewitt and David Shpilberg, technology head, have resigned; company says it might have to dismiss up to 6 percent of its 660 employees (S)
