headline: Chairman Decides to Leave As CNN Is Prepped for Change
abstract: Tom Johnson resigns as chairman of CNN but will continue with network as adviser to its executives, who are retooling CNN's look and schedule (M)

headline: Recent account maneuvers involve big household names like Amazon, Energizer and others.
abstract: Recent advertising account maneuvers involving Amazon.com, Energizer Battery Co, Dial Corp, Visa USA and Wall Street Journal discussed (M)

headline: Talks on Macedonia Conflict at an Impasse
abstract: Talks aimed at ending conflict between Macedonian government and ethnic Albanian rebels deadlock, with each side blaming other; Pres Boris Trajkovski turns to NATO and Western diplomats for help in breaking impasse; photo (M)

headline: Article 2001052692772145627 -- No Title
abstract: CYBERTIMES EDUCATION

headline: Needing Cash, Turkey Plans More Sacrifice
abstract: Turkey's economy minister announced a package of austerity measures today aimed at winning $10 billion to $12 billion in new foreign loans and restoring confidence in the country's battered economy.     The government plans to cut spending by 9 percent for the rest of the year and freeze hiring by the state's bloated bureaucracy.

headline: BOSTON SCIENTIFIC TO ACQUIRE CARDIAC PATHWAYS
abstract: Boston Scientific Corp will buy Cardiac Pathways Corp for $115 million (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: ASIA    CHINA: 89 EXECUTED IN ONE DAY  China executed at least 89 convicted criminals on Wednesday as part of its ''strike hard'' campaign against organized crime, state newspapers reported yesterday. The one-day tally was one of the highest on record for China which, according to Amnesty International, executes more people annually than the rest of the world combined.    (Agence France-Presse)

headline: Have Rate Cuts Lost Their Magic?
abstract: Louis Uchitelle Economic View column questions effectiveness of further Federal Reserve interest rate cuts to reverse current peculiar economic slowdown, saying interest rates do not do much to lift capital investment, powerful engine of economy; notes economists differ on how long it will be before promise of rising profits again seems firm enough to justify purchase of capital goods (M)

headline: Shanghai Journal; Political Power Grows From the Point of His Pen
abstract: Interview with Peng Ruigao, Shanghai government propaganda bureau worker, one of thousands of Communist Party functionaries who write slogans party peppers people with daily; party is ever present in China with billboards and banners urging citizens to follow its plan; public display of verses, fixture since ancient times, shifted to propaganda slogans after Qing dynasty fell in 1911; photo (M)

headline: Personal Business; When Safety Is an Option, Sticker Prices Grow
abstract: Automakers discover that safety features help sell cars, and they are creating more types of advanced safety systems to use as selling points; many of these optional features are costly; photos; chart (M)

headline: Article 2001050490761311617 -- No Title
House Warns U.N. of Pocketbook Revenge
abstract: House of Representatives votes to withhold $224 million in dues to United Nations next year unless US is restored to United Nations Human Rights Commission; decision to add this condition to third and final payment of back dues is approved, 252 to 165, with backing of most Republicans and some Democrats; it goes against wishes of Bush administration, which maintains that frustration with ouster from Human Rights Commission should not affect its payments to UN; House action may be no more than symbolic one unless Senate follows suit (M)

headline: Letters: Too Soon for Web Pads
abstract: To the Editor:

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Costs Up At Brambles
abstract: Brambles Industries expects profits in year ending June 30 to fall to about 343 million Australian dollars ($177 million) from 364.8 million Australian dollars ($186.3 million) in fiscal 2000 (S)

headline: More Bad News, and the Stock Markets Are Happy to Hear It
abstract: Stocks drop sharply on surprisingly negative report on unemployment, then reverse to close with gains; Dow Jones Industrial Average's 154.59 gain leaves it at 10,951.24; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 18.03, to 1,266.61; Nasdaq composite index goes up 45.33, to 2,191.53; Treasury prices fall on jobs data; 10-year Treasury note falls 1/32, to 98 15/32, its yield unchanged at 5.20 percent; 30-year bond loses 15/32, to 95 26/32; its yield rises 5.67 percent, up from Thursday's 5.63 percent; chart; list of key rates (M)

headline: World Briefing/MIDDLE EAST: IRAN: 'GUARDIANS' BAR CANDIDATES
abstract: The Council of Guardians, a board that screens political candidates, barred 145 of the 356 people seeking to run for parliamentary seats in the June 8 election. Reformists in the camp of President Mohammed Khatami said the council had singled out virtually all the president's supporters to minimize his influence in the legislature. The board said it had rejected the candidates for reasons ranging from suspected ties to a violent opposition group to un-Islamic behavior like drinking alcohol.   Neil MacFarquhar (NYT)

headline: I Earn My Wings Under the Plane
abstract: Domenic Bufalini My Job column, written with Patricia R Olsen, describes his job as airline mechanic; photo (M)

headline: Plane Crew Details Detention in China
abstract: On their first full day back home at the Whidbey Island Naval Air Station in Washington, several of the 24 Americans detained in China gave reporters details of an experience in which, at first, many were sure they would die and prepared to bail out. After they landed on Hainan island, they were treated to decks of cards, cigarettes, toothpaste, Chinese food so authentic it included fish heads, and living quarters with bugs and mosquitoes. Interrogations, often in the middle of the night, lasted up to five hours, and their recreation included teaching a guard the words to  ''Hotel California.''    Article, Page A9.

headline: Israel Arrests Ex-General as Spy for Spilling Old Secrets
abstract: Itzhak Yaakov, 75, retired brigadier general who once oversaw weapons development for Israeli military and who has dual US and Israeli citizenship, has been held for month in Israeli prison on charges of 'high espionage' that carry maximum penalty of life behind bars; Yaakov, who was born in Israel, fought for independence and is known as father of Israeli technology industry, was quietly arrested at airport four days after gala birthday party attended by many Israeli leaders; photo; case is sealed but friends say only offense was speaking to Israeli reporter during recent interviews in New York, where he has lived for two decades; say he was upset at being disqualified for Israel Prize because he is expatriate and is too proud to accept US offers of help now; his information would be very dated in any case, and much is known now about Israel's nuclear arsenal; 'secret arrest' is criticized in press, but State Atty Edna Arbel protests contention that Yaakov has 'disappeared' (M)

headline: A New Accounting Rule May Set Up Some Big Baths
abstract: Floyd Norris comment on Financial Accounting Standards Board's plan to reform accounting for mergers; says if approved, no merger annoucned after June 30 will be able to use pooling of interests accounting, meaning companies will no longer be able to keep costs of acquisitions from showing up on their balance sheets; holds changes also include adjustments for way other merger accounting technique, purchase accounting, is applied; says board has come up with method that will be costly for companies to apply and less useful for investors than would obvious alternative; graph (M)

headline: INDIA: PETROLEUM STAKE SALE
abstract: Reliance Industries will sell as much as $1 billion of shares in Reliance Petroleum to overseas investors to help pay for planned fiber optic network linking 115 Indian cities (S)

headline: Text of President Bush's Remarks on Global Climate
abstract: WASHINGTON, June 11 - Following are excerpts from remarks by President Bush today on global climate, as recorded by the White House:

headline: Halifax and Bank of Scotland Said to Have $26 Billion Deal
abstract: Bank of Scotland and Halifax Group agree to combine their companies in deal worth about $26 billion; deal will leave Halifax shareholders in control of about 63 percent of combined company (M)

headline: Credit Offerings During the Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 3.42 percent and a six-month bill was 3.41 percent.

headline: 701,000 DODGE TRUCKS RECALLED BECAUSE OF HOOD LATCH
abstract: DaimlerChrysler recalls 701,000 Dodge Ram pickup trucks in 20 states because spring on hood latch can corrode and cause hood to fly up; recall is for 1994 through 1999 models in states where there is salt on roads (S)

headline: IRISH LIFE WILL SELL 2 OF ITS 3 AMERICAN DIVISIONS
abstract: Irish LifeÃ¯

headline: Private Sector; City of Lights at End of His Tunnel
abstract: Morgan Stanley Dean Witter hires former Eurotunnel chairman Patrick Ponsolle to head its Paris office (S)

headline: Reassessing Mitterrand's Legacy : Of Monuments â€” and Monumental Errors
abstract: PARISâ€”  Nearly 20 years ago Francois Mitterrand was elected president of France with a platform that, at least subliminally, promised to make France the Cool capital of the world. There was an explosion of cheering, honking and partying in the streets of Paris, particularly at the Place de la Bastille, that symbol of regicide. People power was the message.

headline: Ex-President of Philippines Seized on Corruption Charge
abstract: BANGKOK, Thailand, April 25 â€” Three months after being driven from power by a military-backed popular uprising in the Philippines, former President Joseph Estrada was arrested today on allegations of corruption and locked inside a cell in the central compound of the National Police.

headline: Batteries Push Paper Into Electronics Age
abstract: Power Paper, small Israeli company, devises caseless batteries that are printed directly onto paper, plastic or other surfaces; their thinness is kernel of their potential utility, and lends this innovative power source its limitless applications; technology has already been licensed for use in few devices; they stand to be most useful in disposable items; photo (M)

headline: Bush and Jiang Exchange Drafts Of a Letter Stating U.S. Regrets
abstract: Aides to Pres Bush and Pres Jiang Zemin exchange drafts of proposed letter from United States to China that would express regrets for aircraft collision over South China Sea, initiate investigation run by Chinese and American military officers, and clear way toward release of 24 Americans held in China; letter would bear signature of Joseph W Prueher, American ambassador to Beijing, rather than that of Bush; aim is to find language that can enable China's leaders to argue that they received apology and allow American officials to say they got crew members and plane out of China without acknowledging any blame for collision; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Phase 2 Of Chicken Slaughter
abstract: Hong Kong begins slaughtering more than one million chickens and other poultry at farms in territory, week after it detected new strain of deadily avian influenza in chickens at three markets (S)

headline: Private Sector; Dow Is Down, but So Is Decibel Level
abstract: The corporate annual meeting season got off to a quiet start this year without Evelyn Y. Davis, the gadfly who often does more of the talking than any chief executive.    Though she again has proposals up for votes on several companies' proxy statements, Ms. Davis has been sending her regrets to their chief executives. Last week, she called David H. Komansky, the chairman of Merrill Lynch, to say that illness would keep her from attending Merrill's shareholder meeting.

headline: NORTEL EXECUTIVE TO HEAD ENTRUST
abstract: F William Conner is named president and chief executive of Entrust Technologies; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Afghanistan: Taliban Raid Red Cross Hospital
abstract: Taliban religious police in Afghanistan raid Red Cross hospital (S)

headline: General Wounded in Madrid Bombing; Basque Group Is Blamed
abstract: Spanish general, Justo Oreja Pedraza, is severely wounded when bomb in backpack on bicycle explodes outside his home in Madrid; authorities blame Basque separatist group ETA for attack; second explosion in central Madrid damages what police describe as bomber's getaway car (S)

headline: Leftist Ex-President Makes Surprising Comeback in Peru
abstract: Former Peruvian Pres Alan Garcia, who left office 11 years ago as political pariah, has emerged after first round of voting as major contender for presidency; his strong finish, apparently in second place, stuns political analysts; he remains long shot to defeat Alejandro Toledo, who led drive that ousted Pres Alberto K Fujimori; third candidate, Lourdes Flores, concedes defeat; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen gains slightly as traders await report on US labor statistics; in New York, dollar settles at 121.72 yen, down from 122.17 yen; graph; chart (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: PC Connection To Buy Outpost.Com
abstract: Outpost.com agrees to be acquired by PC Connection in stock swap (S)

headline: Editor Quits TheStreet.com, Partly Over Policy Concerns
abstract: Web site TheStreet.com announces resignation of its editor in chief Dave Kansas; David J Morrow, editor at SmartMoney magazine and former business reporter at New York Times, will succeed Kansas (M)

headline: Translators Thrive as the World Speaks
abstract: Translators are in great demand despite growing use of English around the world; proficient translators and interpreters can make a pretty good living, but they are mostly freelancers, for whom work can be unpredictable; competition can be fierce, especially since Internet allows American company to e-mail Spanish translation job to lower-wage translator in Mexico; translation software remains minor threat for now because few programs can trasnslate language-rich text; photos (M)

headline: That Part-Time Pace
abstract: Letter from Kim Rosner applauds May 13 article journaling change from working full- to part-time

headline: ORACLE TO BE PART OF WEB VENTURE
abstract: Royal KPN NV, AtCostPlus and Oracle Corp say they will set up joint venture to sell office and computer supplies over Internet; KPN and AtCostPlus will each own more than 40 percent of venture (S)

abstract: Looking Back at My First PC

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Ethiopia: Rights Advocates Arrested
abstract: Two Ethiopian human rights advocates are arrested on charges of inciting student riots in which 41 people were reported killed (S)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Israel: 50 More Fighter Jets
abstract: Israeli air force orders more than 50 F-16 fighter jets from Lockheed Martin; purchase, worth $2 billion, will be financed largely by American military aid (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Microsoft Pursues AOL Opportunity
abstract: Microsoft Inc will spend estimated $50 million to advertise new price promotion intended to persuade America Online customers to switch to Microsoft's MSN Internet access (S)

headline: Satellite Venture Seeks Right To Offer Land-Based Service
abstract: New ICO Global Communications asks Federal Communications Commission to let it and rival companies develop land-based cellular service using radio-frequency spectrum reserved for satellite communications; says land-based systems would run in urban areas satellites cannot serve effectively because of interference from buildings and should be tied to satellite systems (M)

headline: When a Test Fails the Schools, Careers and Reputations Suffer
abstract: Second of two articles on largely unregulated educational testing industry and costly errors it sometimes makes; while drive to raise academic standards in public schools has led to boom in standardized testing, school districts lack ability to uncover serious testing errors, and must rely on testing companies to do so voluntarily; industry has succeeded in fending off various proposals for federal oversight, deciding themselves what they will disclose and when; error by test publisher CTB/McGraw Hill during 1999 school year, which jolted school districts in at least six states, including New York City, discussed; error victimized Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew, leading advocate of standardized tests to hold students and educators accountable, and may have cost him his job; showed incorrectly that reading scores citywide stagnated after rising for two years, mistakenly sending nearly 9,000 students off to summer school; photos; chart (L)

headline: World Briefing | United Nations: Vote On Annan Expected Soon
abstract: Amb Anwarul Karim Chowdhury of Bangladesh, this month's Security Council president, proposes that Council break with recent tradition and vote this month on second term for Secretary General Kofi Annan (S)

headline: BUSH LINKS TRADE WITH DEMOCRACY AT QUEBEC TALKS
abstract: Pres Bush tells leaders of Western Hemisphere that time has come to create single market from Arctic to tip of South America, and links such an accord to democracy in hemisphere; says he will proceed with negotiations over Free Trade Area of Americas only if it is combined with commitments to protecting environment and improving labor standards; leaves unstated critical question of whether any future trade accord would require all countries in hemisphere to adhere to minimum standards on environment and labor; sows even more confusion when he says, during meeting with Pres Vincente Fox of Mexico, that trade accords should not include 'codicils to destroy the spirit of free trade'; this statement confirms worst fears of protesters, 20,000 if whom take to streets of Quebec to oppose treaty; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Peregrine Systems Buying Competitor
abstract: Peregrine Systems Inc will acquire Remedy Corp for $1.08 billion in stock and cash; graph (S)

headline: Xerox, Under Audit Review, Delays Financial Report
abstract: Xerox Corp says filing of its annual financial statements will be delayed while its outside auditor, KPMG, conducts 'fuller audit review' (M)

headline: A Top Sinn Fein Leader Says He Was No. 2 in I.R.A.
abstract: Martin McGuinness, top leader of Sinn Fein political wing of Irish Republican Army, discloses his role as second in command of IRA on 'Bloody Sunday' in 1972 when 14 Roman Catholic civil rights demonstrators were killed by British Army soldiers; denies in statement to tribunal investigating incident allegations by soldier that he provoked attack by firing first shot; says he issued order that no armed IRA member should take part in march; once scruffy guerrilla leader has since become polished politician who helped negotiate 1998 Good Friday peace accord; is education minister for home rule government in Northern Ireland, created in 1998 pact; photo (M)

headline: U.S. WOULD DEFEND TAIWAN, BUSH SAYS
abstract: Pres Bush says if Taiwan comes under attack from China, he would order 'whatever it took' to help island defend itself; this is more explicit commitment to Taiwan than his recent predecessors have made; Bush does not say he would send American forces into battle with China, although during presidential campaign he questioned wisdom of policy of maintaining 'strategic ambiguity' about how US would react if hostilities broke out, and pledged that his administration would be 'clear about Taiwan'; Bush's comments trigger some confusion on Capitol Hill and among China experts over what he meant and what signals he is sending to Taiwan; 1979 Taiwan Relations Act commits United States to help Taiwan defend itself, but presidents have deliberately kept vague about how they would respond in case of armed conflict; photo (M)

headline: Big Dutch Insurer Sizes Up Potential Takeovers
abstract: ING, Dutch banking and insurance company, is considering more takeover targets in US, Canada, and Mexico; chief executive Ewald Kist says he wants to strengthen his US operations by buying mutual fund company or two, some life insurers and perhaps minority stake in big bank; adds he does not expect to make any bids for 18 months or so; says ING has decided to buy remaining 59 percent of Mexico's biggest insurer, Seguros Comercial America, in which ING took 41 percent stake last year; photo (M)

headline: With 2001 half over, experts' forecasts for spending become even gloomier than before.
abstract: Declines in ad spending in US for 2001 from 2000 are being predicted by John Perriss, chairman and chief executive at Zenith Media, Lauren Rich Fine, analysts who follows advertising industry for Merrill Lynch, and Robert J Coen, considered leading predictor of ad spending; this would be first such drop in decade (M)

headline: 'I Can't Talk Now. I'm Battling Aliens.'
abstract: Motorola loads Sega computer game Borkov into its two new telephone-computer organizer products; organizer applications and games on phones run on new Sun Microsystems platform; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Telecom Profit Surges
abstract: Australia's Cable and Wireless Optus posts stronger-than-expected profit of 423.8 million Australian dollars ($220.3 million) for fiscal year ended March 31, rise of 60 percent (S)

headline: A Baltimore Acquisition Is Part of Eisner's Plan
abstract: Eisner Communications acquires Underground Advertising, which will operate as Eisner Underground; forms two new divisions, Beverly & Eisner Communications and Eisner Interactive (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Drug Maker Profits
abstract: Serono, Europe's largest biotehnology company, posts first-quarter profit of $72 million, up 37.2 percent, with sales up 13.5 percent (S)

headline: EBay Irritates Some Sellers By Banning Links to Home Sites
abstract: EBay announces that, beginning May 31, it will prohibit sellers from linking to their own home pages from eBay pages listing items up for bid; many sellers are irritated by newly-enforced policy (M)

headline: 3 Companies Will Try to Identify All Human Proteins
abstract: Myriad Genetics Inc, Hitachi Ltd and Oracle Corp will spend up to half billion dollars to identify all proteins in human body and all interactions between those proteins; database will be made available for a fee to drug companies and, for reduced rate, to academic researchers; move is latest sign that biotechnology is turning attention from genes to proteins, which actually carry out body's functions and are thus of more direct medical interest (M)

headline: People
abstract: Nancy Barlow, senior vice president and managing director at Xchange Group, relationship marketing unit of CommonHealth, is named president, succeeding Matt Giegerich, who continues as president and chief executive at CommonHealth; Larry Reno is named to new position of managing partner and group account director on Deutsche Bank advertising account at Gotham Advertising; Rod Underhill, principal at Richards Group, is named to added post of chief executive at Spherical, new unit (S)

headline: New Policy Won't Slight Europe, Rumsfeld Says
abstract: Defense Sec Donald Rumsfeld says any efforts to realign America's defense strategies and resources toward Asia will not come at expense of NATO alliance; is on weeklong seven-nation European tour, during which he will try to reassure European allies about his review of Pentagon policies (S)

headline: Iquitos Journal; Simple, Devoted Lives on the Amazon
abstract: Fellow American missionaries attend memorial service in Iquitos, Peru, for Veronica Bowers, who with her infant daughter was killed by bullet fired by Peruvian Air Force fighter jet that was hunting what it thought was drug-trafficking plane; tragedy has been major embarrassment for Peruvian military and has led to suspension of US-Peruvian antidrug operations; it does not appear to have weakened ardor of remaining American missionary families who troll Amazon on their houseboats, playing gospel music, then spend days building churches, digging wells and teaching converts how to minister to their people; photo; map (M)

headline: Krispy Kreme Chooses GSD&M
abstract: Krispy Kreme Doughnuts formally names GSD&M to handle its brand communications after working with agency informally for last seven years; billings undetermined (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Limits On South Korean Fishing
abstract: Japan, asserting sovereignty over Kuri

headline: CYPRESS EARNINGS MISS ESTIMATES
abstract: Cypress Semiconductor, maker of computer chips used for telecommunications, says first-quarter earnings and revenue missed company forecasts as cancellations offset almost every order; revenue was $262 million, below Cypress's earlier estimate of $280 million (S)

headline: In Statement Of President: 'It Is Time'
abstract: Text of Pres Bush's statement on crew of American Navy plane being held in China

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Xerox Says Its Auditors Found No Signs of Fraud  Xerox, whose auditors had refused to sign off on its annual report until they had rechecked the numbers, said that the auditors, KPMG, found some accounting discrepancies but uncovered no signs of fraud.    KPMG did say the company had run afoul of generally accepted accounting principles, and Xerox adjusted its consolidated financial statements for the last three years. Shares of Xerox rose 88 cents, to $9.91. [Page C2.]

headline: Intel Reports Sharp Drop In Chip Sales
abstract: Intel Corp reports that sales dropped sharply from quarter one year earlier, but company slightly beats its lowered earnings forecasts; company executives say they are seeing signs that economic factors have begun to stabilize; company is engaging in aggressive price-cutting strategy, effort industry analysts say could degenerate into price war with Advanced Micro Devices; Intel reports earnings of $1.1 billion for its first fiscal quarter ended March 31; earnings per share represents decrease of 63 percent from first quarter last year, and of 58 percent from first quarter of 2000 (M)

headline: Spain and Argentina Find Themselves in Tangle Over Airline
abstract: Spanish company that controls Aerolineas Argentinas threatens to ground long-struggling airline once and for all, touching off nationalist outrage in Argentina; photo (M)

headline: How Bush Had to Calm Hawks In Devising a Response to China
abstract: Pres Bush, in his first serious foreign policy challenge, took conciliatory approach, suppressing his initial instincts and clamping down on some hawks in his administration and many uniformed commanders; appears to have balanced political instinct and professional advice, ultimately taking cautious path; did delegate to senior members of his administration, but from first moment he was peppering closest aides with questions about state of crew, strategy, and their interpretations of what was going on within Chinese leadership; early on Bush agreed that he should take step back, and that any letters to Chinese government should be sent in name of others, including Sec Colin Powell and Amb Joseph Prueher; using that approach, Bush did not use hotline with China to talk to Pres Jiang Zemin directly; rather, he called leaders of Britain, France, Brazil and Canada to encourage them to quietly press Chinese leaders; former national security advisers Brent Scowcroft and Henry Kissinger also made calls; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Web-Based Appliance Control
abstract: IBM and National Semiconductor to jointly develop products providing Internet-based remote control of home appliances; Shanghai General Electronics Group and C P Technology have committed selves to home-networking platform companies plan to develop (S)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Israel Raises Its Glass To Desalination; Water, Water Everywhere Just Waiting For Price to Drop
abstract: Government is taking bids on Israel's first large desalination project, to be build on Mediterranean south of Tel Aviv; plants promise to ease Israel's chronic water shortage and avert clashes with Arab neighbors over region's dwindling ground water supplies; will use energy-efficient filtration devices Israel has helped to perfect; continuing technological innovation has pushed price for desalted seawater down to affordable level; map; photos (M)

headline: Free Speech Advocates Laud Decision on Student Site
abstract: Civil liberties experts are applauding a district attorney's decision to forgo prosecuting two high school students who posted controversial comments on a Web site.

headline: Business Travel; Airlines await the return of business passengers, creating bargain opportunities in leisure fares.
abstract: Airlines are creating bargain opportunities in leisure fares as they await return of business passengers; Air Transport Association reported recently that average domestic air fares decline 2.5 percent in March from March 2000 (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Satellite Venture Seeks To Offer Service on Ground  New ICO Global Communications, the satellite communications venture that Craig O. McCaw rescued from bankruptcy last year, has asked the Federal Communications Commission to let it and rival companies develop land-based cellular service using radio-frequency spectrum reserved for satellite communications.    Without such a change in the rules, New ICO said, it is unlikely that any company will be able to develop high-speed Internet access and other broadband services for the vast areas beyond the reach of cable and high-capacity land-based wireless networks. [Page C2.]

headline: FPL CANCELS ITS ACQUISITION OF ENTERGY
abstract: FPL Group cancels $15.8 billion acquisition of Entergy Corp because of conflict over who would lead combined company, and FPL says Entergy gave conflicting earnings forecasts; Entergy's chief executive Wayne Leonard says FPL's chairman and chief executive, James Broadhead, planned to renege on agreement to make him chief executive of new company (S)

headline: In a Virtual Maze, Men Are Smart Rats
abstract: TORONTO -- When moving around in the real world, men and women generally use different strategies to get to the same place, cognitive research shows. But in the virtual world, subtle differences in spatial abilities are magnified, and men tend to perform better than women do in navigating computer- generated spaces, according to findings presented this month at the American Psychological Society's convention in Toronto.

headline: North Korea Promises to Extend Moratorium on Missile Tests
abstract: South Korean Pres Kim Dae Jung hails pledge by North Korean leader Kim Jong Il to maintain his nation's moratorium on missile testing until 2003 as unexpected dividend of talks with high-level European Union delegation; also expresses hopes for renewed dialogue between United States and North Korea (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ILLINOIS TOOL WORKS INC.,  Glenview, Ill., a maker of everything from auto parts to plastic packaging, said it had bought four welding-component businesses from the Dover Corp., New York, to add sales to wholesale distributors. Terms were not disclosed.    SCANA CORP.,  Columbia, S.C., owner of a South Carolina utility, plans to build a natural gas-fueled power plant in Jasper County for as much as $300 million to meet electricity demand by customers in the southern part of the state. The plant would generate 500 megawatts to 600 megawatts of power, enough for as many as 600,000 homes in the United States.

headline: Northwest in Accord With Its Mechanics
abstract: Northwest Airlines and its mechanics reached a tentative contract settlement, possibly ending more than four years of often fractious negotiations that ultimately led to White House intervention.    If approved, the four-year contract, which is slightly richer than an 11th-hour proposal made by the airline, would make Northwest's mechanics the highest paid in the industry.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: No Bank Sale
abstract: SeoulBank, one of two major banks taken over by government at height of South Korea's economic crisis in December 1997, will remain for sale for several more months (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Bayer Forecast
abstract: Bayer AG says earnings of its polymers business lag year-earlier results (S)4

headline: COMPANY THAT INVESTIGATES JOB APPLICANTS WILL BE SOLD
abstract: Automatic Data Processing, payroll processor, acquires Avert, which investigates job applicants, for about $81 million (S)

headline: GERMANY: UTILITY DISPUTE SETTLED
abstract: German utility E.ON AG settles dispute with Mirant Corp of Atlanta that will allow it to sell 49 percent stake in Bewag AG once lawmakers back plan; photo (S)

headline: For Noisy Speakers, The Sounds of Silence
abstract: Q. Often when I'm not playing any music or programs that use audio, I can hear music coming from my desktop speakers. What's going on?    A. Many types of amplified speakers, including those used with desktop computers, can be susceptible to radio-frequency interference. The interference can take different forms, from static noises to ominous hums or pop songs from radio stations coming out of the speakers.

headline: Cable and Wireless Feels Pressure of Too Much Cash
abstract: Cable and Wireless will soon have 6 billion pounds ($8.6 billion) in cash on hand and is under pressure from shareholders to return money to them rather than spend it on acquisitions; will buy back as much as 15 percent of its shares, up from previous plan to repurchase 8.7 percent of its stock outstanding; says that it lost 29 million pounds ($41.5 million) for year ended March 31, compared with profit of 293 million pounds year before; graph; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Middle East: Bahrain: Bond Issue
abstract: Bahrain plans to sell bonds that conform to Islamic law banning interest; bonds, 'certificates of peace,' mature in three months and offer share of earnings of state projects they will finance (S)

headline: Fed Medicine: Some Patients Are Too Sick to Be Helped
abstract: THE Federal Reserve is doing all it can. But its rate-cut medicine will take time to work and cannot help some parts of the economy.    Lower interest rates have helped the auto and housing markets, and the corporate lending market has opened up to some extent. But borrowing costs for creditworthy companies are not down very much. The Fed's four rate cuts this year have stirred hopes for a quick recovery, thereby putting upward pressure on long-term rates.

headline: More Cutbacks by Consultants As Accenture Trims Its Payroll
abstract: Accenture, consulting firm formerly known as Andersen Consulting, will lay off about 600 support-staff employees and encourage up to 800 consultants to take voluntary sabbaticals for up to one year as it attempts to control costs (M)

headline: Bush to Tackle Delicate Issue of Resuming China Spy Flights
abstract: White House says Pres Bush would personally decide when to resume reconnaissance flights along Chinese coast and whether planes, which have previously flown unescorted, should be protected by American fighter aircraft; how and when to resume flights emerges as sensitive issue; Bush is not expected to come to any conclusions until after American military officials meet with Chinese officials to review causes of midair collision Apr 1; Pentagon officials say sending fighter escort with slow-moving EP-3E's would probably appear provocative to Chinese, and warn that escort could have clash, even inadvertent one, with Chinese jets chasing reconnaissance plane (M)

headline: Blue Cross Offers to Aid Uninsured in Its For-Profit Plan
abstract: Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shief, in move to win support for plan to become publicly traded for-profit company, says it is ready to establish $1 billion charitable foundation that could bring health care to 100,000 uninsured children or buy prescriptions drugs for 50,000 low-income elderly people in New York; says its continued viability would be jeopardized and its potential for public health service dissipated unless company is allowed to restructure; approval of restructuring by New York State Legislature has been blocked by opposition led by Greater New York Hospital Assocation and Dennis Rivera, head of politically influential Service Employees International Union; letter from investment bankers at Credit Suisse First Boston values Empire at $1 billion to $1.2 billion (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Mission Control For the Home
abstract: La-Z-Boy marketing director Kevin R Wixted introduces Explorer e-cliner, reclining chair with built-in keyboard connected to Sony WebTV Plus receiver for television and Internet use; photos (M)

headline: Pilots Reach Tentative Deal With Comair
abstract: Comair, commuter carrier of Delta Air Lines, and its striking pilots reach tentative agreement, on 81st day of strike; terms undisclosed (M)

headline: MERCER, A CONSULTING FIRM, WILL LAY OFF 159 WORKERS
abstract: William M Mercer, human resources consulting firm, will lay off 159 workers, about 3.3 percent of its work force (S)

headline: Sport Utility Vehicles And the Right to the Road
abstract: To the Editor:     In this country, the guiding principle has been that we can be as free as we wish, until we impinge upon the freedoms of others. Last night, when taking my friends out to dinner, I was forced to park in a much less desirable location because a GMC Yukon had taken up two parking spaces near the entrance.

headline: The Latest Fitness Craze: Play More Video Games
abstract: Stationary bicycle incorporated into two Hollywood Engineering devices integrates actual physical cycling into any Sony PlayStation computer racing game; photo (S)

headline: Microsoft and NBC to Merge Financial Web Sites
abstract: Continuing to scale back its exposure to the Internet, NBC said today that it would merge its CNBC.com site into the personal finance area of Microsoft's MSN site.

headline: Are Index Funds Great Literature?
abstract: IN the pantheon of great investors, index fund managers are all but invisible.    Doomed to lag behind the performance of the hottest mutual funds while the market is going up, they also fail to attract great cheers when their funds sink no lower than the market during a downturn. No one asks them for impassioned reviews of their favorite stocks, nor do shareholders flock to their presentations at mutual fund confabs, breathlessly waiting for a chance to tell them how they have guaranteed young Johnny's college education.

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Yen falls after report showing Japanese household spending fell in Apr and Japanese stock prices fall; graphs; table (S)

headline: Timberland Drops The Martin Agency
abstract: Timberland Co begins review for its worldwide account that does not include its current advertising agency, Martin Agency (S)

headline: PUTIN SAYS RUSSIA WOULD ADD ARMS TO COUNTER SHIELD
abstract: Russia's Pres Vladimir V Putin says if US proceeds unilaterally to construct missile defense shield, Russia would eventually upgrade its strategic nuclear arsenal with multiple warheads to overwhelm it, reversing achievement of arms control in recent decades; tells American journalists in Moscow that although he is buoyed by Pres Bush's pledge that both countries will work cooperatively to investigate full ramifications of Bush's vision for new security network, Russia is also very alert to unilateral American actions; says Russia will not threaten or try to prevent US from building missile shield, but will augment its nuclear forces without regard to treaties that currently require elimination of multiple warheads; says Start I and Start II treaties would be negated by any American decision, which would eliminate verification and inspection requirements and revive era in which Russia would hide abilities and intentions; says Russia is ready to move expeditiously on talks with Bush administration, but that both sides should first discuss whether serious threats actually exist or might emerge in future; says both should then decide what missile technologies may be brought to bear against them, and what provisions of ABM treaty are in conflict with such system; photo (M)

headline: An Unpredictable Politician Moves for Japanese Premier's Job
abstract: Junichiro Koizumi, most idiosyncratic of politicians now vying for leadership of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party, declares that he wants to become country's next prime minister; Koizumi pledges to overhaul Japanese politics and economy; also pledges to force overhaul of banking system and corporate sector to rid Japanese economy once and for all of bad debts that have brought its financial system to brink of collapse and stifled economic vitality; Koizumi exhibits form of bravado that has made him popular with voters (M)

headline: GE Capital to Buy Mellon Units
abstract: GE Capital to Buy Mellon Units**GE Capital agrees to buy two equipment financing and leasing businesses from Mellon Financial; financial terms undisclosed (M)

headline: This Old Thing? I've Had It Forever
abstract: THERE are those who will tell you that hiding purchases from your spouse is a bad thing. Until recently, I was fully prepared to be one of those critics.     I was ready to skewer those women who hide their shopping bags behind their couches just as their mothers did. (Get past your parents' pathetic money script, ladies.) I planned to wag my finger at husbands who secretly fritter away hundreds of dollars at monthly poker games. (Come on, boys. We still admire your big muscles and manly wallet even if you lose at poker.) I knew that within many a covert spender lay jumbo-sized vices -- like adultery.    But just as I was climbing on my high horse, I noticed something strange. Everyone is pretty darn cheerful about this supposedly deep, dark disorder.     Ellen Perry, president of Family Office Solutions, a financial consulting practice in Washington, said concealment often signified trouble in a relationship. ''It's all tied up around the base issues: fear, power and jealousy,'' she said. But the conversation lightened considerably when we started giggling about the contortions some women perform to avoid the dreaded ''Is that new?'' question. With every other woman I talked to, the giggles started immediately.     And why not? One friend puts her Saks designer clothes in plastic dry-cleaning bags, both to disguise and to  explain their immaculate newness. She also hides the bill for the joint Visa card, roundly denouncing a lax billing policy when her husband asks why the bill hasn't yet arrived. Another friend hid her collagen injections for more than a year, timing the red, puffy aftereffects to coincide with her husband's business trips.    My sister, Betsy Russell, 50, of Greensboro, Ga., who has camouflaged her purchases for so long that it has become second nature, can catalog entire periods of her life according to the prevailing method of deception. The expensive outfits by St. John, each costing more than a computer, were easy to hide: the secret was to buy every piece in black, the completely husband-proof color. Over the years, Betsy has become expert at disposing of telltale boxes and packaging, but she only recently perfected a new-shoe sleight of hand. She places a just-out-of-the-box designer shoe on each perfectly manicured hand, walks out to her driveway, bends over and scrapes the soles on the gravel.    We know this is silly. And though there should be a convenient pattern here -- that women without their own income are more prone to hide purchases, for example -- it doesn't  seem to exist. Wealthy women, wives who run the family finances and women who earn more than their husbands tend to hide purchases as readily as women on allowances. As Juliet Johnson, 42, a voice-over performer in Short Hills, N.J., who says she is less than frank with her husband about -- gasp! -- her late fees on credit cards, explained: ''It's not because I'm spending joint money. It's because I don't want to be judged on how I'm spending my money.''   IS taking a brief vacation from spousal judgment a sign of marital decay? Or just one of the ways  that women carve out a little privacy from all that togetherness and sharing they do most of the time? There is a friendly, unspoken competition under the surface of most marriages: the Who Is Working Harder Contest. You are both in the harness, pulling for all you are worth. If one of you spends $130 for a body massage and a pedicure, the partner suddenly feels that his or her yoke is uncomfortably tight, the load a little unbearable and your behavior just a touch unfair. Sometimes it is easier to keep those personal indulgences off the ledger.     You may have noticed in this column that there are no men hiding shopping bags, dissembling about the cost of their golf lesson or pretending that their new suit was on sale. There are two reasons. First, many don't do it. In fact, in the 75 families with whom Ms. Perry has worked, not one of the men feels guilty about his purchases. ''If they buy an extravagant boat or a fancy car, they call up all their friends to come see it,'' she said. ''They get a huge amount of joy from it.''    Second, men are underrepresented here because their definition of hiding differs very conveniently from their wives'. Of the dozen men with whom I talked, only one admitted to any spending deceit. But ask a man if he tells his wife about the cost of his night at Hooters, the $250 he lost on golf-course bets or his January investment in Nasdaq stocks, and he'll say no. There is no guilt, no sheepishness and definitely no giggles. What I detect in their tone is reproach, disappointment that I have failed to grasp who they really are: ''Surely you don't think a man like me needs to discuss such trivial expenditures with his wife?''     Actually, they are right. Every female hider said she did not care about her husband's extravagances. And the men? Would they roar if they discovered a hidden lode of new purchases? Not at all. Or so they said. Maybe I'll try it out on my husband with that afternoon at the spa I have been coveting. Nah. Let's just keep that between you and me.

The group was responsible for the sarin gas attack on March 20, 1995, which killed 12 people and sickened thousands. headline: EMC REPORTS SALES AND PROFIT GAINS
abstract: EMC, which makes data storage equipment for big corporate computer systems, said yesterday that its sales were up 29 percent in the first quarter from a year earlier, to $2.3 billion. Its profits increased 20 percent, to $399 million. The report matched last week's announcement of the company's preliminary results, which were lower than analysts had expected. EMC earned 18 cents a share, compared with the 20 cents analysts had been expecting. Speaking with analysts, the company's chairman, Michael C. Ruettgers, presented an upbeat forecast, suggesting that the sharp decline in corporate computer purchases may be bottoming out. Thomas Kraemer, an analyst with Merrill Lynch, disagreed. ''The survey work we have done suggests that the spending environment will continue to deteriorate,'' Mr. Kraemer said.   Saul Hansell (NYT)

About 170 of them, or a third of the total, chose the magazine.

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: AMERICAS    CANADA: BLUE RUG PRECEDES RED CARPET -- Prince Charles arrived in Ottawa yesterday at the start of a six-day visit and took precautions against bringing foot-and-mouth disease from Britain. With a broad smile, the Prince of Wales carefully wiped his feet on a blue rug soaked in disinfectant -- as all visitors from Britain are now required to do when arriving in Canada -- before stepping onto the red carpet for his official welcome. Sébastien Bois, the official media coordinator for the visit, said the prince and his entourage had been asked to launder their clothes specially before coming to Canada aboard a Canadian Forces Airbus.    (Agence France-Presse)    BOLIVIA: STRIKE ERUPTS IN VIOLENCE -- Two people were killed in clashes between the police and protesters during a 24-hour transportation strike that paralyzed much of the country. The strike came after talks between union and government leaders on a number of economic issues broke down. Opposition leaders are planning a national strike in early May in an attempt to force the resignation of President Hugo Banzer.      Clifford Krauss (NYT)

abstract: VeriSign Inc's deal with Icann extending at least through 2007 its control of database that stores Internet's .com addresses is raising concerns among rivals and critics, who say company may have unfair edge in increasingly lucrative market for reselling Internet addresses; deal lets VeriSign keep its separate business of registering and selling Internet addresses; people who have tried to register expired domain names say process is unnecessarily vague, spurring speculation that VeriSign holds onto expired names for longer than necessary; photos (M)

headline: U.S. Loses a Trade Dispute With Europe
abstract: World Trade Organization dispute panel finds United States tax subsidy for businesses violates trade rules; ruling in favor of European Union may result in Europe's imposing $4 billion in sanctions; at issue is foreign sales corporation program, which partially exempts from taxes profits offshore units of American companies earn from sales of certain goods (M)

headline: PROFIT NEWS LIFTS EARTHLINK
abstract: Earthlink says first-quarter loss narrowed to $107.7 million; revenue was $294.9 million, up 34 percent from year earlier; graph (S)

headline: Webdenda: Executive Changes at Media Firms
abstract: Sheila Leyne, co-director for the public relations group at Mullen, Wenham, Mass., part of the Lowe Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, was named senior vice president and director for public relations. She takes over duties that had been handled by Peter Greer, who left to become public relations principal at VIA Inc., Portland, Me.

headline: SINGAPORE'S GROWTH SLOWS
abstract: Singapore cuts its forecast for economic growth this year by 1.5 percentage points, to range of 3.5 percent to 5.5 percent; first-quarter growth was unexpectedly low 4.6 percent annual rate (S)

headline: Pentagon Review Puts Emphasis On Long-Range Arms in Pacific
abstract: Confidential Pentagon strategy review, part of Sec Donald H Rumsfeld's broad effort to transform military after cold war, casts Pacific as most important region for military planning and calls for development of new long-range arms to counter China's military power; urges less reliance on military bases and more stress on fighting from afar, warning America's Pacific bases are likely to become increasingly vulnerable as China and other potential foes develop more accurate missiles; review is directed by Andrew W Marshall, who has long pressed for radical overhaul of armed forces; Adm Dennis C Blair, who heads United States Pacific Command, backs change, but holds China will present less of threat to American bases and naval forces in region, interview; photos (M)

headline: A Camera Stares Into the Light But Doesn't Blink
abstract: Sarnoff Corp develops tiny, low-cost digital video camera, based on complementary metal oxide semiconductor technology; camera, called Blinc, can produce still and video images and match ability of human eye to deal with widely varying light levels; photo (M)

headline: Making A Judgement On a Moving Target
abstract: Analysis of US Appeals Court ruling in antitrust case against Microsoft says decision leaves unanswered question facing computer industry: will Microsoft have to change how it acts? holds indications are that it is exercising some of same types of power that led appellate judges to uphold trial court's finding that Microsoft abused its monopoly power in software business; charts; photo (M)

headline: IRELAND: WEDGWOOD PROFIT IS UP
abstract: Waterford Wedgwood posts 2000 profit of 68.6 million euros ($61.3 million), up 22 percent from 1999; stock price graph (S)

headline: SOUTH KOREA TO SUPPORT CURRENCY
abstract: Bank of Korea plans to dip into foreign exchange reserves for first time since economic crisis of 1997 and 1998 to shore up declining Korean won; cites fears that won's sharp fall could destabilize economy and unnerve financial markets (S)

headline: Move Against Barbara Walters Touches a Nerve
abstract: Eviction of Barbara Walters' edition of 20/20 from its Friday night time slot has unified ABC News division, with Walters cast as martyr in battle to defend news coverage even though some of her colleagues have long sniffed at what they consider her softer, show-business approach to news; shift has tapped into news divisions' growing sense of its waning relevance; photo (M)

headline: UBS of Switzerland Reports A 29% Decrease in Profit
abstract: UBS AG reports 29 percent decline in first-quarter profit, to 1.58 billion Swiss francs, or $915 million (M)

headline: Milosevic's Guards Put Up Fierce Fight Saturday Morning
abstract: Article describes early-morning arrest of former Yugoslav Pres Slobodan Milosevic at home in suburb of Belgrade (M)

headline: Compressed Data; Register for a Nest Egg Instead of a Gravy Boat
abstract: GreenWish.com, new online gift registry, allows recipients to register for cash and stock instead of traditional gifts; charges givers small transaction fee; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Whale Hunt Begins
abstract: Three Japanese ships leave for Northwest Pacific to begin two-month whale hunt; other countries and conservation groups charge claim of 'research' is front for commercial whaling (S)

headline: DataBank; Mostly Bad News Draws Mostly Cheers
abstract: Stocks end week on high note amid expectations that most of bad news is past; Dow Jones Industrial Average's 141.19-point gain to 10,951.24 raised it 1.3 percent; 13.56-point Standard & Poors 500-stock index rise to 1,266.61 is 1.1 percent gain; Nasdaq composite index gains 115.85 to close at 2,191.53, up 5.6 percent; Treasury market rallies; 10-year Treasury note's yield falls from 5.32 percent to 5.20 percent; charts; table of rates and yields (M)

headline: As Heads Are Spinning
abstract: Michael McKay's letter speaks to issue of copying data, as addressed in May 17 article on digital audio formats

headline: Rules of TV Business Change as Network Race Tightens
abstract: Broadcast television rules for success and fortunes of each network are in flux as networks wrap up season and announce fall plans; four-network rating race is closer than it has ever been; ABC and Fox are giving same-week repeats regular positions in fall schedule; several networks will also repeat their programs on related cable networks in same week; reality shows are essential parts of fall schedule, while comedy and network television movies are in eclipse; photos (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; At American Express, a Fall In Expectations And Earnings
abstract: American Express Co says its first-quarter earnings will decline about 18 percent from period year earlier, chief because of bigger-than-expected losses on its junk bond investments; offers fairly gloomy forecast for its corporate charge-card business (Market Place column) (M)

headline: GUINNESS STRIKE ENDS
abstract: After just one day on the picket lines, five unions at the Guinness Ireland Group, a unit of Diageo P.L.C., called off a nationwide strike that had threatened to dry up Ireland's supply of beer. The walkout ended when management agreed to postpone the closing of a packaging and bottling plant in Dundalk that employs 140 people. The two sides will resume government-supervised talks next week about the future of the plant and about the company's plans to reorganize its Irish operations.   Brian Lavery (NYT)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: The Frugal Palace
abstract: British royal family issues first annual report, showing that Queen Elizabeth II reduced spending to $49 million, down $4.2 million, from previous year (S)

headline: New Yorker Sets Record At Magazine Awards
abstract: New Yorker magazine wins record five awards, and several lesser-known magazines stage upset at National Magazine Awards, sponsored by American Society of Magazine Editors (M)

headline: For First Time, U.S. Is Excluded From U.N. Human Rights Panel
abstract: United States is voted off United Nations Human Rights Commission for first time since panel's founding under Americanleadership in 1947; move reflects growing frustration with America's attitude toward international organizations and treaties; ouster of US while nations like Sudan and Pakistan are chosen for membership is certain to generate further hostility to United Nations among conservatives in Washington; unexpected move, coming in secret vote, is apparently supported even by some friends of US; also elected to commission are Bahrain, Korea, Pakistan, Croatia, Armenia, Chile, Mexico, Sierra Leone, Sudan, Togo and Uganda; Amnesty International USA says removal of US from commission is part of effort by rights-violating countries to escape scrutiny (M)

headline: New Twist In BP Dispute In Russia
abstract: BP PLC's long-running dispute with Tyumen Oil Co has taken unexpected turn, throwing into doubt agreement between Tyumen and Russian oil company Sidanko; Tyumen-affiliated companies has purchased 40 percent stake in Sidanko from Kantupan Holdings, Cyprus-registered group of foreign investors; purchase, which could give Tyumen controlling stake, throws into doubt not only agreement between Sidanko and Tyumen, but also BP's investment strategy in Russia (M)

headline: NBC to Shut Most of Its NBCi Web Portal
abstract: NBC will spend $85 million to buy all outstanding shares of its online spinoff, NBC Internet, and probably shut down most of those operations (M)

headline: Wieden & Kennedy Is Cutting Staff 12%
abstract: Wieden & Kennedy advertising agency is laying off 12 percent of 314 workers at Portland, Ore, headquarters and New York office (S)

headline: Questioning By Chinese Is Intense
abstract: Pentagon officials say meetings with American crew detained in China are shedding added light on circumstances of collision between their surveillance plane and Chinese jet fighter; say Chinese have intensely question crew both about crash and about other aspects of their duties and operations aboard sensitive spy plane (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: EUROPE

headline: A campaign to turn a mattress maker into a 'wellness provider.'
abstract: Sealy Inc, largest manufacturer of mattresses, initiates multimedia campaign to promote importance of sleep; plans include forming partnership with National Sleep Foundation to help educate consumers about benefits of good night's sleep; hires Dot Richardson, surgeon and Olympic softball player, as its spokeswoman; $20 million campaign was developed by ad agency Mullen/LHC; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Illegal Immigrants Caught
abstract: Fishing boat carrying 199 illegal immigrants from Bangladesh, Afghanistan and other countries is intercepted by coast guard off southern Italy; in separate case, 24 illegal immigrants, reportedly Turkish Kurds, are picked up near highway in Calabria (S)

headline: SUN ORDERS WORKERS TO TAKE A VACATION
abstract: Sun Microsystems, seeking to cut costs and avoide widespread layoffs, asks most of its 38,000 United States workers to take off first week of July as paid vacation or unpaid leave while it temporarily halts production (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Gauging Interest In Loans
abstract: Chinese bankers visit New York to gauge investor interest in about $2 billion of nonperforming loans and real estate assets from China's state-owned Industrial and Commercial Bank of China (S)

headline: Article 2001040990390042917 -- No Title
abstract: In the Storage Race, Will Consumers Win?

headline: In Cuba, Clashing Voices Over Ideals and Reality
abstract: Cubans still struggle struggle to make ends meet economically more than 40 years after revolution; ever since collapse of Soviet Union and its subsidies, growth has come mainly from tourism, which has served chiefly to remind them of gap between themselves and outside world instead of helping them better their lives; map; photos (M)

headline: Investing Diary: At the Big Board, the Future Is Late
abstract: Right where, right when?

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Manufacturing Setback
abstract: German manufacturing orders fell 4.4 percent, March, bigger-than-expected drop (S)

headline: Hollywood Talks to Restart
abstract: Writers Guild of America and Hollywood movie and television studios will resume negotiations on new contract about two weeks before union's contract is set to expire (S)

headline: World Briefing | United Nations: Council Hears Workers' Concerns
abstract: United Nations Security Council meets for first time with representatives of UN employees to hear about dangers facing staff workers around world; in last decade, 200 civilians on UN assignments have been killed on duty (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Price Increases Slow
abstract: German consumer prices rose 0.2 percent in June, less than half May's 0.5 percent gain, making more likely that European Central Bank will reduce interest rates as growth slows; annual inflation rate declined to 3.1 percent from 3.5 percent in May (S)

headline: More Cuts by Burnett In Technology Agency
abstract: Leo Burnett USA will close Boston office of its Leo Burnett Technology Group and consolidate remaining operations at its Chicago office; will offer lay off 8 employees (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: 2 Executed In Xinjiang
abstract: China executes two ethnic Uighurs in far western Xinjiang province for making explosives and accepting money from abroad as part of independence campaign (S)

headline: Survivor: The New Economy
abstract: Matt Richtel column suggests several reality television shows about Silicon Valley people watching their stocks tank; drawing (M)

headline: Article 2001042594080312977 -- No Title
abstract: Bike Power: Tired Legs Get a Leg Up

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: A Slap At Taiwan
abstract: Vincent Siew, a former prime minister of Taiwan from the long-ruling Nationalist Party, which lost the presidency last year, held talks in Beijing with China's top foreign policy official, Deputy Prime Minister Qian Qichen. China has shunned Taiwan's new president, Chen Shui-bian, refusing to meet him unless he accepts the ''one China'' principle, and has met with opposition leaders like Mr. Siew in an effort to isolate and pressure him.   Erik Eckholm (NYT)

headline: Falun Gong Members Mark '99 Sit-In With New Protests
abstract: BEIJING, April 25 â€” Members of the banned Falun Gong spiritual group staged small scattered protests today on Tiananmen Square in an attempt to mark the second anniversary of a huge silent sit-in the group held outside the Chinese leadership compound in 1999, seeking government recognition.

headline: Vodafone Picks Wieden & Kennedy
abstract: Vodafone Group names Wieden & Kennedy's Amsterdam office as its lead advertising agency, responsible for creating global campaigns as company moves to single mobile phone brand (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar falls against euro after Federal Reserve cuts interest rates, raising concern that US economy is weaker than previously thought; in New York, euro settles at 88.53 cents, up from 88.22 cents; graph; chart (S)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: SOFTWARE

headline: Finding Free Internet Access for Those Without
abstract: Prodded by high-profile efforts to close the gap between students with access to technology and students without, 98 percent of the countryâ€™s public schools have been wired for Internet connections. But for many low-income students, that access disappears once schools close their doors for the summer.

headline: Wahid Reshuffles Cabinet to Aid Indonesian Economy
abstract: BANGKOK, June 12 â€” In his latest bid to cling to power, President Abdurrahman Wahid of Indonesia shuffled his economic team today, reassigning a chief minister who had clashed with the International Monetary Fund.

headline: Sales Up 14% In a Microsoft Profit Surprise
abstract: Shaking off its lethargy from last quarter, Microsoft showed strong growth in many areas of its business, increasing its revenue for its third quarter by 14 percent, to $6.46 billion.    For the quarter ended March 31, Microsoft said it had net income of $2.45 billion, or 44 cents a share, 2 cents higher than the consensus of Wall Street analysts as reported by Thomson Financial/First Call.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Loss At Software Concern
abstract: Baltimore Technologies will cut 250 of its 1,400 jobs to reduce costs by nearly $50 million after posting first-quarter loss of $24.4 million; graph (S)

headline: Rumsfeld's Office Reverses China Ban
abstract: Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld's office orders suspension of military exchanges and contacts with Chinese armed forces and then abruptly reverses order after White House objects; unusual Pentagon retraction reflects degree of confusion in admininstration that tries to project disciplined management style; it underscores divisions among Pres Bush's advisers over how tough to be with China after confrontation over American surveillance plane that remains at Chinese military base on Hainan Island (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: ASIA

headline: Article 2001042193409408687 -- No Title
abstract: April 21, 2001

headline: Some Possible Carrots and Sticks
abstract: There is remote chance that Microsoft Corp could be broken up; US Appeals Court left some room in its order that lower court reconsider remedy for finding that Microsoft had abused its monopoly power in software business; resolution will depend largely on next judge (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Rwanda: Investigator Charged In Killings
abstract: A defense investigator reportedly working under an assumed name at the United Nations tribunal into the 1994 genocide in Rwanda was arrested on charges of having taken part in the killings. The authorities say that Simeon Nshamihigo, working for defense lawyers at the tribunal in Tanzania, had been a prosecutor in southern Rwanda at the time of the genocide, in which at least 500,000 ethnic Tutsis were killed.   Ian Fisher (NYT)

headline: Economy Grew Less Than 2% for 2 Quarters
abstract: US economy grows by annual rate of 1.3 percent in first quarter, the second consecutive quarters in which growth has been less than two percent; businesses reduce inventories; spending by businesses falls 13.3 percent; consumer spending grows 2.9 percent; consumer sentiment rises; April factory orders for durable goods drops $9.8 billion, or 5 percent; charts (M)

headline: Webdenda: Executive Changes at Media Firms
abstract: Christopher Drew was named to the new post of vice president for corporate planning at Brierley & Partners, Dallas. He had been vice president for corporate development and finance at NextJet Inc., Dallas. Brierley is 20 percent owned by the WPP Group.

headline: Warnaco Given Some Relief by Lenders
abstract: The Warnaco Group Inc., whose shares have fallen 92 percent in the last year, said yesterday that it received a waiver by its lenders of certain financial covenants through May 16.     Warnaco, the maker of Fruit of the Loom and Polo by Ralph Lauren clothes, said that it was holding talks to secure permanent amendments to the covenants. The move is necessary to avoid a possible default after the waivers expire, Warnaco said.

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: TELECOMMUNICATIONS

headline: In Old-Time Boss's Redoubt, Mexico Tests Political Wind
abstract: Election in Mexico's Yucatan, stronghold of longtime political boss Victor Cervera, will test whether Pres Vicente Fox's victory was truly tidal wave of change; Cervera has used every means, legal and otherwise, to delay vote and keep out observers to protect hand-picked successor Orlando Paredesfrom challenge of Patricio Patron; photos; map (M)

headline: Chief of America West Plans To Step Down at End of 2002
abstract: William Franke will retire as chairman and chief executive of America West Holdings with expiration of his contract at end of 2002 (M)

headline: Fidelity Also Buys, a Lot
abstract: Fidelity Investments bought $6 billion of stock of a number of high-tech companies at same time it was divesting itself of stock of several favorites in the sector (S)

headline: McDONALD'S EXPECTS DROP IN PROFIT TO DEEPEN
abstract: McDonald's Corp expects that second-quarter profits will drop more than anticipated (S)

headline: BIG MARGIN IS SEEN AS LEADER IN IRAN WINS SECOND TERM
abstract: Pres Mohammad Khatami of Iran appears to be on way to landslide re-election victory with more than 75 percent of vote, even bigger margin than his impressive triumph in 1997; former labor minister, Ahmed Tavakoli, gets 14 percent of vote, and Defense Min Ali Shamkhani is third with 2.5 percent; outcome is expected to give Khatami mandate to continue pressing for reforms that have been largely thwarted in his first term by conservative clerics who cling tightly to power in Iran; election is being called referendum on Khatami's promises to institute greater democracy and additional personal freedom in country whose increasingly younger population feels suffocated by austere Islamic laws; photo (M)

headline: Exports and a Weaker Currency Help Kia to 117% Rise in Income
abstract: Kia Motors Corp reports first-quarter net profit jumped 117.5 percent, to about $88.5 million (M)

headline: Rebel Group In Colombia Kidnaps 100, But Frees 70
abstract: National Liberation Army, leftist rebel group, kidnaps about 100 Colombian employees of Occidental Petroleum and later releases at least 70; experts see mass abduction as effort by ever-weakening rebel movement to gain recognition (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising changes (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Global Crossing Buys Switches
abstract: Global Crossing Ltd signs multimillion-dollar contract to buy new all-optical switches from Lucent Technologies Inc for use in US and Europe (S)

headline: Tobacco Producers Are Willing to Talk With Justice Dept.
abstract: Some of nation's big tobacco companies are willing to meet with Justice Department officials to discuss possibility of ending government's multibillion-dollar lawsuit against them; cigarette makers like Philip Morris, responding to overtures made by Bush administration, say they will consider department's conditions for dropping suit, but give few indications that they will agree to any significant concessions; R J Reynolds says it has no intention of settling suit, but will join in talks (M)

headline: Milosevic Should Face Trial By Hague Tribunal, Bush Says
abstract: Pres Bush praises Yugoslav government for arresting former president Slobodan Milosevic, but cautions that extent of his crimes warrants trial before UN war crimes tribunal in The Hague and not just trial on local charges in Serbia; suggests Yugoslavia has done well enough in meeting conditions that call for coopertation with war crimes tribunal before American economic assistance is released (M)

headline: Guatemalan Court Sentences 3 Soldiers for 1998 Murder of Bishop
abstract: Guatemalan court sentences three military men to 30 years in prison for 1998 murder of Roman Catholic Bishop Juan Gerardi, who was killed two days after he released report that blamed military for most of 200,000 killings in country's 36-year civil war; court also orders that three other high-ranking officers be investigated for possible complicity; human rights advocates hail verdict as bold strike against official impunity; those sentenced are Disrael Lima, retired colonel, his son, Byron Lima, and Jose Obdulio Villanueva; verdict also results in 20-year sentence for Rev Mario Orantes, priest who helped cover up murder; three years leading up to trial have been marked by death threats against prosecutors, judges and witnesses (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Iran: Ayatollah Backs Media Inquiry
abstract: Iran's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, intervenes in favor of reformers and orders probe into finances of state-run radio and television (S)

headline: Surrounded? Help!
abstract: Robert Gilliard letter replies to June 14 article about Surround Light

headline: Ford May Reshuffle Management in Wake of Tire Problems
abstract: Ford Motor Co is expected to reshuffle senior management in attempt to repair its tarnished reputation in wake of problems with tires and safety; quality-control issues predominate in company's plans; tens of millions of tires must be replaced (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Brewer Profits
abstract: Australia's Lion Nathan says its profit rose 16 percent, to 89 million Australian dollars ($46.3 million), in first half of year (S)

headline: Patents; Several kitchen inventions try to save time and space and reduce guesswork with automation.
abstract: Masahiro Sone patents refrigerator with inventory processing system that keeps track of what is inside and can call grocery to order more food; Ford Bowers patents microwave oven with bar-code reader that can follow cooking instructions on packages of prepared food; Samsung Electronics Co patents microwave oven that can detect how much food is inside and cook it appropriately; Maytag Corp patents sink with heating element and colander for boiling food (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Kyrgyzstan: A Dangerous Border
abstract: Kyrgyzstan government calls on neighboring Uzbekistan to disclose location of antipersonnel mines planted along border between countries after two people are wounded; Uzbekistan says it planted mines along its borders to keep out Islamic insurgents (S)

headline: Europe Indicates to G.E. New Offer Is Unacceptable
abstract: European regulators tell General Electric Co that its last-minute effort to revive its proposed acquisition of Honeywell International will not be enough, sounding death knell for $45 billion deal; GE is not expected to come back with new proposal (M)

headline: Bush Is Likely to Meet Putin During June Visit to Europe
abstract: United States officials say Pres Bush will probably meet Russian Pres Vladimir N Putin during June visit to Europe; topics will include friction over US missile defense plans and Bush's reluctance to provide added financial aid to Russia (M)

headline: Goldman Is Enlisting Regional Partners
abstract: The Goldman Sachs Group said yesterday that it would form partnerships with 13 regional brokerage firms to expand the distribution of its research and products and generate more trading business.

headline: A Match Not Made in Heaven; How a Rabbi's Foray Into Online Dating Ended Up in Court
abstract: Rabbi Shmuley Boteach just wanted to bring Jewish men and women together -- and if he could get rich in the Internet boom, all the better.    So when Rabbi Boteach, the Hasidic author of ''Kosher Sex'' and ''Dating Secrets of the Ten Commandments,'' was introduced early last year to the Israeli founders of an online dating venture that was about to go public, it seemed like a match made in heaven.
