headline: Accounts
abstract: Advertising account changes noted (S)

headline: AOL Raising Monthly Rate 9%; a Rival May Follow Suit
abstract: America Online says it will increase price of its flagship online service by 9 percent, to $23.90 per month; Earthlink is considering similar move (M)

headline: Official Questions the Math Behind California's Energy Bond Issue
abstract: Controller Kathleen Connell questions math behind California's plans for $13.4 billion bond sale, calculating that by time bonds go to market in October--as currently planned--only about $1 billion of proceeds will be left to buy additional power; State Treasurer Philip Angelides is concerned that if various state officials fail to make some critical decisions in next few weeks, plans for October bond sale will be in jeopardy; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Auto Cutbacks
abstract: General Motors' German subsidiary, Adam Opel AG, will shutter its German factories for two weeks longer than its usual two-week summer vacation; lost $257 million in 2000 and another $86 million in first quarter of 2001 (S)

headline: EUROPE: AVIS WARNS ON SALES
abstract: Avis Europe, rental car business, says sales growth will slow in 2001, as pace of economic growth falters and foot-and-mouth epidemic in Britain hampers tourism in region (S)

headline: Ford Tries to Burnish Image By Looking to Cut Emissions
abstract: Ford Motor Co reaffirms its concerns about global warming, but says it does not support stiffer federal-economy standards or international Kyoto Protocol on greenhouse gas emissions as ways to address problem; says it has formed committee of executives to examine ways to reduce company's contribution to global warming; Ford report estimates that Ford factories and vehicles around world emitted about 400 million metric tons of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases per year, or about 2 percent of all emissions caused by people; environmental advocates praise Ford for being willing to address issue of global warming; photo (M)

headline: Bit of Dissent on Rates At Fed's Meeting in May
abstract: Meetings of Federal Reserve in May show policy makers were split about how far to go in cutting interest rates, with one of 10 voting members dissenting from decision to reduce rates by half percentage point and two others expressing reservations (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc, which makes military communications systems and flight-data recorders, and Thales SA agree to form joint venture with avionic systems; called ACSS, Thales will own 30 percent stake for $72 million in cash and L-3 will own remaining 70 percent and manage venture (S)

headline: Las Vegas Casinos, In Shift of Position, Back Online Betting
abstract: Several powerful Las Vegas casinos, in sharp policy shift, are gearing up to lobby against bill they once backed to ban Internet gambling and force Internet companies to block access to illegal sites; hold ban is not technologically feasible and they instead want right to compete with 1,400 overseas sites already offering gambling; Sen Jon Kyl, bill sponsor, says casino shift in position is likely to kill bill; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Insurer's Revenue Falls
abstract: AXA reports first-quarter revenue dropped 3.3 percent, to $18 billion (US); photo (S)

headline: House Votes to Bar U.N. Dues Payment
abstract: Expressing disgust because the United States was removed from the United Nations human rights commission, the House voted to withhold $244 million in dues next year unless the seat is restored.

headline: BANK LOSSES EXPECTED
abstract: Mitsubishi Tokyo Financial Group plans to report loss of 150 billion yen ($1.2 billion) instead of profit of 90 billion for year ending in March (S)

headline: APPEALS COURT VOIDS ORDER FOR BREAKING UP MICROSOFT BUT FINDS IT ABUSED POWER
abstract: Federal appeals court unanimously throws out lower court's order that Microsoft Corp should be broken up, although it does find that company repeatedly abused its monopoly power in software business; appeals court sharply chastises District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson, who oversaw Microsoft antitrust trial, and removes him from any further involvement in case because of derogatory comments he made to press about company and its senior executives; opinion is welcomed by Microsoft, but it is also hailed by federal and state officials for affirming principle that Microsoft bullied smaller software rivals, computer makers and other large companies like chip maker Intel, and broke law in ways that stifled competition; Justice Dept officials, some state attorneys general, and Microsoft executives say they have not decided what to do next; they have three options: they can appeal to Supreme Court, proceed to new trial before different district judge, or reopen settlement negotiations; chronology of case; chart of issues and findings; photo (L)

headline: Wireless Wanderer: Roaming Manhattan With Gadgets in Hand
abstract: I'm not much of an apostle for the wireless cause. Whether it's because I feel my life is busy enough or because of my upbringing in rural New Mexico â€” my family didn't get a telephone until I was 8, and then it was a party line â€” I seem to have an inherent skepticism of new devices.

headline: Omnicom Group Unit Forms TBWA/Connect
abstract: TBWA Worldwide forms unit, TBWA/Connect, that will help clients connect with consumers across all forms of communications, from traditional advertising and beyond (S)

headline: Ford Has Harsher Words For Latest Recalled Tires
abstract: Ford Motor Co, stepping up its feud with Bridgestone/Firestone Inc, says some of tires it began replacing last month failed even more often than those recalled last autumn; Firestone denies Ford's allegations and insists responsibility for more than 100 deaths in Ford Explorer sport utility vehicles equipped with Firestone tires lay partly in Ford's design of vehicle; Ford executives say 15-inch Firestone Wilderness AT tires made at factory in Wilson, NC, aged badly; photo (M)

headline: News in a Huge Grinder of Translation
abstract: Web site by Newstran.com translates hundreds of world's newspapers into English; site links to Babel Fish, AltaVista's free translation service; translations are imprecise, but gist filters through (M)

headline: Micron's Bulls, Defying The Bubble
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Market Watch column on Micron Technology Inc's stock, which defies norms and remains nearer its peak valuation than most others in high-tech sector; graph (M)

headline: ABC Cuts Child Interviews After Their Parents Object
abstract: ABC News agrees to remove interview with schoolchildren from coming special on environment, Tampering With Nature, after their parents complain that children were asked leading questions by host, John Stoessel, intended to get them to say teachings about environment are scaring them; Stoessel has frequently angered environmentalists for painting them as scaremongers and for questioning reasoning behind some of their positions (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Reorganization At Reuters
abstract: Reuters, financial news company, will scrap its product business units and reorganize around customer lines when Tom Glocer succeeds Peter Job as chief executive in July, 2001; photo (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: YEN DROPS***Japanese yen falls on concern government's proposals to cut spending and push banks to write off loans will slow Japan's economy; in New York, dollar settles at 124.42 yen, up from 123.74 yen; graph; chart (S)

headline: Keeping an Eye on Drivers to Keep Their Eyes on the Road
abstract: Volvo Technological Development Corp researcher develops software-based video tracking system for analyzing where drivers are focusing their eyes; distraction of drivers accounts for substantial number of accidents resulting in death, injury and property damage; drawing (M)

headline: Share Prices Gain on Better-Than-Expected Housing Sales
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 170.86 points, to 10,625.20; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 19.28 points, to 1,228.75; Nasdaq composit index rises 43.19 points, to 2,059.80; tables; graph (M)

headline: Breathing Room for Taiwan: U.S. Weapons Can Stave Off Threat
abstract: Array of weapons Pres Bush has offered to sell Taiwan would substantially improve island's ability to cope with threat of Chinese blockade; would strengthen Taiwan's navy and help island stand up to China's political pressure (M)

headline: Article 2001062193340555893 -- No Title
abstract: Game Simulations for the Military Try to Make an Ally of Emotion

headline: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online
abstract: The LTV Mine closed its doors in February, leaving more than 1,400 hundred workers unemployed in an area where the closest community college is 30 minutes away. It takes twice that long to get to the University of Minnesota at Duluth, the nearest four-year university.

headline: No Hype: Four Web Tools That Work and Save Money; Of Marshmallows And Tax Agita
abstract: Nationtax Online offers companies doing business in multiple jurisdictions Web-based system for filing sales and use tax returns; notes states are beginning to push for electronic filing to cut collection costs; Taxware International and Vertex Inc, leaders in offline sales tax software sector, are slowly moving toward Web; drawing (M)

headline: Article 2001041190099506514 -- No Title
abstract: CYBERTIMES EDUCATION

headline: E-Commerce; The rush to the Web appears to be slowing, but has the audience peaked or will it keep growing?
abstract: Rush of new Internet subscribers has slowed, with demise of some free Internet service providers causing small dip in number of residential users last quarter; Telecommunications Reports International analyst Amy Fickling says total Internet audience is about to reach saturation; other analysts predict continued growth; graph (M)

headline: Is There Life After AOL
abstract: AOL's recent increase in monthly fee, coupled with discontent among its subscribers, leads competing services such as Microsoft's MSN and EarthLink to expand their businesses by recruiting AOL defectors; photos (M)

headline: Palestinians Again Shell Israeli Posts In Gaza Strip
abstract: Palestinian militants fire fresh volley of homemade mortar shells at nearby Israeli settlements and military posts, hours after Israel withdraws from corner of Gaza Strip; rightwing critics in Israel criticize Prime Min Ariel Sharon for withdrawing from Palestinian-controlled territory; contend pullout was prompted by American censure; this is denied by Israeli government, but Pres Bush calls Sharon, in apparent effort to smooth tensions raised by Washington's criticism; photo; map (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Comverse Sales In China Authorized
abstract: Comverse Technology Inc is first foreign vendor to receive authorization from China's Ministry of Information and Industry to sell voice-mail and short-message systems to China's service providers (S)

headline: A Positive Culture For Making Profits; Buoyed by Mergers, Medical Labs Await Era of Gene Testing
abstract: Medical laboratory industry, which has consolidated, leaving two giants, Quest Diagnostics and Laboratory Corp of America Holdings, is awaiting era of gene testing; analysts say first medical payoffs from genomics will not be drugs but diagnostic tests; start-up companies like diaDexus and Exact Sciences, as well as established companies like Applied BioSystems, are developing molecular diagnostics, term for gene and protein testing; they hope that patent protection for genes will allow them to charge higher prices for their tests than in past; graph; photos (M)

headline: Business; Can Entrepreneurs and Environmentalists Mix?
abstract: Bob Epstein, investor, entrepreneur and founder of Environmental Entrepreneurs, or E2, seeks to link entrepreneurial fervor of places like Silicon Valley with envrionmental movement in belief that good environmental policy can make good business sense; photo; graph (M)

headline: Women Are Going to the Dogs (and Cats and Birds)
abstract: Women are moving in force into professions once dominated by men, including veterinary medicine, where number of women has increased 22-fold over last decade; graph (M)

headline: When an Interviewer Crosses the Line
abstract: Nine percent of college students questioned by Hanigan Consulting Group say that job interviewers asked them inappropriate questions, such as about the number of girfriends they have had or how becoming pregnant would impact their careers (S)

headline: INSTINET GROUP ADVANCES ITS PROTRADER GROUP BID
abstract: The Instinet Group, seeking to enhance its services for individual investors, reached a preliminary agreement to acquire the ProTrader Group for about $150 million. ProTrader, based in Austin, Tex., provides electronic brokerage services that give customers direct access to stock trading. The company's chief customers are private individuals, according to Jim Herbold, ProTrader's chief information officer. Similarly, Instinet, based in New York, operates an electronic marketplace that permits clients to enter their own orders to buy and sell stocks traded on the Nasdaq and the New York Stock Exchange. The company, a unit of the Reuters Group, has filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to raise almost $400 million through an initial public offering.

headline: Brazilians Argue Over Digital TV Format
abstract: Brazil's broadcast television industry tentatively backs untested Japanese digital television format, in part because it is supposed to be particularly good for mobile service; hopes to expand audiences with signal suited for reception in buses and cars; critics of plan, inside and outside Brazil, warn plan is unrealistically expensive and will leave Brazil outside hemisphere's technological mainstream; regulatory agency also weighs United States and European formats; decision will influence which foreign makers will be able to compete in Brazil and which foreign markets will be able to use equipment made in Brazil; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Crude oil rises on expectations for decline in inventories as refiners use more oil to increase gasoline production; in New York, crude oil for June delivery rises $1.15, or 4.2 percent, to $28.44 per barrel; graph; chart (S)

headline: As Heads Are Spinning
abstract: Letter from Anthony Lunn disputes factuality of parts of May 17 article on digital audio formats

headline: Napster Is Said to Be Near Accord on Music Sales
abstract: Napster reportedly nears accord with three major record companies to use their music in pay version of its online song-swapping service; accord would not affect music industry suit charging Napster with abetting copyright infringement nor alter preliminary injunction forcing Napster to block traffic in copyrighted songs; three companies, AOL Time Warner's Warner Music, Bertelsmann's BMG Entertainment and EMI Group, would retain right to cancel deal if Napster fails to meet security standards; talks are latest tactic in competition among major record companies trying to control music distribution over Internet (M)

headline: Taking On the Saint of Indexing
abstract: JOHN C. BOGLE'S critics like to call him a St. Paul (though he prefers St. Jack) who preaches his vision of the true path, a pontificator with the zeal of the righteous.     Mr. Bogle, the founder and former chief executive of the Vanguard Group of mutual funds, has cast himself as the conscience of the industry. In speeches, articles and books, he rails against what he sees as its sins: excessive portfolio turnover, wasteful marketing, neglect of the shareholder in favor of enriching managers and, most apparent to the consumer, needlessly high costs.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Fight Over Treaty Looms
abstract: Ireland moves closer to divisive national debate on foreign policy as Senate approves European Union's Treaty of Nice, which sets terms for expanding membership to include Central and Eastern European countries (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen falls after Bank of Japan becomes more pessimistic with its June economic outlook, signaling country may be lapsing into recession; in New York, dollar settles at 123.36 yen, up from 123.08 yen; graph; chart (S)

headline: Article 2001040991583901365 -- No Title
abstract: April 5, 2001

headline: The Chinese See 1-2 Punch in Asian Visits
abstract: Pres Bush is set to meet with Dalai Lama, exiled Tibetan leader, on date China marks as anniversary of its 'liberation' of Tibet; China scores meeting and Pres Bush's decision to allow recent New York visit by Taiwan Pres Chen Shui-bian as threat to Chinese-United States ties (M)

headline: China Rejects U.S. Proposal to Fly Spy Plane Off Island
abstract: BEIJING, May 8 â€” China today officially rejected a plan by United States military officials to repair and fly out of the country a damaged American spy plane now stranded on China's Hainan Island.

headline: Article 2001040790179833355 -- No Title
abstract: April 5, 2001

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zambia: A Call For Impeachment
abstract: Zambian legislators file motion to impeach Pres Frederick Chiluba, who wants to amend constitution so he can run for third term (S)

headline: Stressed Out? Bad Knee? Relief Promised in a Juice
abstract: Article on major beverage brands that are embellishing their products with herbs and other ingredients found in dietary supplements, some of which may not be effective or even safe; Snapple is brewing ginkgo biloba into iced tea to 'enlighten your senses,' Celestial Seasonings adds kava to Tension Tamer cocktail to keep away stress and PepsiCo's SoBe line offers elixirs in Wisdom and Karma drinks; Coca-Cola, Procter & Gamble and Dannon are working on tonics and superyogurts, respectively, to soothe aches and pains of aging baby boomers; marketing muscle of such companies catapults 'functional' drinks out of niche market, so that sales have nearly doubled in last four years, reaching $4.7 billion in 2000, while sales of functional foods rose to $23.4 billion; FDA has never approved many of substances as allowable additives; officials say there have been no reports of serious harm, but food companies are not required to disclose such information; labels rarely recommend doses; herbs are usually added in such low doses as to have little likely, good or bad, leading scientists to observe that consumer are being fooled either way; photos; list of major additives and effects (M)

headline: MAKER OF BILLING SOFTWARE TO LAY OFF HALF OF PERSONNEL
abstract: Daleen Technologies Inc, maker of billing software, will cut 200 jobs, close two facilities and have wider-than-expected loss for first quarter; job reductions represent 52 percent of company's work force (S)

headline: WILLIS GROUP SAYS IT PLANS AN INITIAL PUBLIC OFFERING
abstract: Willis Group Holdings, world's third-biggest insurance broker, plans to sell shares in initial public offering (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Troops Beat Journalists
abstract: Seventeen journalists covering funeral in Kashmir are beaten by Indian paramilitary troops (S)

headline: You Will Be Reprogrammed. Your Toaster, Too.
abstract: Every new computer-related gadget generates a hobbyist underground that seeks to disassemble its hardware and decode its software; some find new uses for gadgets, while others look for ways to tweak or reprogram operating systems or soup them up with more power; unintended consequences of such tinkering can either undermine or validate entire business strategy of the gadget's developer; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Deal For Asset Manager
abstract: UBS Asset Management acquires RT Capital Management Inc, institutional asset management business of Royal Bank of Canada, for no more than $230 million; RT Capital will be renamed Brinson Canada when deal is completed in September (S)

headline: Sounding an Alarm For Diabetics
abstract: Russell O Potts, vice president for research at Cygnus Inc, traces development of company's wrist-worn glucose-monitoring device for diabetics, which recently won FDA approval; photos (M)

headline: Lessons in Democracy, and Politics, in a Former Soviet Land
abstract: When the history of Kazakhstan's stuttering transition from Soviet domination to independence is written, a snapshot of 19 people in the snow outside Parliament in the capital, Astana, may occupy an important place.     The picture commemorated something of a remarkable moment in this country, where Parliament is widely regarded as a rubber stamp.  The lower house had just rejected a bill that the president was pushing and that would have benefited his daughter's news media empire. The picture, taken in February, showed smiling people fresh from successful lobbying of the legislators.

headline: G.E. to Offer Light Bulb That Rival Calls Inefficient
abstract: General Electric will unveil new light bulb that company says will make colors appear more vivid; Royal Philips Electronics NV accuses company of acting irresponsibly because bulb is not energy efficient; bulb, called Reveal, filters out red, yellow and green light with chemical element called neodymium, rare-earth metal used in coloring of glass (M)

headline: Technology Stocks Plunge as Profit Outlook Weakens
abstract: Technology stocks plunged today, pulling the broader market sharply lower, as a seemingly unending drumbeat of corporate financial warnings gave investors little reason to believe that profits would improve soon.

headline: Sales Growth In Books Online Is Leveling Off
abstract: Growth in online book sales is apparently leveling off after astonishing five-year spurt; online sales now account for about 7 percent of domestic consumer sales of adult books; Amazon.com chairman Jeffrey P Bezos says online sales may eventually hit 15 percent of market, interview; slowdown, in part, reflects reduced discounting; graphs (M)

headline: Private Sector; Deft Hand at Helm of Pilots' Union
abstract: Profile of Capt Duane E Woerth, president of Air Line Pilots Association; photo (M)

headline: Delhi Journal; Beware Monkey-Man, Scourge of the Gullible
abstract: In teeming narrow lanes where rumors spread like a contagion, bands of excited young men brandished tridents, bamboo poles and iron rods in the wee hours this morning, ready to battle an elusive apparition known as the monkey-man, which has terrorized large swaths of this sprawling metropolis for the last week.    The beast has been likened to a slinky cat with tawny eyes, a bounding black bear and a masked superhero, but most often it is described as half monkey, half man. People who claim to have spied it say it leaps effortlessly across rooftops, scratches with long, poisoned metal claws and vanishes into thin air.

headline: MY MONEY, MY LIFE; The Work That Drains Life
abstract: IT'S springtime, and my daughter, a senior in college, is pondering her next steps. She is clear that she wants her work ''to make a difference,'' but she also wants to have time for  friends, relationships and fun.   She poses a question to me, a baby-boom feminist: ''Mom, can you work and have a life? Your generation tried to say yes, but it seems an illusion. Everyone is always scrambling to find time; everyone always seems so stressed out.''

headline: Cairo Journal; For the Pious and Perplexed, Dial-a-Sheik Service
abstract: Cairo Journal on Islamic Line, dial-a-sheik telephone service for Muslims seeking instruction or advice; photo of Sheik Khalid el-Gendy, one of ten religious scholars who take few thousand calls each day (M)

headline: Judge Accepts Plan to Settle Suit Against Auction Houses
abstract: Resolving a last-minute dispute that threatened to derail a settlement, a federal judge gave final approval yesterday to the $512 million agreement to end a class-action lawsuit by customers who said they were cheated in a price-fixing conspiracy by Sotheby's and Christie's.    In a reference to the convolutions of the long-running lawsuit, Judge Lewis A. Kaplan of Federal District Court in Manhattan said that ''life imitates art,'' adding that the final stretch of the litigation had ''taken on a decidedly Dickensian air.''

headline: Hong Kong Orders Slaughter of Chickens to Stop Bird Flu
abstract: HONG KONG, May 16 â€” In an echo of its drastic response to a deadly flu virus here in 1997, Hong Kong today ordered the slaughter of 4,700 chickens after public health officials detected a new strain of so-called bird flu.

headline: Nexell-Baxter Transaction
abstract: Nexell Therapeutics Inc agrees to transfer rights to company's cell therapeutic development products to health care unit of Baxter International Inc unit and, as result, will lay off about 60 workers (S)

headline: Business; For Busy Art Dealers, the Fair's the Thing
abstract: Top-tier art fairs like Switzeland's Art Basel now drive highly competitive art world; art dealers can often be more productive, both making sales and wooing new clients, at art fairs than they can be at their galleries; so great is lure of art fairs that their numbers are growing even as cost of participation is rising; photos (M)

headline: Patent Adds Twist to Software Lawsuit
abstract: Intertrust Technologies Corp, software for protecting digital information, receives patent that it says will challenge Microsoft Corp's strategy for linking its next-generation operating system to Internet services and content like digital music; Microsoft accuses Intertrust of 'patent terrorism' (M)

headline: World Briefing | Middle East: Egypt: Refinery Stake Sold
abstract: Israel's Merhav Group is selling its 20 percent stake in new $1.2 billion Middle East Oil Refinery near Alexandria, Egypt (S)

headline: Child's Death Has Swiss Searching for Answers
abstract: Death of 16-month-old toddler in Geneva, Switzerland, left alone to succumb to starvation and thirst while her mother is in jail for stealing, stuns Switzerland, and leaves people wondering how such an incident could happen in so orderly a society; infant's mother, 22, had record of drug addiction and petty theft, and was hustled off to Geneva's prison first week of May (M)

headline: U.N. Assembly Votes Today On Decree to Combat AIDS
abstract: The UN Assembly will vote on declaration on fighting AIDS; draft apparently cites groups at greatest risk, such as gay men, prostitutes and drug addicts, although Islamic countries have objected to specifying homosexuals; Dr Peter Piot and other leaders in AIDS fight comment (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: ICQ Reaches 100 Million Members
abstract: ICQ, popular instant-messaging service owned by AOL Time Warner, now has 100 million registered users worldwide (S)

headline: Arab Visitors to Urge U.S. to Renew Mideast Role
abstract: Prime Min Ali Abu al-Ragheb of Jordan says leaders of both Egypt and Jordan will seek to convince Pres Bush that ending violence between Israel and the Palestinians requires renewed intervention from Washington; says mediation by US is essential (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Beef Exports To Resume
abstract: European Union says Northern Ireland can resume beef exports, which were banned under foot-and-mouth disease restrictions (S)

headline: Court Sides With Freelancers in Electronic Rights Case
abstract: WASHINGTON, June 25 â€” The Supreme Court ruled today that by making their contents accessible through electronic databases, a group of newspaper and magazine publishers infringed the copyrights owned by freelance contributors who had not agreed to have their work reproduced in a new format.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Solectron Buys Box Maker
abstract: Solectron Corp acquires box maker Singapore Shinei Sangyo; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Article 2001042890140286865 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: Cardinals Campaign, Very Delicately, for Pope
abstract: Planned College of Cardinals consistory, first since 1994, will bring together all 134 men under 80 who are eligible to vote in papal conclave; gives Pope John Paul II's advisers chance to campaign, delicately, to succeed him; possible contenders noted; photos (M)

headline: GENERAL DYNAMICS EXTENDS OFFER FOR NEWPORT NEWS
abstract: General Dynamics Corp extends $2.6 billion cash offer for Newport News Shipbuilding after federal antitrust regulators request more information on proposal (S)

headline: COMPASS SELLS HOTELS
abstract: Bass PLC pays 810 million pounds ($1.16 billion) for Compass Group's Posthouse chain of 79 three-star hotels; Macdonald Hotels, in joint venture with Bank of Scotland, is paying 235 million pounds ($336.9 million) for 48 country house Heritage hotels owned by Compass; graph (S)

headline: FALSE FILINGS BY SBC COMMUNICATIONS ARE INVESTIGATED
abstract: Regulators investigate more admissions by SBC Communications that it filed false information with the FCC as it sought government approval to sell long-distance phone service in Kansas and Oklahoma (S)

headline: Ulster Troops Enforce End to Riots
abstract: British troops and armored vehicles are posted at ends of Belfast street to bar more rioting between Catholics and Protestants spurred by attacks on girls walking through Protestant area to Catholic elementary school; soldiers credit relative quiet to Protestant community meeting at which parents were urged to keep home children and teenagers, who played large part in rioting (M)1

headline: JAPAN LEAVES INTEREST RATE UNCHANGED
abstract: The Bank of Japan voted to keep its monetary policy unchanged, leaving the interest rates effectively at zero. The central bank moved to lower the rates to near zero last month to avert a serious economic downturn. The decision by the bank's policy board, which ended a two-day meeting had been widely expected.   Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

headline: FORD WILL BUILD DIESEL SPORT UTILITIES FOR EUROPE
abstract: Ford Motor Co will build diesel-powered 2002 Explorer sport utility vehicles for export to Europe to cater to customer preferences in region; plans to produce 10,000 to 15,000 of vehicles annually at its St Louis assembly plant; Detroit Diesel unit of DaimlerChrysler will supply engines (S)

headline: Three Countries Are Warned To Limit Money Laundering
abstract: Financial Action Task Force, Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development arm, threatens Russia, Philippines and Nauru with curbs on their dealings with international banks unless they enact laws by Sept 30 to clamp down on money laundering; adds six nations, Burma, Egypt, Guatemala, Hungary, Indonesia and Nigeria, to list of those that have not cooperated in crackdown; removes Bhamas, Cayman Islands, Liechtenstein and Panama from list (M)

headline: SARA LEE FORECASTS REDUCED PROFITS NEXT YEAR
abstract: Sara Lee Corp says profit might fall in next fiscal year; will reorganize its domestic meat and hosiery businesses and European intimate apparel units (S)

headline: MediaTalk; Latest Reality Mix: Singles and Shackles
abstract: UPN it to begin broadcasting reality-television series Chains of Love, in which four single people are chained to member of opposite sex for four days and explore possibilities of relationships; NBC, which originally owned rights to show, gave up rights in exchange for three other formats from Endemol, Dutch company that owns format; photo (M)

headline: In a Colorful Campaign in Peru, 3 Points of View Emerge
abstract: Peruvians to vote for new president just year after election so clumsily fraudulent that winner, Alberto Fujimori, finally had to leave country and resign; Alejandro Toledo is likely to get most votes but not enough to avoid runoff, so that real race is between left-wing former president Alan Garcia and moderate conservative Lourdes Flores; photos (M)

headline: Companies Begin Talks With South Africa on Drug Suit
abstract: Drug company official says 39 multinational drug companies have begun settlement talks with South Africa on their suit to block nation from importing cheaper anti-AIDS drugs and other medicines; says companies recognize magnitude of nation's AIDS epidemic but want South Africa to renew its commitment to world trade treaties; Doctors Without Borders says 250,000 people have signed petition urging companies to drop suit; advocates for AIDS patients hail victory in public opinion war; photos (M)

headline: The Farm Boy Sharon Recalls Struggle as a Way of Life
abstract: Interview with Israel's Prime Min Ariel Sharon, who explains why he will not agree to freeze construction in existing Jewish settlements in West Bank and Gaza; says settlers need more room for growing families; rejects international view that settlement expansion is provocation to Palestinians or that existence and growth of settlements creates friction and causes conflict; photo (M)

headline: At a forum of big marketers, the economy's slowdown runs quietly through the agenda.
abstract: Executives at Association of National Advertisers' Television Advertising Forum say they are watching consumer behavior to gauge whether economic slowdown will force cut in estimated $53 billion marketers spend annually on television advertising, interviews (M)

headline: Article 2001051393251509254 -- No Title
abstract: Looking Back at My First PC

headline: Laptop Seeks Mobile User; Likes DVD's and CD-RW's
abstract: New NEC laptop model, Versa TXi, has large memory, connecting capabilities and display; offers choice of CD and DVD drive options; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: No More Executions
abstract: Pres Leonid D Kuchma of Ukraine formally abolishes death penalty by signing into law new criminal code that brings Ukraine into line with other European countries (S)

headline: CATERING ACQUISITIONS
abstract: Sodexho Alliance of France, a leading catering company, agreed to buy Sogeres of France and Wood Dining Services of America for a combined 526 million euros ($475 million). The Albert Abela Corporation of Saudi Arabia is selling Wood Dining of Allentown, Pa., and a 60 percent stake in Sogeres. Sodexho is also buying the 40 percent of Sogeres owned by BNP Paribas Capital.

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: HARDWARE

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Interactive TV Raises Privacy Concerns
abstract: Report from Center for Digital Democracy, advocacy group, on marketing materials and filings of companies designing interactive television systems finds that many of them hope to profit by collecting and selling data on customers' viewing habits (S)

headline: It Gets 78 Miles a Gallon, but U.S. Snubs Diesel
abstract: New generation of much cleaner, more nimble diesel-powered cars, such as Audi A2 with its 78-miles-to-the-gallon, is powering nearly one-third of all new cars sold in Europe, in stark contrast to US, where fewer than one percent of new American cars have diesel engines; graph; gap is likely to widen because US antipollution regulations severely limit diesel sales and American environmental groups are adamantly opposed to relaxing them, in contrast to European counterparts; report by National Academy of Sciences panel is expected to suggest that increasing diesel use is surest, fastest way to improve fuel efficiency in US; major strides in diesel technology in last ten years explained (M)

headline: Article 2001050491075648854 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: New Outcry Raised Against Channel One
abstract: Unusual coalition of advocacy groups and individuals in fields from pediatrics to politics is again asking marketers to stop advertising on Channel One, Primedia division that broadcasts daily programs and commercials to some 12,000 schools (S)

headline: After Complaints, Yahoo to Close Access to Pornographic Sites
abstract: Faced with a flood of criticism from users, Yahoo, the vast Internet service, reversed a longstanding policy and said yesterday that it would remove a wide range of pornographic material from its site and make other such information harder to find.    Yahoo closed a section devoted to pornographic videos in its shopping area, and it said that it would no longer take advertisements from pornographic Web sites.

headline: Edison Schools Gains Business
abstract: Edison Schools, nation's largest private operator of public schools, signs contracts with eight Midwestern school districts for summer programs; its first Detroit charter school has renewed its agreement; Edison raises its revenue forecast for fiscal year ending in June to $377 million from $370 million (S)

headline: Bush Moves Against Steel Imports; Trade Tensions Are Likely to Rise
abstract: Pres Bush moves toward broad restrictions on imported steel, as long urged by American companies and unions in once-mighty industry hobbled by unending glut of imports; photo; graph; Bush vows aggressive response to 'unfair trade practices' in case US will bring to International Trade Commission; he narrowly won West Virginia and narrowly lost Pennsylvania, two major steel states, and running-mate Dick Cheney had promised to do more for industry than Pres Clinton had; Bush announces step before completing details of case, in face of Democratic plans to use new control of Senate to order trade commission action (M)

headline: Computer Associates Officials Stand By Their Accounting Methods
abstract: Computer Associates says its accounting conforms to standard rules and it has not inflated its results; New York Times has reported that former employees and analysts raised questions about company's financial statements; company's shares drop 8.7 percent, and company's market value almost $2 billion; chief executive Sanjay Kumar vigorously defends company (M)

headline: Article 2001062090897761974 -- No Title
abstract: Gearing Up for the Car Office

headline: Big Fund Shifts Into Technology
abstract: Fidelity Magellan Fund raises its stake in technology investments for first time in eight months in April and cuts its cash holdings in half (S)

headline: Boots Made for Walking On Pennsylvania Avenue
abstract: Profile of Rocky Carroll, custom book baker at RJ's Boot Co in Houston, who has made customized boots for last six presidents; boot industry is benefiting from some high-profile product placement by current president, George W Bush; photos (M)

headline: Article 2001052592878858215 -- No Title
abstract: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

headline: SingTel's Chief Defends Optus Purchase
abstract: Singapore Telecommunications chief, Lee Hsien Yang, defends his company's winning bid for Australian phone company Cable and Wireless Optus, calling terms fair and final after week in which unimpressed investors punish both companies' shares; graph; photo (M)

headline: Italian Conservative Assures Europe He's in the Mainstream
abstract: Conservative media tycoon Sylvia Berlusconi, elected Italy's prime minister for second time in seven years, assures Europe and US that he is proud to be their partner; reaches out to Italians in nationwide address; Pres Bush and German and French leaders send congratulatory messages; criticisms of Berlusconi by European leaders and editorial writers about conflicts of interests presented by his business dealings and over his affiliation with ultra-rightist Umberto Bossi discussed; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: New Bank Executive

headline: In Athens, Pope Seeks to Mend An Ancient Rift

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST

This surge heartens energy officials but alarms environmentalists, some of whose leaders have begun to worry that the intense battle over the fate of the wildlife refuge has obscured the many other battles they say they should be fighting. [Page A1.]

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: ASIA ENRON PAYMENT DISPUTE The financial woes of the Dabhol Power Company in India, 65 percent owned by the Enron Corporation , have deepened with the government of India's refusal to pay the $22 million that the company says it is owed under its contract with the Maharashtra State Electricity Board. Both the state and central governments had guaranteed that they would pay the bills for the huge power plant if the electricity board failed to do so, but are refusing on the ground that the company owes a penalty for a technical failure to meet other contractual terms. The dispute now goes to a conciliation panel, and, if that fails, to arbitration in London. American diplomats have warned that the government's failure to live up to the guarantee could endanger future foreign investment in India. The Dabhol project is the largest foreign investment ever made in India. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)

headline: Death to Blasphemers: Islam's Grip on Pakistan
abstract: Blasphemy is a capital crime in this volatile Islamic nation, so Dr. Younus Shaikh, while teaching at a medical college, might have wisely avoided any discussion of the personal hygiene of the holy Prophet Muhammad.    But the topic came up during a morning physiology class. And the doctor talked briefly about seventh-century Arabia and its practices regarding circumcision and the removal of underarm hair.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Big Mutual Fund Companies Have Pared Cisco Holdings  Three of the nation's largest mutual fund companies -- FMR, the parent of Fidelity funds; Janus Capital; and Putnam Investments -- led an exodus from Cisco Systems, the leading maker of Internet networking systems, in the first quarter, selling more than 250 million shares, according to new regulatory filings.    The flight was part of a continued move by many fund firms out of former technology stalwarts like EMC, Oracle and Sun Microsystems. The sales of Cisco threaten the company's ranking as the second-most-widely held stock among mutual funds. [Page C4.]

headline: What's Next: Roaming the World With a Translator in Your Pocket
abstract: TRAVELERS of the future may still carry foreign language phrase books. But in a few years they may also load software onto their pocket computers that permits real-time, simple conversations with their foreign hosts.

headline: PowerPoint Invades the Classroom
abstract: Kelvin Mazara, a seventh grader at the Edison School in Union City, N.J., could not have appeared more engrossed in the morning's assignment. He and his classmates had been asked to assemble a report about a play they had just read, "A Raisin in the Sun" by Lorraine Hansberry, and Kelvin's teacher was reviewing the topics to address: Who are the major characters? What are the conflicts? What are the broad themes?

headline: Backers of Caspian Pipeline Say Project Will Move Ahead
abstract: Companies involved in much-debated pipeline to carry oil from Caspian Sea to Turkey's Mediterranean coast have announced that they have found initial cost estimate to be viable and will begin next phase; pipeline would run from Baku, capital of Azerbaijan, through Georgia to Turkish port of Ceyhan; BP PLC, oil company managing project, says investors authorized more detailed feasibility study, which will cost $150 million and should be completed in mid-2002; construction could be completed by end of 2004; BP holds 25.4 percent of Baku-Ceyhan project; six other multinationals, including Unocal and Delta Hess, share additional 24.6 percent; remaining 50 percent is held by State Oil Co of Azerbaijan Republic; map (M)

abstract: BP PLC posts first-quarter profit of $4.12 billion, up about 52 percent from 2000 period; photo (M)

abstract: For the first time in six years, the productivity of American workers declined, falling at an annual rate of 0.1 percent during the first three months of 2001, the Labor Department reported today.

headline: A Dark Secret Comes to Light in Serbia
abstract: Serbia's new democratic authorities have for first time linked former Pres Slobodan Milosevic to war crimes; Serbian newspapers are reporting that truck filled with bodies was found in Danube during war with NATO; police officials and Serbia's new interior minister, Dusan Mihajlovic, claim Milosevic had ordered his interior minister, Vlajko Stojiljkovic, to remove civilian casualties in Kosovo that could be source for investigations by war crimes tribunal in Hague; local journalists find person who claims to have seen someone sinking truck into Danube; map (M)

headline: World Briefing | United Nations: U.S. Offers Iraq Sanction List
abstract: American officials have given the other 14 Security Council members a list of imports that should come under surveillance as the Council moves to debate lifting restrictions on sales of civilian goods to Iraq. In addition to standard international lists of prohibited weapons, the United States has devised a list of civilian items that could have military uses, like high-powered computers and transport vehicles able to carry equipment like tanks. American officials expect the lists to be debated next week.     Barbara Crossette (NYT)

headline: Bike Power: Tired Legs Get a Leg Up
abstract: Electric power-assisted bicycles are slow to catch on in US, but manufacturers, including Currie Technologies, Ford Motor Co, Zap, Giant Bicycle and EV Global Motors, hope they will appeal aging baby boomers; batteries and microchips assist human muscle in powering these devices; some states classify them as motor vehicles, requiring features that greatly add to costs, but bill introduced in Congress would transfer jurisdiction over electric bicycles with a maximum speed of 20 mph to Consumer Product Safety Commission, which handles bicycle safety; photos (M)

headline: Asian Employees at Lucent Are Troubled by Handling of Arrests
abstract: Asian employees of Lucent Technologies and leaders of groups representing Asian scientists and engineers in US express concern over arrests of three men in New Jersey on charges of stealing Lucent trade secrets; are concerned about how Asian and Asian-Americans working in technology-oriented businesses are treated in US; the men arrested, Hai Lin and Kai Xu, Lucent marketing engineers, and Yong-Qing Cheng, marketing director of Village Networks, are accused transferring proprietary information about device that allows companies to handle traffic on Internet-based communications networks ComTriad Technologies, a venture financed and effectively controllled by Datang Telecom Technology Co of Beijing, which is majority owned by Chinese government; photo (M)

headline: Investment Banks See Rising Financing Costs
abstract: Some of world's biggest investment banks are betting that financing costs are poised to rise as they hurry to issue bonds while benchmark rates are at their lowest in more than year; Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, Goldman Sachs Group, Lehman Brothers Holdings and Bear Stearns Companies sold total of $3.35 billion of debt in most recent week, borrowing more money at less cost than some firms found weeks earlier (S)

headline: New-Era Banks Slip Into the Past; Traditional Wall Street Firms Still Make the Investment Rules
abstract: Traditional Wall Street firms are still making investment rules as number of stock offerings involving online firms plunge; Charles Schwab Corp co-chief executive David S Pottruck says major investment banks are still in control and no online upstart is likely to crack oligopoly they have built; Goldman Sachs Group's recent acquisition of Epoch Partners, which was owned by Schwab, TD Waterhouse and Ameritrade, discussed; Epoch's former owner Scott A Ryles comments; William R Hambrecht, founder and chairman of W R Hambrecht & Co, one of remaining young investment banks with online bent, discusses how his firm has tried to land its own deals rather than depend on larger banks; graphs; photos (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: DELPHI AUTOMOTIVE SYSTEMS INC.,  Troy, Mich., the world's largest auto parts maker, will sell an industrial engine parts plant in Cheltenham, England, as the company reorganizes.    STEELCASE INC.,  Grand Rapids, Mich., the largest U.S. office furniture maker, will begin a joint manufacturing venture in Southeast Asia to cut delivery times and lower prices in that region.

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Angola: De Beers Steps Back
abstract: De Beers, world's leading diamond miner, suspends investment and prospecting in war-ravaged Angola after negotiations with government break down (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Army Battles Severe Drought
abstract: South Korean army will help farmers build new ditches to carry water to drought-stricken rice paddies while air force and navy transport emergency supplies of water and equipment (S)

headline: Early Results Show Ex-King Leads Vote In Bulgaria
abstract: National Movement for Simeon II, party of Bulgaria's former king, leads in vote in Bulgarian elections, even though it appeared to fall short of declared goal of clear majority, dealing heavy blow to political forces that have governed Bulgaria since collapse of Communism in 1989; photo (M)

headline: Russian Media Empire Is Hit by New Blow, as Newspaper Closes
abstract: Media-Most journalism empire, which lost control of its flagship television network NTV Apr 13, is staggered again when dissident shareholders who have taken control of company close its daily Moscow newspaper, Sevodnya; shares that prove crucial to decision are owned by state-dominated natural gas monopoly, Gazprom, as was case of NTV; Gazprom is in bitter struggle with tycoon Vladimir A Gusinsky for control of Media-Most; newspaper Sevodnya was known for its aggressive journalism (M)

headline: Mellon to Buy Institutional Money Manager
abstract: Mellon Financial Corp agrees to buy Standish, Ayer & Wood Inc for undisclosed amount (S)

headline: Business Computer Secrecy Vulnerable to a New Flaw
abstract: University of Maryhland researchers discover computer security flaws in popular wireless local area networking standard increasingly used by corporations and consumers; flaws could make it possible for intruder who is physically close to wireless computer network to masquerade as legitimate user in supposedly private network (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Bankruptcy Doesn't Scare Some Investors
abstract: Many institutional investors are buying stock of PG&E; Corp, giant California utility company, despite company's bankruptcy proceedings; investors are counting, in part, on strength of legal concept known as ring-fencing--idea that PG&E; can keep creditors of its bankrupt utility unit from laying claim to assets of its other businesses; many investors believe PG&E;'s most valuable asset is its power generation and trading unit, National Energy Group; some stock analysts expect unit to generate about 60 cents per share in profit this year, and they say it could fetch $12 per share as spinoff (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Morgan Stanley Global Lists Add Focus to Energy Sector
abstract: Morgan Stanley Capital International sets major overhaul of its widely followed global stock indexes; cuts relative importance of telecommunications stocks and emerging markets and increases that of energy companies; shift, in indexes used as benchmarks for up to $3 trillion actively managed or invested in index funds, gives added weight to United States and British stocks and less to Japan; adds 357 stocks and deletes 130; changes will take effect in two stages, beginning in Nov (M)

headline: SPX, A MAKER OF INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTS, TO BUY KENDRO
abstract: Spx Corp agrees to buy Kendro Laboratory Products for $320 million; Kendro makes appliances for pharmaceutical and biology industries (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Hedge Fund Falls Victim To Tech Bear
abstract: Bowman Capital, one of nation's largest hedge fund groups, is shutting $2 billion Bowman Technology fund and returning more than $1 billion in cash to investors; closing of fund, which declined 22 percent in 2001 through May 18, is latest in string of setbacks for technology fund managers during bear market; Bowman Capital says liquidation had been anticipated for weeks and much of fund is already in cash; chief executive Lawrence A Bowman comments; chart (Market Place column) (M)

headline: VIGNETTE EXPECTS TO REPORT LOSS
abstract: Vignette Corp, which develops software used to build Web sites, says it expects to report first-quarter loss (S)

headline: Expectations Low as Israeli-Palestinian Talks Get Under Way
abstract: Israeli Foreign Min Shimon Peres holds talks in Athens with senior Palestinian officials, even as Israeli troops and Palestinian militants exchange mortar fire in Gaza Strip; talks are highest-level public contacts between two sides since Ariel Sharon was elected prime minister, and are aimed at breaking steady escalation of hostilities; expectations are low on both sides that talks would be successful (M)

headline: With This Ring I Allay Anxiety
abstract: Herman Rotenberg writes My Job column on selling wedding rings at his Manhattan jewelry store; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Telecom Profit
abstract: Swisscom posts 5.7 percent rise, to $697 million, in first-quarter operating income; profit was $2.6 billion, up from $1.2 billion year ago; graph (S)

headline: An Extra-Tiny Mouse Can Perch on a Laptop
abstract: Atek Electronics' new Super Mini Optical Mouse is so small that it can perch in front of keyboard on most laptop computers; photo (M)

headline: Singapore, Hoping for a Baby Boom, Makes Sex a Civic Duty
abstract: Here in strait-laced Singapore, it's the new patriotism: have sex.    Alarmed by its declining birthrate, this tiny city-state of just four million people is urging its citizens to multiply as fast as they can.

headline: WebMD Executive Moves to AOL Time Warner
abstract: Patricia Fili-Krushel, former chief executive of WebMD Corp, is named executive vice president for human resources at AOL Time Warner (M)

headline: TV Tycoon and Career Politician Wrap Up Campaign to Lead Italy
abstract: Italy's hurly-burly campaign for prime minister ended tonight the way it began, on television, and circling around the personality of a media tycoon who is trying to return to power seven years after his first government collapsed after seven months.    For his final television pitch, the media tycoon, Silvio Berlusconi, 64, passed up a chance to debate and instead chose to appear live on one of his own networks to denounce what he called a campaign of ''defamation'' by his rival. Mr. Berlusconi, a conservative, said the state-controlled network, RAI, had been ''occupied by the left'' and complained of ''trials and public lynchings against yours truly and his friends.''

headline: People in Streets of Taiwan Are Underwhelmed by It All
abstract: Average Taiwanese show little reaction to United States decision on arms sales that was anxiously awaited by officials but contains few surprises; military hardware issue is much less momentous today than few years ago, with China now viewed as greater commercial than military threat; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Oil Helps BHP Profits
abstract: BHP Ltd earned 27 million Australian dollars ($14 million) in first quarter ended March 31 compared to loss of 46 million Australian dollars year ago (S)

headline: Hopeful Mideast Diplomacy Shows Faint Stirrings of Life
abstract: Subtle signs of shift are appearing as both Israelis and Palestinians seem to be responding to intensified international mediation efforts, especially by United States; US has brokered several recent meetings between senior Israeli and Palestinian security officials; Min Shimon Peres is talking regularly to senior Palestinian officials; Israelis are reconsidering Jordanian-Egyptian peace initiative they earlier spurned; Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat is taking some steps to curb and condemn attacks on Israelis (M)

headline: Behind The New Gleam In Steel
abstract: Kenneth N Gilpin interview with Michelle Appelbaum, steel analyst with Salomon Smith Barney, who discusses prospect for industry now that Bush administration has taken first steps toward imposing broad restrictions on imported steel; photo (M)

headline: KIMBALL SAYS IT HAS LAID OFF 9 PERCENT OF ITS WORKERS
abstract: Kimball International, which makes office furniture and electronic components for products like antilock brakes and insulin-measuring devices, laid off 1,025 workers, or 9 percent of its staff, as sales decreased in some segments. The job cuts occurred between Jan. 1 and April 18 throughout the company, said the chief financial officer, Robert F. Schneider. More cuts are possible if sales continue to decline, Mr. Schneider said. Kimball said overall sales for the third quarter ended March 31 rose 1 percent, to $312.7 million from $309.5 million. Excluding acquisitions, sales declined in the furniture and cabinet, and contract electronics-assembly segments, the company said.

headline: Tape Said to Show That U.S. Jet Tried to Warn Peruvians of Error
abstract: United States officials say tape recordings show that American crew of surveillance aircraft overheard pilot of small plane carrying missionary family communicate with tower at Peruvian airport, and tried to warn Peruvian Air Force fighter before it attacked; say Peruvian jet almost immediately opened fire, and pilot of small Cessna can be heard on tape saying 'they are killing us'; say tapes show that CIA contract personnel repeatedly raised questions with Peruvians about their procedures before Peruvian pilot opened fire; caution that some of facts surrounding incident still must be clarified, including attempts to reconcile tapes with other reports that survivors were strafed after they landed; Assn of Baptists for World Evangelism, missionary group whose plane was attacked, posts on its Web site copy of flight plan that it said it had filed, to rebut charge by Peruvian Air Force that no flight plan could be found for plane (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Dot-Biz Domain Name Opens Its Doors
abstract: Companies that register Internet addresses begin accepting applications from trademark owners for addresses in new dot-biz domain; process is intended to give intellectual property owners chance to make claims on proprietary addresses in dot-biz domain before it is opened to general registration; NeuLevel operates dot-biz registry database (S)

headline: Article 2001061092833423050 -- No Title
abstract: Education: From Working in Mines, to Learning Online

headline: While a Utility May Be Failing, Its Owner Is Not
abstract: PG&E Corp is experiencing banner year, even though subsidiary Pacific Gas and Electric Co, giant California utility, recently made one of largest bankruptcy filings in history; has reaped profits like other large utilities over past decade by buying unregulated power plants, expanding trading-floor operations and and selling power nationwide; has taken advantage of deregulation plans in two dozen states, where they were encouraged by federal rules designed to build new wholesale market-place in electricity; chart (M)

headline: Bush and Putin Explore Hopes of Forging Closer Ties
abstract: BRDO PRI KRANJU, Slovenia, June 16 â€” President Bush sat down with Vladimir V. Putin, the Russian president, here this afternoon and extended an offer of closer friendship, along with a request: that Russians look beyond a landmark 1972 treaty and bless Mr. Bush's plans for a missile defense shield.

headline: Allan Hall, 71, Journalist Who Inspired Beaujolais Race
abstract: Allan Hall, British journalist who devised annual race to ship newly bottled Beaujolais Nouveau to Britain, and then around world, died Apr 26 at age of 71; phto (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Comments Lift Switch Maker's Shares
abstract: Brocade Communications Systems Inc shares rise 16.3 percent after company says it expects to meet or exceed fiscal third-quarter estimates; graph (S)

headline: ICAHN REVOKES $181 MILLION BID FOR NATIONAL AIRLINES
abstract: Financier Carl C Icahn withdraws his bid of $181.5 million to buy National Airlines out of bankruptcy after airline's board rejects offer (S)

headline: Article 2001042490537182360 -- No Title
abstract: CYBER LAW JOURNAL

headline: U.S. Vehicle Sales in March
abstract: Despite a slowing economy, vehicle sales were surprisingly strong in March, due in part to an increase in vehicles sold with rebates or discount coupons.

headline: Delicate Diplomatic Dance Ends Bush's First Crisis
abstract: United States and China resolve standoff after Pres Bush approves compromise language saying United States is 'very sorry' for loss of Chinese pilot, and for American spy plane's emergency landing on Chinese soil; letter from Washington accepts no responsibility for midair collision that now seems certain to color Bush's next encounters with China; aides involved in intense negotiations say Bush drew 'red lines' around two issues: he would not bargain on American arms sales to Taiwan, nor agree to alter Washington's increasingly frequent aerial surveillance of China's military; say it was not clear that Bush's strategy of non-apology and limited negotiations would work; note that China's leaders only made final decision after Bush and Secretary of State Colin L Powell began warning that Washington's broader economic and diplomatic relationship with China was at risk; turning point appears to come when Americans agree to say 'very sorry' rather than 'sorry' in letter describing American feelings about death of Chinese pilot; photos (M)
