headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zambia: President's Party Defies Court
abstract: Zambia's Movement for Multiparty Democracy, party of Pres Frederick Chiluba, defies court order by expelling 23 senior party members, including country's vice president, Christon Tembo (S)

headline: Retail Sales Rise, Holding Recession at Bay
abstract: Commerce Department reports sales rose 0.1 percent after 1.4 percent increase in April compared with revised 1.1 percent increase in April; says retail sales increased at 4.8 percent annual rate in first two months of second quarter, compared with 5.2 percent first-quarter pace; Federal Reserve's so-called beige book of economic conditions says retail sales have been slow to flat; says manufacturing has declined or remained weak and construction appears to have leveled off; Labor Department says prices of imported goods fell 0.2 percent in May; graph; chart (M)

headline: Alcatel Said to Be in Talks to Buy Lucent
abstract: Alcatel of France is in advanced talks to buy Lucent Technologies for more than $40 billion; deal could be announced by early June; Lucent's management is hoping to portray deal as merger of equals although Alcatel would clearly be buyer; if deal materializes, it would be boldest move yet by Alcatel's chief executive Serge Tchuruk; photo (M)

headline: Companies Try to Make Foreign Postings Easier
abstract: Eighty percent of 200 companies surveyed by William Mercer offer special benefit packages to employees working in parts of world deemed difficult (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Graph plots movement of dollar against yen and euro on May 9; dollar settled at 121.63 yen in New York, down from 121.78 yen day earlier; euro traded at 88.42 cents, up from 88.33 cents; graph

headline: How I Undid My Summer Vacation
abstract: Readers relate stories of vacations spoiled by long arm of work; cartoon (M)

headline: Economic Scene; A history lesson: Don't count on stocks to lead the way out of a downturn.
abstract: Jeff Madrick 'Economic Scene' column says stocks do not always lead the way out of economic downturn; says stock prices over last century were sometimes flat for 10 or 15 years, and occasionally even longer; graph; photo (M)

headline: Article 2001051292989277550 -- No Title
abstract: Cyber Law Journal: Does a Parody Site Go Too Far?

headline: Market Place; Hedge Funds Face Shortage Of Top Talent
abstract: Rising popularity of hedge funds has created greater competition for managers and analysts, proliferation of new funds and strain on talent pool; several fund managers and consultants describe litany of job-hopping at top funds; many mutual fund firms have been opening hedge funds to serve their wealthy clients and to pre-empt defections of their best money managers to hedge funds (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Computer Sciences Has Quarterly Loss
abstract: Computer Sciences Corp reports $37.4 million loss in fiscal fourth quarter ended March 30; sales rose 13 percent, to $2.9 billion (S)

headline: INTEL SHEDDING SAMSUNG BONDS
abstract: Intel, which invested $100 million in Samsung Electronics in 1999 by buying Samsung convertible bonds to spur technologies to speed personal computer performance, says it is selling bonds, now worth $211 million (S)

headline: Ads for Ford's New Explorer Sidestep Safety Issue
abstract: Ford Motor Co's new advertising drive for redesigned 2002 Explorer sport utility vehicle will ignore recent safety concerns and instead present vehicle as way for customers to enrich their lives; will not mention design changes made to reduce risks of rolling over or killing other motorists in crashes (M)

headline: C.I.A. Chief Going to Israel In Effort to Maintain Calm
abstract: CIA Dir George J Tenet will meet with Israeli and Palestinian security chiefs in hope of building on three days of relative calm since Yasir Arafat ordered his forces to prevent further violence; Pres Bush acknowledges that despite his desire to allow parties to work out settlement themselves, events are forcing US to try to calm brittle situation; special envoy William J Burns remains in Jordan awaiting next moves; Tenet may not be able to convince two sides to meet; Muhammad Dahlan, security chief in Gaza, has been mostly incommunicado since his jeep was riddled with bullets by Israeli troops in April; West Bank counterpart Jibril Rajoub reportedly agrees to meet Israelis if Tenet is present; Israeli defense minister Benjamin Ben-Eliezer says food and fuel will begin moving and Palestinian workers may return to jobs along border because incidents of violence have decreased, although there are clashes and bomb injures Fatah member; Prime Min Ariel Sharon, on Russian television, calls Arafat 'murderer' and 'pathological liar,' while Hamas leaders make clear they are not bound by calls to end violence (M)

headline: A Novartis Drug Fails To Win F.D.A. Approval
abstract: European drug maker Novartis fails to win Food and Drug Administration approval for Zelnorm, new treatment for irritable bowel syndrome; regulators question drug's safety; Novartis and US partner Bristol-Myers Squibb say they will keep fighting to win clearance and are considering formal appeal (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Drug Maker Cuts Jobs
abstract: GlaxoSmithKline will cut 1,455 jobs, mainly in Britain and Ireland, and sell factory employing 720 more in Scotland; company is looking to cut $2.2 billion in costs by 2003 (S)

headline: Navy Officer Missing in Philippines After Ambush by Guerrillas
abstract: US Navy lieutenant Scott Alan Washburn is missing on Mount Pinatubo in Philippines after becoming separated from small group of US service personnel that came under fire from guerrillas; Washburn is believed to have plunged into jungle for safety after hearing gunfire (S)

headline: QUORUM HEALTH GROUP SETTLES MEDICARE FRAUD CASE
abstract: Quorum Health Group, which owns and manages hospitals, completes $82.5 million settlement with Justice Department in Medicare fraud case; Triad Hospitals is shortly expected to close $2.4 billion transactions to buy Quorum (S)

headline: U.S. Tape Is Said to Show Reckless Flying by Chinese
abstract: Pentagon produces grainy videotape of close encounter between Chinese fighter jet and American spy plane that it says underscores pattern of aggressive and reckless flying by China's Air Force in recent months; tape was taken Jan 24; it shows Chinese F-8, thought to be same jet lost in collision on Apr 1, darting in front of American reconnaissance aircraft; American crewmember is heard to say 'we got thumped' as wash of Chinese jet's engine rocked aircraft; photo (M)

headline: American Human Rights Worker Survives Attack in Guatemala
abstract: Researcher for human rights group Amnesty International is attacked in Guatemala at hotel during failed kidnapping attempt; researcher, Barbara Bocek, an American investigator with Amnesty International, is assaulted in Guatemala City as she concludes trip during which she looks into report that local human rights advocates are being prosecuted (S)

headline: Auditor Finds No Fraud In Xerox's Annual Report
abstract: Xerox Corp, whose auditors, KPMG, refused to sign off on its annual report until they had rechecked numbers, says KPMG found some accounting discrepancies but uncovered no signs of fraud (M)

headline: Argyll, 63, Chief of Clan Of Campbell, Is Dead
abstract: Ian Campbell, 12th Duke of Argyll and Chief of the Clan Campbell, who rebuilt Inveraray Castle, his family's ancestral Scottish home, after disastrous fire, dies at age 63; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Visor Maker's Stock Surges
abstract: Shares of Handspring, manufacturer of Visor line of hand-held computers and phone modules, rise 15.6 percent as company begins selling Visor in South Korea; graph (S)

headline: At Annual Meetings Around the World, the Shots Aren't Heard; A Debacle Stirs Little Turmoil
abstract: Survey of annual meetings around the world describes scene at Swissair Group meeting in Zurich (M)

headline: Judge Rules That Tyson Must Complete Takeover of IBP
abstract: Judge Leo E Strine Jr rules that Tyson Foods Inc has no legal grounds for withdrawing its $3.2 billion offer to buy IBP Inc, largest US beef packer, and orders that acquisition be completed; Tyson protests that hidden financial troubles at IBP are sufficient to scuttle deal; bad blood taints this takeover (M)

headline: Koizumi Woos Peace Faction After Backing Rearmament
abstract: Junichiro Koizumi is sworn in as Japan's ninth prime minister in 10 years; his cabinet is expected to be in place before end of day; selection of ministers will be first major test of his independence from party's traditional power brokers; he has gratified conservatives with unusually strong call for Japan to field army, then met with coalition partners opposed to any such move (M)

headline: Falun Gong Holds Protests On Anniversary of Big Sit-In
abstract: Members of banned Falun Gong spiritual group stage small scattered protests on Tiananmen Square in attempt to commemorate second anniversary of silent sit-in that movement held outside leadership compound in 1999; that demonstration, 10,000 strong, took government by surprise and catapulted obscure spiritual organization into international awareness, also leading few months later to government ban; in latest protest, at least 12 members are detained; photo (M)

headline: Bombing Adds Leverage to Colombia Bill Bolstering Military
abstract: Recent fatal bombing outside Bogota university is likely to boost controversial anti-terrorism bill that would give Colombia's public security forces broad new powers; detractors, including United Nations, human rights groups and Reps Bill Delahunt and Sam Farr, warn bill would undermine basic rights, insulate military from outside scrutiny and possibly spawn new paramilitary groups; military and its supporters back bill (M)

headline: SOUTH AFRICA: DIAMOND DISPUTE
abstract: Investors holding almost 10 percent of De Beers' stock say they will oppose plan of consortium led by Oppenheimer family and Anglo American to take company private; deal could collapse if 15 percent of minority shareholders oppose it (S)

headline: Hartlepool Journal; On Doorstep, Asking Votes: Blair's Fallen Friend
abstract: Peter Mandelson, former Labor Party strategist twice forced out of top posts in British Prime Min Tony Blair's government by scandals, is campaigning hard to retain own seat, from Hartlepool; dismisses reports he continues to play role in national campaign, but criticizes job done by former rival, Gordon Brown, who runs campaign; indicates he intends to remain national force; map; photo (M)

headline: Sharon, in New York, Urges Arafat to 'Put Out Flames'
abstract: Israeli Prime Minister Ariel Sharon, in address at America-Israel Friendship Committee dinner in New York, demands end to violence by Palestinians as condition of carrying forward peace efforts; calls on Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat to bring permanent halt to attacks on Israelis; stops short of making concessions, such as support for freeze on building and expansion of settlements--one of recommendations made in support of peace by international committee led by former US senator George J Mitchell (M)

headline: Cyber Law Journal: Does a Parody Site Go Too Far?
abstract: One day about seven years ago, Michael T. Doughney was driving his car when he saw a bumper sticker that read: "People Eating Tasty Animals."

headline: At Placebo Consulting, We're as Good as it Gets
abstract: Clayton M Christensen letter responds to May 13 article about consultants and Internet companies

headline: Czechs Pick French Bid For Control Of Big Bank
abstract: Societe Generale acquires 60 percent stake in Komercni Banka from Czech government, for unexpectedly high price of 1.19 billion euros ($1.01 billion), beating out offers from UniCredito Italiano and HypoVereinsbank of Germany (M)

headline: MediaTalk; For One Week, CNN Finds Its Old Sparkle
abstract: CNN's coup as only network to broadcast live images of American spy plane crew leaving Hainan Island, China, and again leaving plane in Guam helps revive spirits of CNN's staff; photo (M)

headline: At Heroin's Source, Taliban Do What 'Just Say No' Could Not
abstract: Afghanistan's ruling Taliban has accomplished what seemed impossible: almost total elimination of poppy crop in country that produced 75 percent of world's crop just year ago; Taliban banned growing of poppies last July as sin against teachings of Islam, in edict issued by Mullah Muhammad Omar, supreme leader of faithful; ban was carried out through chain of command; violators were few, but those that were found had fields plowed over; poppy ban has caused mass hardship among farmers, and they are pleading for foreign assistance; many critics question Taliban's motives in imposing ban; suggest that poppy ban may be Taliban's push for legitimacy, or for assistance from wealthier nations, including United States, who gratefully compensate third world allies in drug war; photos; map (M)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: SOFTWARE</P

headline: Chairman of Disney's Studios Resigns to Return to Broadway
abstract: Peter Schneider, chairman of Walt Disney Studios, unexpectedly announces his resignation to set up new Broadway production company that will be partly financed by Disney; there is no indication of when, or if, corporation intends to replace Schneider as studio chairman (M)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: SOFTWARE

headline: Ad Spending Grows for Funds
abstract: Mutual fund industry spent 22 percent more for advertising in 2000 than in 1999; total is record $515 million (M)

headline: Rally by Semiconductor Shares Lifts Technology Issues
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average closes up 20.50 points, or 0.2 percent, to 11,090.74; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains 6.93 points, or 0.6 percent, to close at 1,276.96; Nasdaq composite index rises 46.27 points, or 2.1 percent, to 2,264; graph; chart (M)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: HARDWARECYPRESS BUYING CHIP DESIGNER The Cypress Semiconductor Corporation , a maker of chips used in telecommunications equipment, agreed to buy the closely held Lara Networks Inc. for about $225 million to expand its product line. Lara's sales last year were $25 million and are expected to rise to $70 million by 2003, a Cypress spokesman said. Lara designs semiconductors that sort and speed information in communication networks.

headline: No Hype: Four Web Tools That Work and Save Money; Taking a Meeting Over the Internet
abstract: Number of companies have developed online services to make business meetings more efficient; services, often called online collaboration tools or virtual meeting services, combine data-sharing abilities of Internet with phone; let participants in far-flung sites take conference call while viewing documents or demonstrations or taking part in online tutorial on same Web site; say such meetings do not eliminate need for face-to-face talks, but are better than audio conference call and save on travel costs; drawing (M)

headline: AMERICAN AIRLINES AND FLIGHT ATTENDANTS STILL AT ODDS
abstract: American Airlines and its flight attendants fail to reach accord after four bargaining days (S)

headline: Bristol Is Said to Be Near Deal To Acquire DuPont Drug Unit
abstract: BÃ¯

headline: U.S. Appeals Court Overturns Microsoft Antitrust Ruling
abstract: Afederal appeals court overturned Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's ruling to break up the Microsoft Corporation today, and it ordered the judge removed from the case, saying his actions "seriously tainted the proceedings."

headline: Wireless Wanderer: A Field Study
abstract: Simon Romero article says he spends workday in Manhattan equipped with three devices: Kyocera Smartphone incorporating Palm computer and Web access, BlackBerry 957 e-mail pager and Sanyo Dual-Band phone with Web access; article chronicles his experiences with these mobile tools; photos (M)

headline: Mischievous Species Capitalize on Globalization
abstract: PARISâ€”  Invading "aliens" are costing the global economy possibly hundreds of billions of dollars every year as well as spreading diseases and causing massive ecological destruction, yet no one is doing much about it. Environmental scientists say this invasion is among the costliest but least understood aspects of globalization.

headline: Bristol Buying Drug Unit Of DuPont for $7.8 Billion
abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb Co agrees to acquire drug business of DuPont for $7.8 billion in cash; DuPont says it will use some proceeds to complete $2.5 billion share buyback program; also authorizes new $2 billion share buyback program (M)

headline: In Peru Trial, Ex-Associate Contradicts New Yorker
abstract: Pacifico Castrellon testifies for prosecution in Peru trial of Lori Berenson, American woman jailed for alleged involvement with Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement; Castrellon, who hopes to have his own sentence reduced in retrial, describes Berenson as go-between for Nestor Cerpa Cartolini, top Tupac Amaru military commander; describes himself as innocent man duped by terrorists, unaware of their plot to attack Congress; Berenson's lawyer is expected to question him about fact that rebels rented him apartment where he drew detailed street maps for them of area around Congress (M)

headline: RÃ‰MY PROFIT INCREASES 40%
abstract: Remy Cointreau SA, world's sixth-largest liquor company, says profit for 2001 fiscal year rose 40 percent, buoyed by increasing demand for cognac and acquisition of Bols Royal Distilleries; earnings per share rise slightly to more than 2 euros in year ended March 31; graph (S)

headline: e-UROPE; How Ducati Roared Onto the Internet
abstract: Italian companies like Ducati, maker of top-of-the-line motorcycles, and Pirelli, maker of tires and telecommunications cables, are pioneering use of Internet to promote and sell products and reduce cost of manufacturing them; photo (M)

headline: BUSH WILL PRESS FREE-TRADE ISSUE AT QUEBEC TALKS
abstract: President Bush arrived at his first summit meeting today declaring that he would make the expansion of economic and political ties with Latin America his first foreign policy priority.     But before Mr. Bush and other leaders could get down to work, tonight's opening ceremony of the Summit of the Americas was delayed for an hour, to about 7:30, as thousands of mostly young protesters clogged the narrow streets of this walled city seeking to block talks over a Free Trade Area of the Americas.

headline: Deutsche Telekom Posts $359 Million Quarterly Loss
abstract: Deutsche Telekom AG reports first-quarter loss of 400 million euros, or $359 million, in line with analysts' expectations and much lower than its loss of 1 billion euros ($894 million) in last three months of 2000 (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Railtrack Falls
abstract: Railtrack Group shares fall 17 percent to record low after analysts report that company is worth only fraction of its market value; stock price graph (S)

headline: Feuding Agencies Settle Differences
abstract: WPP Group's Cohn & Wolfe and independent Titan Group dismiss lawsuits filed against each other after principals of Titan left Atlanta office of Cohn & Wolfe in January to go into business for themselves; settlement stipulates that Titan executives will not solicit current and former clients and employees of Atlanta office through Feb 28, 2002, and will not 'use or disclose confidential information belonging to Cohn & Wolfe' through Jan 1, 2003 (S)

headline: At Home, Mexico Mistreats Its Migrant Farmhands
abstract: Article in series examining third-world production for first-world markets focuses on plight of Mexico's migrant farmhands, who abandon homes for part of year to harvest crops, exported mostly to US, and endure dangerous and unsanitary conditions; about 200,000 who settle in nearly 150 work camps across Sinaloa state are among poorest of Mexico's 40 million poor; half are women and girls, and at least 30 percent are children under 15; they travel mostly as families or entire communities, and almost 40 percent are Indians who do not speak Spanish well; even though Pres Vicente Fox has been outspoken advocate of Mexican laborers in US, pressing Washington to improve their working conditions, he has not devoted attention in five months in office to cares of migrant workers at home, even following recent discovery that young children work at his family's plants packing vegetables; photos; map (M)

headline: PANAMSAT EARNINGS DECLINE 91%
abstract: PanAmSat Corp's earnings fell 91 percent in first quarter, to $5 million (S)

headline: I.B.M. Stretches Silicon in New Ways to Speed Up Chips
abstract: IBM plans to announce that it has figured out how to stretch silicon during standard semiconductor manufacturing, leading to faster, less power-hungry microchips; will detail findings at conference in Kyoto, Japan, next week (M)

headline: Blair Says Cattle Disease Is Near End; Elections Due
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair says that Britain is in home stretch of its race to contain ruinous epidemic of foot-and-mouth disease, prompting widepread forecasts that he is on verge of calling general election in June (M)

headline: Rioting in Britain Gives Voice to Silent Minorities
abstract: Rioting between whites and Asians in Oldham, England, and finger pointing in aftermath by politicians expose volatile tensions in what outwardly is one of Europe's most stable multi-ethnic cultures; authorities blame white supremacist National Front for two nights of rioting, in which 30 people were injured and 37 arrested, while some politicians trade accusations of provocation; Prime Min Tony Blair says he does not believe incident is typical of race relations in Britain; many rioters are sons and daughters of immigrants who came to work in city's textile mills in 1960's; mills have since closed, leaving younger generation without work, little chance of advancement in British society and smoldering sense of resentment that their backgrounds may be holding them back; map; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: HARDWAREDE

headline: Defense Cites Political Role Of Egypt Trial
abstract: Defense lawyers in Cairo sum up arguments in case of Saad Eddin Ibrahim, prominent Egyptian-American sociologist accused of defaming Egypt and accepting illegal donations from abroad; lead defense lawyer tells three judges hearing case that accusations against his client are politically motivated and intended to silence him; case is being watched by human rights groups in Egypt and abroad; charges against Ibrahaim and 27 others working with him are viewed as attempt to scare independent research groups away from sensitive public issues; study center Ibrahim founded delved into subjects like electoral fraud and tensions between Egypt's Muslim majority and Christian minority; his center planned to monitor parliamentary election, and he write satirical magazine article about Arab leaders grooming their sons to succeed them, which mentioned Pres Hosni Mubarak (M)

headline: Unemployment Up, Prices Down In Sign of Japanese Recession
abstract: Japan's unemployment rate returned to its peak level of 4.9 percent in May, consumer prices fell 0.7 percent from year earlier, and wages dropped 2.6 percent, further signs that recession is once again gripping Japanese economy (M)

headline: Article 2001042490991087120 -- No Title
abstract: Bike Power: Tired Legs Get a Leg Up

headline: Top Executives' Pay Is Still on the Rise
abstract: American chief executives grew richer in the last decade, when their pay package was linked to their companies' stock performance. But a slower economy hasn't slowed their income. While salaried employees got 4 percent raises and investors lost 12 percent of their portfolios, chief executives received an average 22 percent raise in salary and bonus and much more in stock.    Money and Business

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Foreign Investments Approved
abstract: India will allow 100 percent foreign investment in several industrial sectors like pharmaceuticals, hotels and tourism, airports and rapid transit systems. A ministerial panel eased the curbs at a meeting on Wednesday. The parliamentary affairs minister, Pramod Mahajan, said foreign investors would no longer be required to sell a 26 percent stake to an Indian partner or the public. India also raised foreign investment limits from 20 to 49 percent in banking, and from 49 to 74 percent in Internet service providers, paging and bandwidth. The country also opened its military sector to private investors, an area that previously was classified off-limits even to domestic investors.   Saritha Rai (NYT)

headline: Thai Prime Minister Denies Graft Charges
abstract: Thai Prime Min Thaksin Shinawatra makes emotional appeal before Constitutional Court in Bangkok, denying charge of corruption; is accused of intentionally concealing assets; faces immediate removal from office and exile from politics for five years if court upholds ruling by government anticorruption commission; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Women's Wear Daily Site Dismisses 13
abstract: WWD.com, Web site that generated new content and also took content from its mother publication, Women's Wear Daily, dismisses 13 employees (S)

headline: Look out Madison Avenue, here come the search consultants. And they're growing in importance.
abstract: Start-up company and new alliance are underscoring increasingly important role being played in advertising industry by search consultants, third-party advisers who help advertisers and agencies find and keep working with each other; Jan Boyle and Howard Lesman are starting firm MatchWorks, with divisions devoted to review process and to strengthening bonds between clients and agencies; AAR Partners, New York search consulting firm, is becoming partner of Aprais in London, worldwide consulting company (M)

headline: Court Rules for Trump in Casino Case
abstract: Two Indiana men recruited by Donald J Trump to lend 'Hoosierized' flavor to his bid for Lake Michigan riverboat casino have lost their chance for big payoff; federal appeals court in Indianapolis throws out $1.4 million jury award to pair, ruling they were mere window dressing to 'gussy up' Trump's application for gambling licence (S)

headline: Chemical Weapons Ban May Suffer for Lack of Dues From Treaty's Parties
abstract: Arms control experts warn that Organization for Prohibition of Chemical Weapons, international body charged with verifying 1997 chemical weapons ban, is in debt and may have to curb inspections because US, Russia and other signatories have not paid dues; director Ron G Manley explains (M)

headline: China's Bonus: Attention, and Respect
abstract: Analysis of what China got out of its latest run-in with United States; says Chinese government acquired secrets from downed American spy plane as well as attention and some respect from new Bush administration; notes that Bush administration initially paid so little heed to China that it had no high-level China experts in its ranks at time of incident, which proved to be handicap when 24 Americans were detained on Chinese soil; says Bush is now calling for 'fruitful and productive relationship' with China (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Online Brokers Manage to Ride Rally in Stocks
abstract: Investors bid up shares of online brokerage firms E*Trade Group Inc and Ameritrade Holding Corp from near their 52-week lows, apparently hoping that worse of trading slump is over; however, Christos M Cotsakos, chief executive of E*Trade, in announcing E*Trade's lack of earnings in first quarter, says depressed level of stock trading by individual investors will probably last at least until early fall; E*Trade's revenue dropped 20 percent, to $330 million, as its commissions on transactions were cut in half from year ago; net loss was $9.2 million; spending on sales and marketing fell almost 50 percent, to $93.7 million from $180.6 million in first quarter of 2000; shares of E*Trade rise $1.32, to $7.55, while Ameritrade jump 90 cents, to $5 (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Stay-at-Home Instinct Fosters Flush Times At 'Shelter' Magazines
abstract: Magazines about interior decoration, known in industry as shelter magazines, thrive while other magazines struggle; shelter magazine field is changing swiftly and is highly competitive; magazines carry advertising for products--food, furniture, pharmaceuticals--that are part of category considered recession-proof; table of leaders in field; photos (M)

headline: Disease Is Big Setback For Brazil Cattle Region
abstract: Brazil, which expected to take advantage of foot-and-mouth disease outbreak in Western Europe to expand meat exports, faces own outbreak of livestock illness; producers had abandoned traditional use of vaccines to win right to export chilled beef to United States in false hope that disease had been eradicated throughout Brazil; outbreak has strained ties among Mercosur trade group members, with Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay accusing Argentina of covering up 2000 outbreak; map; photo (M)

headline: U.S. May Withhold Main Radar Item on Taiwan's List
abstract: WASHINGTON, April 17 â€” President Bush's senior national security aides have recommended that he defer the sale to Taiwan of advanced destroyers equipped with a highly sophisticated ship-borne radar system but have advised him to provide a range of less advanced weapons to counter China's growing arsenal.

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Msn To Work With Loudeye
abstract: Loudeye Technologies, which makes software to broadcast audio and video on Internet, said it will provide music samples to MSN, online music service owned by Microsoft Corp; graph (S)

headline: U.S. Negotiates a Reduction of Its Dues to Support W.H.O.
abstract: GENEVA, May 22 - The United States today won a reduction in its budgetary contributions to the World Health Organization, although the head of the United Nations agency warned that some health programs could suffer as a result.

headline: Loews Gets More Time to Develop Buyout Plan
abstract: Loews Cineplex Entertainment Corp persuades Bankruptcy Judge Allan L Gropper to allow more time to develop $850 million buyout plan that unsecured creditors oppose; Gropper extends deadline by 120 days; Loews has agreed to be acquired by Onex Corp and Oaktree Capital Management LLC (M)

headline: In Ulster's Political Script, Mostly Monologues Still
abstract: David Trimble, Ulster Protestant most committed to power-sharing, is bringing re-election campaign for nine seats in British Parliament to Ulster's obstinate nay-saying enclaves in struggle to persuade distrustful majority Protestants to keep alive provincial government he leads in Belfast, where power is shared with Catholic minority; while contest among Catholic voters is interesting because of effort by Sinn Fein to gain ground on larger and moderate competitor, Protestant battle is drawing more attention because of consequences for peace project; vote in Ulster is referendum on April 1998 accord that has brought end to 30 years of sectarian violence; photo (M)

headline: With Sales Up, Pathmark Posts 1st-Quarter Profit
abstract: Pathmark Stores Inc posts net income of $5 million in fiscal first quarter ended May 5, compared with year-earlier loss of $16.1 million (S)

headline: TECHNOLOGY BRIEFING  Telecommunications: Wireless Deal Heads for Finish Line
abstract: Deutsche Telekom expects to complete its acquisition of VoiceStream Wireless by end of May; US Committee on Foreign Investment, which considers national security issues when foreign companies buy into American markets, has reviewed deal and will not take further action (S)

abstract: Kathleen Sullivan, lawyer for Web magazine 2600 and its publisher Eric Corley, urges federal appeals court to strike down 1998 law that seeks to limit unauthorized copying of digitized material; movie studios sued Corley in January 2000 after he posted DeCSS on his Web site and linked to other sites distributing program (M)

abstract: Article on financier Martin Ebner's decision to sell his 32 million shares of Roche Holdings at premium of 5 percent to Roche rival, Novartis, after being rebuffed by Roche for seat on its board; says Ebner's dealings could lead to merger of two pharmaceutical companies; photo (M)

abstract: SALT LAKE CITY -- IT was 9 a.m. on a Sunday here. Hundreds of people had gathered, mostly middle-aged or older, though there was an occasional young couple who had brought their toddler.

abstract: Parents of newborns at Sequoia Hospital in Redwood City, Calif, get free Web domain names and e-mail addresses for their babies (S)

headline: Webdenda: Executive Changes in Advertising
abstract: Jody Bilney, president for consumer markets in the retail markets group at Verizon Communications, Dallas and New York, was named senior vice president for brand management and marketing communications. She succeeds Janet Keeler, who is retiring, the company said. Ms. Keeler was based in New York.

headline: China Agrees to Return Partly Dismantled Spy Plane as Cargo
abstract: US and China agree 'in principle' that American surveillance plane that made emergency landing on Hainan Island on April 1 will be partly dismantled and removed from China on giant Russian-designed AN-124 cargo plane; timing of removal and other final details are still under discussion (M)

headline: Chief of Thai Central Bank Is Dismissed Over Rates
abstract: Prime Min Thaksin Shinawatra dismisses Bank of Thailand governor, Chatumongkol Sonakul, replacing him with Pridiyathorn Devakula, president of Export-Import Bank of Thailand; Thaksin has called for higher interest rates to encourage and reward bank depositors, a move opposed by Chatumongkol, economists and International Monetary Fund, who say low rates are appropriate given Thailand's weakening economy; benchmark rate has been at 1.5 percent for more than one year; photos (M)

headline: German Surprise! Who Are the Guest Workers?
abstract: Eastern German town of Saxony, where 20 percent of work force is unemployed, is source of labor for other European countries--such as Britain, Ireland and Netherlands--where labor markets are tight; unemployed residents of Saxony are becoming 'guest workers,' reversing trend in which millions of foreigners were drawn to Germany for decades by promise of highly paid jobs but who had almost no prospect of citizenship; photo (M)

headline: Another F.C.C. Clearance For Verizon Long-Distance
abstract: Verizon Communications receives approval from Federal Communications Commission to provide long-distance service in Massachusetts, bringing to five number of states where large Bell local telephone companies can enter into fast-changing long-distance communications business (M)

headline: Mexico's Image Is Buffed and Tarnished With Military Drug Arrests
abstract: Government of Pres Vicente Fox makes its first important drug arrests since taking power five months ago; three men arrested are Army Brig Gen Ricardo Martinez and his aides, Capt Pedro Maya and Lt Javier Quevedo; three are charged with having provided protection from arrest in return for payoffs from cocaine and marijuana traffickers operating along gulf coast; Pres Fox has promised to withdraw military from drug war (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Mcdonald's Offer
abstract: McDonald's Japan will list its shares on Japanese over-the-counter market on July 26, selling 26.2 million shares; photo (S)

headline: Stock Analyst Conduct Code Due
abstract: Securities Industry Association is set to release code of conduct for stock research that will urge Wall Street firms to limit ties between analysts and their investment banking businesses; Congressional hearings are set to begin into allegations that Wall Street research has been used to support investment banking business as opposed to providing investors with objective analysis (M)

headline: China's Release of North Korean Refugees Sidesteps Sensitive Issue
abstract: China, in pemmitting seven North Korean asylum seekers to leave Beijing on medical grounds, turns its back on central question incident raised; are the hundreds of thousands of illegal North Korean immigrants in China political refugees who deserve protection from persecution in their homeland, or are they simply poor people in search of better life who should be forcibly returned (M)

headline: French Premier Opposes German Plan for Europe
abstract: Prime Min Lionel Jospin of France categorically rejects Germany's proposals for more centralized federal Europe and instead offers extensive blueprint for fine tuning system that keeps most power in hands of member states; favors making Europe without unmaking France or any other European nation; says while union needs to be strengthened, France could never accept radical dimunition of its sovereignty; photo (M)

headline: Media Talk; Forget the Lipstick! Rosie Presses Limits.
abstract: Rosie O'Donnell breaks with conventional magazine wisdom by appearing in hospital gown, without makeup, on cover of her new magazine, Rosie, showing the bandaged hand that was treated for staphylococcus aureus infection; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Insurer Investigated
abstract: French police officers investigating PanEurolife, insurance company based in Luxembourg that is suspected of tax evasion, have questioned French insurer AXA chairman Claude Bebear and its chief executive Henri de Castries; AXA acquired PanEurolife in 1997 as part of its purchase of Union des Assurances de Paris, but later sold stake in PanEurolife to Nationwide Holdings; PanEurolife executives, including managing director Jacques Drossaert, are being investigated over suspected scheme in which investors made deposits in French postal savings accounts that were then transferred to Luxembourg and converted into life insurance policies, enabling policy owners to avoid taxes on investment income; photo (S)

headline: Management: Behind Bars And on the Clock; Despite Low Pay, Felons Show Up Motivated
abstract: Prison population is one of fastest growing work forces in United States, with about 85,000 of nation's 1.3 million inmates in federal and state prisons holding jobs; Oregon is leader in trend, as result of 1994 law requiring all able-bodied prisoners to work 40 hours a week; managers of Array Corp, garment manufacturer that employs Oregon prisoners, say felons are highly motivated workers, even though they get to keep only 20 percent of pay; jobs offer release from dreariness and danger of prison life, some money and skills that can be used on outside; graph of employed inmates; photos (M)

headline: Missionaries' Church Casts Net Wide
abstract: Article on Calvary Church in Muskegon, Mich, which supported Veronica Bowers, American missionary who was killed with daughter as result of attack by Peruvian Air Force plane during antinarcotics reconnaissance flight on April 20; church is ambitious in its support of people who preach Gospel far and wide (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Gasoline prices rally on speculation that inventories will stay below year-earlier levels during summer travel season; in New York, gasoline for May delivery rises 0.47 cent, to $1.1297 per gallon; graph; chart (S)

headline: A Flood of Sites That Make Every Fan a Steinbrenner
abstract: Rotisserie baseball and its more popular cousin, fantasy baseball, are becoming big business on Internet, where about 60 sites are devoted to games; an estimated 10 million people play games in some form, a figure that may be doubled by Internet; photo (M)

headline: General in Balkan War Says Pentagon Hampered NATO
abstract: Gen Wesley K Clark, NATO commander during war with Yugoslavia, accuses Pentagon of repeatedly hampering alliance's military planning and discouraging steps that might have made fighting unnecessary; new memoir, Waging Modern War, says Pentagon leadership, notably former Defense Sec William S Cohen, repeatedly tried to limit American involvement, fearing deepening commitment to Balkans, which had not figured in national military strategy; portrays former president, Bill Clinton, as capable leader who was prepared to make tough call by moving toward use of ground troops, and NATO secretary general Javier Solana as decisive figure who tried to rally support in Europe for bombing; provides inside account of planning and conduct of 77-day war, as well as of diplomacy that preceded it; Clark comments; photos (M)

headline: Virgin Is Said to Be in Talks With Sprint on U.S. Venture
abstract: Virgin Mobile is reportedly in talks with Sprint to create joint venture that would be Virgin's first foray into United States telecommunications market (M)

headline: For Those Who Would Click and Cheat
abstract: Three high schools and 14 colleges, including Pace University, install new software designed to protect against students' cheating on examinations administered via computer; system, called Securexam, was created by Software Secure Inc; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: The Uncountable Toll
abstract: International Rescue Committee says as many as 2.5 million people may have died since 1998 as result of civil war in Congo (S)

headline: Stocks End Lower as Wall Street Awaits April Employment Data
abstract: Shaking off some recent gains, stock prices fell today, led down by technology issues, as Wall Street displayed some nervousness ahead of Friday's employment report.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Congress Seeks Information On Fraud
abstract: Members of Congress ask for guidance from some of companies that are hosts to Internet auctions--Yahoo, eBay and Amazon.com--in assessing prevalence of online auction fraud; photo (S)

headline: Spending, Without Excuses
abstract: Russell Reinhardt letter responds to April 15 Love & Money article about spouses hiding their purchases from each other

headline: Keeping Hold Of Top Office In Paraguay
abstract: Pres Luis Gonzalez Macchi, whose party has long held power in Paraguay, finds rank and file turning on him as emboldened opposition demands resignation, and public support dwindles amid allegations that presidential limousing is stolen car; Colorado Party's scandal-plagued history recounted (M)

headline: Soldiers in Georgia Stage a Brief Near Mutiny
abstract: As many as 400 Georgian national guardsmen left their barracks today and took over a police station outside the capital, Tbilisi, to protest long delays in paychecks and other economic hardships, briefly raising fears of a coup.    But late today, after face-to-face talks with the soldiers, President Eduard Shevardnadze of Georgia said that their protest was economic, not political, and that the soldiers would end their near mutiny on Saturday. He called the action a grave crime, but said he did not support prosecuting the troops.

headline: Baby's First Webcast: A Visit With Family
abstract: BabyPressConference.com, which broadcasts newborns' faces over Internet to friends and family worldwide, is offered by many hospitals' obstetrics departments as amenity; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Journalist's Body Identified
abstract: FBI experts say that headless body found in November near Kiev is that of missing journalist, Georgy Gongadze (S)

headline: First Boston Won't Be Giving Midyear Raises to Its Top Tier
abstract: Credit Suisse First Boston tells about 5,400 executives of its investment banking operations that they will not receive midyear raises because of slowdown in financial markets (M)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: EUROPE    RUSSIA: AMERICAN'S TRIAL OPENS  The trial of an American on drug charges opened in Voronezh, in central Russia. John Tobin, left, a 24-year-old Fulbright scholar, faces up to 15 years in jail if convicted. He denies any wrongdoing and says marijuana found in his apartment was planted by the police. The security force also says he was training to be a spy, but admits there are no grounds to prosecute him.    (Reuters)    VATICAN CITY: ARMENIAN IS 'MARTYR'  The Vatican proclaimed an Armenian Catholic bishop who was killed in 1915 and 26 Ukrainians who died in Communist persecutions to be martyrs, the first step toward sainthood. The honor for Ignace Maloyan, archbishop of Mardin, Turkey, came on the day that Armenians commemorate the deaths of hundreds of thousands in what they say was an Ottoman campaign to force them out of eastern Turkey. Turkey says that the toll is inflated and that Armenians were killed or resettled as the empire tried to quell unrest. The Ukrainians were killed during anti-church campaigns by Ukraine's former Communist rulers.    (AP)

headline: A Warm, if Quick, Heroes' Welcome, Then On to Long Hours With Debriefing Teams
abstract: All 24 crew members of American surveillance plane held in China land at Hickam Air Force Base in Honolulu, and are given deliberately low-key heroes' welcome; they face two long days of debriefing interviews there before going home to more tumultuous salute being planned at their base, Whidbey Island, near Seattle; Navy officials want to determine how crew's lumbering EP-3E plane and Chinese jet fighter collided, as well as how much of sensitive electronic gear crew was able to destroy and what intelligence windfalls Chinese might have gained from downed craft; photo (M)

headline: Prosperous Colombians Flee, Many to U.S., to Escape War
abstract: Many of Colombia's most promising young professionals and business people have reluctantly emigrated, fleeing civil conflict and economic stagnation in quest for success and stability; government says nearly 1.1 million of nation's 40 million people have left since 1996; many have wound up in United States; size of exodus is rasing concerns about long-term effects on nation's economy and psyche; graphs of exodus; photo (M)

headline: GERMANY: CONFIDENCE GAUGE FALLS
abstract: Germany's IFO index of business confidence dropped for ninth consecutive month in March and reached its lowest level in 12 months (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Gasoline futures prices drop after industry report shows rise in inventories; gasoline for July delivery falls 2.5 cents, to 88.04 cents a gallon; graphs; table (S)

headline: Zimbabwe Doctors Flee As AIDS Crisis Widens
abstract: Medical professionals are abandoning Zimbabwe as never before, fleeing deepening hardships there and following lure of opportunities elsewhere; business executives, teachers, engineers and others are also leaving, costing Zimbabwe much of enormously successful investment it made in education after blacks won majority rule 21 years ago; Zimbabwe's economy, once one of Africa's most promising, is a wreck; standoff over how white-owned farmland should be redistributed has roiled country and harmed agriculture, its economic base; exports and tourism are also down; World Bank and International Monetary Fund have cut Zimbabwe off, and Pres Robert Mugabe refuses to make concessions in state's policies and priorities to get them back; photos; map (M)

headline: Generation X, Still Undecided
abstract: Abby Ellin column on confusion about career choices that continues to afflict graduates of late 1980's and early 1980's; cites economic factors that contribute to problem; drawing (M)

headline: Fun, games and even a little business at the 2001 Four A's management conference.
abstract: Advertising column on some of highlights, lowlights and sidelights of 2001 management conference of American Association of Advertising Agencies in Naples, Fla (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: AMERICAS

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Increase in Medical Costs Contributes to Aetna Loss  Aetna, the ailing health insurance giant, posted a first-quarter loss and said that its main business was in trouble and unlikely to recover before late next year.    Aetna attributed the loss to an unforeseen 15 percent increase in medical costs, the highest reported by any big for-profit managed-care company. [C11.]    Chicago Will Be Boeing's New Home  After weeks of negotiations since it said it was leaving Seattle, Boeing chose Chicago over Dallas and Denver as its new home. [C3.]    Changes by G.E.'s Next Chairman  In his first major corporate and personnel move since becoming president and chairman-elect of General Electric, Jeffrey R. Immelt, left, named Gary L. Rogers, head of GE Plastics, as a corporate vice chairman and split the plastics business into two operations. The move points to growing confidence at G.E. that its deal for Honeywell International will ultimately be approved. [C3.]    Appeal to F.D.A. on Allergy Drugs  Wellpoint Health Networks will argue before an F.D.A. advisory panel today that Claritin, the top-selling prescription allergy drug, and two of its competitors should be made more widely available. [Page A1.]    The F.D.A. approved Gleevec, a new kind of anti-cancer drug, after a swift, two-and-a-half month review of clinical data. [A1.]    Microsoft Hires a Start-Up Ad Shop  Microsoft is dismissing FCB Worldwide in San Francisco, which had served as the creative agency for the digital video recorder Ultimate TV, and hiring instead a San Francisco start-up shop. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. [C5.]    W.W.F. and NBC Pull Plug on XFL  The XFL expired, three weeks after the last game of its only season, a victim of dismal TV ratings, a subpar quality of play and inflated expectations. The demise of the football league is a highly visible failure for its parents, the World Wrestling Federation and NBC. [D1.]    Markets Are Mixed as Rally Fizzles  The latest attempt to sustain a rally on Wall Street fizzled. The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 43.46 points at 10,910.44. The Nasdaq composite index fell 27.77 points, to 2,128.86, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 0.36 point, to 1,255.18. [C6.]    Retail Sales Climbed 3% in April  Retailers' sales rose more than forecast in April, led by low-price chains like Wal-Mart. Sales at stores open at least a year rose 3 percent in April compared with March. Gap, the biggest clothing chain, showed improvement, although its sales still fell 2 percent. Analysts had expected a drop of as much as 10 percent. The April results lifted Gap's first-quarter profit above analysts' estimates. Its shares rose $3.61, to $32.41. [C5.]    British Telecom Outlines Overhaul  British Telecommunications outlined a widely anticipated corporate overhaul that would enable it to raise $8.4 billion and spin off its wireless division. [World Business, Section W.]    Shift in Technology Helps I.B.M.  Louis V. Gerstner Jr., chairman of I.B.M., said that the company was benefiting from a new golden age at its research laboratories and a shift in technology markets toward areas in which I.B.M. is especially strong. [C2.]

headline: In Bush's Words: ABM 'Prevents a Full Exploration of Possibility'
abstract: Excerpts from news conference by Pres Bush and Prime Min Jose Maria Aznar in Madrid (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Security Expert Warns Of Risk in Windows Version  The Internet is sustaining a growing plague of attacks that overwhelm Web sites by flooding them with data, and an Internet security expert is warning Microsoft that the planned consumer rollout of its Windows XP operating system for personal computers could make the global network even more vulnerable.    The software's Internet-connection features, he contends, makes server computers more susceptible to a Web intrusion known as a distributed denial of service attack, in which attackers remotely commandeer hundreds of personal computers connected to the Internet and use them to release a disabling deluge of data against a Web site. [Page C7.]

headline: South African Leader Fights a Fraying Image
abstract: south african leader fights a fraying image** Thabo Mbeki of South Africa, hailed as can-do president when he was elected 22 months ago, faces rising criticism and slipping approval ratings in public opinion polls; members of governing African National Cognress are circulating pamphlets calling for 'one president, one term,' and three senior ANC members are being investigated on charges of conspiring to oust him; many ANC leaders say there is conspiracy to undermine Mbeki and his effort to put levers of economy in black hands; analysts cite Mbeki's own missteps, not plots orchestrated by white men; say he has dissatisfied many within his own ranks; say his conservative fiscal policies, praised by Western donors, have been accompanied by loss of thousands of jobs; say he has been assailed by his traditional allies for questioning safety of AIDS drugs and for musing about causes for epidemic while thousands of South Africans are dying; photo; map (M)

headline: Birenda, 55, Ruler of Nepal's Hindu Kingdom
abstract: Biographical article on King Birendra Bir Bikram Shah Dev, who was shot to death in massacre of Nepal's royal family; he was 55 years old; he was sidelined into role of constitutional monarch after fierece wave of street revolts in 1990; he gained stature and approval in his final years because he did not call in military to stop democracy movement; photo (M)

abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Personal Business Diary: Loans Among Friends
abstract: The stories are common enough: A parent provides a child with a car loan, a brother lends a sister money to get by after a layoff or a friend gives another friend start-up money for a business.

abstract: Article reports that, unlike in US, executive salaries overseas are less publicized and, often, not disclosed, especially in Europe; some examples cited; photos (M)

headline: An Easter Release For Christmas Toys; Companies Use Spring Holiday As Way to Create a December Rush
abstract: Easter becomes an important holiday for toymakers, as they look to bring out their products earlier in year, taking advantage of parents' visits to stores to shop for Easter gifts and of children being taken on spring vacation; with toy companies releasing similar products--miniature dolls, electronic dogs, robots--many manufacturers are introducing more toys in spring in hopes of capturing market early and escaping fall clutter, when most new toys make their way to store shelves; photo; chart (L)

headline: For China-Born U.S. Citizens, Visiting Homeland Has Risks
abstract: China's State Security Ministry begins detaining American citizens born in China and questioning them about their affairs in move diplomats regard as troubling change in government policy; China experts and others say situation marks first time since Korean War that American citizens have been held by State Security apparatus; six American citizens, none prominent critics of China, have been questioned and detained since end of last year; include businessmen, writers and academics; number of Chinese citizens with permanent residency status in US have also been held; detentions highlight new government scrutiny of group that has become prominent in China's business and academic sectors in recent years, namely, Chinese citizens who immigrated to US to study in 1980's and 1990's and are returning in large numbers to work--often armed with liberal ideas and foreign passport or green card; photo of American professor, Li Shaomin, who remains in Chinese custody (M)

abstract: Corn drops after US government estimates that China's crop could be 19 percent bigger than last year; in Chicago, corn for July delivery falls 6.75 cents, or 3.3 percent, to $1.9825 per bushel; graph; chart (S)

abstract: George Bell, former chairman and chief executive of ExciteatHome, is named chief executive of Upromise Inc, succeeding founder Michael Bronner, who will remain chairman; photo (S)

abstract: David Pugue State of the Art column reviews vastly improved mobile computer game device unleashed by Nintendo, Game Boy Advance; finds quality similar to that of stationary console models; photo (M)

headline: Cordial Rivals: How Bush And Putin Became Friends
abstract: Official who helped plan Pres Bush's European trip says warm rapport shown between him and Russian Pres Vladimir Putin represents significant achievement for US; critics on Capitol Hill say Bush was too willing to praise Putin as trustworthy after meeting for only first time; Democrats who control Senate are relieved that Bush's visit did not go badly, but some say he went too far in cozying up to Putin; photo (M)

abstract: Shareholders of nearly 20 companies, including Exxon Mobil, can vote in Spring, 2001, on proposals obliging management to offer two candidates for each vacancy on board of directors instead of traditional take-it-or-leave-it one (M)

abstract: David Leonhard column says today's phenomenon of brisk consumer spending despite sharp loss of optimism about economy is exactly what happened in other recessions since 1969; chart (M)

headline: AVENTIS CROPSCIENCE DECISION PLANNED
abstract: French-German pharmaceuticals group Aventis SA will decide by July on either taking agrochemicals unit Aventis CropScience public or selling it; Schering AG, which holds 24 percent stake in unit, could block either decision and has said it will not approve deal at current low market valuations (S)

headline: Argentina Plans Debt Swap in Billions, Delaying Payments
abstract: Argentina announces voluntary plan to swap as much as $67 billion of existing debt for new, longer-term securities that would delay millions of dollars in interest payments for government; analysts say purpose of debt swap is to avoid default (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Sentencing Hearing For Teenage Hacker
abstract: Montreal youth court begins sentencing hearing for teenage computer hacker who uses name Mafiaboy; 16-year-old pleaded guilty on Jan 19 to 56 charges that he used computers throughout America to block communication with some of busiest sites on Internet (S)

headline: VW Holders Approve Buyback
abstract: Volkswagen AG receives overwhelming approval from shareholders to buy back its stock and shore up its defenses against hostile takeover; there are protests from dissident investors, including several large institutions; Ford Motor Co and General Motors Co have been rumored to want German automaker (M)

headline: Lenders Try to Fend Off Laws on Subprime Loans
abstract: More than dozen states and cities are considering laws limiting so-called predatory lending, which is blamed for rising foreclosures of inner-city homes, and lenders have mounted coordinated counterattack that has managed to fend off or weaken some of farthest-reaching proposals; latest battle is in Philadelphia, where Citigroup, Household International and other lenders are seeking to derail measure; lenders say proposals will curtail access to credit for many families and create awkward patchwork of regulations across country; among industry advisers are Connie Mack, former Republican senator from Florida, and Thomas F McLarty, former chief of staff for Pres Clinton; regulators have recently toughened rules in New York and Massachusetts; graph (M)

headline: Japan's Premier-to-Be Seeks Right to Openly Field Army
abstract: TOKYO, April 25 â€” In the clearest statement in memory from a top Liberal Democratic Party figure, the prime minister in waiting, Junichiro Koizumi, says Japan's Constitution needs to be changed so Tokyo can openly field an army.

headline: Falun Gong Stages Protests as Jiang Visits Hong Kong
abstract: Pres Jiang Zemin of China visits Hong Kong, where he hails freedom in former British colony; protesters from Falun Gong spiritual movement rally throughout city, accusing Jiang of imprisoning and torturing their members on mainland; photo (M)

headline: Stocks End Lower as Investors Take Profits From Recent Rally
abstract: Stock prices fell today as investors pulled back in the absence of economic news and took some profits from the market's recent rally.

headline: Opinion Is Divided in Serbia Over Handover of Milosevic
abstract: Many Serbs are happy that Slobodan Milosevic is gone, but many oppose his handover to international court on all grounds; indictment of Milosevic is expanded to include names of hundreds more victims in Kosovo; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Did The Doctor Kill More Than 400?

headline: M.B.A. Programs That Look a Lot Like Work
abstract: Customized MBA programs are being offered by major corporations, giving them another carrot for luring and retaining talent--priority as baby boomers retire and corporations face looming management shortage; programs offered by Texas Instruments, GM and Intel Corp discussed; photo (M)

headline: German Utility Close to a Deal For Powergen
abstract: E.ON, large Germany utility, is close to agreement to buy Powergen, British gas and electricity supplier, for $7.4 billion; Powergen assets include seven generators in Britain and LG&E Energy Corp in Louisville, Ky; acquisition would give E.ON foothold in both British and United States electricity markets at time of rapid consolidation and comes as other large European utility companies seek acquisitions abroad to help offset fierce competition at home; deal is subject to regulatory approval in US and Europe (M)

headline: Market Place: Have Stocks Hit Bottom? It Depends on the News
abstract: Wall Street analysts will tell you that you have to be back in the stock market before the economy and corporate earnings turn if you are going to catch a rally early enough to make a nice profit.

abstract: Roy J. Bostock, chairman at the Bcom3 Group in Chicago since it was formed in February 2000, is stepping down, Bcom3 said yesterday. He will be succeeded by Roger Haupt, who continues as chief executive.

headline: British Airways Makes Deal To Sell Its Discount Carrier
abstract: British Airways reaches agreement to sell Go, its discount airline subsidiary, for $153 million (US) to 3i, venture capital firm, and Go's senior managers; Go's chief executive Barbara Cassani will continue to run airline, along with existing management team; Go reports that it made profit of $3.9 million (US) in year ended March 31; revenue increased 59 percent, to $222 million (US) (M)

abstract: Charles Herold Game Theory column describes Shadow of Destiny and Myst III: Exile, new computer games; they were developed by, respectively, Konami Computer Entertainment and Presto Studios; photos (M)

abstract: Article on ESPN's new advertising campaign promoting professional basketball and 2001 Women's NBA season that showcases beauty and grace of game and its players; campaign was developed by Wieden & Kennedy; photo (M)

headline: Saying 'Buy' as They Sell
abstract: Dan Goldman letter on May 27 article proposes way in which compensation for stock analysts could be based on how well they do for investor

headline: U.S. Wades Into Macedonian Conflict and Skopje Erupts
abstract: American troops escorted hundreds of Albanian rebels from a town that has been the most recent flashpoint, setting off a huge riot in Macedonia's capital

headline: Crew Is Back At Its Base To Cheers Of Welcome
abstract: The Navy crew held for 11 days in China returned home to a heroes' welcome today, reuniting with relatives and basking under cheers from thousands of area residents at an afternoon arrival ceremony.     As they exited a jetliner that carried them from Hawaii to the Whidbey Island Naval Air Station, their home base, the crew of 21 men and 3 women waved back to a sea of flag-wavers who had waited hours for the plane to land.

headline: Baporo Forest; A Stately Elephant Moment, a Bit Like an Elegy
abstract: Elephants once roamed all over West Africa, but they have fared poorly there and now make up only tiny percentage of total number of elephants on continent; they are fighting losing battle against human beings, who have been growing in numbers and who have settled in previously sparsely populated areas; experts say part of difficulty in protecting elephants in West Africa lies in absence of wildlife tourism found elsewhere in Africa; say governments in region have invested little in programs for conservation; photo of elephants crossing main highway in Burkina Faso; map (M)

headline: Stocks End Sharply Higher After Fed Slashes Rates
abstract: Investors roared their approval today after the Federal Reserve unexpectedly and aggressively cut interest rates.

headline: U.N. Report Says U.S. Slowdown Is Damaging Other Economies
abstract: Forecasters from more than 60 countries warn that American slowdown is damaging many other economies around world, particulaly Asian nations with high-tech industries that have just begun to recover from 1997 regional crash; economists, meeting at UN, predict world economic growth will slow this year to 2.4 percent, from 4 percent; (M)

headline: World Briefing  Asia: North Korea: Warning To U.S.
abstract: Editorial in North Korea Communist Party newspaper accuses US of seeking pretext to start war on Korean peninsula (S)

headline: Article 2001061692696143290 -- No Title
abstract: Gearing Up for the Car Office

headline: A Plan to Expand Internet Addresses
abstract: Cisco Systems is set to unveil software for next-generation Internet routing system capable of providing relatively infinite supply of Internet addresses; current Internet protocol provides for over four billion unique addresses, number engineers say will be inadequate for explosion in devices being connected to Internet; Cisco engineers are unsure how quickly major customers will adopt new technology; existing technology makes it possible for single address to be translated into tens, hundreds or thousands of unique addresses (M)

headline: All Bets Are Off; Bali Is On
abstract: IT has been six months since I first wrote about Jill and Brandon Lowitz, the starry-eyed newlyweds in Manhattan who vowed to step out of the rat race twice each month and meet for lunch. When their friend Richard Ellenson laughed at the idea that love could triumph over work, a wager was born.    The details were these: the Lowitzes would ''do lunch'' together 24 times in one year, then fax the receipts to Mr. Ellenson. For every lunch over 24, Mr. Ellenson would owe Mr. Lowitz $100. For every lunch short of 24, Mr. Lowitz would have to pay $100 to Mr. Ellenson.

headline: U.S. Sends 2 To Assess Drug Program For Afghans
abstract: Bush administration, in first cautious step toward reducing near-total isolation of Taliban, has sent two American narcotics experts to Afghanistan as part of United Nations team assessing how to help farmers who stop cultivating poppies; State Sec Colin L Powell confirms approving trip; Taliban reportedly has all but wiped out poppy crops in nation that had been world's largest opium producer and source of much of heroin sold in Europe (M)

headline: U.S. Plans to Appeal Dismissal of American Airlines Lawsuit
abstract: WASHINGTON, June 26 â€” The Justice Department announced today that it would appeal a recent Federal District Court decision to dismiss the government's predatory pricing antitrust case against American Airlines.

headline: Merger Helps Pfizer Exceed Expectations
abstract: Pfizer Inc says first-quarter profit rose 34 percent as it cut costs after buying Warner-Lambert; profit from operations rose to $2.13 billion from $1.58 billion year earlier; revenue rose 6.8 percent, to $7.6 billion (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: MIDDLE EAST

headline: I.L.O. Sees Rise In Forced Labor And Slavery
abstract: International Labor Organization says forced labor, slavery and criminal trafficking in people are increasing globally, with women and children most at risk (S)

headline: Trying to Win A New Name Game; Trademarks Must Vie for Net Addresses
abstract: Two new suffixes for Internet addresses will be added over next several months: .biz for business or commercial Web sites and .info, open to anyone who wishes to register name; goal of new extensions is to relieve overcrowding in popular .com, .org and .net addresses, known in vernacular of industry as generic top-level domains; managing rollout is complicated, with many constituencies to appease plus challenge of carrying out technology project on global scale; one of main challenges of expansion has been developing registration procedures that give intellectual property owners chance to protect trademarked names; idea is to avoid cybersquatting that has plagued .com domain, where speculators buy addresses in hope of selling them at profit to owners of similar trademarks; organization that oversees Internet's address system is Internet Corp for Assigned Names and Numbers; photo; graphs (M)

headline: College Entrance in China: 'No' to the Handicapped
abstract: Universities in China, where bias against handicapped runs deep, continue to reject applicants with limps and other disabilities despite anti-discrimination laws; official policy is often contradictory; schools fear accepting any disabled students will attract attention and spur others to seek admission; map; photo (M)

headline: Surplus of Finger-Pointing In California Energy Crisis
abstract: Many experts believe woes of California's natural gas market are as profound as those of its electricity market; state is short on pipelines, and rules of gas market, critics say, encourage sellers and traders--including biggest local gas utility--to drive prices higher; state's electricity is generated by gas-fired power plants, higher proportion than in most parts of country, and since 80 percent of gas consumed there comes from outside, shortage of pipelines leading into and within state has become big handicap in fueling plants; strain has become especially acute as droughtin Pacific Northwest has curtailed imports of hydropower and gas-fired power plants have worked overtime to meet demands of booming state economy; photo; map (M)

headline: Flying Americans Home, and Reaping Bonus Miles
abstract: There was, aside from President Bush, one chief executive who was particularly enthusiastic about the return of the 24 men and women detained in China when their spy plane made an emergency landing there two weeks ago. Splashed across the front pages of newspapers throughout the world â€” and seen by millions on television â€” was a white jet with a huge Continental Airlines logo carrying the returning crew members. "We are tremendously proud," said Gordon M. Bethune, the airline's chief executive, who, after receiving word on Wednesday, announced to a cheering Houston Chamber of Commerce meeting that the Continental plane was "in the air."

headline: Recent Attacks Spook Surfers and Swimmers : Australia's Love of Water In Jaws of Shark Phobia
abstract: SYDNEYâ€”  It was midafternoon and the waves kept rolling in from the Pacific Ocean. Mark Butler, an experienced board surfer, had been in the water for more than an hour and had just caught a wave almost to the shore of the deserted beach.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS MACHINES CORP., Armonk, N.Y., the No. 1 computer maker and computer-services company in the world, said it had won a $1.3 billion contract over 15 years to modernize the technology department of the United States Customs Service.

headline: U.S. Accused Of Diluting a Global Pact to Limit Use of Tobacco
abstract: No progress is reported at meeting in Geneva where governments from more than 150 countries are trying to work out provisions of treaty that World Health Organization is pushing to stem rising death toll around the world from tobacco-related diseases; US and other major countries are now backpedaling on proposed complete ban on cigarette advertising and promotion; antismoking activists accuse US and Japan of siding with tobacco multinationals seeking to dilute treaty language (M)

headline: Investing Diary: Union Tries New Route in Eastman Kodak Vote
abstract: This time, Bill Bradley, the former senator and basketball star whose bid for the Democratic presidential nomination fell short last year, is almost certain to win an election. But millions of union members, a natural constituency, will not be supporting him.

headline: Learning, One Bullet Point at a Time; Pupils Who Can't Even Spell 'PowerPoint' Can Use It as Slickly as Any C.E.O.
abstract: PowerPoint, Microsoft presentation software long favored in corporate world, infiltrates primary and secondary education classrooms; photos (M)

headline: Bear Market? The Young Needn't Be Restless
abstract: IN the last decade, the stock market has become something of a hometown sports team for the entire nation. We check up on it during the day, much the way people steal a peek at afternoon baseball games. When our team -- call it the Bulls -- is losing, we all feel a little glummer. When the team is winning, as it was last week, we head home for the night a bit happier.    The reason for this cheering is basic. The whole country -- or its growing class of investors, at the very least -- appears to prosper with a rising market. That is not quite right, however. There are actually millions of investors who could benefit from a lengthy bear market. In fact, it would probably improve the long-term economic security of most Americans under the age of 40.

headline: Introduction Is Set for Broadband Data-Voice System
abstract: Jetstream Communications Inc and Matsushita Electrical Industrial Co's Panasonic unit develop technology for residential market that would let home users operate up to four phone circuits and high-speed Internet access through single base unit connected to single line from public phone network; up to eight wireless handsets could communicate with base station, each with access to all phone circuits; partnership plans to compete in nascent market for voice services delivered over broadband networks; photo (M)

abstract: Fiber optic equipment maker Sycamore Networks forecasts third-quarter loss on lower-than-expected sales and says it will cut 140 jobs, or about 13 percent of its work force; graph (S)

headline: WORLD BRIEFING
abstract: ASIA    PHILIPPINES: WARRANT FOR EX-PRESIDENT -- A special anti-graft court issued an arrest warrant on corruption charges for former President Joseph Estrada, who was booked, photographed and fingerprinted. Mr. Estrada, who has insisted that he is innocent, posted bond and remained free.   Seth Mydans (NYT)    VIETNAM: POISON ATTACKS -- Sixty-five more children and teachers were reported to have fallen ill in chemical poison attacks in schools in Dak Lak Province. More than 600 children and teachers have been sickened in recent weeks in Dak Lak, which has been hit by political unrest.   Seth Mydans (NYT)

headline: A Pre-emptive Strike On Global Warming; Many Companies Cut Gas Emissions To Head Off Tougher Regulations
abstract: Many multinational companies plan to continue reducing emissions of global-warming gases despite Bush administration's decision to back away from regulating emissions cause they face strong pressure to do so in Europe and Japan, fear rising energy costs or want to promote their products as being friendly to environment; some top officials at these companies say that while voluntary action is right approach in short term, at some point they expect US and others to adopt binding restrictions on gases; emissions of global-warming gases by American industry are falling at surprising rate; measures taken by such companies as American Electric Power, Visteon Corp and other companies to lower emissions detailed; graph; chart; photos (M)

headline: State of the Art: Makeover for Desktop PC Adds Style, and a Stylus
abstract: FIFTY years from now, no doubt, we'll wear our computers on our earlobes, snap them into our belly buttons or even swallow them like tablets. On crisp winter evenings, we'll sit by the fire and tell our grandkids about the days when PC's were big, ugly contraptions that sat on our desks for only three years before becoming landfill.

headline: Bulgaria, Voting Today, Looks Kindly on Ex-King
abstract: Bulgaria's former king, Simeon, returned to country in April and founded political movement that is leading in polls for legislative elections; photo; map; Simeon is campaigning but not running himself, but would be eligible to become prime minister if party wins; bid for power upsets supporters of Prime Min Ivan Kostov, whose party swept to majority in 1997 but trails now (M)

headline: Ireland Arrests I.R.A. Dissident Suspected of Omagh Bombing
abstract: LONDON, April 11 â€” Ireland has arrested the alleged leader of the dissident Real IRA, the group that blew up the market center of Omagh three years ago, and Irish and British officials plan to base their prosecution on the testimony of an American who succeeded in infiltrating the ruling council of the clandestine group.

headline: 'Survivor' v. 'Boot Camp' In Latest TV Lawsuit
abstract: Creators of hit show Survivor and show's network, CBS, sue Fox network and creators of show Boot Camp of stealing concept behind show from Survivor; suit asks for injunction to prevent show from continuing on air and for unspecified damages; CBS says format as well as 'look and feel' of Boot Camp are deliberate copies of Survivor and thus unlawful theft of intellectual property under federal copyright act; Fox says there is absolutely no basis for claims by CBS; photo (M)

abstract: Euro rises on speculation that European Central Bank will cut interest rates as soon as next week to increase growth; in New York, euro settles at 90.20 cents, up from 89.65 cents; graph; chart (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Great Train Robber Eyes Return
abstract: Ronnie Biggs, member of Great Train Robbery gang of 1963, sends Scotland Yard message saying he wants to return after years as fugitive and celebrity in Brazil, even if it means facing criminal charges; photo; Biggs is 71 and in poor health (S)

abstract: Delta Air Lines Inc threatens to shift or sell aircraft from its Comair commuter carrier if unit's 1,400 striking pilots reject settlement offer (S)

abstract: Chartered Semiconductor Manufacturing of Singapore reports loss of $30.8 million in first quarter of 2001; sales fall 13 percent, to $206.7 million (S)

abstract: Cardinals gathered at Vatican to chart course of world's one billion Roman Catholics take inward look, calling for more power-sharing and frank discussion at top of church (M)
