abstract: Fellowes PDA Pocket Keyboard, joint effort of Cirque Corp and Fellowes Manufacturing, serves Palm-based hand-held computing devices; photo (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: German Court Fines Hewlett
abstract: Hewlett-Packard is ordered by German court to pay fees on compact disc burners it has sold there over last three years; court order is result of law passed last year that requires fee equivalent to $1.58 under current exchange rates for each compact disc burner sold in Germany in last three years, and $5.28 for each compact disc burner sold in future; graph (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Natural Gas Prices Remain High in Southern California  Natural gas prices have plunged during the last two months except in Southern California, where the wholesale cost of gas is still more than $11 per thousand cubic feet, compared with $4 in New York.    To many experts, the woes of California's natural gas market are as profound as those of its electricity market: The state is short on pipelines, and the rules of the gas market, critics say, allow sellers and traders to drive prices higher. [Page A1.]

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Appeals Court Throws Out Order to Split Up Microsoft  A federal appeals court unanimously threw out an order to break up Microsoft while finding that the company had repeatedly abused its monopoly power in the software business.    The court also chastised the judge overseeing the case and removed him from any further involvement because of his comments about the company and its senior executives. The opinion, welcomed by Microsoft, was also hailed by government officials. [Page A1.]

headline: U.N. Chief Calls on U.S. Companies to Donate to AIDS Fund
abstract: UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan appeals to US corporations to give to planned multibillion-dollar global fund to fight AIDS; meets with Sec Colin Powell, who has joined Annan in high-profile, personal campaign to spotlight Africa's AIDS tragedy (M)

headline: World Business Briefing/Asia: China: Airline Alliance
abstract: Six state-owned Chinese airlines form alliance to compete against three large state-owned airline groups being formed through state-mandated consolidation; China is trying to narrow number of airlines without forcing any into bankruptcy (S)

headline: Workplace: Off the Streets and Into Respectability
abstract: have a full-time job," said Debra Bounsell, 42, a receptionist at Time Warner Cable. "I love saying that: a full-time job."

headline: Serbian Town's Deadly Secret Points the Finger at Milosevic
abstract: KLADOVO, Serbia, May 29 â€” For two years the people of this Danube River town kept the dark secret that has now led â€” after a decade of Balkan death and destruction largely attributed to Slobodan Milosevic â€” to the first move by Serbia's new democratic authorities to charge him with war crimes.

headline: Suddenly, the Stakes Are High for Disney's Film and TV Businesses
abstract: Release of $135 million film Pearl Harbor by Walt Disney Co raises questions abouth where Disney's movie division is headed and what it means to company's health; Walt Disney Studios head Peter Schneider and Disney chairman Michael D Eisner say studio is becoming more serious about cost controls; studio will release about 14 films this year, lower than usual, amid cutbacks by other studios; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: European Union: Inflation Slows
abstract: European Union reports producer price inflation slowed in 12-member euro zone in March, with prices up 0.1 percent from Feb, compared with 0.2 percent rise in Feb from Jan; prices were up 4.1 percent from March 2000; producer price inflation was unchanged in European Union as whole, at annual rate of 3.6 percent; graph (S)

headline: A Smaller I.R.S. Gives Up On Billions in Back Taxes
abstract: Internal Revenue Service, with its staff reduced by sixth since 1992 and its mission shifted to customer service, has virtually stopped pursuing more than one million tax delinquents and sharply curtailed other kinds of enforcement; internal documents, provided by IRS executive who opposes new policy, show that more than third of three million Americans who are behind on paying taxes have had their cases sent to inactive file since IRS decided in June 1999 not to try to collect their debts; that decision effectively wrote off $2.5 billion in taxes owed by 668,018 taxpayers for just last year; by contrast, just 98 taxpayers had their cases sent to inactive file in 1998; David A Mader, assistant deputy commissioner, says dropped cases, some involving as much as tens of thousands of dollars, are too small to be worth going after, given agency's current resources; Mader declines to discuss criteria used by IRS to deactivate cases; since 1992, IRS enforcement actions have fallen by two-thirds for audits and by 99 percent for seizures of property to pay back taxes; IRS Oversight Board, created by Congress to supervise tax agency, issues report saying IRS is seriously underfinanced and calling for greater spending than amount in Pres Bush's budget; Treasury Sec Paul H O'Neill says Bush's budget allotment for IRS, $9.4 billion, is adequate; photo; chart (M)

headline: Iran's President Wins a New Mandate to Promote Reform
abstract: Preliminary results show Iranian Pres Mohammad Khatami wins re-election with over 76 percent of vote amid huge turnout, thumping victory his supporters say he needs to revive drive for greater democracy and social freedom; closest of his nine rivals, Ahmed Tavakoli, wins some 15 percent of vote; reformers hold voters show they are weary with unelected Guardian Council and judiciary overriding Khatami and Parliament; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Uruguay: Currency Policy
abstract: Uruguay plans to devalue its peso at rate of 1.2 percent a month, up from current 0.6 percent rate, to help exporters compete with Brazil and Argentina, its main export markets; photo (S)

headline: S.& P. Cuts Ratings On California Debt, Citing Power Costs
abstract: Ratings on $25 billion of California bonds are cut two notches by Standard & Poor's Corp because of state's mounting energy costs; state has spent $5.15 billion buying power, 60 percent of this year's budget surplus, on behalf of Pacific Gas and Electric unit of PG&E Corp and Southern California Edison unit of Edison International; California plans to sell $10 billion of bonds backed by part of utility company revenue to cover power-buying costs (M)

headline: Investing; Can Kraft Lay Enough Golden Eggs?
abstract: Analysts differ on what value to put on shares of Kraft, 16 percent of which is being sold by Philip Morris in what is likely to be second-largest initial offering by an American company; photo; table (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Bolivia: Pact With Coca Growers
abstract: Bolivian government and coca growers reach agreement ending three weeks of protests that threatened government's stability; coca growers win concessions (S)

headline: In Milan, the American Slob Is Out
abstract: MILANâ€”  Marking an emphatic end to the era of luxury sportswear, Miuccia Prada has taken the upscale slob by the scruff of his neck â€” and put him back in a tie.

headline: COCA-COLA ENTERPRISES APPOINTS CHIEF EXECUTIVE
abstract: Coca-Cola Enterprises, largest bottler of Coca-Cola Company beverages, names Lowry F Kline chief executive, succeeding Summerfield K Johnston Jr, who is retiring; Johnston will remain chmn (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Ex-Actress Takes Office
abstract: Former movie star Jayalalitha Jayaram is sworn in as chief minister of southern state of Tamil Nadu (S)

headline: Space Tourist, Back From 'Paradise,' Lands on Steppes
abstract: Dennis A Tito, first paying space tourist, emerges from Russian Soyuz space capsule after it lands in Kazakhstan; he is shaky on his feet but buoyed by his adventure; end of his eight-day mission, which took him to International Space Station, does not end public dispute between Russian and American space agencies over space tourism; NASA administrator Daniel S Goldin promises to present Russian space agency with bill for hours of work required by extra precautions and 'incredible stress' placed on NASA employees as they tried to ensure that Tito would not break anything or otherwise endanger space station; photo (M)

headline: Mexico City Journal; Pummeling the Powerful, With Comedy as Cudgel
abstract: Profile of and interview with Jesusa Rodriguez, Mexico City cabaret owner who for 20 years has been skewering nation's elite, rich, powerful and sanctimonious; photos (L)

headline: People
abstract: David Kratz, president at public relations division of Magnet Communications, is named president and chief executive at Magnet, succeeding Darryl Salerno, who resigned; Tim Lindsay, president at Lowe Lintas & Partners Europe, is named president for international, new post; Gary S Laben, executive vice president for sales and marketing at Knowledge Base Marketing, is named president and chief executive, succeeding Mike Hail, who is retiring; Brad Ashton is named senior vice president and creative director at Ivory, succeeding Eddie Snyder, who resigned; Lori Cloud, vice president for entertainment marketing at Bragman Nyman Cafarelli, is named to added new duties of heading practice that will match celebrities with marketers to serve as endorsers, make guest appearances and speak about new products (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Silicon Storage Technology Reports Canceled Orders
abstract: Shares of Silicon Storage Technology drop 13.6 percent after company, maker of memory chips for computers and consumer products, says order cancellations will hurt second-quarter profit and sales; graph (S)

headline: Rebels in Colombia Free 4 in the Start of a Prisoner Exchange
abstract: Colombia's largest rebel group, FARC, frees badly injured police colonel and three other officers, first step in exchange that could lead to release of about 150 soldiers and police officers held by guerrillas in jungle camps (S)

headline: Blair Sets June 7 for British Election
abstract: After riding out the political damage of Britain's foot-and-mouth epidemic, Prime Minister Tony Blair announced today that a general election would be held on June 7.

headline: Weak Ads and Failed Movie Depress News Corp.'s Profits
abstract: Weathering a weak advertising market and a Hollywood flop, the News Corporation of Australia, the media conglomerate, announced today that its earnings fell sharply in the most recent quarter.

headline: To European Eyes, It's America the Ugly
abstract: A torrent of hostile articles in Europe's press have focused on American foreign policy stances in President Bush's first 100 days, but any missteps by the Bush administration provided ammunition for a gun that was already partly loaded.    News analysis, Page A10.

headline: U.N. Officials Revive Plan to Return Serbian Refugees to Kosovo
abstract: International officials in Kosovo, who are under pressure to show results, reconsider plan to return Serbian refugees to province despite shelving idea last year because of security concerns; United Nations officials are seeking Belgrade's support for elections in Kovovo, which are planned for November (M)

headline: San Alberto Journal; Local Cry: An Awful Lot of Brazilians in Paraguay
abstract: Thousands of poor Brazilian immigrants who have streamed across border into Paraguay in recent years, drawn by promise of land and opportunity, have brought burst of economic growth to border area of San Alberto de Mbaracayu, but have stirred nationalist sentiment and even xenophobia among reluctant hosts, who feel they have become second-class citizens in own country; Paraguay's population of 5.5 million, contrasts with Brazil's 170 million; map; photo (M)

headline: Look Back at WordStar And Ahead to XML
abstract: Q. What ever happened to WordStar, that very popular word processing program from many years ago?    A. For those too young to remember it, WordStar was perhaps the most successful and widely used word processing program in the early 1980's. WordStar is generally credited as the first such program to have a rudimentary form of the ''what you see is what you get,'' or Wysiwyg, style of on-screen document display, and it used a series of keyboard commands for text entry and navigation that some users still pine for.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: Trade Accord With U.S.
abstract: Vietnam begins ratifying trade agreement with US (S)

headline: Stanley I. Tannenbaum, 73, Ad Executive
abstract: Stanley I Tannenbaum, top executive at advertising agency Kenyon & Eckhardt, dies at age 73 (M)

headline: Vivendi Will Acquire Houghton Mifflin for $1.7 Billion
abstract: Vivendi Universal, expanding its presence in US educational publishing market, agrees to acquire Houghton Mifflin Co for about $1.7 billion in cash; Vivendi seems bent on rapidly becoming international media conglomerate; photo (M)

headline: Telecoms' Tunnel Is Still Dark At the End
abstract: Interview with Investco Telecommunications fund manager Brian Haywood on outlook for telecommunications industry; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: ASIA<BR PHILIPPINES: ECONOMY SHRINKS Slack global demand for electronics helped slow the Philippine economy's growth to 2.5 percent in the first three months of 2000, the government said, down from a 3.8 percent annual rate in the prior quarter. Electronics make up least half of Philippine exports. While many of the country's problems are not of its own making, economists say swelling public debt and political turmoil have scared off investors and amplified the impact of the global downturn. Â Â Wayne Arnold (NYT)

headline: Trade Deficit Shrinks as U.S. Cuts Imports
abstract: US trade deficit declined to $27 billion in February from $33.3 billion in January, largest drop since monthly record-keeping started in 1992; imports declined 4.4 percent, largest drop on record; exports rose 1 percent, after 0.4 percent increase in January; trade deficit with China dropped to $5.1 billion; imports from China were $6.4 billion, lowest since May 1999; deficit in goods with Japan widened to $6.1 billion from $5.9 billion in January; deficit with Canada, largest trading partner, narrowed to $4.5 billion from $5.9 billion; deficit with Mexico dropped to $1.46 billion from $2.1 billion; Conference Board reports its index of leading economic indicators fell 0.3 percent in March after drop of 0.2 percent in February; chart on balance of trade (M)

headline: DataBank; Rate Cut Helps Investors Chase the Blues
abstract: Federal Reserve's unexpected cut in rates overshadows disappointing earnings reports; Dow Jones Industrial Average finishes week up 452.91, or 4.5 percent, at 10,579.85; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closes at 1,242.98 after rising 59.48, or 5 percent; Nasdaq composite index's 201.98-point rise to 2,163.41 represents 10.3 percent advance; Federal Reserve's aggressive action diminishes attractiveness of Treasuries; bellwether 10-year note's yield jumps to 5.28 percent from week earlier's 5.15 percent; charts; table of rates and yields (M)

headline: Goldman Adds Unit Aimed At Individuals
abstract: Goldman Sachs Group will buy Epoch Partners, online investment bank created by Internet brokerage concerns Charles Schwab & Co, TD Waterhouse Group and Ameritrade Holding Corp, gaining access to broader range of individual investors; purchase gives Goldman exclusive right to distribute equity offerings, including initial stock offerings, to customers of brokerage firms; financial terms undisclosed (M)

headline: Article 2001040590731785471 -- No Title
abstract: April 5, 2001

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: EUROPE

headline: Microsoft Has Patch For Security Flaw
abstract: Microsoft Corp is issuing software patch for troubling security flaw in its Windows NT 4.0 and Windows 2000 server operating system programs; vulnerability, which is known as buffer overrun flaw, could permit attacker to gain control of Web server by sending data to computer running certain versions of Microsoft operating system; flaw was discovered by eEye Digital Security (S)

headline: Jeep's Split Personality
abstract: Give me Liberty or give me . . . a Hyundai Santa Fe? A Subaru Forester? A Ford Escape? A Honda CR-V?

headline: Tortured Tale Of Journalism And Monkeys
abstract: Michael Kinsley, editor of online magazine Slate, says he will run statement saying that key aspects of June 7 article called 'The Shame of Fishing for Monkeys' were fabricated; article, by Jay Forman, described monkey-infested island in Florida Keys and cruel sport once practiced there by local fishermen who baited hooks with fruit to catch monkeys; bizarre account raises questions about how thorough fact checking can be; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Air Crew Departs China, Ending 11-day Standoff
abstract: HAIKOU, China, Thursday, April 12 - Twenty-one men and three women boarded a Continental Airlines plane this morning for the first leg of their trip home, ending 11 days in Chinese custody that began when their spy plane collided with a Chinese fighter jet and made an emergency landing on Hainan island.

headline: Patents; Requests for new trademarks by Internet companies have fallen as the market has slowed.
abstract: Number of applications for trademarks with 'dot.com' tag or 'e-' prefix has plummeted with decline in Internet companies after two years of sharp increases; some of new-economy companies challenging Patent and Trademark Office ruling barring trademarks for generic names with dot-com tag have gone out of business before suits got to court (M)

headline: Of Politics, Free Markets, And Tending To Society
abstract: Tom Redburn Economic View column defends on moral as well as economic grounds Pres Bush's abandonment of free market principles in supporting quotas against foreign steel makers after invoking those principles in refusing to impose price caps on Western electricity rates (M)

headline: At the Fed, 2 Opinions Of the Same Storm
abstract: Richard W Stevenson Economic View column on divergence of views within Federal Reserve between Laurence H Meyer, governor, who is formulaic rule-based forecaster, and Alan Greenspan, chairman, who has more pragmatic, intuitive approach; notes that Meyer is skeptical of notion that economy's capacity for noninflationary growth has been permanently improved by productivity increases, while Greenspan advocates idea that economy is just beginning to reap benefits of technological advances; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Rambus Guilty On Fraud Charge
abstract: Rambus Inc, which develops memory-chip technology, is found guilty of fraud for using information from an industry standards group to obtain patents (S)

headline: At the Four A's meeting, an agency chairman delivers a stern assessment of the dot-com era.
abstract: THE dot-com debacle cast its shadow yesterday over the opening general session of the annual management conference of the American Association of Advertising Agencies.    But speakers at the general session also told the members of the association, which is known as the Four A's, that the stunning rise and abrupt collapse of Internet marketers and stocks offered them opportunities they could capitalize on as they grapple with the aftermath of dot-com mania.

headline: FACTORY 2-U, DISCOUNT CLOTHING RETAILER, WILL POST LOSS
abstract: Factory 2-U Stores shares fall 12 percent after company, retailer of discount clothing, says it will have unexpected fiscal first-quarter loss (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Defiance On Khmer Rouge Trials
abstract: Cambodia Prime Min Hun Sen ass

headline: Really Plugged-In People Reveal Really Useful Web Sites
abstract: Several people well versed in Internet reveal some of their favorite Web sites, one of which may become the next Napster or eBay; recommendations are from Jennifer Wu, Steven Morgan Friedman, Nathan Carter, Dr Thomas Lee, John Jones, Oliver Hurst-Hiller, Munira Rahemtulla and Jamea Jackson; photos (M)

headline: PRICELINE FOUNDER TO SELL $9.9 MILLION WORTH OF SHARES
abstract: Priceline.com Inc's founder, Jay Walker, will sell nearly $9.9 million of company's stock (S)

headline: California Utility Says Gas Company in State Inflated Prices
abstract: Witnesses for Southern California Edison assert that Southern California Gas Co, unit of Sempra Energy, played role in creating $3.7 billion in higher natural gas prices, which severely impacted SCE's power generation expenditures; assertion comes in Federal Energy Regulatory Commission proceeding on whether El Paso Corp possessed or exercised 'market power' that allowed it to artifically raise gas prices (S)

headline: BANK MERGER ACCORD
abstract: South Korea's Kookmin Bank and Housing and Commercial Bank merge, with agreement to make Kookmin main partner, with 63 percent of combined bank (S)

headline: Bush Says U.S. Will Give $200 Million to World AIDS Fund
abstract: President Bush said today that the United States would contribute $200 million to a global fund to attack AIDS, malaria and tuberculosis, but critics and some members of Congress said the initial donation was paltry.    Mr. Bush made the announcement in the Rose Garden during a visit by Nigeria's president, Olusegun Obasanjo, and the secretary general of the United Nations, Kofi Annan, who has called for a global fund to raise $7 billion to $10 billion a year.

headline: Dispute and Blackouts
abstract: Southern California Edison accused the El Paso Corporation of inflating the price of natural gas by $3.7 billion in the last year by restricting the flow in a pipeline it partly controls. And a second straight day of blackouts affected nearly 300,000 California customers.    Articles, Pages C1 and A28.

headline: What's Next: Growing PC's Into Supercomputers, All in a Row
abstract: Say you have a couple of Pentium computers in your house, linked by a fast Ethernet connection.

headline: Glimmers Of New Life In Initial Offerings
abstract: Kenneth N Gilpin interview with David Menlow, president of IPOfinancial.com, new-issues research company, regarding glimmer of new life in initial public offerings marketplace; photo (M)

headline: More Meets Eye
abstract: Joseph L Hern letter responds to May 17 article concerning gender's effects on e-mail styles

headline: INVESTING WITH/Keith A. Lee, Robert E. Hall and Kempton M. Ingersol; Brown Capital Management Small Company Fund
abstract: SMALL is in the eye of the beholder.    Most money managers use the market capitalization of a company -- its number of shares outstanding multiplied by the share price -- as a proxy for its size. But not Keith A. Lee, Robert E. Hall and Kempton M. Ingersol, who run the $146 million Brown Capital Management Small Company fund.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Step For Global Criminal Court
abstract: Sweden becomes 36th country to ratify treaty setting up International Criminal Court (S)

headline: Easing Web Anxiety by Going Online
abstract: Anxiety of neophyte Internet users is eased by coaching available at www.netforbeginners.about.com, Web site from About.com; other tutorials for beginners are also available; photo (M)

headline: Talks Don't Calm Foes of Antimissile Plan
abstract: After a week of consultations with allies and former adversaries, the Bush administration has failed to overcome deep concerns over whether its proposal to erect a broad array of missile defenses and abandon a major arms control treaty would undermine the strategic balance and promote an arms race.    An American team led by Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz was still wrapping up its meeting with top Foreign Ministry officials here today when the ministry spokesman, Aleksandr Yakovenko, announced that the American delegation had not addressed Russia's fundamental questions.

headline: New Jersey High School Is Winner of Fed Contest
abstract: Team of students from Montclair High School in New Jersey wins first prize and $40,000 in annual Fed Challenge national competition that tests economic wits; contest is sponsored by Federal Reserve; prize is provided by Citibank (M)

headline: Hewlett-Packard Says Sales Faltering This Quarter
abstract: The Hewlett-Packard Company said today that sales were sluggish because corporate and consumer spending on information technology products was slowing in markets outside of the United States and Europe.

headline: Bridgestone Stock Ends Steep Fall
abstract: Shares of Bridgestone Corp end steep fall as concerns ease about future of its American subsidiary, Bridgestone/Firestone; stock closes unchanged, at $10.58 (US), after falling 9.6 percent on May 22 (S)

headline: An Upriver Battle for Votes in Peru
abstract: Alejandro Toledo pursues presidency of Peru with campaign that is pure spectacle, rich in personal scandal that obscures his message and damages his credibility; Toledo denies allegations ranging from sex with prostitutes and cocaine use to domestic violence and money laundering, but he barely won third of vote in first round of balloting and is struggling to maintain shaky lead over Alan Garcia in runoff; photo; map (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Former Kremlin Aide Back In Court
abstract: Pavel Borodin, former Kremlin property manager under investigation for money laundering, maintains his silence during appearance before Geneva justice officials; was freed on $3 million bail in April (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Immigrants Seek Legal Status
abstract: Thousands of illegal immigrants flood government offices in Athens and other cities seeking to avert deportation by providing evidence that they have lived in Greece for at least one year; government suggests that Greece is home to about 800,000 illegal aliens, mostly Albanians (S)

headline: Election Tomorrow Likely to Add Impetus to Montenegro's Move Toward Independence
abstract: ''Good morning, Montenegro, good night, Yugoslavia!'' shouted the first speaker at the government's final rally this week before parliamentary elections on Sunday.    The voting will probably set the course for the independence of tiny Montenegro from its sister republic, Serbia, and thus spell the end of federated Yugoslavia, an experiment that dissolved in blood twice in the last century.

headline: Article 2001060192888963881 -- No Title
abstract: PowerPoint Invades the Classroom

headline: Technology Briefing | People: Sales Executive Hired By Apogee
abstract: Apogee Networks reportedly hires Nina Aversano to oversee worldwide sales operations; photo (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Hewlett Warns on Profit And Plans to Cut Some Jobs  Hewlett-Packard warned that its quarterly earnings would fall short of Wall Street's estimates by at least 50 percent. It said it would eliminate as much as 20 percent of its managerial staff and take a charge of $150 million.    But the company offered a glimmer of hope for an improved second half of the year, saying the sharp declines in consumer sales of its products in the United States have slowed and do not appear to be worsening. [Page C4.]

headline: Borders Is Said To Be Quitting Online Effort To Sell Books
abstract: Borders Group, nation's second-largest bookseller, is closing its struggling online store and will have Amazon.com serve its customers instead (M)

headline: John Paul Prays for Peace In Former War Zone in Syria
abstract: Pope John Paul II prays for peace and forgiveness in Middle East in visit to Quneitra, shattered city on Golan Heights seen as symbol of irreconcilable conflict; pope is greeted by thousands of Syrians, many of them former residents, who stand silently in front of their flattened houses; they are brought by bus to greet him; Golan Heights were captured by Israel in 1967 Arab-Israeli war; Quneitra is portion returned to Syria in 1974 agreement brokered by United States; Syria has kept city uninhabited and in ruins as museum; pope's very presence in Quneitra provides showcase for Syrian government's efforts to portray him as their ally against Israel; map (M)

headline: Filipinos Vote on What's Seen as Referendum on President
abstract: BANGKOK, May 14 â€” After rival "people power" demonstrations changed the face of Philippine politics in the last four months, Filipinos finally got a chance to vote today in a nationwide election that is being viewed as a referendum on the legitimacy of President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo.

headline: KGA Shuts Its Doors After a 22-Year Run
abstract: KGA Advertising in Middletown, Conn, closes after about 22 years (S)

headline: EUROPE CLEARS LIBERTY MEDIA-UNITEDGLOBALCOM DEAL
abstract: European Commission approves planned merger of Liberty Media Corp and UnitedGlobalCom Inc to form largest cable television operator outside United States (S)

headline: Japan's Imperial Family Reports Princess Masako Expecting Child
abstract: Japan's imperial family announces that Crown Princess Masako is pregnant; news generates excitement in Japan, where there has been worried speculation since 37-year-old princess's miscarriage 16 months ago that immediate heirs to so-called Chrysanthemum Throne would be unable to produce eventual successor (M)

headline: MediaTalk; Gore Questions Report in Woodward Book
abstract: Former Vice Pres Al Gore tells journalism class at Columbia University that Bob Woodward, in his book, The Choice, made up description Gore's private weekly lunches with Bill Clinton in early months of 1996 presidential race; Woodward holds Gore talked to him about lunches in Apr 1996 interviews (M)

headline: At Placebo Consulting, We're as Good as it Gets
abstract: Letter from Charles Shoopak responds to May 13 article which discussed how consultants helped fuel Internet bubble

headline: From Ocean to Pond, With More Room to Swim
abstract: More professional in all kinds of industries are making move from large corporations to small ones, giving up some job benefits in order to play broader roles in their companies; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Weighing Future of Strategic Arms Pacts
abstract: Military analysis; Pres Bush's decision to build missile defenses and eventually break with strategic arms control treaty, central treaty of cold war, is first outward sign of far-reaching debate over whether US should simply abandon business of negotiating strategic arms treaties; question centers on whether with end of cold war there is any need to begin yet another drawn-out arms control negotiation with Russia, which is no longer enemy (M)

headline: Executive to Lend Millions To Construction Business
abstract: Chairman Dennis R Washington agrees to lend Washington Group International construction company at least $10 million while it restructures under bankruptcy protection; says deal would give him right to buy up to 40 percent of stock when company emerges from bankruptcy, interview; says court has approved $220 million in loans from group of banks; will remain chairman (M)

headline: Credit Offerings During the Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week is limited to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 3.50 percent and on a six-month bill, 3.60 percent.

headline: TIMKEN PLANS TO CUT ABOUT 1,500 JOBS IN NEXT TWO YEARS
abstract: Timken Co, maker of bearings used in automobiles, railcars and computers, will cut about 1,500 jobs during next two years; most of jobs are at two plants company will close and one it will sell (S)

headline: Shoe Designer Pleads Guilty To Charges of Stock Fraud
abstract: Steven Madden, designer and retailer of shoes for young women, and founder of Steven Madden Ltd, pleads guilty to federal charges of securities fraud and money laundering; Madden pleads guilty before Judge Kimba M Wood and at hearing later before Judge John Gleeson; sentencing hearing is scheduled for Sept 6; photo (M)

headline: U.N. Chief Asks for New Funds to Fight AIDS
abstract: UNITED NATIONS, May 9 â€” With anger rising in Congress over the United States' loss of seats on two United Nations panels, Secretary General Kofi Annan went to Washington today to ask the Bush Administration for more money to fight AIDS in Africa.

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Graph plots rise in gasoline futures prices on commodities markets on May 9; in New York, gasoline for June delivery rose 3.23 cents, or 3.1 percent, to $1.0767 per gallon; graph

headline: A Bidder for Bridge Plays Down Its Rival
abstract: SunGard Data Systems says its $165 million bid for assets of Bridge Information Systems has better chance of obtaining regulatory approval than competing bid by Reuters Group (S)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: EUROPE

headline: 12-Year Term in Largest Securities Fraud
abstract: Robert Catoggio, co-founder of Hanover, Sterling & Company and three other New York brokerage firms that are now defunct, is sentenced to almost 12 years in prison and ordered to pay $80 million in restitution for his role in scheme that is said to have cheated investors out of more than $150 million; prosecutors contended that Catoggio funneled millions to Alan Longo, reputed captain in Genovese organized crime family; Catoggio says he is insolvent (M)

headline: With Crew in U.S., Bush Sharpens Tone Toward China
abstract: Pres Bush says American spy plane definitely did not cause midair collision with Chinese jet; tone toward China sharpens after American crew's safe arrival in Hawaii; Pentagon officials are even more explicit in blaming pilot of Chinese jet fighter that was tailing spy plane for causing collision; Bush telephones 24 crew members who had been detained by Chinese to welcome them home; later, in Rose Garden, he warns that two nations will have to make 'determined choice' to improve frayed relations after 11-day standoff; says United States will ask 'tough questions' to China about its practice of challenging American aircraft flying over South China Sea, in recognized international airspace; administration officials say such reconnaissance flights off coast of China may resume as soon as this week; photo (M)

headline: In Strategy Overhaul, Bush Seeks a Missile Shield
abstract: WASHINGTON, May 1 â€” President Bush called today for sweeping changes in security strategy, including a new relationship with Russia, that would build an expansive missile defense system and cut "to the lowest possible number" the nuclear arsenals that both sides assembled in the cold war.

headline: 43 Die in Stampede at Johannesburg Stadium
abstract: At least 43 soccer spectators are killed during stampede at crowded stadium in Johannesburg, South Africa, at beginning of match between country's most popular professional soccer teams; more than 100 others are injured in chaos that erupts as crowds of fans press thier way into stadium which may have already been packed to capacity; match goes off as scheduled, but is halted after 35 minutes when security personnel learn of grim drama unfolding (M)

headline: New-Economy Worth
abstract: To the Editor:    Re ''How Did They Value Stocks? Count the Absurd Ways,'' (March 18), which discussed how analysts threw away traditional valuation measures on new-economy stocks:

abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   7.00   7.00   9.50        Discount rate   3.50   3.50   6.00        Federal funds   3.94   3.97   6.52        3-month T-bills   3.37   3.37   5.80        6-month T-bills   3.35   3.34   5.90        10-yr. headline: Joe's Back, And Looking For a Ride; Hasbro Reaches For Some Coattails From 'Pearl Harbor'
abstract: Hasbro Inc has released new line of Pearl Harbor-themed GI Joe figures; company has no direct ties to movie Pearl Harbor but it sees film as opportunity to revive interest in GI Joe; push to revive GI Joe is coming at critical moment for Hasbro, which has posted large losses for last two quarters; graph; photos (M)
